column2: BURKHART-MOSES--Lucille Uptegraff, 92, died July 26 in Silver Spring, MD. She was the widow of the late Campbell Moses, Jr., MD. Married in 1995, they resided in Manhattan and Spring Lake, NJ. She was first married to the late Eugene L. Burkhart of Pittsburgh, PA. She moved to Maryland after Dr. Moses' death in 2007. Survivors include her daughter, Susan Burkhart of London, UK, and sons, Michael Burkhart of Aiken, SC, and Geoffrey Burkhart of Takoma Park, MD and his partner, Bruce R. Williams, as well as four step-children and their families: C. Warren Moses, James Moses, Robert Moses and Ann Brown. Messages may be left at: simpletribute.com.

WASSERMAN--Craig lost his valiant fight against a malignant brain tumor Monday. Craig fought stoically for two and a half years and never stopped living his life despite the challenges caused by his disease. His unbelievable determination, unwavering strength and love for his family will live on forever. Craig is survived by his wife, Marla, and his two adoring children, Alison and Jared. While nothing will ever fill the void left by his passing, Alison and Jared were blessed to have Craig as a father and he gave more to his children in the short number of years he had than most give in a lifetime. Craig is also survived by his mother, Sandra, and his sisters Debra and Mindee and his in-laws, Rita and Stan Weinstein and Marcy Schneider and Marni Charm. He is the son of the late Bert W. Wasserman. Craig spent more than 23 years practicing law at his second home, Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, and he remained a proud partner until the day he died. His business and legal acumen were legendary and his clients clamored for his invaluable judgment. Craig graduated from Yale University and Yale Law School and was a founding member of the Slifka Center at Yale. Craig's many acts of generosity and friendship will never be forgotten and the world is a sadder place as a result of his death. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to support brain tumor research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center where a website has been established, http:/skcc.convio.net/CraigWasserman, or checks can be mailed. Funeral services will be held at 11:45am, Wednesday, August 25th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

SCHEIDLINGER--Dr. Saul, 92. Loving husband of Rosalyn Tauber and the late Lucy Prince, father of Dr. David Scheidlinger and wife Carla, grandfather of Eric and Vera. He came to this country in 1936 escaping Hitler's troops, who eventually killed his mother and two sisters. Coming here without any knowledge of the English language, two years later he entered City College and graduated in 1942 Magna Cum Laude, Phi Betta Kappa with the four top honors in the class. He went on to a Master of Science at Columbia University and Ph.D. at New York University. He became a leader in Group Psychotherapy and was tendered a dinner with one thousand associates present by the American Group Psychotherapy Association when he retired as its president. He wrote hundreds of articles and books on this subject. Saul will be sorely missed by family, friends and associates. Cousin Stanley Batkin Michael Tenzer Family Circle
LANGERMAN--Bea, Redhead. How lucky we were to be touched by you. Never will you be forgotten. Love always, Herb and Brian

A picture caption on Monday with the Our Towns column, about the poet Alfred Starr Hamilton, the reclusive Bard of Monclair, misidentified a book being held by the author Lisa Borinsky. It is a 1970 edition of Hamilton's poems, not Ms. Borinsky's own book about the poet's letters to the Montclair Police Department.
WESTREICH--Helene. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the loss of our dear sister-in-law Helene. She was a devoted and generous person. May you rest in peace. Murray & Arlene Westreich and Family

Sunday, Aug. 8 When doing fieldwork in Congo one thing is for sure: the best-laid plans will very probably go horribly awry. This time it's nothing too dire, but our ''10-hour trip'' upriver to the small settlement of Tshumbiri has taken a full three days. It's been a series of very long days sprawled on top of bags full of our hard, lumpy equipment, slowly motoring upriver. The river is huge here, more than a kilometer wide, and as we struggle upstream we dodge large clumps of grass, some as large as small islands, that flow downstream in the current. The fast boat we hitched a ride on immediately morphed into a slow boat, probably because it was filled to capacity with our field gear, the fishing team and three other passengers who are also trying to reach the Malebo field station, not to survey fishes but to see bonobos.

LAKE BORGNE, La. -- The great wall of Lake Borgne is a monster. Nearly two miles long and 26 feet high, it spans a corner of the lake, 12 miles east of New Orleans. On Aug. 29, 2005, that corner funneled Hurricane Katrina's surge into New Orleans, causing some of the city's most violent flooding. Now the corner is being blocked. Nearly five years after Katrina and the devastating failures of the levee system, New Orleans is well on its way to getting the protection system Congress ordered: a ring of 350 miles of linked levees, flood walls, gates and pumps that surrounds the city and should defend it against the kind of flooding that in any given year has a 1 percent chance of occurring.

A picture caption last Tuesday about the restoration of a whaling ship, the Charles W. Morgan, misidentified the year the Morgan arrived in Mystic, Conn. It was 1941, as noted in the article, not 1966.

An article on Saturday about a South Korean Christian pastor, the Rev. Han Sang-ryol, who fueled a bitter debate by visiting North Korea without government permission and was arrested by the South when he returned, misstated the time period in which a South Korean novelist repeatedly entered the North illegally. The novelist, Hwang Sok-young, entered five times between 1989 and 1991, not ''1998 and 1991.''
SCHLESINGER--Stanley. Stanley will always remain in our hearts and memories. A well respected lawyer and a dear, close friend. With deepest sympathies, Mickey, Paola, David and Jonathan Schulhof

HAMM--Sarah. The members and staff of Herzfeld and Rubin, PC join our esteemed colleague, David Hamm, in mourning the death of David's mother, a true aishis chayil, on August 21 at age 97. Principal of the New Jersey Hudson County Hebrew Day School for over 30 years and operator, with her deceased husband Isidore, of summer camps in the Catskills, she leaves, beside David, daughters Chaya Korf, Itty Rosenblatt and Elke Weintraub, 33 grandchildren and their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Her influence for kindness and righteousness was and will be enduring. Herbert Rubin, President

8 P.M. (History) JEFFERSON He professed to believe that all men are created equal, yet he owned slaves. He disliked politics but served as governor of Virginia, secretary of state and president. He lived lavishly and died in debt. This two-hour special explores the contradictions of Thomas Jefferson, left, as juxtaposed against his political career; his longtime relationship with Sally Hemings, one of his slaves, after the death of his wife; his support for an agrarian way of life; his intellectual pursuits, including botany, cartography, astronomy and architecture; and his final major achievement, the founding of the University of Virginia. 9 P.M. (Bravo) FLIPPING OUT Jeff decides to be more attentive to client satisfaction and his own professionalism. But that doesn't stop him from dealing with a smelly pet problem. In ''The Rachel Zoe Project,'' at 10, Rachel encourages Cameron Diaz and Demi Moore to be more daring as she styles them for the Oscars -- a task that keeps her from celebrating her wedding anniversary with Rodger. Meanwhile, Brad navigates Fashion Week for the first time without Taylor.

Saturday, Aug. 14 I have to be honest - there is very little at this moment that I would not give for a soft bed, a hot shower, and a cold beer! This past week has been hot, humid and hard work. But the fishing is good and already we have some interesting findings.

LANDY--S.J. Rev. Joseph V.,on August 22, 2010. Beloved brother of the late John, James, Sr. Mary SC, Eleanor and Kathleen. Loving uncle of ten nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx NY on Tuesday August 24th from 3-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian burial will be held at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel Wednesday, August 25th 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500

An article on Aug. 14 about concerns within the Obama administration over evidence of a possible succession problem in North Korea's secretive leadership misstated a comment about the previous transition that was made by Joel Wit, a former State Department negotiator with the North. In that transition, Mr. Wit said, the founder of North Korea, Kim Il-sung, ''gradually gave authority to Kim Jong-il,'' who is a son of Kim Il-sung and is the current leader. Mr. Wit did not say Kim il-sung ''gradually gave authority to Kim Jong-un.'' (Kim Jong-un is a son of Kim Jong-il and is thought to be the designated next leader.)

KELLOGG--George Dwight, Jr.,93, of Lakeville, Conn., beloved husband, father, grandfather, and teacher, died August 19, 2010. He is survived by Katharine (Kit) Kellogg, his wife of 44 years; his children Nancy Lightbody of Falmouth, Maine, Stuart Kellogg of Phelan, Calif., David Kellogg of Chappaqua, NY., and Peter Whitmore of Washington, D.C.; and his grandchildren Anne and Lisa Lightbody, Matt and Ben Kellogg, and Ethan and Kyla Whitmore. George was predeceased in 1961 by Wynne Krementz Kellogg. He was the son of the late George Dwight and Anna Mary (Collins) Kellogg of Schenectady, NY. George graduated from the Hotchkiss School and Yale College. After a brief stint in the United States Navy, George returned to Hotchkiss, where he spent 40 years in a variety of roles, including science and math teacher, Director of Admissions, and Director of College Guidance. For 16 years he was Assistant Headmaster, the position he held when he retired in 1982. George continued to be involved in the community. An active volunteer, George served as president of the Sharon Hospital, the Salisbury Association, and the Salisbury Volunteer Ambulance Service. He was a member of the Salisbury Congregational Church, where he was a devoted member of the choir. Since 2008, George lived at Noble Horizons Retirement Village in Salisbury. There will be a celebration of George's life at the Salisbury Congregational Church, 30 Main St., on Monday, August 30, at 11:00am. Donations in George's name may be made to the Salisbury Volunteer Ambulance Service, P.O. Box 582, Salisbury 06068, or CHI Noble Horizons Employee Scholarship Fund, 17 Cobble Rd., Salisbury 06068.

ELKIND--Morton Digby died on August 22, 2010 at the age of 93. He was a loving husband to his wife of 59 years, Charlotte Woods Elkind, a devoted father to Elisabeth, Sam and Margaret, and an adoring grandfather to Cordelia and Miranda Alquist, Eric and Will Van Gelder and Alexandra Elkind. Born in New York, NY, he graduated from NYU in 1937 and Harvard Law in 1940. He enlisted in the US Army in 1942 and served with the 236th General Hospital Division in France. A lawyer in private practice for many years, he had homes in Brooklyn, NY and Saltaire, Fire Island. Graveside service will be held at 1:30pm, Wednesday, August 25th at Westchester Hills Cemetery in Hastings on Hudson.

For at least 2,000 years Chinese healers have used acupuncture to treat pain and other ailments. Now Western doctors want proof that it works. There is little dispute that people feel better after receiving the treatment, in which thin needles are inserted deeply into the skin at specific points on the body. But are they benefiting from acupuncture itself, or just getting a placebo effect?

ROTHKOPF--Jules Solomon, beloved husband of Phoebe J. Rothkopf, died peacefully on Sunday, August 22, 2010, in Bedford Hills, NY. Born on February 17, 1926, to Sarah and Abraham Rothkopf of Brooklyn, NY, Jules attended Boys High. He served his country as a Radioman 2nd class in the US Navy during WWII and attended the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, from which he graduated with honors in 1948. During a 42 year career as a Vice President with Oppenheimer & Co. Jules was beloved by colleagues and clients as a man of impeccable integrity, acuity and honor. He is survived by Phoebe, his cherished wife of 62 years, his daughter, Wendy Rothkopf, of New York, NY, his son and daughter-in-law, Dr. Douglas Rothkopf and Dr. Holly Blatman-Rothkopf of Harvard, MA, and his three precious grandchildren, Ian, Sarah Jayne and Emma Rothkopf. He will be missed and loved for eternity. Funeral Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY, 10am on Wednesday, August 25, 2010.

SCHLESINGER--Stanley. It is with deep sorrow that we mourn the death of our closest friend and advisor for over 40 years. We extend our deepest sympathies to the family. Jules and Mary Ann, Ben Levine and Annie Krimstock Pick Quick Foods, Inc.

PERKELL--Al, died at home August 23, 2010, surrounded by his loving family. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Joan, sister, Millie, adoring children and grandchildren. We will always remember his fighting spirit and outside jump shot. Services today 10am at "Boulevard-Riverside Chapels" 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

Legislators have begun to recognize the medical, humanitarian and economic value of helping terminally ill patients and their families navigate treatment options as they approach the end of life. Last week, over the objections of New York State's medical society, Gov. David A. Paterson signed into law a bill -- the New York Palliative Care Information Act -- requiring physicians who treat patients with a terminal illness or condition to offer them or their representatives information about prognosis and options for end-of-life care, including aggressive pain management and hospice care as well as the possibilities for further life-sustaining treatment.
VIDEO A clinic in Cambodia treats victims of acid attacks. In contrast to other countries, men are often the victims of such attacks in that nation. nytimes.com/foreign

PILZER--Vivien, 69, died August 22nd, 2010. Daughter of the late Yetta and Leo Davis. Survived by husband Stephen, her brother Rick Davis, cherished daughter, Janie Steinberger (Harry) and loving grandchildren Jake, David and Lauren. Our hearts ache.
International GENERAL CITES U.S. GOALS

Chuck Hagel, a former Republican senator from Nebraska, is weighing in on the Senate race in Pennsylvania - on the Democratic side of the ticket. Mr. Hagel on Tuesday will announce his endorsement of Representative Joe Sestak, a Democrat, who is locked in a competitive race with Pat Toomey, a Republican. The Pennsylvania contest is among the most closely watched in the country, one of several that Democrats hope to win in order to keep their majority in the Senate.

The Chilean government is committed to punishing those responsible for the Aug. 5 San José mine collapse that trapped 33 miners who were found alive Sunday more than 2,000 feet underground, the mining minister, Laurence Goldborne, said Monday. ''There is not going to be any impunity here, neither public nor private,'' Mr. Goldborne said after one of the mine's owners told a radio interviewer, ''This is not the time to talk about responsibilities or ask for forgiveness.'' On Sunday, jubilant rescuers determined that the miners were alive, although they face up to four months in their subterranean prison before a new tunnel can be dug to lift them out. Until then, crews will use a thin shaft to lower food, water, health questionnaires and medicine to the miners, to exchange information about rescue efforts and to carry communications from family members.
GOLD--Honey. A beautiful, brilliant, extraordinary woman and we will miss her. Ivy and Marvin Blumenfeld

SIMON--Ruth L.,art collector and Francophile, passed away on August 23, 2010 at The Osborn in Rye. Born Ruth Elaine Lichtenberg in New York City in 1917, to the late Minerva Kahn and the late Bernard Lichtenberg, founder of the Institute for Public Relations. She attended New College of Columbia University, and completed her B.A. at Sarah Lawrence College. Mrs. Simon was a past president of the board of the Hudson River Museum and a trustee of the Council of the Arts in Westchester County. She was the widow of the late Dr. Norman Simon, a radiation oncologist affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital and inventor of the Simon afterloader to treat gynecological cancers. She is survived by her brother, John Lichtenberg (Sao Paolo); three children, Roger L. Simon (Los Angeles), Wendy S. Schwartz (New York City), and Martha J. Simon (San Francisco); six grandchildren, Raphael, Jesse and Madeleine Simon (Los Angeles) Isaac Schwartz (Hong Kong) Noah Schwartz (New York City), Rachel Marino (San Francisco), and two great-granddaughters, twins Natalia and India Simon DeLeon (Los Angeles). She was the sister of the late Claire Sampson (Chicago). Contributions may be made to the Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Ave., Yonkers, NY 10701-1899 or to The Mount Sinai Medical Center, One Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029-6574. Services will be on Wednesday at 11:30am, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.
Wednesday, Aug. 11 Looks like we are back on track.

HARWOOD--Stanley, 84, died August 21, 2010. Loving of father, grandfather and husband. Former New York State Assemblyman and Supreme Court Justice. Survived by his wife, Cathleen, children, Richard, Ellen Jacobs, Michael, and Jonathan and six grandchildren. Step-children, Kim Maguire, Jennifer Porter and Paul Hamilton and eight step-grandchildren. His family will miss him dearly.

An article on Sunday about independent music companies' getting into the independent film business misstated the day that the movie ''Make-Out With Violence'' is opening at the ReRun Gastropub Theater in Brooklyn. It is Friday, not Thursday.

VERONIS--Peter, 87, died peacefully on August 20. He was married for 57 years to Dorothy (Babs) White, who died in 2004, and is survived by his daughter Judith Anne Rodgers, son-in-law Philip Rodgers, step-grandchildren Dina Weitz and Suellen Rodgers, and four siblings, Mary Thompson, George (Kim), John (Lauren) and Reverend Alexander (Pearl) Veronis. In 1941 he joined the U.S. Navy which he served for 10 years, during which time he became Chief Petty Officer on the battleship USS North Carolina and participated in major battles in the Pacific. After his honorable discharge he attended Columbia University from 1951-1954 while working in advertising for the Springfield Newspapers. Subsequently he became an advertising sales executive at Ridder Johns Co. and Look magazine before becoming Vice-President, Advertising Director of Psychology Today magazine and later Saturday Review. In 1973-1980 he served as Publisher of Book Digest magazine. Later, he created the CBS Magazine advertising network. Funeral services will be held 11am Wednesday, preceded by a 10am viewing at Archangels Greek Orthodox Church, 1527 Bedford Street, Stamford, CT. 06905 (1-203-348-4216). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, Habitat for Humanity or Archangels Greek Orthodox Church.

SCHLESINGER--Stanley, died peacefully in his sleep in his 76th year from lung cancer caused by a genetic mutation which primarily afflicts non-smokers. Married for 51 years to Helen, his partner in life. Loved and loving father of Ken (Alison) and Karen (Gary Yablon). Proud and loving grandfather to Joshua, Zachary and Ethan Yablon, and Ilyana and Sabrina Schlesinger. Born and raised on the Lower East Side of NYC, he received his undergraduate and law degrees from New York University. He served in the National Guard, was an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and a Senior Partner at Warshaw, Burstein, Cohen, Schlesinger & Kuh. He was one of the first American attorneys to engage in business negotiations in the old Soviet Union, where he made many friends, and during his career he represented many of the leading companies in the United States. His intelligence, integrity and loyalty will be remembered by everyone whose lives he touched. A man of endless intellectual curiosity, he traveled the world with his wife and made lasting friendships wherever he went. He loved his family dearly and they all loved him and he balanced a demanding and full career with a rewarding and complete family life. We will miss you. Funeral services will be on August 25th at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 11am. The family will observe shiva at their residence. Donations in Stanley's honor can be sent to the Mitral Foundation at Mt. Sinai Hospital, Guggenheim Pavilion, Floor 2, 1190 Fifth Avenue, Box 1028, New York, NY 10029, Attention: Dr. David H. Adams.

WASHINGTON -- Earlier this month, Israeli soldiers were pruning a tree on their country's northern border when a firefight broke out with Lebanese soldiers across the fence, leaving one Israeli and four Lebanese dead. The skirmish seems to have been accidental. But it quickly set off a war of words in Washington and Beirut, with American lawmakers warning of Hezbollah infiltration in the Lebanese Army, and threatening to cut off $100 million in military aid.

SCHILLER--Lynn C. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Lynn C. Schiller. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Services were held on Monday, August 23, at Plaza Funeral Chapel, 91st St. at Amsterdam Avenue. The Friars Club

TONKIN--Laurence. South African Advocate, Laurence Tonkin died of cancer on Thursday, 19th August, 2010. A service will be held at Saint Thereses' Church in Edenvale, Johannesburg, South Africa At 10am on Tuesday, 24th August. He will be sorely missed by his wife Yvonne, all of his family, his sister, Jill Parsons, his nephew, Dave Parsons and his niece, Emma Culbert.
BERNATSCHKE--Rudolf, A. On August 22. Beloved husband of Wynne Miller Bernatschke. Memorial service Thursday 11am at Our Lady of Peace. 237 East 62nd St, between 2nd and 3rd Ave.

First Lady Michelle Obama and her immediate predecessor, Laura Bush, are expected to speak at a ceremony next month honoring victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the National Park Foundation announced Monday. They will appear at the future site of the Flight 93 Memorial in Shanksville, Penn., on the anniversary of the attacks. The memorial is being built to pay tribute to the passengers and crew members who fought hijackers aboard a United Airlines flight scheduled for San Francisco until the plane crashed in a nearby field.

GERARD--Sophie A.,102, on August 14, 2010. Mother of Manny Gerard and Ruth Poley. Grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and friend. She is at last with her beloved husband Samuel N. Gerard who died 50 years ago.

This is the second of a two-part On the Records series examining the 2007 sale of the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society's former headquarters at 122 East 58th Street to a celebrity-studded Long Island synagogue. The $24 million deal has not gone as planned for either party. On Sunday, we looked at the transaction from the seller's side. Today, we look at the experience of the buyer. Rabbi Marc Schneier comes from a long line of prominent rabbis, stretching back 18 generations.

An article on Aug. 17 about a condominium and hotel development in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to a company involved in the project, Graves World Hospitality. It is on the development team and will operate the hotel, but is not the lead developer. (That is KM Construction and Development Group.)
BLUMBERG--Jerome D.,M.D. 36 years, yesterday, today, tomorrow, and always, our love. Phyllis, Marjie, and Ellin

SCHLESINGER--Stanley. The firm of Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh mourns the untimely passing of one our founding partners, a dedicated and respected leader of our firm. Stanley was instrumental in establishing our firm in 1978 and was one of the driving forces in continuing our growth over the last 32 years. During that period, he developed a large number of clients who are involved in a remarkable range of businesses. He had those special skills of a "rainmaker" that are desired by many but possessed by few. For his clients, he was attorney, counselor, advisor and friend. He loved to travel with his beloved wife of 51 years, Helen, and there were few parts of the globe that they had not visited together. He was a physically imposing person, and used his stature to maximum advantage in his weekly game of tennis, which he relished. For those of us who had the privilege of spending time with him on a daily basis, he was a selfless colleague who always put the interests of our firm first. He earned the respect and affection of everyone with whom he worked and associated. He is irreplaceable and will be dearly missed by all of us. We extend our deepest sympathy to Helen, children Kenneth and Karen, grandchildren Zachary, Joshua, Ethan, Ilyana and Sabrina, and the other members of the family.
Everybody put me on the back burner for years and years. HENRY C. ALLEN, on official action in the 1964 killing of his father, Louis Allen, a civil rights worker in Mississippi. [A14]
LINK--Joshua 55/80 - 8/24/09 Missing you more every day. Always with us Love you forever. Mom, Dad and Sara

OXENBERG--Henry, died at age 98, August 20, 2010 in Atlantic City, NJ. Born in Philadelphia, PA, son of Jacob and Blima (Marcus). A resourceful and creative businessman, he and his wife, Sylvia, founded, and for twenty-five years, operated the successful Boardwalk leather goods store, J.S. Briggs, ltd., in Atlantic City. He is survived by his brother Morris, daughter Judith Rubin and her husband, Robert, grandson James Rubin and his wife, Gretchen, grandson Philip Rubin and his wife, Lauren, and great-grandchildren Eliza, Eleanor and Henry. Graveside service will be held 11am, Tuesday, August 24th at Beth Israel Cemetery, Black Horse Pike, Egg Harbor Township, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Shore Memorial Health Foundation, 1 East New York Avenue, Somers Point, NJ 08244. Services byRoth-Goldsteins' Memorial Chapel, Atlantic City, NJ. www.rothgoldsteins.com

Thursday, Aug. 19 Back in Kinshasa, and at last we have some time to relax in the mission where our journey began. It was quite a trip downriver - our ''speed'' boat had broken down, so we ended up hitching a tow from a leaky pirogue with an ancient 15-horsepower outboard engine. The journey from Tshumbiri to Kinshasa took a day and a night of solid motoring, and we arrived rather bedraggled but happy to have made it in one piece. But now well rested and re-energized, for the last few days we have been packing specimens, meeting with students and colleagues and getting our export permits in order - as well as making plans for a return next year.

WESTREICH--Helene 83, of Bal Harbour, FL, formerly of Paterson, NJ, and New York City, on August 22nd. Predeceased by her beloved Alexander. Survived by her "fella" Seymour Rosenblatt, loving children Gail White, Dede Harris, William (Anne) Cohen, and Stanley (Ruth) Westreich, cherished grandchildren Noah, Noelle, London, Jesse, Maximilien, Julien, Cameron, Nicholas, Anthony, Dana, and Lauren, adored great-grandchildren Naomi, Jayden, Max, Gabriel, Oliver, Kalie, Quincy, Nathaniel, and Greta. Service Wednesday, 11:00am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

The Beliefs column on Saturday, about Buddhist leaders who addressed a sex scandal, referred incorrectly to a 1990 article by Katy Butler, a journalist, titled ''Encountering the Shadow in Buddhist America.'' Ms. Butler did not describe Richard Baker, the abbot of the San Francisco Zen Center during the 1970s and 1980, as an alcoholic. She was comparing patterns of behavior by his followers to patterns of enabling behavior of relatives of alcoholics.

HUBBARD--G. Morrison, Jr.,died peacefully, August 21, 2010 at his home in Summit, NJ. He was 101. Born in 1909, he resided in Summit, NJ all of his life. He was the oldest camper from one of the oldest camps in the country. Keewadyn, Salisbury, Vermont. Before he was fifteen, he had built up a writing paper business in eight surrounding towns and had about 200 customers. At 17, he had crossed the country with three other boys in a second hand Buick, returning home by working on a cargo freighter the day before school started. It stopped at three Mexican ports and went through the Panama Canal. He also spent summers sailing with several boys from Long Island to Canada on chartered sail boats. He attended the public schools in Summit, and was in the Class of 1926. He graduated from Lawrenceville in 1928 and Dartmouth College in 1932. Afterwards, he joined his father's firm of Hubbard, Westervelt, and Motley in New York City. He married Elizabeth Jones, his childhood sweetheart, in 1942 and proceeded to his Army training assignment on the same day. After World War II ended, he retired from the military in 1945 as a major. His father having died during the war, he and his brother, John C. Hubbard, built the firm into one of the best in the country that arranged financing for corporations. They sold their company in 1968 to Merrill Lynch becoming a wholly owned subsidiary and the brothers were partners in Merrill Lynch. Shortly thereafter, his brother retired and he continued solely running the company. He served on Merrill Lynch's domestic and international boards and various committees. In 1974, his company changed its name to Merrill Lynch Hubbard. He retired that year from Merrill Lynch, having reached 65, the mandatory retirement age at that time. At the time of his death, in addition to being a retired partner of Merrill Lynch, he was an emeritus director of Urstadt Biddle, formerly Hubbard Real Estate, a REIT founded by the two brothers in 1968 and listed on the New York Stock Exchange. He was also an emeritus director of the Hyde and Watson Foundation. He was honored for his service in World War II in May 2002 by the State of New Jersey and the City of Summit with citations and a key to the city. In 1999, he was honored by the Board of Education for his civic contributions by renaming Lincoln Hubbard School. In June 2006, at 97 years old he received a proclamation and second key to the city with appreciation from Summit, recognizing his lifelong civic commitment. Also, Summit's local television channel, TV36, premiered the series, "Legends of Summit," with an hour-long interview in two parts on him. He was a member of the Central Presbyterian Church since 1927, giving him the longest membership in the church. He was an honorary member of the Canoe Brook Country Club, the Beacon Hill Club, and the Union League Club in New York City. He was also a member emeritus of the Baltusrol Golf Club. He played many of the leading golf courses in Europe and the United States, including the Augusta National many times. He was a member of the United States Seniors' Golf Association. He traveled for business and pleasure in most of the 50 states and to 40 foreign countries. His wife Elizabeth Jones Hubbard, predeceased him in 2005 after 63 years of marriage. He is survived by his daughter, Morrene Jacobs of Short Hills, NJ, a son, G.M. Hubbard, III (Mary) of Savannah, GA., four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Known for his character, generosity, wisdom, and sense of humor, Mr. Hubbard told wonderful stories of his life experiences. When asked about the major challenges facing us today, he always replied, "Keeping civic pride and responsibility in our home, our schools and the community. Civic pride and patriotism are not bad attributes to live by." His greatest concern for our country is the loss of individual incentive. Calling hours will be Wednesday, August 25, 5-7pm at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit, NJ (908-273-2323). Memorial Services will be Thursday, August 26, 11:00am at Central Presbyterian Church, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, Memorial Gifts can be made to the Summit Area Public Foundation, Attention: the Sayre Finnegan Fund, P.O. Box 867, Summit, NJ 07901.

In the centuries-old conflict between Christianity and Islam, tolerance has generally outpaced antagonism. But with a proposed Islamic center two blocks from ground zero reigniting an international debate about the compatibility of Islam with Western democracy and Christian teachings, some of the old battle lines are being redrawn.

On the Lower East Side, in the space of just three blocks, there are four drinking establishments owned by Rob Shamlian, a man who, incidentally, does not drink. There is a cevicheria-cum-tequileria (Los Feliz), a look-at-all-those-beers-on-tap burger joint (Spitzer’s Corner), a two-floor rock club that reminds me of some sweaty Oberkampf boîte (Fat Baby), and Mason Dixon, a bourbon bar with a mechanical bull. “Did you know they have special mechanical bull insurance?” asks Shamlian, who intended the bull as an ironic hat-tip to the rodeo. It’s hipster bait, but still kind of adorable.

“The Social Network”–also known as “the Facebook movie”–is coming in October, but already there’s been drama behind the scenes. To some extent, the controversy surrounding the Cordoba Initiative's Lower Manhattan venture is really a controversy about how non-Muslim Westerners should relate to the would-be spokesmen for a moderate (or "moderate," depending on your point of view) Islam. One school of thought, prominent among conservatives but associated with liberal thinkers like Paul Berman as well, holds that anything short of an absolute commitment to Enlightenment values is unacceptable from such figures, and that moderate Muslims must demonstrate this commitment, and prove their secular bona fides, by making a frontal assault on Islamic culture as it currently exists. To this school, explicitly-liberal figures like Ayaan Hirsi Ali or Irshad Manji represent the beau ideal of moderate Islam, because they're forthright in their critiques of Muslim societies' failings, and unstinting in their insistence that the Western way of faith and politics is ultimately superior. A high-profile bridge-builder like the ubiquitous Tariq Ramadan, on the other hand,  is much more suspect, and possibly beyond the pale - because he tends to use different language and strike different notes depending on his audience, because he often seems to be making excuses for illiberalism in the Islamic world, because he's less-than-forthright in his condemnations of certain kinds of extremism, and so on down the line. To his critics, such bobbing and weaving is proof enough that his "moderate Islam" project is really just a flowery fraud and a Trojan Horse for Wahhabism, with no redeeming value whatsoever. And this critique is easily extended to many other self-described moderates as well - including, lately, Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, who arguably has a stronger claim to moderation than Ramadan, but who seems to share some of his more evasive qualities when the conversation turns to, say, Hamas or the Islamic Republic of Iran.

Starting in the 1970s, the French publishing house Robert Laffont issued a series of cookbooks by young chefs who were gaining fame as developers of what was then being called nouvelle cuisine - and what is now pretty mainstream. I'm not talking about the parody of that style - a one-ounce red mullet fillet sauced with raspberry vinegar and garnished with kiwi - but about the freedom to experiment with traditional French cooking. The Laffont authors included Michel Guérard, Jean and Pierre Troisgros, Alain Chapel and so many others.

Though Merce Cunningham is no longer with us, some of the biggest stars in the dance world are working to ensure his legacy. On Oct. 4, Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform as part of a special benefit program to introduce a new collaboration between the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and Baryshnikov Arts Center. "BAC Flicks: Mondays With Merce," a new monthly film series and programming collaboration, is intended to educate audiences about Cunningham's legacy and creative process. The event will feature a performance of "Occasion Piece2" by Baryshnikov and the Cunningham company, with music from John Cage's "Song Books" performed by Joan La Barbara and John Kelly. It will also include a screening of Charles Atlas's film "With Merce."

There is not much question about the outcome of a hearing on a preliminary injunction to block the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group's deal with Hertz Global Holdings. I watched the first hour of the hearing in Delaware Chancery Court on Wednesday, courtesy of Courtroom View Network, and my opinion from that time is that Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. is not going to enjoin the deal. He is also unlikely to touch the termination fee or the matching rights that Hertz has negotiated in its agreement. Francis Ford Coppola will receive the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award this year from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, while honorary Oscars will go to the director Jean-Luc Godard, the actor Eli Wallach and the film preservationist Kevin Brownlow, the academy said on Wednesday. The recipients were chosen by the academy's board of governors on Tuesday evening, and the awards will be handed out at a dinner ceremony in Los Angeles on Nov. 13. Mr. Brownlow is known for his work on films of the silent era. Mr. Godard, whose credits include "Breathless" and "King Lear," has been a central figure in French film, and Mr. Wallach has appeared in a long string of features, including "The Misfits" and "The Magnificent Seven," after he made his debut in 1956 in "Baby Doll." The Thalberg award, named for the legendary MGM executive, recognizes Mr. Coppola's work as a producer of films including "The Conversation," "The Godfather: Part II" and "Dracula."

Julian Cribb, in his book "The Coming Famine" (which I reviewed today over in Arts), contends that we've already seen peak oil - the time when production can do nothing but decline. Paul Hogan, the Australian actor whose "Crocodile Dundee" movies and tourism ads for American television were surely responsible for the sale of thousands of shrimp and countless accompanying barbies, is not having a good day, mate. A lawyer for Mr. Hogan said the actor was being prevented from leaving Australia until he pays millions of dollars in back taxes, Reuters reported. Mr. Hogan, who is based in the United States, is being investigated by Australian officials who say he put film royalties in offshore tax havens, a charge he denies. His lawyer, Andrew Robinson, said in a statement that Mr. Hogan was served with a departure prohibition order by the Australian Taxation Office when he traveled to Sydney last week for his mother's funeral. "The process of detaining Paul in Australia away from his wife and child in Los Angeles has devastated Paul," Mr. Robinson wrote in a statement. A spokesman for the Australian Taxation Office told Reuters that he was unable to comment on individual taxpayers.

Bob Dylan may be too busy these days with his painting career and his year-round touring to create an album of new material -- even a record of cherished holiday songs -- but that won't keep a new Dylan album from hitting shelves in the fall, this one comprising material from the earlier end of his 50-year career. A new entry in Mr. Dylan's Bootleg Series, "The Witmark Demos" -- M. Witmark & Sons was one of his early publishers -- will be released by Columbia Records on Oct. 19, Billboard reported. It consists of 47 demo recordings that Mr. Dylan made from 1962 to 1964. Among the tracks that will appear on this two-CD release are early versions of future standards like "Blowin' in the Wind" and "The Times They Are A-Changin', "  as well as songs that have not been previously released in any version, like "Guess I'm Doing Fine," "Long Ago, Far Away" and "Ballad for a Friend." Columbia will also release new vinyl versions of Mr. Dylan's first eight albums, taken from their original mono mixes, on Oct. 19.

There are 11,000 tropical wood planks in the Brooklyn Bridge boardwalk, and millions of feet and wheels tread on them every year. Eventually, the boards wear out and must be replaced. Currently, the city uses similar tropical hardwoods, though under pressure from rain-forest advocates, it has begun to test alternative materials. But a Manhattan architect and sustainable-development consultant has proposed a third way: a dedicated, sustainably managed patch of rain forest to grow Brooklyn Bridge planks.

ELKIND--Morton Digby died on August 22, 2010 at the age of 93. He was a loving husband to his wife of 59 years, Charlotte Woods Elkind, a devoted father to Elisabeth, Sam and Margaret, and an adoring grandfather to Cordelia and Miranda Alquist, Eric and Will Van Gelder and Alexandra Elkind. Born in New York, NY, he graduated from NYU in 1937 and Harvard Law in 1940. He enlisted in the US Army in 1942 and served with the 236th General Hospital Division in France. A lawyer in private practice for many years, he had homes in Brooklyn, NY and Saltaire, Fire Island. Graveside service will be held at 1:30pm, Wednesday, August 25th at Westchester Hills Cemetery in Hastings on Hudson.

WEEKS--Louis Seabury Jr.,born February 17, 1918, died in Stonington, Connecticut, August 21st. He is survived by his wife Terry, his children Kip (and Chris), Ann (and Arleen), Louis (and Margie), and his grandchildren Sam, Meg, Louis, Neile, and Teddy. He was the son of Isabel Coxe and Louis Seabury Weeks. His sister was the late Ann Weeks Tilney. He is also survived by his brother, Howard of Alstead, New Hampshire. He graduated from Brooks School in 1936, Princeton University in 1940, and Columbia Law School in 1946 where he was a member of St. Anthony Hall. He was a partner in the New York law firm of Beekman and Bogue for 30 years. There will be a memorial service in Calvary Church, Stonington, CT, Saturday, August 28 at 3pm. Please omit flowers.

SCHLESINGER--Stanley. The law firm of Julien & Schlesinger, P.C. is deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Stanley Schlesinger, loving brother, friend and confidant of our Senior Partner, Stuart Schlesinger. Stanley was a highly respected attorney with tremendous knowledge and enthusiasm for so many legal issues. Stanley always made himself available for consultation with the attorneys of our firm concerning both practical and esoteric questions of law. We extend our deepest sympathy to his brother Stuart, his family and Stanley's family.

A tree's shadow, a darkened doorway, what looks to be a section of ripped-up carpet. This was the scene on Nicholas Avenue on Staten Island after one of the most grisly crimes of the summer, a murder-suicide and arson fire that left a mother and her four children dead. Three of the children's throats had been cut, and investigators initially focused on one of them, a 14-year-old boy, as the killer after the fire on July 22. But autopsies of the victims later found that the mother, Leisa Jones, 30, had died of smoke inhalation, indicating that she had been alive when the fire was set and contradicting the theory that the 14-year-old had carried out the killings. A charred note also implicated Ms. Jones. ''We just pray for their souls,'' a cousin said. Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

9 P.M. (13) LAW & DISORDER On Sept. 2, 2005, in the immediate wake of Hurricane Katrina, Edward King (at right, pointing, with the correspondent A. C. Thompson), aided by William Tanner and possibly a third person, rushed Mr. King's brother Henry Glover, who was bleeding from a gunshot wound to the chest, to a temporary SWAT compound in the Algiers neighborhood of New Orleans. (A police officer was later charged with the shooting.) Mr. King hoped to get medical attention from the police. Instead the brothers were handcuffed, and Henry would soon die. His charred body was eventually discovered inside a burned car on a levee on the banks of the Mississippi, not far from a police station -- an incident that resulted in the indictment of five police officers by a federal grand jury in June. The case, which involves charges that also include obstruction of justice and lying to the F.B.I., is one of at least eight current federal investigations into the New Orleans Police Department. In this collaboration with the nonprofit investigative news service ProPublica and The Times-Picayune, ''Frontline'' investigates several other mysterious deaths in the storm's aftermath -- including a shooting on Danziger Bridge in New Orleans in which officers shot six unarmed civilians, killing two -- and the climate in the city that led to them. In ''Washing Away: After the Storms,'' at 10, six survivors of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita discuss successes and setbacks in the recovery of Louisiana, as well as imminent new threats. Patricia Clarkson, a native of New Orleans, narrates. 8 P.M. (Fox) MASTERCHEF The contestants must save themselves by baking a single cupcake, after which the survivors compete as teams against the Iron Chef Cat Cora.

The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about discussions between doctors and patients regarding end-of-life care, described incorrectly the professional credentials of Dr. Alexi A. Wright of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and misstated her role in a 2008 study on the subject. A capsule summary on Saturday about a potential $23 million executive exit package after the merger of First Niagara Financial and NewAlliance Bancshares misstated which company's chief executive stood to collect the package. It was the chief of NewAlliance, the bank being acquired -- not the chief of First Niagara Financial, the purchasing bank.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about business competition in Europe among vendors of coffee cartridges for espresso machines misstated the United States currency value of a cartridge sold by Jean-Paul Gaillard's Ethical Coffee Company. Mr. Guillard's cartridge sells for about 32 cents -- not 25 cents, which is its price in euro cents. Also because of an editing error, the article misstated the length of time that Remy Romana, a user of the capsules, estimated that $120 worth of them would last. He said it was enough for a few weeks, not a few months.

WASSERMAN--Craig lost his valiant fight against a malignant brain tumor Monday. Craig fought stoically for two and a half years and never stopped living his life despite the challenges caused by his disease. His unbelievable determination, unwavering strength and love for his family will live on forever. Craig is survived by his wife, Marla, and his two adoring children, Alison and Jared. While nothing will ever fill the void left by his passing, Alison and Jared were blessed to have Craig as a father and he gave more to his children in the short number of years he had than most give in a lifetime. Craig is also survived by his mother, Sandra, and his sisters Debra and Mindee and his in-laws, Rita and Stan Weinstein and Marcy Schneider and Marni Charm. He is the son of the late Bert W. Wasserman. Craig spent more than 23 years practicing law at his second home, Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, and he remained a proud partner until the day he died. His business and legal acumen were legendary and his clients clamored for his invaluable judgment. Craig graduated from Yale University and Yale Law School and was a founding member of the Slifka Center at Yale. Craig's many acts of generosity and friendship will never be forgotten and the world is a sadder place as a result of his death. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to support brain tumor research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center where a website has been established, http:/skcc.convio.net/CraigWasserman, or checks can be mailed. Funeral services will be held at 11:45am, Wednesday, August 25th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

MARDEN--Bernard A.,91, financier and philanthropist, of Palm Beach and New York City. Survived by Chris, his beloved wife of 62 years; daughter Patrice Auld of Seattle (Merritt Kevin Auld, MD); son, James Marden of New York; daughter Cathy Marden of Great Barrington, and five granddaughters; Meghan, Sasha, Lizzy, Gaby and Olivia. A graduate of New York University, Mr. Marden served as a Major in the U.S. Army Air Corp during World War II. After the war he began a diverse and successful career as a businessman and venture capitalist, first working on printed circuits with Circuitron Corporation in partnership with J.H. Whitney, and later founding Marden-Kane, Inc., the innovative promotion agency for major corporations, and Odd Lot Trading, a 160-store wholesaler and retailer of close-out consumer goods. Mr. Marden served on the boards of many private and public companies and foundations. He was a Trustee of New York University Medical Center where he endowed a chair in neurology, and was the founder of Oakdale Foundation, a non-profit organization providing housing, education and guidance for adults with special needs. He was also an early Trustee of Conservation International, a leading global non-profit that works to protect the earth's most important resources. A longtime resident of Palm Beach and strong supporter of the arts, Mr. Marden was a founding contributor to The Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, having underwritten the stage in Dreyfoos Hall which is named in his wife's honor. His generosity was extended to the Palm Beach Community Chest through the Alexis de Tocqueville Society, The Norton Museum and countless local charities. Contributions in his memory may be made to Oakdale Foundation, 16 Oak Street, Great Barrington, MA 01230. A memorial service will be held in his honor at the Metropolitan Club in New York City on September 16th at 4:30pm.

MADRID - The United States completed its roster for the world basketball championships on Tuesday with a surprising departure: Boston Celtics guard Rajon Rondo is heading home from Athens. Rondo began as the team's starting point guard, but he did not play Sunday against Spain after a poor outing against Lithuania. That means the Chicago Bulls' Derrick Rose, who started against Spain and scored the game-winning free throws, will most likely be the starting point guard entering the world championships against Croatia in Istanbul on Saturday.

SCHLESINGER--Stanley, died peacefully in his sleep in his 76th year from lung cancer caused by a genetic mutation which primarily afflicts non-smokers. Married for 51 years to Helen, his partner in life. Loved and loving father of Ken (Alison) and Karen (Gary Yablon). Proud and loving grandfather to Joshua, Zachary and Ethan Yablon, and Ilyana and Sabrina Schlesinger. He served in the National Guard, was an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and a Senior Partner at Warshaw, Burstein, Cohen, Schlesinger & Kuh. He was one of the first American attorneys to engage in business negotiations in the old Soviet Union, where he made many friends, and during his career he represented many of the leading companies in the United States. His intelligence, integrity and loyalty will be remembered by everyone whose lives he touched. A man of endless intellectual curiosity, he traveled the world with his wife and made lasting friendships wherever he went. He loved his family dearly and they all loved him and he balanced a demanding and full career with a rewarding and complete family life. We will miss you. Funeral services will be on August 25th at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 11am. The family will observe shiva at their residence. When Proenza Schouler’s Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez imagined bringing their fall 2010 collection to life in a video they immediately thought of Harmony Korine. The writer of Kids and director of the troubling art-house favorites Gummo, Julien Donkey-Boy, and most recently 2009’s Trash Humpers, was ideal, in their minds, to take on the theme of innocence they had explored in the clothes. The results will appear the first week in September on the Proenza Schouler website. We caught up with the designers and the filmmaker to see how it all went down.

Before he became a writer, Douglas Coupland (“Generation X,” “JPod”) studied art and design, so his current collaboration with the Canadian clothing company Roots is no surprise. Roots X Douglas Coupland, a collection of clothing, accessories and even furniture, stems from the Canadian writer’s interest in the way that electronic media have connected the far-flung provinces of his homeland. Among other things, the collection’s test-pattern logo is reproduced on hang tags and a T-shirt; a motherboard pattern adorns tights and a miniskirt; and tables (the Electric table, shown here, is $1,000) have legs inspired by Canada’s ubiquitous electrical transmission towers. The Paris retail mecca Colette has picked up the limited-supply collection, which goes on sale there Sept. 7. It’s also available at selected Roots stores in Canada, or at usa.roots.com.

“Don’t go back to Dalston,” sang Johnny Borrell on Razorlight’s debut album in 2004. But by 2009 things had changed. The Guardian declared the northeast London neighborhood “the coolest place in Britain” by virtue of its young fashion-star residents, including Gareth Pugh and Christopher Kane; its club nights; and the arrival of the hot bar Dalston Superstore. A new train route has made Dalston easier than ever to get to, but at the same time, local urban projects are ensuring that the area does not become over-gentrified and providing new outdoor spaces for Londoners to enjoy.

Inès de la Fressange is the kind of woman who gets what she wants. And, as the brand ambassador for the shoe designs of Roger Vivier, de la Fressange wanted a sultry signature fragrance — or five, to be exact. “Our goal was a perfume with personality, style and quality, not just a huge launch with lots of ads,” she says, “so we used very precious and rare ingredients, just like a couture collection.” She worked closely with the nose Rami Mekdachi, and the resulting scents — L’Iris, Le Néroli, La Rose, Le Santal and L’Ambre — are heady but not aggressive. Les Parfums Roger Vivier ($195 a bottle) will make their debut at Fashion’s Night Out on Sept. 10 at the New York boutique (750 Madison Avenue), and they will be available at all Roger Vivier boutiques in October.

The Pakistani Taliban called the presence of foreign relief workers in their flood-ravaged country "unacceptable" on Thursday and suggested that militants could carry out attacks against members of aid groups, Salman Masood reported. Any violence would add strain to relief efforts that have been slow to reach the millions of Pakistanis uprooted by the worst flooding in the country's history. A spokesman for the United Nations dismissed the threats, saying that its aid work remained unaffected by security worries. But the United States State Department said it was concerned that militants "may well" attack foreign aid workers or Pakistani government officials trying to help flood victims.

A couple of months back I asked, does fiscal austerity actually reassure markets? I noted there the curious case of Ireland, which embraced savage austerity early on; quite a few press reports declared that this had gained it the confidence of markets, but the actual numbers said otherwise. And I noted the contrast with Spain, which has been relatively slow and reluctant to embrace austerity, but has been treated no worse by investors.

Joe Miller is not yet assured of victory over Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska: With just 1,668 votes separating the candidates, the official result may not be known until September when at least 7,600 absentee ballots are counted. Through a thick late-summer drizzle, throngs of hipsters shook and gyrated to the sounds of !!!, backed by Light Asylum's incomparable Shannon Funchess, who pranced the Williamsburg Waterfront stage, tambourine in hand, hyping the audience into a damp frenzy. The Lower Manhattan theater company 3-Legged Dog has reached an agreement with its landlord, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, that will allow it to stay in its home at 80 Greenwich Street, The Wall Street Journal reported. In May the M.T.A. threatened to evict the company. At that time 3-Legged Dog owed more than $300,000 in back rent and interest. In a deal reached Wednesday, the company will pay on Oct. 15 all the rent owed since June 1. It will pay the rest over roughly three years, at an interest rate of 5 percent. In addition, the M.T.A. will forgive $59,000 to settle claims related to 3-Legged Dog's construction costs in the building. The executive artistic director of 3-Legged Dog, Kevin Cunningham, said the company had increased its earned income in recent months and had also received a major grant from a New York foundation, which he said would be announced in October.

Brooklyn, already no stranger to schemers, misfits and would-be Machiavellis, had better make room for one more such character. On Thursday, the Bridge Project - the trans-Atlantic theater collaboration among the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Old Vic Theater in London and the British production company Neal Street - said it would bring a new staging of Shakespeare's "Richard III" to BAM in 2012 for what will be the project's final season. Not content to serve solely as the artistic director of the Old Vic, Kevin Spacey (pictured), the Tony- and Academy Award-winning actor, will play the title role in "Richard III," which will be directed by Sam Mendes (who previously directed Mr. Spacey in "American Beauty").

Novartis and Nestlé said Thursday that they had wrapped up a $28.3 billion all-cash deal that gives Novartis, the Swiss drug giant, a controlling stake in the eye-care company Alcon, one of the last steps in a deal initiated in 2008.

The route to a fully charged electric vehicle runs through the parking lot. At least that's the path followed by the Car Charging Group, a Florida-based electric-vehicle service provider that announced on Monday it is teaming up with Icon Parking Systems to install plug-in stations at some of Icon's more than 200 garages and lots in Manhattan. In July, Car Charging Group announced a similar deal with Laz Parking, which has 1,350 facilities in 21 states.

Back in June, with oil still spewing from BP's blown-out well, President Obama charged Navy Secretary Ray Mabus with crafting a Gulf Coast restoration plan that would address  the short-term impacts of the spill as well as the long-term environmental challenges facing the region. This week, Mr. Mabus, a former Mississippi governor, pledged that the first iteration of that plan would be unveiled soon.

It will say Southfork Kitchen. That's the name of the restaurant.

Kodak has expanded its pocket camcorder line with the new PlayTouch Video Camera, a slim, snazzy update to its very capable (but plain-Jane) Zi8 model. It's more compact than its predecessor and the waterproof PlaySport, and has a bigger 3-inch LCD screen with touch navigation. The $230 PlayTouch is just 0.6-inch thick and weighs 3.5 ounces. The screen lets you view video in horizontal widescreen mode, although shooting is done vertically.

In the battle against filth, the workers at the Brooklyn Central Laundry in East Flatbush are stalwart foot soldiers. About 80 union workers wash the dirty sheets, towels and uniforms for most of New York City's hospitals, folding more than 10 million pounds of laundry a year. Employees say the linens sometimes hold body parts. They nearly always contain blood. But under a proposed reorganization plan announced in May by the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the laundry, the service would be taken over by an undetermined private company. The city says private companies can beat the laundry's price per pound, which the union estimates at $1.30.

Christoph Schlingensief, a filmmaker, theater director and political gadfly who made it his life's work to upset German complacency and the status quo, died on Saturday in Berlin. He was 49. His death was announced by Oliver Golloch, a spokesman for the Ruhr Triennale festival, where Mr. Schlingensief had been working on the premier of his play ''S.M.A.S.H.: Suffocating in Aid,'' before his declining health forced its cancellation in July. No details on the cause of death were provided, but Mr. Schlingensief had been ill with lung cancer for several years.

In the days when television sets were rare and children gathered each afternoon at the neighborhood house in which one of those big, boxy black-and-white sets stood, ''The Howdy Doody Show'' was one of the biggest draws, and a blessing for mothers making dinner. ''It's the type of show that could be responsible for the sale of lots of sets,'' Variety said in 1947. ''In the middle-class home there is perhaps nothing as welcome to the mother as something that will keep the small fry intently absorbed, and out of possible mischief, for an hour.'' The program, Variety added, ''can almost be guaranteed to pin down the squirmiest of the brood.''
CONWAY--Lawrence. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Lawrence Conway, associated with The New York Times from April 30, 1972 until retiring on March 3, 2008.

''There seems to be something about politics that can make the rational parts of the brain turn off. FiveThirtyEight was designed to be the antidote to that,'' Nate Silver writes on his FiveThirtyEight blog. The blog, which gained attention in the 2008 elections, is now at nytimes.com, which is also enlisting The New York Times's interactive journalists and graphics experts to deepen and enhance it.

TUMBLEWEEDS that rolled past the shuttered storefronts on upper Madison Avenue are finally clearing out. In recent months, a bevy of new boutiques has brought luster back to the shiny retail strip, most notably Lanvin (No. 815). More are on deck, including the first namesake boutique for the designer Reed Krakoff, who worked his magic on Coach (No. 831). And Ralph Lauren's gilded empire between East 71st and 72nd Streets is expanding, with a store devoted to his women's line and home now under construction (No. 888). 1 At HICKOREE'S HARD GOODS, ''We like products that evoke nostalgia for our childhood, like astronaut ice cream,'' said Emil Corsillo (pictured, left, with Sandy, his brother), who opened the store inside the just-opened, pine-fresh J. Crew Men's Shop. The Hickoree's shop, which occupies a former bank vault, began online and specializes in uncommon American-made products. Items include Hill-Side ties ($76); colorful Solmate socks (recycled materials, $19), canvas Mason bags ($79) and the Original Tree Swing (a slingshot, $21). The store is at 1040 Madison Avenue (79th Street); (212) 453-2677, hickorees.com.

WASHINGTON -- With fresh signs that the housing market is weakening, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Friday will offer his outlook on the economy, explain the Fed's recent modest move to halt the slide and possibly outline other actions. Mr. Bernanke's speech, at an annual Fed symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyo., will be his first public comments since the Fed announced it would invest proceeds from its holdings of mortgage bonds to buy more long-term Treasury securities to prop up the recovery.

NEURATH--Irene, beloved friend and mentor, died peacefully at home on August 11. Born in 1915 in Vienna, Irene arrived in the U.S. in 1938 with her husband Hans Jakob Neurath. Her knowledge of human development and psychoanalysis led her to join with progressive educators, first at Downtown Community School and then as founding Director of Corlears School. She was an innovator, fostering growth in children, teachers and parents. Her insight and care helped us grow toward the potential she saw in each of us. We remember Irene with gratitude, admiration and love. Her companionship will be deeply missed.

SCHLESINGER--Stanley. The law firm of Julien & Schlesinger, P.C. is deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Stanley Schlesinger, loving brother, friend and confidant of our Senior Partner, Stuart Schlesinger. Stanley was a highly respected attorney with tremendous knowledge and enthusiasm for so many legal issues. Stanley always made himself available for consultation with the attorneys of our firm concerning both practical and esoteric questions of law. We extend our deepest sympathy to his brother Stuart, his family and Stanley's family.
An article on Aug. 12 about a home in the Czech Republic misidentified its designers. They are HSH Architects, not Sepka Architects.

President Obama will address the nation on Tuesday night about the end of combat operations in Iraq, in his second televised speech from the Oval Office, the White House announced on Wednesday. Earlier that day, Mr. Obama will go to Fort Bliss, Tex., to meet with troops. Early in his presidency, he set Aug. 31 as the deadline for removing combat troops from Iraq, more than seven years after the United States invaded. Fewer than 50,000 troops will remain to train the Iraqi military, counter suspected terrorists and protect American personnel.

Heavy fighting erupted in Mogadishu, the capital, for a third day on Wednesday, a day after insurgents stormed a hotel and methodically executed more than 30 people. Dozens of people have been killed since the Shabab, an insurgent group, began a coordinated offensive on Monday. Officials revised the death toll from the hotel attack, saying 33 people had been killed, including 4 members of Parliament.

A dance review on Monday about a program by the Eglevsky Ballet that included ''À la Françaix'' by George Balanchine misstated the performance history of that work. New York Theater Ballet presented it in 2004; it is not the case that it ''had not surfaced in decades'' before the Eglevsky Ballet performance, or that the Eglevsky company is the only one that has performed it in recent decades.

Nikon has upgraded its entry-level D.S.L.R. camera lineup with the $700 D3100 , which can shoot full 1080p high-def video with continuous autofocus, impressive features its predecessor, the D3000, lacked. The D3100 will ship with a DX-format Nikkor 18mm to 55mm f/3.5-5.6G lens in mid-September.
KATZ--Howard. 4/18/22 - 8/26/03. Seven short years were never so long. Your life was, and your memory is, always, a blessing. Love, ABK

WALLACH--Jacques Burton, MD, pathologist, author and educator died August 10, 2010, of complications from Progressive Supranuclear Palsy. He was 84. He taught pathology at Albert Einstein, Rutgers and SUNY Downstate, and consulted for Children's Specialized Hospital in Mountainside, South Amboy Memorial, and Kings County in Brooklyn, and for the Bronx Zoo. Illness forced his retirement at 81. He wrote Rheumatic Heart Disease (1962), Interpretation of Diagnostic Tests (1971, 8th edit 2007), translated into nine languages, and Interpretation of Pediatric Tests (1983), Timetables of the American Presidents, and A Timetable of Medical History and over 40 articles for medical journals. He was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians, the American Society of Clinical Pathologists, the College of American Pathologists and the New York Academy of Medicine. From 1975-1985, he donated his time and expertise in pathology to laboratories around the world. His interests included Tai Chi, photography, games of strategy, humor and wordplay. He is survived by Doris Foss, his wife of 57 years, three daughters and one son-in-law, Kim Wallach, Lisa and Anthony Auteri and Tracy Wallach, and four grandchildren: Gabriel, Jonah and Zach Auteri and Ariel Temple. No public service will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to: Cure PSP www.PSP.org

Seymour and Shirley are greatly admired for their extraordinary generosity in New York, in Westchester, and around the world. The Front Row column last Thursday, using information from the store Opening Ceremony, misidentified the creators of a gold-dusted cookie and accompanying T-shirt. Christina Tosi, the chef for Momofuku Milk Bar, and the clothing company Band of Outsiders are making them; the chef David Chang of Momofuku is not.

Jim Furyk overslept and missed his tee time at the pro-am Wednesday morning at the Ridgewood Country Club. Under PGA Tour rules, that made him ineligible for the tournament itself, the first of four FedEx Cub playoff events. But he was not the first to be late to an important event: While with the Mets in 2005, Pedro Martinez and his driver got stuck at the George Washington Bridge on their way to Yankee Stadium, then ended up lost and needed a police escort. He arrived an hour before the first pitch and beat the Yankees, 6-4.

ROSENBLATT--Norma. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing our of esteemed member, Norma Rosenblatt and extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Charles Miller, President Steve Tolman, Secretary

Too bad there's not a reality TV show called ''America's Most Freaked-Out Tech-Company Meetings,'' where you watch classic panicked board meetings. For example, when the Apple employee left an iPhone 4 prototype in a bar. Or when Intel learned that its Pentium chip contained a math error. Or when Microsoft was caught bribing bloggers with $2,500 laptops to promote Windows Vista. One of the most exciting episodes, though, could have been shot at Amazon the day Apple announced the iPad.

DEEMS--Jean (Sweetland), 90, of New York City, NY, passed away peacefully at home on Saturday, August 21, 2010. She was born in Youngsville, PA, and managed The Jefferson Hotel in Washington, DC, for several years prior to her marriage to her beloved husband of 47 years, Richard E. Deems, who predeceased her in May 2009. Mrs. Deems is remembered as a most gracious, thoughtful lady. She is survived by her nieces, Penny Lester, Janet Wilson, and Heidi Ciborek; nephew Jack Sweetland; sister-in-law Vivian Sweetland; step-daughter Cynthia Von Keyserling; grandchildren Elizabeth Lynch, Katherine Berliner, and Richard Von Keyserling; great-grandchildren Olivia, Michael, and Mary Grace Lynch, and Avery Berliner; and grandniece Lily Ciborek. Funeral services are being handled by the McKinney Funeral Home of Youngsville, PA, with a graveside service at 11:00am on Thursday, August 26, at the Warren County Memorial Park, Warren, PA. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to Freedom Guide Dogs, 1210 Hardscrabble Rd., Cassville, NY 13318 (www.freedomguidedogs.org), or the Edward Harkness Eye Institute at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, c/o Jane Heffner, 635 W. 165 St., New York, NY 10032.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the possible flaws in N.F.L. drug testing misidentified, in some editions, the person who said the World Anti-Doping Agency reviewed the N.F.L.'s testing protocol and did not cite monitoring and notification as areas that needed to be improved. It was Adolpho Birch, the N.F.L.'s top drug testing official -- not Gary Wadler, an official of the World Anti-Doping Agency.

An article on Sunday about Feisal Abdul Rauf, the imam behind the proposed Lower Manhattan Islamic Center, referred imprecisely to the Very Rev. James P. Morton, who cautioned against stereotyping Mr. Abdul Rauf as an extremist. While he is indeed a ''longtime dean'' of the Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan, he no longer holds that position.

Another Samsung Galaxy phone is being released. This one, the Epic from Sprint, sports two significant differences from others in the family. While it still has the bright, detailed AMOLED screen and great battery life of the other Galaxy phones, it adds a spacious slideout keyboard and works on the speedy 4G WiMax network.

MALKIN--Martin z"l. Temple Emanu-El of Closter mourns the passing of Mr. Martin Malkin, President of our Congregation from 1987-1989. He was a valued leader and dear friend to the synagogue and the community. Martin's dedication and commitment to Temple Emanu-El was appreciated by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife Syma, and sons Seth, Barnett and Harwyn. May Martin Malkin's memory be a blessing. David-Seth Kirshner, Rabbi Arthur Sinensky, President

CHEN--Maie-Lee. Mrs. Maie-Lee Chen passed away peacefully on Friday, August 20, 2010 in New York City, at the age of 86. A talented concert harpist and protegee of the world's leading harpist Carlos Salzedo in her earlier years, she subsequently devoted her life to partnering her beloved husband, the late Dr. Christopher C.Y. Chen, and surrounding him with elegance and beauty. They were a strikingly attractive couple who thrived together amidst the excitement and hope of New York in the years after World War II. She is survived by her sons, Kimball and Kendall Chen, their wives Patrizia and Gale, six grandchildren, numerous friends and extended family in the U.S., Europe and China. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am in St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street, New York City, on September 10, 2010. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to institutions she passionately loved and supported, The China Institute and The Morgan Library.

He is Roland Monson, not Ronald.

MARDEN--Bernard. Loved and respected. Dear friend, mentor, and role model. He will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him and enjoyed his incredible sense of humor. Les, Gwen, Karen and Marty

MARDEN--Bernard A. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Bernard A. Marden, a life trustee of the Medical Center. Bernard, an alumnus of New York University, was a close friend and benefactor of the Medical Center and endowed the Bernard A. and Charlotte Marden Professorship in Neurology. He will be missed, and we extend our condolences to his wife, Chris, daughters Patrice and Cathy, his son, James, and his entire family. Robert I.
