An article on Wednesday about two researchers whose claim of injury led to a judge's decision on human embryonic stem cell research described the decision incorrectly. The judge issued a preliminary injunction banning federal funding for the research; he did not ban the research itself.

An article on Sunday about attacks in Afghanistan misstated the time period during which 37 soldiers in the American-led military coalition there were killed, as compiled by iCasualties.org, an online database. That figure reflected coalition soldier deaths for the month of August as of Saturday -- not ''so far this year.''

WASSERMAN--Craig. Lazard Managing Directors mark with sorrow the passing of Craig Wasserman, a man of exceptional wisdom, judgment and integrity. A lawyer distinguished by his creativity and vision, he was a key architect of Lazard's initial public offering and we were fortunate to be his client. He touched the lives of many with his humanity and extraordinary courage. To his family and his partners we extend our condolences.

Alan K. Simpson, the Republican co-chairman of President Obama's bipartisan fiscal commission, removed his ''size 15 feet'' from his mouth to apologize to a critic on Wednesday for a stinging letter in which he compared Social Security to ''a milk cow with 310 million tits.'' The apology came as some liberal groups and members of Congress who oppose any changes to Social Security benefits called on Mr. Obama to fire Mr. Simpson, a former senator from Wyoming long known for his irreverent and often biting remarks.

A picture caption on July 22 with an article about the family members who inherited a 43-room house called Rokeby in Barrytown, N.Y., misstated the location of the bathroom shown. It is on the third floor, not the second.

SHEKHETS--Irina. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the tragic loss of Irina Shekhets '10, a cherished graduate, classmate and friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to Irina's parents, Tatiana and Boris Shekhets, her sister Marianna, and her family and friends. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, President Michael A. Gerber, Interim Dean

Dedicated e-readers, like Amazon's Kindle, Barnes & Noble's Nook and Sony's Reader, have one thing in common: they all use black-and-white screen technology from a company called E Ink. Not that E Ink wouldn't like to be able to offer color, but their prototype color displays, as the company concedes, are not yet ready for sale. Consumers used to rich, saturated colors found on typical LCD computer screens would be disappointed with today's E Ink color products.

10 P.M. (ABC) NIGHTLINEPRIME: SECRETS OF YOUR MIND -- WHY WE DO WHAT WE DO In the second installment in this four-part series, Martin Bashir ventures inside the mind of a psychopath to examine the origin of evil in the brain, whether people are born with a tendency for morally objectionable or violent behavior, and if it can be detected in childhood. Mr. Bashir also visits two serial killers on death row and talks to Michael Benoit, above, the father of Chris Benoit, the professional wrestler who murdered his wife and 7-year-old son before killing himself in 2007. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Segments focus on family projects, fall fashion trends for clothes under $75, seasonal wine and room makeovers. Venus Williams is a guest. Trisha Yearwood performs.

STELLMAN--Ann, 99, died August 24, 2010. Retired New York City school teacher, devoted wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, she lived life to the fullest. Funeral, Sunday August 29, 2010, 10am at Parkside Funeral Home, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Park, NY 11374.
ITZKOWITZ--Steven B.,age 48, son of Murray Itzkowitz and Charlotte Wald, died August 20, 2010 in North Carolina from complications of treatment for lymphoma.

CHASSIN--Jameson L. M.D. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are saddened by the passing of Dr. Jameson Chassin, a renowned physician and medical author. Dr. Chassin is also father to two of our cherished colleagues, Mark R. Chassin, MD, MPP, MPH, and Robert Chassin, Senior Director, Business Development and Network Operations for The Mount Sinai Hospital. Dr. Mark Chassin, who is now President of The Joint Commission, was the founding Chairman of the Department of Health Policy and Executive Vice President for Excellence in Patient Care, both at Mount Sinai. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mark, Robert, and the entire Chassin family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

WASSERMAN--Craig. A son, brother, husband, father, uncle and friend. Craig was gifted with a sharp intellect, a sensitive soul and a warm heart. He will be sorely missed for many years to come. With deep love and affection, Sandra K. Wasserman, Mindee E. Wasserman, Jason Glasser and Debra Wasserman, Bret and Blake.

MARDEN--Bernard A. Bernie was a shining example to all of us who had the privilege and pleasure of knowing him. Kind and compassionate in so many ways to the many he helped in his own quiet style, especially those who were sick or needy. Bernie was a good and true friend whose love and concerns were for his beloved wife Chrissie and his adored children and grandchildren. A smile and a joke for all that he met which meant so much to them. Our wonderful friend, our "Rabbi and Doctor" who was always so full of life and fun. We loved him dearly, and he will never be forgotten as he will always be with us in our hearts. Sylvia, Geoffrey and all our Family

NA CHUEAK, THAILAND -- Three months ago, images of protesters battling the military in the streets of Bangkok seized the world's attention. Now, by some measures, Thailand is bouncing back: the country's economy is projected to grow as fast as 7.5 percent this year, and the government is pushing ahead with a program of ''reconciliation'' with its opponents. But even as Thailand pulls itself back together, there are concerns that deep-seated problems among its young people represent a quieter, long-term threat to the country's future.

Yesterday was the first day of the three-day vernissage leading up to the official public opening on Sunday of the 12th International Architecture Exhibition in Venice, better known as the Venice Architecture Biennale. This year’s curatorial director is Kazuyo Sejima, principal of the Tokyo-based architecture firm SANAA, better known to most New Yorkers as the architect of the New Museum. Sejima is breaking new ground on many levels: not only is she the first woman to spearhead the Architecture Biennale, but her theme, “People Meet in Architecture,” is also refreshingly simple and easy to understand, for architects and laypeople alike (unlike titles of previous years, like “Metamporh” or “Next”).

Ali Fatourechi knows his jeans. Before introducing Genetic Denim in 2006, the Los Angeles-based Fatourechi was known as the Denim Guy on college campuses across America. He earned the title based on the year he spent in a U-Haul traveling from New York to Texas (42 cities!) selling jeans and interviewing college students to discover what people really want from their jeans. Here, Fatourechi shares his knowledge of L.A. and beyond:

Frank Gehry designed the first of his famous fish lamps in 1983, when he was asked by the Formica Corporation for ways to use the company’s new laminate product, ColorCore, which was colored all the way through, rather than just on the surface. When Gehry was playing around with the material, he broke a piece, which looked to him like a fish scale — and the rest is design history, with the fish swimming into the collections of art world notables like Jasper Johns. On Sunday, “Fish Forms: Lamps by Frank Gehry” opens at the Jewish Museum. Organized by Ruth Beesch, the museum’s deputy director for program, the exhibition, which includes just eight lamps, was inspired by the glass fish lamp in the museum’s own collection. The lamps themselves are engaging objects, the gentle glow of the light within them contrasting with their substantial, expressionist bases. But they were never designed just for the sake of making something. The fish form was something that had fascinated Gehry for its purity and its dynamism and was well on its way to becoming a major theme in his architecture, a point that is made quite well in a video that accompanies the exhibition, which runs through Oct. 31.

Most fashionistas progress directly from playing with dolls to sticking pins in them, but even the cattiest divas won’t mess with Anna Wintour and Grace Coddington. To celebrate Fashion’s Night Out on Sept. 10, Barneys New York commissioned the Brooklyn-based artist Andrew Yang to make these one-of-kind, hand-sewn, hand-painted rag-doll replicas of the celebrated Vogue editors. Strictly couture (bien sur!), the duo took two weeks to make. “I had to special-order Anna’s wig and cut it myself to get the bob right,” Mr. Yang says. “And Grace’s hair was the right color, but it needed a perm.” Alas, the question on everyone’s lips – What are they wearing? – has a disappointingly democratic answer. “The outfits are my own take on their signature looks,” he says. “It would have been unfair to single out specific designers.” Anna and Grace will be auctioned off on charitybuzz.com beginning August 31, with the proceeds benefiting The New York City Aids Fund.

A confidential U.N. report by a mapping team on atrocities in Congo between 1993 and 2003 has been leaked and implicates Rwanda in stunning levels of brutality aimed at Hutus. It raises the possibility that Rwanda wasn't just the victim of genocide (mostly against Rwandan Tutsis) but also a perpetrator (mostly against Rwandan Hutus who fled to Congo).

Federal researchers have published work concluding that a particular variant of the periodic El Niño warmups of the tropical Pacific Ocean is becoming more frequent and stronger. The pattern appears to fit what is expected from human-driven warming of the global climate, said the researchers, Tong Lee of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and Michael McPhaden of the Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory, part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Tyler Hicks of The New York Times has photographed the marooned village of Garhr Khairo, where 250 of its 68,000 people have chosen to remain. (Slides 1, 2 and 3.) Even as Pakistani and international relief officials scrambled to save people and property, Carlotta Gall reported, they despaired that the nation's worst natural calamity had ruined just about every physical strand that knits this country together - roads, bridges, schools, health clinics, electricity and communications. The destruction could set Pakistan back many years, if not decades, further weaken its feeble civilian administration and add to the burdens on its military.

Updated Voters in states like Illinois and North Carolina, where both the Republican and Democratic nominees for Senate are unpopular and where the number of undecided voters remains high, might lament the choice before them. Sure, if they wanted to register their displeasure with the major-party nominees, they could vote for a minor-party candidate instead (LeAlan Jones, the Green Party's nominee in Illinois, has polled as high as 14 percent in some surveys). Or they could simply stay home.

These days, everyone is a curator. Fashionistas curate their closets. Interior designers curate rooms. So it wasn't such a stretch when London's Haunch of Venison gallery asked the D.J. James Lavelle, a curator of music, to put together a show of work by visual artists set to his own soundtrack. For "Daydreaming With James Lavelle," Lavelle, the founder of the Mo'Wax record label and the trip-hop collaborative UNKLE, used his personal street-art collection as a starting point, including works by the graffiti legends Futura, Bäst and Faile, and added music-inspired conceptual art by James Shovlin, art-inspired fashion by the London label Boudicca's and new works made in response to Lavelle's own compositions to the mix.

As we noted this week, Continental recently showed off the cabins of its 787 Dreamliners. Well, there is a new estimated arrival time for the planes: Boeing announced on Friday that it was postponing the delivery of its 787s until the middle of the first quarter of 2011 because of a delay in engine availability, among other issues. Continental still expects to roll out the planes late next year because it has not received a revision to its delivery schedule, according to Christen David, a spokeswoman. But ANA, which had planned to inaugurate the planes this year, called the delay "regrettable," the Associated Press reported.

"The city of New Orleans has yet to erect a formal monument to the catastrophe that left 80 percent of the city flooded," said Nicole Bengiveno, a Times photographer who was there in 2005 and recently returned. A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Over on the Green blog, James Kanter reports that European scientists have successfully bred captive bluefin tuna without using hormones. A research commissioner at the European Union, which gave nearly 3 million Euros to the project, said that if the results of the experiment could be adopted for large-scale commercial use, it could help lead to sustainable bluefin fishery management.

I was tweaking a photo for a friend's antiques store Web site the other day, experimenting with Adobe Photoshop Lightroom to adjust the color and add a subtle vignette. I like Lightroom because it doesn't have the arduous learning curve that Photoshop does, and it's designed specifically for photographers and photographs.

We are bursting with excitement that Michael Shear will be joining us at The Caucus. He comes to The New York Times with years of experience covering government and politics, most recently reporting from the White House for The Washington Post. At The Caucus, Mr. Shear will provide analysis and breaking news, but really, Richard W. Stevenson, our political editor and deputy Washington bureau chief, says it all in his memo announcing the news:

No sooner has Simon Cowell departed from "American Idol" than the reality series has started distancing itself from that acid-tongued former judge, as his British series "The X Factor" finds itself embroiled in scandal.
Today's Patient Money offers advice about high-deductible health plans.

Recognizable players from the women's tour, in competitive, sometimes controversial matches, with fans watching from about a yard away, in an outer borough park -- only it's not the United States Open qualifying but the EmblemHealth Bronx Open, which is taking place this week on the hardcourts in picturesque Crotona Park.

Corporate profits are near their pre-recession peak, according to a report released today by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. The numbers were released alongside revised estimates for second-quarter gross domestic product.

A wave of deals in what is typically a sleepy summer month is keeping bankers and analysts very busy. Yet the giants in M.&A. advisory work have seen their shares of the market slump in August, according to Thomson Reuters data.

KABUL, Afghanistan - When I heard about the pregnant woman who was executed by the Taliban, I felt deep sorrow for her - sorrow because she was just a widow who was without a man in her life for four years, and because the man had reportedly told her he would marry her. Where is the crime in that?
Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

Does testing positive for herpes mean you will inevitably have outbreaks? Does a positive herpes test result always mean you can spread genital herpes to others? These are among the questions raised by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Peter Leone, associate professor at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine and Public Health, addresses testing for the two types of herpes simplex virus: HSV-2, the main cause of genital herpes, and HSV-1, responsible for most cases of oral herpes, or cold sores.
The federal government has downgraded its estimate of the economy's growth in the second quarter to an annual rate of 1.6 percent, down from an initial estimate last month of 2.4 percent.
How high can the bidding war between Dell and Hewlett-Packard for 3Par, an 11-year-old storage company, go?

Things are looking very literary this week. At No. 3 on the hardcover list is "The Dark Tower: The Battle of Jericho Hill," which explores the world and characters created by Stephen King in his series of "Dark Tower" novels. Previous installments of this series landed on the list back in February.

This week, our Student Challenge writers responded to everything from Denmark's new unemployment policy to teens using Botox and the Beloit College Mindset List. Many also felt compelled to write about the trend in which back-to-school shopping increasingly involves a stop in the cleaning products aisle of their local stores.
Just hours after Dell matched its $27-a-share bid for data storage company 3Par, Hewlett-Packard has raised its offer to $30 a share, or an enterprise value of $2 billion.

Scientists in Europe have bred Atlantic bluefin tuna in captivity, and without using hormones, potentially boosting stocks of a fish that has become endangered because of huge demand for sashimi and sushi in Japan and other countries.

Since ArtsBeat will be closely focused on its coverage of the Emmy Awards on Sunday night, we'll be unable to watch "Mad Men" in real time when it's shown at 10 p.m. (And if we're going to be an hour behind the rest of the East Coast, why even bother?) So we'd like to treat ourselves to a little taste of what we're missing while we watch the television industry give itself fabulous prizes, but as "Mad Men" fans know, the official trailers for each week's coming installment provide no help. Because of the series creator Matthew Weiner's well-known dislike of spoilers, these previews are edited to the point of inscrutability, and, often, accidental comedy.

It's been nearly 30 years since Dr. Peter Rabins, a Johns Hopkins psychiatrist, and his co-author Nancy Mace published "The 36-Hour Day," the best known guide to caring for someone with Alzheimer's disease. Now in its fourth edition, it remains a trusted source of information and support.

The Bluetooth accessories maker BlueAnt has released a new earpiece that can do some remarkable things if your phone is up to it.

You may remember one of my posts from last year in which I talked about not needing a public relations firm because we were getting plenty of media coverage organically. Well, as I looked back on that coverage recently, I realized that it was more focused on me as a business owner than on the company and the team. And right now, I'm so busy building the company, training new employees, and managing my pregnancy that I haven't had time to seek speaking and interview opportunities.

A Mongolian coking coal company, the Mongolian Mining Corporation, has received approval from the listing committee of the Hong Kong stock exchange to proceed with its $800 million to $1 billion initial public offering, sources close to the deal told Reuters on Friday.

The Oscar winners Curtis Hanson and William Hurt have joined the HBO project "Too Big to Fail," based on the book about the 2008 financial crisis by DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin. Deadline.com reported that Mr. Hanson would direct and be the executive producer while Mr. Hurt would play Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson Jr.

William Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management is betting against the debt of BP through credit-default swaps, saying the energy company's creditworthiness will be dented for years by the biggest offshore oil spill in United States history.
Two unidentified private equity firms are said to be bidding for the  largest dentist office chains in America, The New York Post reported.

I caught up with Chevron's vice president for global exploration this week to ask him what impact the BP well disaster and the drilling moratorium in the Gulf of Mexico would have on his company's plans for future deepwater development.
Blockbuster, the movie rental chain, is said to be readying a bankruptcy filing for mid-September, The Los Angeles Times reported on Thursday, citing people briefed on the matter.

Kazakhmys, the copper producer, told The Financial Times that it was mulling a listing in Hong Kong.
David Kim is the co-founder of FantasyPros, a site that rates the accuracy of fantasy experts and provides simple tools that reduce the time and stress involved in making good fantasy decisions.

The American International Group has scrapped plans to sell a strategic stake in its Asian life insurance business, AIA, ahead of its initial public offering, a source familiar with the process told Reuters on Friday.
Max Willens explores the wide Web for stories about the Giants.

No one embraces jazz like the French. They first fell under its spell in the 1920s, when American artists like Josephine Baker and Sidney Bechet found refuge in their country, disillusioned by the racial situation in the United States. Still among jazz's biggest supporters, the French hold terrific festivals, like Jazz à la Villette, which runs from Aug. 31 to Sept. 12 in beautiful Parc de la Villette and other venues around Paris.
Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.
The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board agreed to buy the Intoll Group for 3.44 billion Australian dollars ($3 billion), gaining stakes in toll roads in Toronto and Sydney, Bloomberg News reported.

ArcSight, a maker of security software, has set its sights on finding a buyer. Citing people familiar with the matter, The Wall Street Journal reported that the company had quietly put itself up for sale and may have attracted interest from such potential bidders as Oracle, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and CA.

Carl C. Icahn this week bought deeper into Motorola, lifting his holdings to about 10.6 percent, according to a filing made to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Icahn spent $86.2 million on acquiring the shares.

MOSCOW -- For years, environmentalists have risked arrests and sometimes beatings by the police and masked plainclothes thugs in their efforts to halt the construction of a highway linking Moscow to St. Petersburg that they say would destroy the Khimki Forest, one of the few remaining in the Moscow region. Typically in Russia, such efforts lead to little but holding cells or worse for proponents of a cause. But supporters of the Khimki Forest were handed a surprising victory on Thursday when President Dmitri A. Medvedev reacted to the public outcry. He postponed construction of the highway. ''Given the number of appeals, I have made a decision,'' Mr. Medvedev said in a message on his video blog. ''I order the government to halt the implementation of the decision to build this highway and conduct further civic and expert discussions.''

DAVISON--Daniel P. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Daniel P. Davison, a generous and committed Trustee, advisor, donor, and friend. He served with great distinction and devotion on the Board for nearly 50 years--first as a Trustee (1963-1989) and then as Trustee Emeritus--and held a number of leadership positions, including that of Vice Chairman for 15 years. From 1983 to 1989, a time of significant growth for the Museum and of the accompanying financial challenges, he chaired the Finance Committee with sound judgment and far-sighted guidance. With his wife, Katusha, he supported the Met's capital projects, publications, and the departments of Egyptian Art and Musical Instruments. Addressing the Board in 1989, he said that his work at the Museum brought him great happiness. Through decades of sharing his wisdom, experience, energetic spirit, and good cheer, he in turn influenced this institution in myriad ways that will continue to benefit the staff and millions of visitors annually, long into the future. We will miss him greatly and extend condolences to Katusha and his entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

The Stockholm Journal article on Wednesday, about a movement in Sweden to abolish the monarchy, described incorrectly the circumstances surrounding the breakup of Prince Carl Philip and his girlfriend. It was amicable, not ''because of his alleged philandering.'' The article also misidentified the subject of a comment by Susanne Nylen, the monarchy reporter for Aftonbladet, Sweden's leading newspaper. When she said, ''We knew about his affairs for a long time,'' she was speaking about the former boyfriend of Princess Madeleine, a sister of Carl Philip -- not about Carl Philip himself.

Questions about birthday dinners flooded the mailbox while your faithful correspondent was on vacation these last few weeks. And there was one inquiry about entertaining a first-time visitor to the island of Manhattan. I did my best to answer their needs. Send me your questions! A. I am going nowhere near the question of comfortable chairs. One man's comfortable chair at Ben Benson's is another man's torture device. Some people love the stools at Momofuku Ko. Others decry the plush seats at Per Se. I'm happy in a bistro chair at Quatorze. I have thought to bring a boat cushion to dinner at Cookshop. It's all relative. What makes a comfortable chair is not a scientific, objective description, like the best restaurant criticism.

An article on Thursday about the possibility of additional economic actions by the Federal Reserve referred incorrectly in some editions to the Fed's lowering of the federal funds rate following the dot-com collapse. The rate was lowered to 1.25 percent in November 2002, from 6.5 percent in January 2001 -- not January 2003. Because of an editing error, the article also gave an outdated title for Donald L. Kohn in some editions. While he is still a Fed governor, he is no longer the board's vice chairman -- a post he stepped down from in late June.

CHEN--Maie-Lee. Mrs. Maie-Lee Chen passed away peacefully on Friday, August 20, 2010 in New York City, at the age of 86. A talented concert harpist and protegee of the world's leading harpist Carlos Salzedo in her earlier years, she subsequently devoted her life to partnering her beloved husband, the late Dr. Christopher C.Y. Chen, and surrounding him with elegance and beauty. They were a strikingly attractive couple who thrived together amidst the excitement and hope of New York in the years after World War II. She is survived by her sons, Kimball and Kendall Chen, their wives Patrizia and Gale, six grandchildren, numerous friends and extended family in the U.S., Europe and China. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am in St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street, New York City, on September 10, 2010. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to institutions she passionately loved and supported, The China Institute and The Morgan Library.

WASSERMAN--Craig. A son, brother, husband, father, uncle and friend. Craig was gifted with a sharp intellect, a sensitive soul and a warm heart. He will be sorely missed for many years to come. FRANK--Max. After a short illness, Max Frank passed away peacefully on August 24th, at the age of 96. He worked for Kaufmann Trading Corporation and lived with his beloved wife Lilli in Great Neck, from 1946 to 1993, when they moved to San Mateo, California. He once wrote, "Whatever you do, it should be to the good of yourself as well as other people, and it should not do any harm. If everybody would follow this principle, we would have the ideal world." A man with a loving wise heart, whose name never appeared in a newspaper (although he read the New York Times daily since 1966), he was a role model and mentor to so many family members and friends about the important values in life; caring about each other. For those of us blessed to be part of his life, he has made this a better world. His memory and legacy will live on. Contributions can be made to The Birthright Israel Foundation (P.O. Box 1784, New York, NY 10156. Phone: 1-877-477-7517), an organization that offers Jewish youth worldwide a trip to Israel to experience its history, culture and community.

CHASSIN--Jameson L. M.D. The trustees, administration, medical staff, and employees of New York Hospital Queens mourn the death of Dr. Jameson Chassin. Dr. Chassin was a skilled surgeon, a remarkable teacher and a productive scholar. His book, Chassin's Operative Strategy in General Surgery, third edition is the most widely read surgical atlas in the world. He was the first full time chairman of surgery for our institution, which was then known as Booth Memorial Hospital, and he was the founder of our surgical group CRT Surgical Associates. Today, his imprint remains visible both through the programs he built to provide excellent outcomes for our patients, and in the hundreds of students and young surgeons who were lucky enough to have him as a teacher and mentor. We extend our sympathy to his entire family. His family, and ours, has lost a giant. George F. Heinrich, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees Stephen S. Mills, President and Chief Executive Officer John E. Sciortino, Senior Vice President and Chief Operating Officer Stephen Rimar, M.D, Senior Vice President and Chief Medical Officer Jack M. Mann, M.D., President, Medical Staff Society William G. Wolff, M.D., President, Medical Board James W. Turner, M.D., Chairman, Department of Surgery

ISTANBUL - The fallout from the brawl between Greece and Serbia last week could have a significant impact on those countries' advancing out of pool play at the world basketball championships, which begin in Turkey on Saturday. Nenad Krstic of Serbia, the starting center for the Oklahoma City Thunder in the N.B.A., was suspended for Serbia's first three games and fined about $35,000. His teammate Milos Teodosic will miss Serbia's first two games, and FIBA fined the Serbian basketball federation $15,300.

Gary was founder and President of Manhattan Tool Company. He was a renowned expert on antiquities, archaeology, pre-Columbian art and Mayan ruins. He was particularly fond of doing the New York Times crossword puzzles. He will be sorely missed by all. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, Sunday 11:30am.

At the end of August, the narratives around baseball's top awards have formed, and the contenders are jockeying for position for the stretch run. The 60 writers who vote for these awards have their reasons for how they vote, but as a body they often favor runs batted in leaders on playoff teams for the Most Valuable Player awards. Sabermetricians back to the 1980s and before have been working on ''one-number'' measures: a statistic that takes every contribution from players of different skills and positions and runs it through a variety of formulas ending with one number. This number typically known as wins above replacement or WAR endeavors to tell us how many wins a player was worth to his term over replacement talent. The idea of a replacement player is a debated one, but the basic premise is that if a team lost a player, it would use a bench player or a call-up from Class AAA to replace him. This mythical replacement player is our baseline for all evaluation.

10 P.M. (Discovery) BEYOND SURVIVAL WITH LES STROUD In ''Survivorman'' Mr. Stroud stranded himself -- equipped only with his clothes, a multitool, a pocketful of everyday items and a video camera -- in some of the remotest locations on the planet and then tried to get out alive. In this new series he immerses himself in daily life with indigenous people to learn survival techniques and rituals rarely divulged to outsiders. His first stop: Sri Lanka, above, where he studies post-tsunami behavior alongside the men of the Veddah tribe, once believed to be half human and half demon, and takes part in two ''devil dances,'' believed to exorcise dark forces. Leading in at 9 is a new episode of ''Man, Woman, Wild,'' in which Mykel Hawke, a wilderness expert and former Green Beret, and his wife, Ruth England, a city girl and television journalist, find themselves all wet in Utah when their raft overturns in the chilly Colorado River. 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: OLIVIA DE HAVILLAND ''Every actor in the business owes a great debt of gratitude to Olivia for what she did,'' Bette Davis said after Ms. de Havilland, now 94, took Warner Brothers to court in 1943 -- and won -- for trying to keep her under contract after she believed she had fulfilled her legal obligation. This all-day tribute runs the gamut from ''The Private Lives of Elizabeth and Essex'' (1939), at 10, in which Ms. de Havilland plays Lady Penelope Gray to Davis's Queen Elizabeth and Errol Flynn's Earl of Essex, to ''The Heiress'' (1949), at 8 p.m., in which Ms. de Havilland subverted her beauty (and won the first of two best-actress Oscars). She portrays the title character, the awkward young woman at the heart of Henry James's novel ''Washington Square,'' in 1840s New York City. She falls for a handsome suitor (Montgomery Clift), whom her father (Ralph Richardson) suspects is a fortune hunter.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital. Most of us invest in bonds or bond mutual funds to keep our principal safe and to earn a bit of income. People think bonds are safe because when you buy an individual bond, like a U.S. government bond, you have a stated interest rate and a known maturity. In other words, you know exactly what income you will earn and exactly when you will get your principal back, much like a certificate of deposit at a bank that is backed by the F.D.I.C.

When Linda Falcao applied for a mortgage from Wells Fargo, she didn't realize she would be required to write the type of essay that's more commonly included with a college application. So she and her husband, Kemuel Ronis, were taken by surprise when Wells Fargo asked the couple, both 50, to pen a ''motivational letter'' explaining why they were moving. What they found even more shocking, however, were some of the themes that Wells required them to include in their statement, specifically, their plans regarding an ''increase/decrease in family'' or property size.

A chart on Friday about nominees for the top Emmy Awards misidentified, in some editions, the character played by Jim Parsons on ''The Big Bang Theory.'' Mr. Parsons, who has been nominated for the award for outstanding lead actor in a comedy series, plays Sheldon, not Leonard. The chart also misspelled the name of the fictional town in Indiana that is the setting for ''Parks and Recreation,'' whose star, Amy Poehler, has been nominated for the Emmy for outstanding lead actress in a comedy series. It is Pawnee, not Pawnie.

Hearts were probably broken all over Brooklyn on Thursday night, but one was shattered for sure: a glass sculpture of a human one, installed three weeks ago in a Greenpoint park. The heart was part of the Humanity Fountain, a temporary sculpture in Monsignor McGolrick Park that features a solar-powered, stone-and-concrete perfume-dispensing fountain. A woodsy, lemony fragrance wafts from inside the sculpture, and the heart had rested on top of it.

A Somali man pleaded guilty Friday to attacking a Navy ship in the Gulf of Aden in April 2010. Earlier this month, a federal judge in Norfolk threw out piracy charges against the man, Jama Idle Ibrahim, and five others accused in the attack on the U.S.S. Ashland, saying the government had not shown that the men's actions violated American piracy law. Mr. Ibrahim pleaded guilty to three charges, including attacking to plunder a vessel. The dropped piracy charge carried an automatic life sentence; the deal calls for a sentence of 30 years, and Mr. Ibrahim agreed to cooperate with the authorities to provide information that may help fight future attacks. He is also expected to plead guilty in an attack on the CEC Future, a Danish-owned merchant ship that was hijacked in November 2008.

9 P.M. (Starz) THE MEN WHO STARE AT GOATS (2009) George Clooney (above left with Kevin Spacey), outfitted with a heavy mustache, a range of haircuts and a variety of comic tics, plays Lyn Cassady, a recruit in an experimental Army program centered on parapsychology and developed by Bill Django (Jeff Bridges), a Vietnam vet, with the support of a gonzo general (Stephen Lang). Ewan McGregor is Bob Wilton, a journalist who heads to Iraq to find meaning in his life after his marriage goes bust -- and who thinks he's just stumbled upon the perfect story subject. Adapted from the nonfiction book by Jon Ronson, the film is directed by Grant Heslov, Mr. Clooney's frequent producing partner, with whom he wrote ''Good Night, and Good Luck.'' ''What makes this a story worth telling, it emerges quickly, isn't the journalist but the men who thought they could travel the world or stop a goat's heart with their minds,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times of this ''likable, lightweight, absurdist comedy.'' ''The journalist hook is an easy way into the material, but both Bob and the flashbacks, which probably account for some of Mr. Heslov's unsteadiness, get in the way.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Betty Rollin reports on the work of mediators who help divorcing interfaith couples with the religious upbringing of their children. Kim Lawton visits the First Baptist Church in Chalmette, La., which was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina and rebuilt by volunteers from 34 states and is now trying to reinvent itself after losing 97 percent of its congregation after the storm.

ANDORRA -- Andorra, one of Europe's smallest nations, has relied on banking secrecy, tourism and duty-free trade to turn itself into one of the Continent's most impressive postwar economic success stories. Wedged between France and Spain and with a population of 84,000, Andorra has benefited from its hybrid status as a principality headed by representatives from its two neighbors, to attract their entrepreneurs and tourists. It also gained a reputation for being unwilling to share information, particularly financial data.

An eloquent lawyer, joyful piano player and avid golfer, he was, above all, a beloved and devoted husband of Shirley, cherished father of Lee and son-in-law Donald, adored grandfather of Paul, Joyce and granddaughter-in-law Lisa. His wit and wisdom brightened all our lives.

ASCHNER--Ernest, of Boynton Beach, FL, died August 26, 2010 at the age of 97 from complications following a fall. Born in Breslau, Germany in 1913, arrived in New York in 1938. Survived by his loving and beloved wife Gisela, daughters Vivian Lando (Mark) and Marilyn Katz (Leonard), three grandsons Juddson, Curtis, and Seth Lando, and great-grandchildren Cooper, Parker, and Peyton Lando. Owner and president of Elizabeth Kugelmann Co., manufacturer of military insignia. He was a skilled tennis player, ardent tennis fan, and founding member of Shelter Rock Tennis Club, Manhasset, NY. A lifelong supporter of music and the arts. Love for his family permeated his daily life. There will be a private graveside service. Donations in his memory can be made to the Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC.

MOTOR VEHICLES are banned during the summer along most of Fire Island's pencil-thin 31 miles. As a result, ''nobody gets anything onto or off of the island without the ferry,'' said Tim Mooney, president of Fire Island Ferries, virtually the only game in town when it comes to shuttling homeowners and vacationers, and all their stuff, from Bay Shore, on Long Island, across the Great South Bay. The company frowns on bringing large amounts of stuff onto its 11 passenger ferries. What can't be carried over someone's shoulder or under someone's arm usually gets shipped separately on a freight ferry, which runs once each way, Monday to Saturday, year round (ice permitting). Every grocery in every market, every beer in every bar, every houseplant, every bicycle and red wagon comes by freight boat.

BARDAVID--Isaac, 89, died August 23, 2010. Survived by his beloved wife of almost 68 years, Charlotte; children Herb and Jane Bardavid, Elliot and Debra Bardavid, and Lynda and Jack Kauffman; grandchildren Jessica and Steve Graff, Joshua Bardavid, Jonathan and Jennifer Bardavid, Jennifer and Robert Franck, and Karen Bardavid; great-grandchildren Samantha Graff, Carter Graff, Gabrielle Bardavid. He was loved and will be missed.

Burberry plans to offer customers a substantial portion of its Prorsum spring 2011 runway collection - to be shown Sept. 21 in London - for immediate online sale, with delivery in six to eight weeks. Last February, Burberry made news when it allowed individuals to order pieces directly from the runway, as part of a live Web stream in which approximately 20 outerwear garments and all the bags were designated for sale. Customers were given a window of seven days in which to place orders at Burberry.com. The items were the same pricey coats - part of an aviator-themed collection by designer Christopher Bailey- that would be in stores months later.

A brief report in the Inside the List column last Sunday about Mary Roach's ''Packing for Mars,'' a book on the ways humans adapt to space travel, misstated the location of a toilet equipped with a closed-circuit camera used as a training aid for astronauts. It is at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, not on the space shuttle.

THE NEWS Incumbents and establishment figures, for the most part, fended off strong challenges from well-financed ''outsider'' candidates to win primary contests across five states despite a widely perceived tide of voter dissatisfaction. BEHIND THE NEWS Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, handily beat J. D. Hayworth, a conservative talk-radio host, in part by shifting to the right on Mr. Hayworth's big issue, immigration. Among Democrats, Kendrick B. Meek, a Miami congressman, won the Senate nomination though he was far outspent by Jeff Greene, a wealthy real estate investor who poured millions of his own dollars into his campaign.

As we lament the disappearance of manual transmissions, Buick is actually coming out with its first manual in 22 years with the upcoming 2011 Buick Regal GS. The Regal GS, based on the Opel Insignia in Europe, will be available with a 6-speed manual transmission by the end of the year. Price is expected to be in the high $30,000 range.

An answer in the Q & A column last Sunday about repairing broken windows in a co-op apartment occupied by a rent-stabilized tenant overstated the owner's responsibility for the repairs. Responsibility is generally spelled out in the co-op's proprietary lease, which may put it on either the co-op board or the unit owner; the burden may not be solely the owner's.
WEISS--Doris T. 10/16/30--8/30/03. In my heart always. Your daughter, Wendy

An article last Sunday about the role that technology plays in visitors' mishaps in national parks described incorrectly an increase in the number of search and rescue missions from 2005 to 2009. While the number of such missions was higher in 2009 (3,593) than in 2005 (2,430), according to National Park Service figures, it is not the case that the numbers ''have been climbing for the last five years.'' (For instance, the highest number -- 3,623 -- was recorded in 2006.)

For some city residents, summer weekends are the best times, with the streets relatively empty of traffic and people -- except for tourists. Special happenings include the closing of much of Park Avenue and other streets for three Saturday mornings in August. Bicyclists, skaters, joggers, strollers and baby carriages fill the wide avenue, divided by a garden mall. Gaining popularity at these events are adult bikes colored like children's trikes. The invasion of sidewalk boutiques continued. Three portable swimming pools and a sun deck at East 40th Street delighted gawkers. Among the eye-catchers were a rider with extensions of bright horsehair tubes and two dogs wearing bike helmets.

EISENBERG--Daniel, 86, passed away peacefully on August 22, surrounded by his loving family. He will be missed greatly by his wife of twenty-four years, Nan (Schiff) Eisenberg, his sons Larry, Gary, and Richard, his stepchildren Todd and Lewis, his daughters-in-law Mary, Cathy, Mary and Lynette, his grandchildren Amanda, Benjamin, Rebecca, Mary, Jackie, Hayley and Jacob, his brother-in-law Mort Spiller, his nephew Harley Spiller and nieces Lora Spiller and Jill (Spiller) Underwood. He was pre-deceased by his sister, Harriet Spiller. Daniel graduated Townsend Harris High School, City College and St. John's Law School and NYU. From 1943 to 1946, he served in the South Pacific with the US Army. His legal career spanned more than half a century, beginning in the film industry and ending with a 27-year tenure as a highly respected attorney in the enforcement division of the New York Stock Exchange. He retired at the age of 82. Daniel was an avid patron of the arts, a world traveler and a member of the Atheist Society of New York. We will remember his loving kindness, unimpeachable moral character, and inquisitive intellect. He will remain forever in our hearts. A memorial service is planned for the fall.

WARSAWER--Harold N.,beloved husband of the late Sally (Kingsbury), devoted father of Alice Cooper (Marty), Nancy Arkuss (Neil), Carole Warsawer and adored poppa of Jeffrey, David, Julia, Brett, and R.J. died Saturday, August 28, 2010, just shy of his 98th birthday. He was a gentle man with a quick wit and a loving heart. MBA from Harvard Business School. Served as a Captain with the United States Army Air Corps in WW II. CEO of Atlantic Appraisal Company, Manhattan until retirement at age 85. Member of the Appraisal Institute (M.A.I.) where he served on the National Board. Service will be held Tuesday Beth Am Teaneck NJ.

Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer performed their compelling act a few times at Wimbledon, several more times in Paris, but also in Madrid, Shanghai, Dubai, Hamburg and Monaco. The rivalry between Nadal and Federer, considered the two best tennis players in the world, has been showcased all over the globe, but never in New York. They have played 21 times since 2004, when they first met in Miami, - the only time they played in anything other than the final or semifinals of a tournament - and Nadal holds a 14-7 advantage. But somehow they have never met at the United States Open, where Federer has reached the last six finals and won five and where Nadal has never make it past the semifinals. The rivalry may seem one-sided, especially on clay, but on center court at Arthur Ashe Stadium, Federer had been invincible until last year's final, when he lost to Juan Martin del Potro. If Federer, who had won 41 consecutive matches at Arthur Ashe, can get back to the final, and Nadal overcomes his usual end-of-summer obstacles and reaches the Open final, it would provide the most compelling final matchup here since Pete Sampras beat Andre Agassi in 2002. The friendly foes, Nadal and Federer, No. 1 against No. 2. ''People seem to love it,'' Federer said. ''It's one of the biggest rivalries we have in all of sports, and I'm happy it's been on a fair basis. It would be a bit of a pain if it weren't like that.'' Mostly because of the respect Nadal showed for Federer when he eventually assumed his mantle as the world's best player, Nadal never outwardly annoyed Federer, so their relationship has not had the edge that Jimmy Connors's and John McEnroe's or Justine Henin's and Serena Williams's had. ''Look, he's not my rival since three weeks,'' Federer said. ''He's been my rival for almost five years now. So we're a very healthy rivalry. We get along really well. We chat a lot in the locker rooms, just hang out sometimes. ''So it's nice to have a rival like Rafa who has been so respectful, really. I think I've helped him to be a better player. Same for me. I think he's helped me to become a better player.'' Whether the speed of center court or Nadal's late-season injuries kick in again to thwart the matchup, Nadal said he fully expected Federer to hold up his end. ''If I am in the last rounds, I am going to have a big chance to play against him,'' Nadal said, ''Because he always is here.'' Federer comes into the Open on an upswing after a difficult summer. After winning the Australian Open in January for his record 16th Grand Slam title, he did not win another tournament until Cincinnati last week. At the French Open, he lost to Robin Soderling in the quarterfinals, breaking his record of 23 consecutive Grand Slam semifinal appearances. After he lost to Tomas Berdych in the semifinals at Wimbledon, he uncharacteristically complained of leg and back problems. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DAVISON--Danny. The Board of the Florence Gould Foundation mourns the death of its Co-Director Daniel P. Davison - a friend, wise counselor and delightful fellow traveler. We express our heartfelt condolences to Danny's beloved wife Katusha and his family.

More than six decades ago, the Florentine aristocrat Emilio Pucci decided to break from 1,000 years of family tradition and work. What started with some comfortable ski wear for his girlfriend grew into one of the world's first fashion lifestyle houses. From bathing suits to bath towels, if there was a need, Pucci sought to fill it in print. In celebration of the designer's life and work, Taschen has recently released ''Pucci,'' a limited-edition art book featuring hundreds of photographs, sketches and personal notes, each book bound in a vibrantly printed fabric from a recent collection.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''An Athlete With No Illusions About Steroids,'' Aug. 22: Harold Connolly's quips were taken out of context of his athletic achievements, his world records in particular. His experimentation with steroids was minimal -- and during times steroids were not outlawed. His world records were not steroid-enhanced; they were achieved through his grit and determination.
Theater Ben Brantley

Online travel sites can predict the future, in a way, by checking their own bookings. If users who booked hotels through Orbitz.com and Priceline.comare any indication, American travelers are remaining stateside for Labor Day, and four cities will get the benefit of their company (and their hotel taxes). New York, Seattle, Chicago and Las Vegas are among the top five cities on lists that each site recently released outlining the most popular destinations for the holiday. The lists differ slightly: New York is No. 1 for Priceline users and No. 2 for Orbitz users, for example. Orbitz, in a summary of events, manages to help explain the appeal of some of its top cities.

Continental Airlines, which next year will become the first domestic carrier to fly the new Boeing 787 Dreamliner, offered a preview of the plane's interior this month at the National Business Travel Association convention in Houston. If the preview matches reality, the new planes will offer several enhancements. Overhead bins - the largest in the industry, according to Continental - are big enough to hold a standard-size carry-on for every passenger. Larger windows give everyone on board a view of the horizon. Air purification will be improved and greater humidity will make for cleaner, less drying air. The plane will be able to fly using 20 percent less fuel and emitting 20 percent less carbon dioxide than the Boeing 767, the airline says.

Q.My boyfriend and I plan to take a two-week wedding trip to Argentina around Thanksgiving. We'd like to spend part of the time in Buenos Aires, with a side trip or two. And we'd enjoy some time at a nice beach. Any recommendations for some gay-friendly destinations? Zach Patton, WashingtonA.Buenos Aires is a sprawling city with 48 barrios, so you'll want to concentrate on a handful of neighborhoods. It's best to get around on foot, or by metro (www.subte.com.ar) or taxi.

SCHEIDLINGER--Saul, Ph.D.,CGP, DFAGPA, The American Group Psychotherapy Association, the Group Psychotherapy Foundation and the National Registry of Certified Group Psychotherapists Officers, Boards of Directors and Membership mourn the loss of Dr. Saul Scheidlinger, who passed away on August 21st in Manhattan. He was a Distinguished Fellow, AGPA Past President, former Editor of the International Journal of Group Psychotherapy, a pioneer in the application of group treatment to emotionally-deprived youth, and author of 75 articles and chapters and three much-consulted books. He mentored generations of mental health professionals and touched the lives of countless number of patients. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Rosalyn Tauber and his son and daughter-in-law, Dr. David J. Scheidlinger and Carla Scheidlinger and their two children. At his family's request, donations in his honor may be sent to the American Group Psychotherapy Association's Group Psychotherapy Foundation and the Museum of Jewish Heritage.

The parents and players on my 7-year-old son's baseball team assembled near the pitcher's mound on a recent Saturday. Under a blazing sun, the boys lined up to receive a handshake from the coach, a trophy and an entreaty to smile from their camera-toting parents. My son's trophy named him the 2010 East Brunswick, N.J., Baseball League Instructional 7's ''Most Valuable Player.'' I was stunned. Had my skinny but baseball-addicted son really surpassed all his teammates? As the rest of the boys received their awards, the truth came out: The inscription was the same on every trophy.

In ''The Last King of Scotland,'' which I watched dubbed in Spanish on the bus from Tapachula to Oaxaca, Mexico, last week, the Scottish character Nicholas Garrigan comes up with a travel plan: to spin a globe, to place his finger down randomly, and to go wherever it lands. His destination: Uganda. Unfortunately, it was 1971, and the brutal dictator Idi Amin had just seized power. Things do not go well. My plan for my 10th week of travel through Latin America had just enough in common with Nicholas Garrigan's to give me pause. I was in Mexico, a country in the throes of a murderous drug war, where I had decided to buy a Oaxaca state map, arbitrarily pick a town maybe an hour from the capital (also named Oaxaca) and settle in for the week. The only requirements were that it be small, rural and have no known tourist attractions. Rather than spinning a globe, I relied on a bus driver who suggested his own hometown to me when I told him of my quest.

''I am no fan of Ms. Perry. I find her calculating and hypocritical. Her song ''I Kissed a Girl'' trivializes and condescends to lesbians, even as it is intended to shock those with more conventional and traditional lifestyles and philosophies; and unlike someone like Randy Newman, she manages to irritate two polar-opposite cohorts without a shred of humor or irony. She shocks to get attention, not to make any substantive statement.'' SANDY ANDINA of Chicago, responding to Melena Ryzik's profile of the pop singer Katy Perry.

The Podgorze district in Krakow, Poland, has had a tough go of it. Established by the Hapsburgs in the 18th century, the industrial area was turned into a ghetto by the Nazis during World War II and then commercially orphaned in the postwar years. But now Podgorze is becoming Krakow's newest museum quarter. Spurred by the June opening of an ambitious history museum in the renovated Schindler Factory, the promise of a modern art museum next door and a theater-themed museum along the river, a number of colorful hangouts have cropped up in the unassuming waterfront area. But with more young students drinking coffee than tourists taking pictures, and just a handful of venues open after midnight, Podgorze still moves at Old World speed. RACHEL B. DOYLE
VALENTINE--Eric. We share with Christine the sorrow of her loss. From friends who love them

Most fashionistas progress directly from playing with dolls to sticking pins in them, but even the cattiest divas won't mess with Anna Wintour and Grace Coddington. To celebrate Fashion's Night Out on Sept. 10, Barneys New York commissioned the Brooklyn-based artist Andrew Yang to make these one-of-kind, hand-sewn, hand-painted rag-doll replicas of the celebrated Vogue editors. Strictly couture (bien sur!), the duo took two weeks to make. ''I had to special-order Anna's wig and cut it myself to get the bob right,'' Mr. Yang says. ''And Grace's hair was the right color, but it needed a perm.'' Alas, the question on everyone's lips - What are they wearing? - has a disappointingly democratic answer. ''The outfits are my own take on their signature looks,'' he says. ''It would have been unfair to single out specific designers.'' Anna and Grace will be auctioned off on charitybuzz.com beginning August 31, with the proceeds benefiting The New York City Aids Fund. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Last week, Sam Roberts wrote a front-page article in The Times detailing how the traditional immigrant gambit of changing one's name to something that sounds more ''American'' -- to help speed assimilation, avoid detection, deter discrimination or begin a business -- has all but disappeared. The practice began to decline within the past few decades, he wrote, ''and the evidence of its rarity, if not formally quantified, can be found in almost any American courthouse.'' About 200 readers commented on nytimes.com. Following are excerpts -- some readers signed their names, some did not.

JACOBSON--Gary, 63. We mourn the untimely passing of Gary Jacobson, beloved brother of Lorraine Podell and brother-in-law of Herbert S. Podell, cherished uncle to Pamela, Allison, Nicole and Brad. Gary was founder and President of Manhattan Tool Company. He was a renowned expert on antiquities, archaeology, pre-Columbian art and Mayan ruins. Gary was a master of the New York Times crossword puzzle always in record time and in pen. He will be sorely missed by all. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, Sunday 11:30am.

Havasu Canyon in Arizona, JULY 3, 2010 I took this photo of my husband, Robert, at the base of Havasu Canyon, an offshoot of the Grand Canyon. We spent three days in Havasu over the Fourth of July, camping and hiking with a small group of fellow adventurers and three wonderful guides. One of my favorite parts about our hikes was the water crossings. We wore mesh shoes and plodded through knee-deep water that cooled us from the bottom up, a welcome relief from the canyon's 105-degree heat. The water was the most amazing shade of turquoise blue. I love the contrast of the blue-green to the red rock walls of the canyon. Georgia Hunter Farinholt, Seattle

If I hadn't been feeling anxious about my daughter's departure to college - a whole year away - I'm beginning to now. Almost everywhere I turn, around town, on Facebook, even in the movie theater, I hear the sounds, read the words and see the faces of emotionally charged parents preparing for the big day - the college send-off.

On the Screen Brew York, New York is an unpretentious celebration of the 8,000 beers that Chris O'Leary estimates are available at the city's bars, restaurants and refrigerator cases and the central role that barley and hops occupy in New York culture. Mr. O'Leary, a self-proclaimed beer geek who brews in his East Village apartment, generally avoids the reviews and ''tasting notes'' common on other beer blogs. Instead, he posts suggestions of what to drink on a particular weekend or holiday, links to tidbits of beer-related news and shout-outs to local brewers, writing in a mellow tone with little attitude.

FORTUNOFF--Everett. Our heartfelt condolences to Isabel and the entire Fortunoff families on the passing of their beloved Everett. We will miss his warm smile, gentle style and elegance. Marilyn & Steve Lauren & Josh

Before he became a writer, Douglas Coupland (''Generation X,'' ''JPod'') studied art and design, so his current collaboration with the Canadian clothing company Roots is no surprise. Roots X Douglas Coupland, a collection of clothing, accessories and even furniture, stems from the Canadian writer's interest in the way that electronic media have connected the far-flung provinces of his homeland. Among other things, the collection's test-pattern logo is reproduced on hang tags and a T-shirt; a motherboard pattern adorns tights and a miniskirt; and tables (the Electric table, shown here, is $1,000) have legs inspired by Canada's ubiquitous electrical transmission towers. The Paris retail mecca Colette has picked up the limited-supply collection, which goes on sale there Sept. 7. It's also available at selected Roots stores in Canada, or at usa.roots.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Champion Against Cancer, Now Under Siege,'' Aug. 22: For those who question Lance Armstrong's integrity in spite of his being perhaps the most-tested athlete, perhaps the first question that should be asked is if one can accomplish his achievements without doping.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel finds a jazz concert, an art museum and other culture in Zacatecas, Mexico.

SCHWARTZ--Elayne G. August 26, 2010. Beloved mother of Dr. Penny J Schwartz, and Steven Schwartz and daughter-in-law Roberta. She is also survived by her three grandchildren: Louis, Jennifer and Matthew and her great-grandson, Jacob. Donations may be made to: The Columbia University School of Social Work, The Hunter College School of Social Work or the Department of Social Work Services at the Mount Sinai Medical Center.

FERRIGNO--Nicholas, 88 years old of Flushing, NY died August 27, 2010. Nick retired in 1980, after 39 years of service, from American Airlines as Senior Instructor in Maintenance at JFK and LGA. As one of the four DC10 experts for the airline, he opened all their routes in the Caribbean after the merger with "Transcarib". He was a member of the prestigious Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE). He taught for a few years at the College of Aeronautics at LGA. The saying among "the guys" at AA was that "perfection was not good enough for him." He was very popular among the three Diamond retirees, many of whose annual luncheons he arranged. He was Founding Vice President of Broadway-Flushing Homeowners' Association, Inc. in 1964 and served diligently in different offices as a member ever since. He is survived by his inseparable wife, Marjori, devoted brother, Charles and his wife Gloria, and several adoring nieces and nephews, and their children and grandchildren. The cause of death was complications from leukemia. Following cremation, interment will be at Flushing Cemetery. A brief Memorial will be planned with happy memories, as part of October Meeting of B.F.H.A., Inc., and part of the next AA Retirees' luncheon. The family gathering will be private.

Her children; Doris, David and Robert, their spouses, her grandchildren and her many friends, mourn her death as they celebrate her life. Funeral today, Sunday 1pm at Shalom Memorial Chapel, Smithtown, with Shiva at her home Sunday, 5-8, and Monday, 12-4. Donations to ORT.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Semenya Returns, and So Do Questions,'' Aug. 23: The Times made a curious decision to highlight the return of Caster Semenya as the most important track and field news of the day. The real news was that the men's 800-meter world record had fallen to David Rudisha.

CARUSO--Anthony S.,died of natural causes August 19 in Richmond, VA. He was 88. Born June 3, 1922 in Brooklyn, Dr. Caruso was a prominent dentist in the New York City area for 54 years. A resident of Brooklyn, then Scarsdale until 2004 when he moved to Virginia. Predeceased by his wife of 52 years, Eleanor M. Zimmerman. Survived by children, Dr. Anthony Caruso of Richmond, VA, Dr. Joseph Caruso of Manhattan, Karen DiGasbarro of St. Louis, MO, Janine Caruso of Watertown, MA, brothers Peter of La Jolla, CA, Alfred of Kansas City, KS, grandchildren Alex Caruso and Christina, Phillip and Diana DiGasbarro.

An elegant gentleman admired by all who knew him, loving father of Andrea Abramson, Robert and Andrea Fortunoff, cherished grandfather and great-grandfather of Jackie Cohen, Gregory, Lisa, Scott and Laurie Fortunoff, Jill and Darren Gerstenblatt, Emily, Caroline, Benjamin, Oliver, Aaron, Julia and the entire Lehrer family. Funeral service private.

John Stone does not want to hear your joke about his unicycle. He has heard all of them already. He doesn't want to hear you whistle ''Entry of the Gladiators,'' that circus song. He is not a clown. He's a commuter on his way to work just like you. He just rides a giant 36-inch wheeled unicycle from his home on the Upper West Side down to his job as a composer near Astor Place. ''Walking for me is a bit too slow - bicycling is a bit too fast,'' he said. ''It's hard to forget that you're doing something that to other people is a little weird. Sometimes you just want to be anonymous, you just want to ride.''
Pop Nate Chinen

An article on Aug. 15 about the Obama administration's secret counterterrorism operations overseas described incorrectly a recent strike in northern Africa that was cited as an example of coordination with allies. The strike in question, on July 22, was carried out by French and Mauritanian troops near the border between Mauritania and Mali; it was not a French strike in Algeria.

STEWART-GORDON--Thomas James, of Dallas, TX, died peacefully at home on August 19, 2010. Born in New York City on February 25, 1943 to James and Belle Burch Stewart-Gordon, Tom is survived by his wife, Patricia Ann (Test) Stewart-Gordon, his sister, Christina Bellinger, and many friends and family. Charitable gifts in memory of Tom may be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network at www.pancan.org or the animal rescue organization of your choice. A private memorial is planned.

Conference USA Anything less than a conference championship would be disappointing for Houston. The Cougars have their sights set even higher, with a high-powered offense capable of scoring a lot against any team in the country. Although Houston is the best team in the West division, do not be shocked if Tulsa or Southern Methodist threatens to win nine games in the regular season. S.M.U., against all odds, won eight games in 2009. June Jones must know what he's doing. The bottom of the West is extremely weak. Rice and Tulane may not combine for five victories. Texas-El Paso must get back to a bowl game to ease the pressure on Coach Mike Price. The East division is more competitive. East Carolina is the defending division champion, but the Pirates will be hard-pressed to repeat. Ruffin McNeill takes over for Skip Holtz as coach. Central Florida looks to be the team to beat, if it can find any offense. Southern Mississippi, on the other hand, has the offense but can't stop anyone. Coach Doc Holliday replaces Mark Snyder at Marshall. The Thundering Herd could find itself bowl eligible, but U.C.F. is more consistent. It is worth noting that Central Florida Coach George O'Leary is nine games under .500 for his career in even-numbered years, 21 games over .500 in odd-numbered years.

An article last Sunday about the history of Building 1 on Treasure Island in San Francisco misstated where Adm. Chester Nimitz conducted the war in the Pacific. He ran the war from Hawaii, not from the basement theater of Building 1.

An entry on the ''On the Market'' page on Aug. 8, for a Victorian house at 305 Upper Mountain Road in Montclair, described the condition of the third-floor bathroom incorrectly. It is not in need of updating; it has in fact been recently renovated.

KNAPP--Bettina Liebowitz, died August 27, 2010 at the age of 84, one day short of her 61st wedding anniversary to her beloved husband Russell who survives her. She was the Thomas Hunter Professor at Hunter College, a respected member of the faculty of the Romance Language Department and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. A prolific author, recipient of numerous academic and scholarly awards, her true memorial is the hundreds of students whose lives she touched and guided. She will be missed by many, but most of all by her husband, her two sons, Albert and Charles, her daughter-in-law Susan and her two granddaughters, Emily and Caroline. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center at Columbia University Medical Center, 1150 St. Nicholas Avenue, New York, NY 10032.

Ines de la Fressange is the kind of woman who gets what she wants. And, as the brand ambassador for the shoe designs of Roger Vivier, de la Fressange wanted a sultry signature fragrance - or five, to be exact. ''Our goal was a perfume with personality, style and quality, not just a huge launch with lots of ads,'' she says, ''so we used very precious and rare ingredients, just like a couture collection.'' She worked closely with the nose Rami Mekdachi, and the resulting scents - L'Iris, Le Neroli, La Rose, Le Santal and L'Ambre - are heady but not aggressive. Les Parfums Roger Vivier ($195 a bottle) will make their debut at Fashion's Night Out on Sept. 10 at the New York boutique (750 Madison Avenue), and they will be available at all Roger Vivier boutiques in October. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DILL--Robert (Bob, Rod) Jr.,Air Force veteran, long time member of the New York Stock Exchange and a man defined by his passion for life and devotion to his wife Susan and daughters, Lauren Georgelos and Katie Dill, died on August 21 in Savannah, Georgia. He was 69. He was born to Robert and Charlotte Dill in Long Island and attended Hobart College. He married Susan McNulty in 1974. Their life together carried them to Westchester, NY, The Adirondacks, and Savannah. Rod was a sincere friend whose unsurpassed charm, wit and integrity will be sorely missed. His legacy of honor and strength will persist, and he will forever be admired and remembered by those who had the good fortune to know him well.

An answer in the Q&A column on Aug. 15 about an overnight trip to York and Durham in England misstated the room rate for the Alexander House in York; rates are £42.50 per person in a double, not simply £42.50 for a double. The answer also referred incorrectly to York Minster's great east window, the largest sheet of medieval stained glass in the world. The window is now covered while it undergoes a restoration, so it cannot in fact be viewed at this time. A second answer in the column, about Balboa Island in Orange County in California, misstated the length of time a ferry from Balboa Peninsula to the island takes; it is about 4 minutes, not 30.

SKLAR--Dr. Barrett D.,75, a lifelong physician and avid fisherman, died after a four year battle with multiple myeloma. Born in Newark, NJ, he started his successful medical career delivering babies and making house calls in Hicksville, LI. Most recently, he served as Chief of Family Medicine at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, NY. Barry is survived by his wife of 49 years, Marjorie; brother, Jay; two sons; and six grandchildren.

He is also survived by three grandnephews. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St., NYC on Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10:30am at Immaculate Conception RC Church, 754 Gun Hill Road, Bronx, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

Those who so choose may donate to the Tuttle Fund, 1155 Park Ave., New York City, 10128, in his memory. A service will be scheduled.

Because of an editing error, the cover article on Aug. 15 about the Greenbrier in West Virginia misstated the telephone number for the resort. It is (800) 453-4858. DAVIS--Roberta, 69, retired after a distinguished career as a high school teacher in Greenwich, CT, dearest wife of Gerard, mother of Sima and her husband, Chip Farmer, and devoted grandmother of Lily, Henry, Anna, and Olivia. She will always be in our hearts.

Richemont has made it official: Geoffroy de la Bourdonnaye is the new chief executive at Chloe, replacing Ralph Toledano. In a statement today, Richemont's head of fashion and accessories, Marty Wikstrom, cited Mr. de la Bourdonnaye's brand and management experience, notably at Liberty, where he was chief executive. He has also worked at LVMH, Disney and L'Oreal.

BENJAMIN--Robert, of New Rochelle, NY, 91, died peacefully on August 27, from complications after a fall while working on his garden. Veteran of WWII, he served as an Officer with the 5th Air Force in the Pacific and Japan. Beloved husband and best friend of Betty, devoted father of John and Richard, and proud grandfather of Scott. ''Why isn't the government getting tough with banks?'' - Judge Emmet G. Sullivan of Federal District Court. He scolded federal prosecutors, saying that a settlement he grudgingly approved with Barclays over accusations of illegal financial activities was too lenient. ''It's very problematic that losses like this are showing up.'' - Janet Tavakoli, who runs a finance consulting firm, on banks' continuing ability to make risky bets on behalf of clients. (Financial overhaul legislation applies to their own money.) JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs each lost more than $100 million on transactions handled for customers from April to July.
PITA--Edward G. Three Arrows Cooperative mourns the loss of lifelong social activist who served in WWII against the rise of fascism. Ed is survived by his loving wife Dorothy and family.

Mercedes-Benz, as part of its collaboration with Tesla Motors, will produce 500 battery-powered ''E-Cell'' versions of its small A-Class, introducing the car at the Paris auto show in October. According to Shirin Emeera, a Daimler spokeswoman, details of the electric car will be announced on Sept. 15. She said the car would be produced at the Mercedes Rastatt plant, near Stuttgart, Germany, where the A-Class (which is not sold in the United States) is produced. Delivery of the cars will begin early next year.

GAINESVILLE, Fla. - By now, the story of Urban Meyer's return to the Florida's sideline has become familiar. He stepped down, went to practice the next day and became inspired to come back after watching his team. But it did not unfold exactly that way. Interviews last month revealed that the turning point in Meyer's return was a fiery, mostly one-sided conversation with the strength coach Mickey Marotti during that morning's practice.

An article last Sunday about parents' decisions on delaying kindergarten enrollment misidentified the book by Malcolm Gladwell that included a study of young Canadian hockey players that found the strongest players were the oldest. It is ''Outliers,'' not ''The Tipping Point.''

ARLEDGE--Gisele "Gigi", beloved wife of Roone Arledge and mother of Catherine Shaw died on August 25, 2010, at 58 from complications of pancreatic cancer. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. In her honor and to help find a cure for pancreatic cancer, the Gigi Arledge Private Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research is being established. In lieu of flowers or gifts, a donation to the foundation would be appreciated. Please send contributions to: 778 Park Avenue, Apt 15, New York, NY 10021.

Mike Tanier, a contributing editor at FootballOutsiders.com, will write a weekly notebook during the preseason. Roster cuts are imminent, and fringe players are learning that college success means little in the N.F.L. Catching 350 passes for Directional State will not land you a bottom-of-the-roster spot: you have to play special teams or fill some other niche to avoid the Turk. (That is the coach who summons cut players, not Virgil Sollozzo or a chess-playing robot.)

The fashionable W Hotel brand is expanding its fashion offerings: the boutique chain has commissioned 15 designers to create its third Global Glam winter-resort collection, which will be introduced at New York Fashion Week at Lincoln Center next month and will be available to travelers and shoppers alike at W Hotels the Store locations and online in October. The designers - including Behnaz Sarafpour, Lulu Frost, Christys of London, Kara Ross and Saga Furs - were charged with drawing from the concept behind new or coming W Hotels. They were given swatches and other materials from the interior designers and architects behind the W London, Leicester Square; W St. Petersburg; and W Retreat & Spa, Vieques, among others.
