Problems, problems, problems. I've been mulling over some thorny issues this week. They aren't really related to each other, but I'm going to need to make decisions on each of these soon. As always, your comments and suggestions are greatly appreciated. So here they are:

An article on Wednesday about internal dissent and staff losses at the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission gave an incorrect first initial for the commission's first executive director in some editions. He is J. -- not B. -- Thomas Greene.

GREENE--Dawn. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our great friend and benefactor, Dawn M. Greene. We are deeply grateful for her visionary support of our Division of Cardiology; and with her late husband, Jerome L. Greene, and through the Jerome L. Greene Foundation, she established an enduring legacy across our campus, at the College of Physicians and Surgeons and the Mailman School of Public Health. We were fortunate to be among the many beneficiaries of Mrs. Greene's generosity, and all of us in the Columbia community extend our condolences to her family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University

Reading about it online, you would think that the controversy over this year's assigned reading for students new to Brooklyn College would have led to fevered student and faculty protests by now, making the campus the latest to be roiled by the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But so far at least, the furor over the book -- ''How Does It Feel to Be a Problem? Being Young and Arab in America,'' by Moustafa Bayoumi, an associate English professor at Brooklyn College - is unfolding a bit like the debate over the planned Islamic community center in downtown Manhattan: much of the intensity seems far afield, while the response in the neighborhood itself is more muted.
GREENE--Dawn. The Cronson family mourns the passing of their friend Dawn Greene and extends their heartfelt sympathy to her family.

VAN de WATER DOCK--Marian. In Essex, Connecticut: August 30, 2010, Marian Van De Water Dock a noted Connecticut artist, and art educator. Graduate of Pratt Institute, New York University and Columbia University with a Masters in Art, she held the following positions with in the New York City Board of Education, teacher, art supervisor of elementary and junior high levels along with curriculum writing for grades K-9, and the Assistant Director of Art for the entire New York City School system. She was the first art educator to become the TV producer, writer, program director, and instructor of the changing small groups of New York City school children on "Time For Art with Marian Dock" a half hour weekly TV show that was viewed by selected classes for the promotion of art activities as recommend by the art curriculum of the Bureau of Art of the New York Public Schools. Born and resided in Brooklyn she moved to Essex in 1970 with her husband, the late Commander Albert F. Dock, USNR. Throughout her career she explored many areas of arts and crafts from traditional to the abstract, in media ranging from oils, acrylic, watercolor, lithograph, to print-makeup and collage. Throughout her retirement she exhibited her original art annually in Essex and throughout Connecticut.

SEOGWIPO, South Korea -- Here on Jeju Island, famous for its tangerine groves, pearly beaches and honeymoon resorts, South Korea is conducting a bold educational experiment, one intended to bolster opportunity at home and attract investment from abroad. By 2015, if all goes according to plan, 12 prestigious Western schools will have opened branch campuses in a government-financed, 940-acre Jeju Global Education City, a self-contained community within Seogwipo, where everyone -- students, teachers, administrators, doctors, store clerks -- will speak only English. The first school, North London Collegiate, broke ground for its campus this month.

PINCUS--Pearl, age 93, died peacefully at home with family at her side. Beloved and loving wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and dear friend. A graduate of Brooklyn College, class of 1937, Pearl worked part time for many years as a substitute middle school English teacher. She was intelligent and wise, elegant and charming, caring and loving and beautiful and stylish and she meant so much to her family and friends. Though she had been ill this last year, she still enjoyed time with her family and friends, good conversation, dining out (she had a small party at her favorite steakhouse for her 93rd birthday in June), shopping outings (she could always find something at Marshalls) and being with her 98 year old boyfriend, Bill Horn, a most devoted and wonderful man. Pearl's proudest achievement and greatest joy, however, was her family. She is predeceased by her dearly beloved husband Morris and is survived by her loving children, Cynthia and Jerry Rothstein and Jerry and Janet Pincus, her adored grandchildren, Michael, Lori and Dan, Meryl, Lauren and Jon, Melanie and her cherished and adorable great-grandson Gilles. She was loved dearly and will be greatly missed. Funeral will be held Thursday 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

BROOKER--Jeffrey. The Chairman of Webb and Brooker Real Estate Inc., and staff announce with sorrow the untimely death of its President, Jeffrey (Jeff) Brooker on August 27, 2010 at New York Presbyterian Hospital, New York, NY. Jeff, a graduate from Dartmouth College, received his academic real estate training at the Real Estate Institute of New York University and began his professional career in real estate as an assistant manager and manager of leasing at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. At the time of his death, Mr. Brooker served as President and senior operating office of the forty-two year old real estate company of which his late father was one of the three founders. A member of the Real Estate Board and former governor, at the time of his death, Mr. Brooker served on the Boards of the Council of the Environment of New York City, the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, Weston United For Community Renewal, the 125th Street BID District and the Harlem Business Alliance. Predeceased by his parents, Mr. Brooker leaves as immediate family his brother, George M. Brooker, sister-in-law C. Jill, and two nephews Lance and Asa. A memorial service will be announced later by the family. Eugene H. Webb, Chairman

I really have only one indulgence. I bought an expensive convertible a few years ago. It is not a midlife crisis car; I would call it a midlife celebration car. It is not red. It was a prerecession purchase. In any case, I was driving to work one recent morning, sitting at a stoplight when a car pulled up next to me and the young man behind the wheel rolled down his window. He shouted over, ''How can I be successful like you?''

KOFF--Gail. The Committee of 200 mourns the loss of extraordinary founding member Gail Koff. Gail, a founding partner of Jacoby & Meyers, was a pioneering lawyer and businesswoman. We greatly admire her significant career achievements and we honor her integrity, grace and fortitude. Gail was a shining star who represented the best of our organization. The loss of Gail is felt deeply by all of us and she will forever be in our hearts. We share our heartfelt condolences with Gail's beautiful children Micah, Loren and Wade Brill, and with her brothers Michael, Peter and Larry Koff.

BARASCH--Clarence. To soar with the eagles, you must fly like an eagle. Dearest Uncle Clarence, you soar. We will miss you so. Nancy, Murphy, Timothy, Michael, Samantha, Duncan, Isabelle, Kelly and Jon

You can't ignore the pirates anymore. They're getting more and more muscle. They used to invest their money in just boats and going out to sea but now they're building up their military side. MOHAMED ADEN, a clan leader in central Somalia. [A10]

BARASCH--Clarence S. On Tuesday my friend, Clarence S. Barasch died. He was a man of great wisdom and understanding. I shall never forget sitting in his office as he framed the issues and discussed the law. He truly was a great lawyer, advisor and friend. Clarence was a very learned and thoughtful person. I shall miss him terribly. My deepest sympathy to the family. Charles R. Borrok

TOWNSEND--Charles Cooper, Jr. died at home on August 27, 2010 after a long illness. He was the beloved husband of Daphne A. Townsend, who survives him. Born in 1927 in Bryn Mawr, PA. He was predeceased by his parents, Charles C. Townsend and Ethel H. Townsend and by his wives, Ann T. Frothingham and Mary Elizabeth Carr. Also surviving him; his sister, Barbara Crawford, his brother-in-law, Alan, his children by his first wife, Charles C. Townsend, III and Elinor T. Mahony, four grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Mr. Townsend attended Episcopal Academy, Overbrook, Pennsylvania, and graduated from The Pomfret School. He received his BSEE from Princeton University, summa cum laude, Class of 1949, where he was a member of the Ivy Club. He was a Baker Scholar at Harvard Business School, Class of 1956. He served in the 82nd Airborne Division of the United States Army, stationed in Italy, and was honorably discharged in 1948. He was employed at The Atlantic Refining Company, Philadelphia, PA and Seatrain Lines, New York. In 1978, he retired from partnership at Morgan Stanley & Co. to farm and raise polled Hereford cattle at Raynham Farms, in Hopewell, NJ. Mr. Townsend served on the boards of The Bunbury Company, W. P. Carey & Co., Collier Enterprises, The Evergreens, Stockton State College, Stony Brook-Millstone Watershed Association, Trinity Counseling Service, University Medical Center at Princeton, and The Windham Foundation. He loved the out-of-doors and was an avid fly-fisherman. He was a member of The Bedens Brook Club, Harvard Club of New York, Nassau Club, Pohoqualine Fish Association, and a former member of the Tobique Salmon Club. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, September 14th at 11:00am at Trinity Episcopal Church, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Princeton Healthcare System Foundation, 253 Witherspoon Street, Princeton, NJ, 08540.

KOFF--Gail. August 31st. Devoted mother of Micah, Loren and Wade Brill and beloved sister of Michael, Peter and Larry Koff. Gail inspired her family and many friends with her amazing strength, beauty, and love of life. She was a founding partner of Jacoby & Meyers and an active contributor to women's business associations and to organizations such as The Bank Street School for Children and Africare. We mourn her passing; she will remain in our hearts forever. The family will be receiving visitors from 1-8pm on Wednesday and Thursday, September 1st and 2nd, at home, 111 Central Park North. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be sent In Memory of Gail Koff to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016 or to The Bank Street School for Children, 610 West 112th Street, New York, NY 10025.

FISHER--Caroline Speer, of Cambridge, MA, died Saturday morning, August 28, at Martha's Vineyard Hospital, in Oak Bluffs, MA. Born August 10, 1922 in Wilkes-Barre, PA, she was the first of three daughters of Charlotte Rose Welles Speer and the Rev. Elliott Speer. She lived as a girl in Northfield, MA, where her father served as Headmaster of the Mount Hermon School for Boys, until his death in 1934. She graduated from Vassar College in 1944, attended Union Theological Seminary, NYC, 1944-45, where she served as a research assistant to theologian Paul Tillich. She taught at the Spence School 1945-46 and served as Director of Religious Education at St. James Church 1947-48. She married Roger Dummer Fisher in 1948 and they lived in Paris in 1948-49, while he worked for the Marshall Plan. They returned to live in McLean, VA for nine years, where she worked at the Madeira School. In 1958, they moved to Cambridge when her husband joined the faculty of Harvard Law School. She is survived by her husband of sixty-one years, Roger Fisher, Emeritus Professor of Law Harvard University, her sister Margot Goudsmit of Norwich, VT, her son Elliott Speer Fisher of Norwich, VT, her son Peter R. Fisher of Maplewood, NJ, and five grandchildren: Allegra, Kate and Josie, of Norwich VT, and Duncan and Charlotte, of Maplewood, NJ. A memorial service will be held on October 2, at 2 pm at St. Barnabas' Episcopal Church, Main Street, Norwich VT. In lieu of flowers or gifts, donations can be made to the Martha's Vineyard Hospital Annual Fund, c/o MV Hospital Development Office, P.O. Box 1477, Oak Bluffs, MA 02557, noting "In Memory of Caroline S. Fisher".

KOFF--Gail. The Women's Forum of New York records with sorrow the death of our colleague Gail Koff, Esq., a pioneer in making legal services available to the general public. Deepest sympathy is extended to her children Loren, Wade and Micah. Janice Reals Ellig, President Women's Forum, Inc.

KOFF--Gail, a client and friend for whom I cared deeply. An inspiration with never-ending strength, vision and positive spirit, she dedicated her life to righting the world by making high-quality legal services available to all. She will be truly missed. Jeff Fromm, Dorsey & Whitney LLP

WIEDERHORN--Hortense Gross 1918-2010. She leaves her dearly loved children Toni, Eric and Hilary, her cherished grandchildren Lauren, Lesley, Dayna, Mindy, Scott and Jason, her great-grandchildren Adam, Jacob, Nathaniel, Benjamin and Hannah. She was young at heart and had many magical days but also some very hard times. She faced life bravely, with humor and a song in her heart. We will all miss her. Service Thursday 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

GREENE--Dawn. The Board and Staff of New York Public Radio mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Dawn Greene. Her visionary leadership enabled the building of our state of the art Jerome L. Greene Performance Space and helped preserve WQXR Classical Music on the radio for all New Yorkers. Dawn believed that philanthropy can be transformative and relished the power of the big idea. We will miss her charm, her wit, and her creative spirit, which have helped to make our dreams become reality. We celebrate her and Jerry's tremendous contributions in the arts, sciences, education, and health. We extend our deepest condolences to her daughter, Christina McInerny, and her extended family and friends. Herb Scannell, Chair Laura Walker, President/CEO New York Public Radio

GREENE--Dawn. The Juilliard community mourns the death of Dawn Greene. Along with her husband, Jerome L. Greene, and through the foundation bearing his name, Dawn had a major impact on scholarship programs at Juilliard. The first scholarships ever created for students in all three divisions of the School-dance, drama, and music-occurred through the generosity of Dawn and Jerry. We extend our deepest condolences to Dawn's daughter, Christina, her grand-daughter, Maggie, and her step-daughter, Patricia. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

KOFF--Gail. The entire Bank Street community is deeply saddened by the sudden and tragic loss of Gail Koff, a dedicated trustee and our general counsel for two decades, and a passionate advocate for the College for far longer. To her children Micah, Loren and Wade all of whom are graduates of the Bank Street School for Children and to her family, we express our condolences and profound grief. Gail often referred to "the Bank Street magic" that touched everyone who enters the College's doors. Gail was a vital part of that magic, helping in so many ways to make the College what it is. While we will be diminished by her absence, we were enriched by her devotion and will always be inspired by her example. Anthony K. Asnes, Chair, Board of Trustees Elizabeth D. Dickey, President

GREENE--Dawn. The President and the Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore family mourn the loss of Dawn Greene, a wonderful supporter of Montefiore. Dawn and her late husband Jerome L. Greene shared a strong commitment to the Bronx and particularly to the health and well-being of the children of the Borough. Through Dawn's leadership of the Jerome L. Greene Foundation, The Children's Hospital at Montefiore was able to establish a new Pediatric Hematology-Oncology Program bringing state-of-the-art specialized cancer care to the community. We are very grateful for Dawn and Jerry's long standing support which has enabled Montefiore to further its mission of advancing the health of the communities it serves. Our deepest and heartfelt condolences are extended to Dawn's daughter Christina McInerney and her entire family. Steven M. Safyer, MD, President and CEO David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees, Montefiore Medical Center

McBRIEN--Kathleen "Katie," of Bronxville on August 30, 2010. Beloved wife of Joseph J. McBrien. Loving mother of Jennifer (Stephen) Dunn, Tim (Rose), James and Molly McBrien. Devoted Grandmother of Shannon, Ciara, Jack and Declan. Daughter of Helen and the late Frederic Leon Forrest. Sister of Daniel and John Forrest. Words cannot express our deep sorrow, she will be engrained forever in our hearts. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 6-9pm Wednesday and 4-8pm Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronx-ville on Friday, September 3, 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, office of Planned Giving Bronx, NY 10458 www.NYBG.ORG or the American Heart Association.

MAHER--John T.,of New Hyde Park, NY on August 27, 2010. Loving son of the late John and Veronica. Beloved brother of the late Maureen. Graduate of Sullivan County Community College and C.W. Post. Dedicated employee of AT&T for over 30 years. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30 at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:15am at Notre Dame R.C. Church. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

The cleanup of the Hudson River by the General Electric Company -- dredging industrial pollutants that have been poisoning the river for 60 years -- finally started last year. That is the good news. The bad news is that the project turned out to be full of unexpected problems. This does not mean that the dredging of buried polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, should be abandoned. It does mean that changes need to be made in the way the company and the Environmental Protection Agency, which is overseeing the project, tackle the second and much larger phase, scheduled to begin in May.
International IN MEMOIRS, BLAIR

METTLER--Cornelia Daley, 69, of New York, NY, Fishers Island, NY and Jupiter Island, FL, died peacefully at home on August 28th. Born in Boston, MA to Charles and Catherine Daley, she was a graduate of the Winsor School and Briarcliff College. An avid bridge player and accomplished decorative painter, she was a long-serving board member of the Isabel O'Neil Foundation. She is survived by her husband, John W. Mettler; daughters Melinda Mettler and Catherine Carlson; and granddaughter Alden Carlson, all of New York, NY. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 9 at 11am at St. James Church, 71st and Madison Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name to the Isabel O'Neil Foundation, 315 East 91st St., NYC 10128 or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, NYC 10087.

Seagate has pulled off a remarkable feat: The company has integrated remote access to files stored on its new GoFlex Home Network Storage System so thoroughly and intelligently that it requires no setup. In fact, when testing the GoFlex Home network-attached storage (N.A.S.) drive, I called Seagate for technical support because I couldn't figure out how to set up remote access. I was never prompted to set up a dynamic DNS account, as other NAS drives do, and figured something was amiss.

GREENE--Dawn M. President and CEO of the Jerome L. Greene Foundation, died at home in her apartment at the Carlyle Hotel on August 30, 2010. A native New Yorker born April 8, 1922, she was 88 years old. The cause of death was congestive heart failure. Mrs. Greene, an avid theatergoer and arts patron, continued a long tradition of philanthropy in education, arts, and medicine begun by Jerome L. Greene, her late husband, who created endowed scholarships at the Juilliard School and at Columbia Law School and was a benefactor of Channel 13, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the Jewish Museum, the Mostly Mozart Festival, and Montefiore Medical Center (The Jerome L. and Dawn Greene Medical Arts Pavilion and Children's Hospital). Mrs. Greene continued her late husband's legacy with continued support of these outstanding institutions and took new exciting initiatives in his name in support of the American Cancer Society (Hope Lodge), Calvary, WNYC, WQXR, and the Yale School of Drama. She made the lead grant of $250 million in support of the Jerome L. Greene Science Center at Columbia University, which will be the first building by Renzo Piano on the new Manhattanville campus. Mrs. Greene, a graduate of Fordham University in sociology with a Masters in Social Work, completed clinical counseling work at the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health. She served on the boards of Planned Parenthood of New York City and Inwood House and received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Columbia University in 2008. She is survived by her daughter, Christina McInerney, and her granddaughter, Margaret Williams.

An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about government stimulus spending, incorrectly rendered the name of an organization that identified needed investments in public infrastructure in the United States. It is the American Society of Civil Engineers, not the American Society of Engineers.

In her first year of operation, Fran Gunsaulis, founder of Oh Baby Foods, learned that her business plan overlooked the logistical -- and costly -- realities of producing and distributing her organic, locally sourced baby foods. Her products are sustainable, but at a $5.80 cost per unit -- down from $8.01 in 2009 -- her business isn't. The Challenge: There is only so much Sweet Potato Boogie and Bean Me Up, Baby that one woman (with some part-time kitchen help) can make, sell and distribute. Oh Baby, which is based in Fayetteville, Ark., must increase production to realize the economies of scale that will allow it to become profitable.

HERMAN--Simon, 97, husband of Yvette, his co-adventurer, co-everything, for 72 years, and father of Robbie (Bob) and Steve (Cindy and son Jonathan). He made a swift and painless exit August 28, less than two weeks into his last act -- a cross-country move with Yvette to La Jolla, CA, to be with their children. A joyous, authentic Renaissance man, Herman was passionate about politics, great books, great art, great music...and the Yankees. As curious about people as about ideas and a tireless listener, he made you feel you were the most interesting person in the world. Herman was born in Union City, NJ, where he started out as a teacher and harnessed his radical commitment to fairness to form the district's first teachers' union; he retired as Assistant Superintendent of Schools, an inspiring leader who initiated lasting, innovative programs. He also owned and directed Camp Idylwold in Schroon Lake, NY, which was to become his beloved home base: he and Yvette tended and expanded the 1840s Bullet Pond farmhouse they bought in 1965; they remain honored senior residents of the town (as they do of Parliament House in Pompano Beach, FL, where they made their winter home). A President of the Schroon Lake Association for eleven years, Herman was devoted to keeping the lake pure for future generations. He was "best father in the world" to his daughter and very best friend to his son, both of whom grew up in Teaneck, NJ, except during the family sabbatical year in Paris and Rome that set the stage for Herman's next career, operating student tours, and for four decades of traveling the world. Herman lived long enough to experience in life the tributes accorded most of us only in eulogy tributes from his adoring extended family, his friends, and the generations of young people he mentored. Pre-deceased by siblings Morris and Lillian, he is survived by his brother Raymond and by nieces Tasha, Lisa, Melissa, Brooke, Mickey Rae, Renee, Cory and Vera, and by nephew Daniel. Herman will be remembered, as he was loved, for his enthusiastic unbounded spirit. We will cherish his legacy. Contributions in his memory will be welcomed by the Schroon Lake Association or the Seagle Music Colony, both of Schroon Lake, NY, 12870.

KOFF--Gail. The Calhoun School community mourns the passing of our friend and Trustee Gail Koff. We extend our deepest condolences to Gail's family members, particularly her daughter Wade Brill, a member of Calhoun's class of 2007. Gail's gentle wisdom and infectious good humor touched everyone in her presence. Her remarkable courage, modesty, dignity and the ever-present twinkle in her eye will remain with us always. Our school is a better place because of Wade and Gail. We cherish that legacy. Eric Potoker, Chair Steve Nelson, Head of School on behalf of the Trustees, faculty, staff and families of the Calhoun School

KRAMER--Selma Vera, 100. Of Bal Harbour, FL, passed away peacefully on August 31 in Miami. Born and raised in Paterson, NJ, she was a graduate of Barnard College. She was the Honorary President of the Women's Auxiliary at Paterson's Barnert Memorial Hospital and was active in Miami's Mount Sinai Medical Center, where she was a member of the Society of Mount Sinai, a Board Member of the Wien Center and a member of The Cancer Lifeline. Mrs. Kramer also served on the Fine Arts Committee of Fairleigh Dickenson University and served as a Chairperson of both the Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal and Israel Bonds. She was on the National Board of several groups, including the United Jewish Appeal, the Federation of Temple Sisterhoods and the Jewish Welfare Board and she was one of the Founders of the Women's National Division of the Jewish Federation. Mrs. Kramer was a life member of Hadassah, the National Council of Jewish Women and the Daughters of Miriam Home for the Aged in Clifton, NJ. Among others, Testimonials in her honor were given by the United Jewish Appeal, Israel Bonds and the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She is survived by her devoted son, Paul, four grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Raymond and her daughter Elizabeth. Her compassion, vitality and wit will be missed by all who knew her. Donations may be made to the Veritans Club for Underprivileged Children of Hawthorne NJ.

BARASCH--Clarence. You were the "BEST". The man who wrote the book on real estate brokerage law. We enjoyed our 40 year relationship. Your guidance and mentoring will never be forgotten. We will miss you. Deepest feelings of sympathy to Lionel and the entire Barasch family. The Lansco Corporation

BlackBerry lovers are a loyal bunch, but even the most rabid must have watched with envy these last few years as new features for iPhones and Androids were paraded out. The new BlackBerry Torch 9800 may inspire a little envy of its own. It is the first BlackBerry with a true touch screen and the first with a slide-out keyboard. New features bring it much more in line with the rest of the market.

An obituary on Tuesday about the chemist Jacob Bigeleisen, who worked on the development of the atomic bomb, referred incorrectly to the method used by the United States during World War II to separate uranium-235 from uranium-238 for atomic bombs. It was gaseous diffusion; centrifuges were not used to separate the uranium.
BARASCH--Clarence. We mourn the loss of Uncle Clarence, an extraordinary man. Betty Cohen and family

GREENE--Dawn. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Dawn Greene. Inveterate theater-goer, devotee of Shakespeare's plays and Shakespearean actors, she almost always regarded Lincoln Center Theater productions and was kindly critical when so moved. We will miss both her encouragement and support and send condolences to her daughter Christina McInerney and her granddaughter Margaret Williams. Lincoln Center Theater J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer

STUART--Janice E. (Berkley), born October 7, 1918 in Philadelphia passed away on September 1st, leaving behind her brothers William and Edward Lifson of Short Hills, NJ, sons Paul, William and Harry Berkley, their wives, step-son Paul Kopel and his wife, twelve grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husbands, Paul Berkley, Henry Kopel and Harold Stuart. Janice grew up in Elizabeth, New Jersey and was of late a resident of Delray Beach, Florida and Greenwich, Connecticut. A graduate of Julia Richmond High School in New York City and Smith College, she was the last surviving member of the 1935 Maccabiah Games team. A national award winning swimmer and diver in her youth, the last fifty years of her life Janice worked as an insurance agent. She will be missed by friends and family. Services will be private. Those wishing to call on the family are welcome at 150 Doubling Road in Greenwich from 3pm to 8pm on Thursday, September 2nd at 23 Eugene Drive, Montville, New Jersey on Friday September 3rd from 2pm to 6pm. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to support Juvenile Diabetes research in Janice's memory.

An article on Monday about the history of the relationship between Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York and Adam Clayton Powell IV, his most vocal opponent in the Sept. 14 Democratic primary, misstated the economic status of Mr. Powell's father. He came from middle to upper middle class roots -- not from working class -- the younger Mr. Powell confirmed.

BARASCH--Clarence S. May 20, 1912-August 31, 2010. In his 99th year. Graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School. Member of the New York Bar since 1935. World War II veteran stationed at Bletchley Park, U.K. Commended by Her Majesty's Government in 2010. Lecturer, an author of the Law of Real Estate Brokers and frequent contributor to the New York Law Journal. Patriarch of the extended Barasch family. Survived by this sons Lionel and Jonathan and his daughters-in-law, Lili and Lisa, and by grandchildren Nicholas, Kimberly, Julia and Francesca and many nieces, nephews, and grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Funeral services at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th St., 11am, Thursday, September 2, 2010.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about a demand by lawyers for the estate of Lehman Brothers Holdings for documents from several prominent hedge funds and Goldman Sachs reversed the identifications for two of the men shown. Daniel Och of Och-Ziff Capital Management was second from the left, and Steven A. Cohen of SAC Capital was third from the left.

It's sign time. A restaurant needs a sign. The one I have in mind will have black lower-case letters painted on a piece of Philippine mahogany with a little light above it. It will stand in front of the building, in the garden, two-sided so you can see it when traveling north or south. Maybe it should be a black sign with white letters. We'll see. It will say Southfork Kitchen. That's the name of the restaurant. But first, a permit is needed. Southampton is very touchy about its signs -- shape, location, luminosity and content. When you attend enough planning board meetings, you get to hear the debates about sundry signage. One of my favorites involved a holistic veterinarian who wanted to use a bird on his sign. Members of the board wondered aloud if the proposed bird was an egret or a heron. That it looked like a stork, said one board member, might confuse the citizenry into thinking the doctor was an obstetrician, not a veterinarian. But a heron is a stork, argued a more ornithologically minded board member.

8 P.M. (Sundance) THE STORY The Sundance Channel celebrates the new academic year with ''Back to School Fest,'' to be kicked off by this original production from Maurice Marable, which ventures inside the South Bronx classrooms of the Ghetto Film School, a nonprofit organization that offers mentors and college scholarships to aspiring filmmakers, and where 20 teenagers will compete to travel to Uganda to make a film. ''The Story'' is followed by three coming-of-age tales: ''One Last Thing ...'' (2005), at 9:30, Alex Steyermark's bittersweet comedy about a 16-year-old (Michael Angarano, above) dying of cancer who makes a wish to spend a weekend with a surly, alcoholic supermodel (Sunny Mabrey). Cynthia Nixon also stars. In Natasha Arthy's ''Fighter'' (2007), at 11:15, the rebellious daughter (Semra Turan) of Turkish Muslims chooses kung-fu class over medical school. Ms. Turan, a kung fu champion, performs many of the film's action sequences, which were choreographed by Xian Gao, a martial arts trainer and actor on ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.'' The evening closes with ''Quinceañera'' (2006), at 1 a.m., Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland's drama about a 14-year-old Mexican-American (Emily Rios) from Echo Park in Los Angeles, whose life is thrown into turmoil when she learns she is pregnant, even though she is technically a virgin.

GREENE--Dawn M. Dean David M. Schizer and the entire Columbia Law School family are deeply saddened by the loss of Dawn M. Greene, a great humanitarian, devoted friend, and dedicated benefactor to generations of Columbia Law School students and faculty. Dawn and her late husband, Jerome L. Greene, a distinguished member of the Class of 1928, were towering figures in the history of Columbia Law School. To honor their generosity, the Law School named its flagship building -- the hub of its intellectual life -- Jerome Greene Hall. As president and CEO of the Jerome L. Greene Foundation, Dawn provided visionary leadership that further transformed Greene Hall into an international nexus for legal scholarship and pedagogy. Her gifts supported significant enhancements to our classrooms, faculty offices, and community spaces. In addition, Dawn made an indelible impact on our campus community. She established the Jerome L. Greene Professorship in Transactional Law, as well as the Greene scholarships, which have provided financial aid to more than 25 students each year since 1994. She also generously supported innovations in the Law School's clinical legal education program. We celebrate the life of a remarkable woman as we mourn the loss of our dear friend. We will remember fondly Dawn's generosity of spirit, her integrity, and her enduring devotion to Columbia Law School. Our hearts go out to her daughter, Chris; her granddaughter, Maggie; and to her family, friends, and colleagues.

TURITZ--Philip. We mourn the passing of Philip Turitz on August, 29, 2010 so few days before his 87th birthday, beloved husband of Arlynne for almost 63 years, adored father of Daniel and wife Hillary, and Bethanie and her husband Giancarlo Alhadeff. He was loved by his grandchildren David Alhadeff and his fiancee Tara Bagherzade, and Allison, Andrea and Alexa. He will be with us always, and remembered for the love and strength he shared with us and the wisdom he showed us. No day will go by without remembering you, Dad, and when this moment passes we will think of all the wonderful times we shared. Contributions to the the Hole-in-the Wall Gang Camp.

VOGELGESANG--Frederick. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on August 30, 2010, of Frederick Vogelgesang, 89, a violinist with the Orchestra from 1953 to 1956. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Rosily, and family.

Do you know about that data port in your car? Of course you don't. But as of 1996, all cars sold in the United States have had to have an on-board diagnostics port that can give technicians information on the performance of various automotive subsystems. It is usually located under the steering wheel. This is a way for mechanics narrow down what is wrong with a car when the ''check engine'' light comes on. Now a company has figured out a few things that consumers can do with the data port. Lemur Monitors, based in Newfoundland, Canada, has come out with a trio of data port devices that can help you drive more safely and keep an eye on other drivers of the car as well.

GREENE--Dawn. The Board of Directors of Planned Parenthood of New York City is saddened by the passing of Dawn Greene, a former Board member and longtime supporter of our mission. We are grateful for her many years of commitment and send our deepest condolences to her family. Diane Max, Chair Joan Malin, President & CEO

OPELOUSAS, La. -- At 18 months, Kyle Warren started taking a daily antipsychotic drug on the orders of a pediatrician trying to quell the boy's severe temper tantrums. Thus began a troubled toddler's journey from one doctor to another, from one diagnosis to another, involving even more drugs. Autism, bipolar disorder, hyperactivity, insomnia, oppositional defiant disorder. The boy's daily pill regimen multiplied: the antipsychotic Risperdal, the antidepressant Prozac, two sleeping medicines and one for attention-deficit disorder. All by the time he was 3.

Michael Llodra rode his retro serve and volley game to a 7-6 (7-3), 6-4, 6-4 convincing victory over one of the game's power players, Tomas Berdych, in straight sets on the Grandstand court. Time and again, Llodra slid in his wide lefty slice, forcing Berdych to reach on his two-handed backhand return. When Berdych would hit a solid return, Llodra handled the first volley with soft hands that recalled John McEnroe in his prime. He made difficult volleys look easy, often using exquisite touch to thwart Berdych, who returned from deep in the court. All told, Llodra made 75 forays to the net, winning 48 of them, often with a textbook first volley that Berdych could not run down.
Give some travelers a cupcake with butter cream frosting, and that’s all they need to be happy. For others, it’s a pillow menu, or cobblestone streets, or a good wine list.

Thursday in The New York Times, I reviewed the MiFi from Virgin Mobile. It’s a pocketable, portable Wi-Fi hot spot, which ensures that you and up to four other people can get online almost anywhere you go. Anywhere in Sprint’s 3G network, that is.

Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, wearing his green military cap and clothing like the commandant of old, spoke before the Cuban public on Friday, warning of the threat of nuclear war. Reuters reported that Mr. Castro, 84, made his speech from the same steps of the University of Havana where 60 years ago he stirred fellow students to political action in the beginnings of the revolution that eventually put him in power in 1959. About 10,000 people, mostly students, filled the steps and nearby streets to listen to the man who led Cuba for 49 years before an intestinal illness prompted his resignation as president in 2006.

In my essay for The Stone, "The Third Replicator," I argued that new replicators can piggy-back on older ones. This happens when the product of one replicator becomes copying machinery for the next replicator, and so on. Memes appeared, I wrote,  when humans (a product of genes) became capable of imitating, varying and selecting a new kind of information in the form of words, actions, technologies and ideas. The same thing is happening now, I argued, with a new replicator. Computers (a product of memes) are just beginning to be capable not only of copying but of copying, varying and selecting digital information. This means the birth of a new  replicator ─  temes, or technological memes.

Whenever the issue of fiscal stimulus comes up, you can count on someone chiming in to say, "Only a moron could believe that the answer to a problem created by too much debt is to create even more debt." It sounds plausible -- but it misses the key point: there's a fallacy of composition here. When everyone tries to pay off debt at the same time, the result is contraction and deflation, which ends up making the debt problem worse even if nominal debt falls. On the other hand, a strong fiscal stimulus, by expanding the economy and creating moderate inflation, can actually help resolve debt problems.

If you are mystified over where a spreadsheet or document is - was it an attachment to Gmail or a Google Doc? -Gmail Labs has a time-saving solution called Apps Search. To turn it on, log in to your Gmail account on the Web, click the green Labs icon (or click Settings and then the Labs link). Scroll down to Apps Search and click the button next to Enable the features. Then click on the Save Changes button. The search box in the Gmail window now says Search Mail and Docs - and lets you look in both places at once for that elusive file.

ARMOUR--Sarah Wood. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Sarah Armour, a devoted and generous friend of the Met for many years and an Advisory Director on our board from 1999 to 2002. On behalf of the entire company, we extend our sincere condolences to her son, Dr. Whitney Addington; to her nephew by marriage, James W. Kinnear, the Met's Honorary Chairman; and to all the other members of her family. Christine F. Hunter, Co-Chairman Ann Ziff, Co-Chairman William C. Morris, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager

SHMERLER--Paula (nee Cohen), on September 2, 2010 at age 81. Beloved wife for almost 60 years of Edwin. Adoring mother of Andrew (Tina), Bill (Susan) and Cindy (Ford Levy). Loving grandmother of Erica (AJ), Bari, Kristen, Max and Harry. The first woman graduate in interior design from the architecture school at Washington University in St. Louis, Paula was a Past-President and 50-year board member of Surprise Lake Camp and a champion golfer at Fairview Country Club. Graveside service on Sunday, September 5, 2010 at 11am at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. The family will receive visitors at Cindy and Ford's home in Pleasantville, NY following the service and Monday, September 6 from 3-8 pm. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 Seventh Ave., Suite 900, New York, NY 10001 or the charity of your choice.

GREENE--Dawn M. The Jewish Museum joins in mourning the loss of Dawn Greene. We are privileged to be the beneficiary of Dawn's generosity, a legacy that grew initially from the interest of her late husband Jerome L. Greene, and one that became equally her own during the past decade. Their magnificent capital and endowment support has an enduring impact on the Museum's exhibitions and collections and on the audiences we serve. We deeply admired her as a woman of intelligence and insight, a lover of the arts, and a figure of elegance and style. We send our heartfelt condolences to Chris and Maggie, to Dawn's philanthropic colleagues, and to her friends. Joshua Nash, Chairman; Robert Pruzan, President; Joan Rosenbaum, Director

The day after she collapsed in her second-round match, Victoria Azarenka called it quits at the United States Open. Azarenka, a 21-year-old from Belarus who entered the tournament as the No. 10 seed in singles, and her partner, Dinara Safina of Russia, quietly pulled out of their doubles match Thursday, ending the tournament for both of them.

BARASCH--Clarence S. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Clarence S. Barasch. Clarence was a member of REBNY for over 42 years. During that time Clarence provided extraordinary and invaluable service and advice to REBNY. He wrote numerous articles for the Annual Diary including Outline of Real Estate Broker's Rights and Duties. Every year, Clarence reviewed and updated the articles as changes in the law occurred. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his sons Lionel and Jonathan and the entire Barasch family. Mary Ann Tighe, Chairman Steven Spinola, President

STUART--Janice K. On behalf of the New York University community, we extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Janice K. Stuart. Her son William Berkley is a dear friend, longtime supporter and wise counselor to our schools and medical center, serving as vice chair of the Board of Trustees, chair of the Board of Overseers at the Leonard N. Stern School of Business, and a trustee of NYU Langone Medical Center. May William and Janice's entire family find comfort at this difficult time in their memories of her long and rich life. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees; Kenneth Langone, Chair, NYU Langone Medical Center Board of Trustees; John Sexton, President, New York University; Robert Berne, Executive Vice President for Health, New York University; Robert I. Grossman, MD, Dean and CEO, NYU Langone Medical Center; Peter Henry, Dean, Stern School of Business

8 P.M. (Disney) CAMP ROCK 2: THE FINAL JAM (2010) The last time around, Demi Lovato starred as a cook's daughter posing as a socialite to infiltrate the popular clique at a rock 'n' roll camp. The Jonas Brothers were the band Connect 3, and Joe Jonas played a teenage pop sensation in search of the girl with the beautiful voice who is heard but not seen. This time there's a new camp across the lake, and it wants Camp Rock to go away. Can someone say duel of the bands? Frankie Jonas -- the younger brother of Nick, Joe and Kevin (above, from left) -- joins in the commotion. An 11-minute preview of ''Fish Hooks,'' a new animated series about three fish in high school, created by the book illustrator and author Noah Z. Jones, will follow at 9:50. The show will have its official premiere on Sept. 24 at 9. 6 A.M. (TCM) TCM BIRTHDAY TRIBUTE: ALAN LADD This salute in honor of what would have been Ladd's 97th birthday (he died in 1964 from the effects of a combination of alcohol and drugs that was ruled accidental) begins with ''Brother Rat and a Baby'' (1940), about three military school graduates on a job search, with Ladd in an uncredited role as a ''cadet in trouble.'' The lineup concludes with ''The Blue Dahlia'' (1946), with Ladd as a veteran who must prove he didn't kill his cheating wife (Doris Dowling), at 2:15 p.m.; ''Shane'' (1953), starring Ladd in perhaps his greatest role, as a mysterious drifter who helps farmers fight off a cattle baron (Emile Meyer) and his hit man (Jack Palance), at 4; and ''The Badlanders'' (1958), featuring Ladd and Ernest Borgnine as outlaws teaming up for a daring gold robbery, at 6:15. Starting at 8, TCM presents a Pancho Villa trilogy, directed by Ismael Rodríguez and starring Pedro Armendáriz as the Mexican revolutionary general.

GREENE--Dawn. The faculty, staff and students of Yale School of Drama are deeply saddened by the passing of Dawn Greene. Her dedication to the theatre and sensitivity to the needs of actors led her to establish the extraordinary Jerome L. Greene Scholarships for students studying acting at the School. We are grateful for the remarkable breadth of her cultural engagement, as well as for her friendship and visionary support, and we extend our sympathies to her daughter Christina McInerney, her granddaughter Margaret Williams, and to the entire family. James Bundy Dean, Yale School of Drama Artistic Director, Yale Repertory Theatre

When the Royals' Zack Greinke won the American League Cy Young Award last year, it was a watershed of sorts. Writers recognized his individual brilliance over his team's performance. It's all part of the challenge of assessing player value. How many wins hasRoy Halladay added to his team this year? Is that more than the wins added by Jayson Werth or Ubaldo Jimenez? In last week's Keeping Score, I laid out a statistic for position players called Wins Above Replacement.

An editorial on Thursday about the dredging of pollutants from the Hudson River misstated the history of the project. It resulted from an agreement between the General Electric Company and the Environmental Protection Agency, not a court order.

SHMERLER--Paula. Surprise Lake Camp mourns the loss of Paula Shmerler. Paula served as a member of our Board of Directors for 52 years! She was a Past President, a longtime member of our Personnel Committee, and a generous and dedicated advocate of our mission. Her support has enriched the lives of thousands of children. We extend condolences to her wonderful husband, Edwin, to her daughter Cindy Levy who is also a member of our Board, and to the entire Shmerler family. A candle will burn throughout this weekend at our Shmerler Building in her memory.

Never mind the raccoons. Here come the skunks. Earlier this week, we at City Room posted a tale about the newly found brashness of New York City's raccoons. But several readers commenting on that article told us: Hold on. What about the skunks?

LEVINSON--Saul, age 92, died peacefully at home. He is survived by his devoted wife of nearly 60 years, Gloria, and his cherished children, Paul and Susan Levinson, Jayne and Chuck Maller, and Nancy and Benjamin Aryeh. He was adored by his grandchildren Tara, Nicole, Lauren, Brandon, David, Lexi and Andrew. He is also survived by his dear sister, Shirley Schaffer, and his caring and compassionate aide, Bola Mixen. A humble man of integrity who, after graduating from New York University School of Business, served his country with distinction as a Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps in the Pacific Theater in World War II, and then enjoyed a long and successful career in the lace industry. Funeral private.

SIMON--Herman, 97, husband of Yvette, his co-adventurer, co-everything, for 72 years, and father of Robbie (Bob) and Steve (Cindy and son Jonathan). He made a swift and painless exit August 28, less than two weeks into his last act -- a cross-country move with Yvette to La Jolla, CA, to be with their children. A joyous, authentic Renaissance man, Herman was passionate about politics, great books, great art, great music...and the Yankees. As curious about people as about ideas and a tireless listener, he made you feel you were the most interesting person in the world. Herman was born in Union City, NJ, where he started out as a teacher and harnessed his radical commitment to fairness to form the district's first teachers' union; he retired as Assistant Superintendent of Schools, an inspiring leader who initiated lasting, innovative programs. He also owned and directed Camp Idylwold in Schroon Lake, NY, which was to become his beloved home base: he and Yvette tended and expanded the 1840s Bullet Pond farmhouse they bought in 1965; they remain honored senior residents of the town (as they do of Parliament House in Pompano Beach, FL, where they made their winter home). A President of the Schroon Lake Association for eleven years, Herman was devoted to keeping the lake pure for future generations. He was "best father in the world" to his daughter and very best friend to his son, both of whom grew up in Teaneck, NJ, except during the family sabbatical year in Paris and Rome that set the stage for Herman's next career, operating student tours, and for four decades of traveling the world. Herman lived long enough to experience in life the tributes accorded most of us only in eulogy tributes from his adoring extended family, his friends, and the generations of young people he mentored. Pre-deceased by siblings Morris and Lillian, he is survived by his brother Raymond and by nieces Tasha, Lisa, Melissa, Brooke, Mickey Rae, Renee, Cory and Vera, and by nephew Daniel. Herman will be remembered, as he was loved, for his enthusiastic unbounded spirit. We will cherish his legacy. Contributions in his memory will be welcomed by the Schroon Lake Association or the Seagle Music Colony, both of Schroon Lake, NY, 12870.

An article on Thursday about the perils of prescribing psychiatric drugs to young children misspelled, in one instance, the name of a Louisiana town that is home to a family whose son has been weaned off several such drugs. As the dateline correctly noted, they live in Opelousas, not Opalousas.
WERNICK--Jeffrey. A year hasn't blunted the pain, ease the loss or diminished the memories. Your loving family.

An article on Saturday about the political donations of Paul Singer, a hedge fund manager, described imprecisely the source of significant contributions to the National Republican Senatorial Committee. Mr. Singer and others affiliated with his firm, Elliott Management, are collectively the top source of contributions to the committee, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, which collates campaign finance data. The hedge fund itself is not the committee's biggest source of money. (Under campaign finance rules, the firm cannot make such contributions.)

GREENE--Dawn. The Board of Directors, Officers and staff of The Peter Jay Sharp Foundation are saddened by the passing of Dawn Greene, who, with her late husband Jerome L. Greene, were longtime friends of Peter Jay Sharp and our organization. We were proud to share her dedicated commitment to New York City and its varied cultural institutions. The Greene legacy will remain a significant part of New York City. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Christina McInerney, and to her family. She will be missed.

MYERS--Lewis, age 84. Graduated Harvard and MIT. Infantryman WWII, Battle of the Bulge. Founded Omega Wire Camden, NY. Survived by Norma Fishel Myers, wife of 57 years. Leaves three daughters, Susan Greenberg, Wendy Myers Foody, Sarah Altman, and eight grandchildren. Funeral Friday, September 3, 1:00pm at Kol Ami 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY.

An article on Wednesday about a new computer memory technology called the memristor misstated the expected capacity of advanced flash storage chips by 2014. It is 170 billion bits per square centimeter, not per square inch.

TURITZ--Philip. We mourn the passing of Philip Turitz on August, 29, 2010 so few days before his 87th birthday, beloved husband of Arlynne for almost 63 years, adored father of Daniel and wife Hillary, and Bethanie and her husband Giancarlo Alhadeff. He was loved by his grandchildren David Alhadeff and his fiancee Tara Bagherzade, and Allison, Andrea and Alexa. He will be with us always, and remembered for the love and strength he shared with us and the wisdom he showed us. No day will go by without remembering you, Dad, and when this moment passes we will think of all the wonderful times we shared. Contributions to the the Hole-in-the Wall Gang Camp.

NEW ORLEANS -- An oil platform in the Gulf of Mexico caught fire on Thursday morning, forcing its 13 crew members overboard and sending waves of anxiety along a coast that has just begun to recover from the Deepwater Horizon disaster. By early evening, the workers had been rescued with no serious injuries reported and the fire had been put out. Coast Guard officials said that no oil could be seen on the water near the platform, contradicting an earlier report.

An article on Tuesday about a dispute over whether a box of negatives bought at a garage sale are lost work of Ansel Adams or at least partly the work of another photographer, Earl Brooks, misstated part of a comment by Arnold Peter, a lawyer for the man who bought the negatives. When told that an expert who originally attributed the negatives to Adams had changed his mind after viewing some photographs by Brooks, Mr. Peter said that ''without possession of the negative, there is no evidence that Earl Brooks created the negative from which the prints were made.'' He did not say ''without possession of the negative of the negative.''

An article on Monday about the release of secret tapes showing that the former leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium urged a man sexually abused by a bishop to keep silent for a year, until the bishop could retire, misstated the given name of the abuser. The retired bishop, who is the victim's uncle, is Roger Vangheluwe, not Robert.

The day after she collapsed in her second-round match, Victoria Azarenka called it quits at the United States Open. Azarenka, a 21-year-old from Belarus who entered the tournament as the No. 10 seed in singles, and her partner, Dinara Safina of Russia, quietly pulled out of their doubles match Thursday, ending the tournament for both of them.

HOWARD-SNEYD--Thomas. Geneva, 27 August 2010, aged 69. Much loved partner of Randolph Paul and father of Henry, Justin and Antonia. Died of a heart attack on his way to a good lunch. He had been living with cancer for some time. Private cremation in Geneva. London memorial later in the year.

The Tea Party Express is rolling in Delaware. The group that endorsed conservative insurgents in primaries in Nevada and Alaska is out to claim another establishment upset, starting a $250,000 media campaign for Christine O'Donnell, the virtually unknown conservative commentator running for the Republican Senate nomination in Delaware.

An article last Friday about the effort of Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates to reduce the number of generals and admirals in the United States military described incorrectly the method used to calculate retirement benefits in the military. Pensions are based on base pay -- not on full pay, which can include extra money to cover, for example, the cost of food and housing.

GREENE--Dawn. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Dawn Greene. Inveterate theater-goer, devotee of Shakespeare's plays and Shakespearean actors, she almost always regarded Lincoln Center Theater productions and was kindly critical when so moved. We will miss both her encouragement and support and send condolences to her daughter Christina McInerney and her granddaughter Margaret Williams. Lincoln Center Theater J. Watching Favre-a-thon 2010 unfold, the Packers might have stifled a giggle. They should not even pay attention. Green Bay is a Super Bowl-caliber team no matter what Favre does because General Manager Ted Thompson made the right bet at the right time on Aaron Rodgers, who is one of the top five quarterbacks in the league and looked particularly sharp in the preseason. If his line does not get Rodgers killed, the way it nearly did early last season, the offense will again be one of the most productive in the N.F.L. (The Packers were third in points scored last season.) The defense was seventh in points allowed, and although Al Harris and Charles Woodson are among the best cornerback tandems in the league, they are each at least 33 and injuries are taking a toll. Harris (knee) is on the physically unable to perform list and unavailable for at least six games. The best news for the Packers is that the schedule offers a relatively easy first six games before they play the Vikings, the Jets and the Cowboys in a row. After a bye, they face the Vikings, the Falcons and the 49ers.

ATLANTA -- It seems like a risky move for a team to use its star cornerback, an All-American candidate no less, as a kick returner. But Louisiana State is doing just that with Patrick Peterson, exposing him in the open field to gunners on coverage teams and opening up the possibility that his knees could be wrecked.

The first month of a college football season is filled with teams from lesser-known conferences traveling to play teams from powerful ones. They are known as guarantee games, in which the road teams receive a guaranteed paycheck and often a guaranteed loss.

TELLURIDE, Colo.- One of the open-air panels at the Telluride film festival this year is called "Human/Nature," about how filmmakers address the natural world, and it's an apt subject, both because of the festival's setting and because of one of the themes that links a number of selections in the program. Nestled in a high mountain valley surrounded by jagged, soaring peaks, Telluride, a former mining town, frequently upstages the movies on its screens, at least as far as sheer visual sublimity is concerned.

Did 49ers Coach Mike Singletary annoy someone in the scheduling office? The Niners open with three of their first four games on the road, with the home game against the Saints. Still, this is a team on the rise after finishing 8-8 last season, coupling a premier N.F.L. defense (fourth best in points allowed in 2009) with the hope that quarterback Alex Smith will make a big leap by playing the same offense for two consecutive years. Smith is surrounded by plenty of talent, including tight end Vernon Davis and the emerging receiver Michael Crabtree. Do not look for Smith to finally get to use the spread offense he prefers, though. Singletary wants to be an old-school, smash-mouth team - he defined that style as a player - and the Niners upgraded their offensive line in the draft to that end. Their schedule will not make it easy - they also play a "home" game in London and play the Cardinals twice late in the season - but the Niners should get above .500 for the first time since 2002, and that may be enough to win the division.

The N.F.L. has planned a parade in New Orleans on Thursday, the day of the season opener, which is a good way to remind the Saints that the party is over. As loaded as they remain, the Saints will have to guard against complacency and the fact that every opponent that will be trying to take down the champions. The Saints' task will be made easier by the virtually intact offense of Drew Brees and his nearly unstoppable passing game. Brees was transcendent in the Super Bowl, and the Saints led the league in points last season. They also topped the league in scoring differential, despite a defense that finished 20th in points allowed. We will know plenty about the way the Saints handle the hangover when they open against Minnesota in an N.F.C. championship game rematch. After that, the schedule is manageable enough to at least ensure a return playoff trip, if not the division title.

MAYER--Klaus. The staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn the death of Member Emeritus Klaus Mayer. Dr. Mayer spent his entire professional life at MSKCC, beginning in 1952 as a resident. During his 53 years at the Center, he held many positions, including Director of the MSKCC Blood Bank and Hematology Laboratories. He was an acknowledged expert in the mechanisms of red blood cell aging and the reduction of finite red cell life span in patients with cancer. Thousands of patients had the benefit of his gifts as a hematologist, and his work will continue to benefit patients with cancer in the future. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. Martin Fleisher Chair, Clinical Laboratories George J. Bosl Chair, Department of Medicine Robert W. Wittes Physician-in-Chief Memorial Hospital John R. Gunn Acting President

Saturday's meeting between the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays will be a single game at Yankee Stadium, but it may seem like a doubleheader in terms of the Yankees' roster. In the hours before the 1:05 p.m. first pitch, the injuredAndy Pettitte will pitch to the injured third basemanAlex Rodriguez during a simulated game. If all goes well, both will move closer to returning for the conclusion of the regular season and the playoffs.

THRAVALOS--Vasilios H.,passed away peacefully at his home in Riverdale, NY, on September 2, 2010 at the age of 81. He was born March 2, 1929 in Kardamyla, Chios, Greece to Haridimos and Katherine Thravalos. Fluent in Greek, English, French, Italian and Spanish, he was educated at Universita Scienze Marittima e Commerciale in Genoa, Italy and Saint Helen's School of High Commerce in London, England. Having served in the Greek military as a member of their special operations forces, he followed in the family tradition by embarking on a career at sea, which culminated in his elevation to the rank of Captain in the Greek Merchant Marine. In 1969, he immigrated to the United States and began a successful career as a shipping executive in Mew York City. A loving husband and wonderful father, he is survived by his beloved wife of 35 years, Evangeline, and their devoted son, Haridimos.

BARASCH--Clarence S.. Columbia/Barnard Hillel (Jewish Campus Life Fund) mourns the passing of our dear esteemed friend, mentsch, supporter and leader. His legacy will continue in our work and the good deeds of our students. May his memory be for a blessing. Michael P. Lustig, Judith Schwartz, Co-Presidents, Simon Klarfeld, Executive Director

SHMERLER--Paula (nee Cohen), on September 2, 2010 at age 81. Beloved wife for almost 60 years of Edwin. Adoring mother of Andrew (Tina), Bill (Susan) and Cindy (Ford Levy). Loving grandmother of Erica (AJ), Bari, Kristen, Max and Harry. The first woman graduate in interior design from the architecture school at Washington University in St. Louis, Paula was a Past-President and 50-year board member of Surprise Lake Camp and a champion golfer at Fairview Country Club. Jerry Miccolis, co-author of ''Asset Allocation for Dummies'' and chief investment officer at the wealth advisory company Brinton Eaton in New Jersey, shared his list of 10 mistakes investors should avoid. Let us know in the comments section below what you would add to the list.1.) Overlooking the importance of asset allocation: According to Mr. Miccolis, getting asset allocation right is the building block of investing successfully. Many investors, however, skip this step and instead build their portfolio by haphazardly buying securities they like.

GAGARIN--Nancy Tyner, died at her home in Greenwich, Connecticut after a long and courageous battle with COPD. Born in 1926, the daughter of Richard Legge Tyner and Jean Hill Tyner, and grand-daughter of John Hill, founder of the Hill Publishing Company which later became McGraw-Hill, She attended Miss. Porter's school in Farmington, CT and took post-graduate courses at Columbia and Sarah Lawrence. A lover of nature, animals and all things beautiful, Nannie (a nick-name she could never shake) was also a talented sculptor, poet and flower arranger. A long-time member of the Greenwich Garden Club, she was twice awarded the Fenwick Medal for flower arranging. In addition she was a Garden Club of America Zone Representative and Judge. During WWII, she was a nurse's aide in Military Hospitals and post-war volunteered with the Red Cross and locally, the Greenwich Hospital. Beloved by her family and fiercely loyal to her many friends, she is survived by her husband of 60 years, Peter, her son Anthony Gagarin of Santa Rosa, CA and two daughters Nina Gagarin of Palm Beach, FL, Wendy G. Chadsey of Molalla, OR, as well as four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11am, September 9 at the 1st Church of Round Hill in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Adopt-A-Dog, 849 Lake Ave., Greenwich, CT 06831.

CAPOZZOLA--Richard. Died September 3 at age 73. Richard was the honored and legendary principal of Mount Vernon High School in the 1980"s. He was a terrific sandlot pitcher and slugger. He authored "Five Centuries of Italian American History" and was fierce activist against negative stereotypical portrayals of Italian Americans in the media. He will be dearly missed by his sons, Michael and Steven and his many friends.

The world was a much better place for Ruth's nearly 90 years. May her memory always be both a blessing and inspiration for everyone who was privileged to know her. Robert Elman, President David Harris, Exec. Director

INTERNATIONAL A headline on Thursday about efforts by the former head of the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium to distance himself from a sexual abuse case involving his longtime friend and colleague, Bishop Roger Vangheluwe, referred incorrectly in some editions to the former official's current status in the church. While the former official, Godfried Danneels, no longer heads the church in Belgium, he is still a cardinal; he is not a ''former cardinal.''

If you're considering buying a new car, you may want to consider buying it this weekend. According to Juan Flores, director of vehicle valuation for Kelley Blue Book, Labor Day is traditionally the best time to buy a car. That is because manufacturers offer generous incentives on current-year models to clear them out and make room on dealer lots for vehicles from the next model year, which traditionally start arriving this month.

COLAVITO--Rose, age 93, died September 2nd. Born in Pennsylvania, she grew up in East Harlem and the Bronx. At 17, she dropped out of high school. In her forties, she returned to evening school, graduating as valedictorian of her class. Receiving a BA from Hunter College and her Masters in English Education from NYU, she began teaching English at JHS 118 at age 50. Rose developed a Drama program with classes performing musicals from West Side Story to Man of La Mancha. She received a teaching award from the Federation of Italian-American Educators (FIAME). At the Bronx New School, she opened and ran the school library. The origami work Rose and her students created while volunteering at the NY Botanical Garden was displayed at both the Garden and the American Museum of Natural History. She was a strong advocate for individual and social justice. She is survived by her husband of 68 years, Bill Colavito, her sons Joe and Bill, daughter-in-law Deana, her grandchildren Peter, Eve, Paul and Andrew, and four great-grandchildren. Condolences may be offered at Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY on Tuesday, September 7 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent in her name to either the Enrico Fermi Branch of the New York Public Library in the Bronx or to the Pleasantville Public Library.

(TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: COUGAR TOWN Robert Osborne and Alec Baldwin guide a tour through the older woman-younger man oeuvre, starting with ''The Graduate'' (1967), starring Dustin Hoffman, above, as Benjamin Braddock, newly returned to the California home of his wealthy parents after finishing college back East, and Anne Bancroft as Mrs. Robinson, the seductress who has a few lessons of her own to teach him. But it's Elaine (Katharine Ross), Mrs. Robinson's daughter, who gives him a real purpose in life. Other affairs to remember: ''A Cold Wind in August '' (1961), at 10, with Lola Albright as an aging stripper who falls for a teenage boy (Scott Marlowe); ''Summer of '42'' (1971), at 11:30, with Gary Grimes as a high school student in love with a World War II bride (Jennifer O'Neill); ''Love and Pain and the Whole Damn Thing'' (1973), at 1:30 a.m., about two tourists (Timothy Bottoms and Maggie Smith) who find solace with each other while traveling through Spain; and ''The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone'' (1961), at 3:30, starring Vivien Leigh as a fading stage star who becomes mired in obsession after hiring a male companion (Warren Beatty) during a vacation in Italy. 10:30 A.M. The latest New York Times poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 27 through 31 in New York City with 892 adults, of whom 195 lived in Manhattan and said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish. The sample of land-line telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the city. The exchanges were chosen to ensure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.

The technology driving the three-story scoreboard on the side of Louis Armstrong Stadium at the National Tennis Center is more sophisticated than the storied manual scoreboard at Fenway Park in Boston. But not by much. Each day, sometimes several times an hour during the Grand Slam's first week, Burford Smith and his first-year assistant, Frank Ayala, can be found scaling one of the four ladders that slide across the 160-foot plywood board, painted blue like the courts and stenciled white to make room for the men's and women's 128-player draws. Their job is to post the day's final match results, using hand-cut vinyl characters and industrial-strength double-sided masking tape.

This week, City Room reported that skunks have taken up permanent residence in Upper Manhattan and are starting to make their way south. We asked readers to tell us about their encounters with the stinkers. Here, some skunk tales of the city. ''A few nights ago, my apartment in Washington Heights was undergoing renovation, and I was staying with a friend who lives on Bennett Avenue. I stayed in the apartment while she went to the first floor to do her laundry. Several minutes later, I received a hysterical phone call: 'There is a skunk in the laundry room!' I rushed downstairs, and sure enough there he was behind the machines. The super eventually came to rectify the matter, but I could not help but smile and marvel at the appearance of our little guest. I'm oddly comforted by their presence.'' -- Alex

Anton Geesink, a 6-foot-6 Dutchman who stunned Japan when he defeated Japanese opponents to win the 1961 world judo championship and a gold medal at the 1964 Tokyo Games, died Aug. 27 in Utrecht, the Netherlands. He was 76. His death, at a hospital, was announced by the International Judo Federation.

NATIONAL An article on Friday about an oil platform in the Gulf of Mexico that caught fire, forcing its 13 crew members overboard, misidentified the governmental body that announced in August that the use of categorical exclusions for offshore drilling would be restricted. The Department of Interior, not a presidential commission, made the announcement about the exclusions, which are waivers that allow companies to proceed with drilling without having to undergo an in-depth environmental review.

There is a story about Bertrand Russell giving a public lecture somewhere or other, defending his atheism. A furious woman stood up at the end of the lecture and asked: “And Lord Russell, what will you say when you stand in front of the throne of God on judgment day?” Russell replied: “I will say: ‘I’m terribly sorry, but you didn’t give us enough evidence.’ ”

Eight of the last 11 Super Bowl losers failed to qualify for the playoffs the next season. Get serious. As long as Peyton Manning is upright, the Colts are a Super Bowl contender. Bill Polian, the Colts' president, has surrounded Manning with superb talent, so much so that Indianapolis's 2007 first-round draft pick, Anthony Gonzalez, could be the odd man out in a fabulous group of receivers. The offensive line has gotten much bigger with the hopes of establishing a ground game, but how much does that really matter? Manning threw 571 passes last year and was a coach's decision from leading Indianapolis to a likely undefeated regular season. The defense, which allowed fewer than 20 points a game, should be better in Year 2 under Larry Coyer because Bob Sanders, a supremely gifted safety, is healthy again. The only problem the Colts face is that the expectations are so high, if they don't win it all, the season will be a huge disappointment. They will reach at least the A.F.C. championship game.

When will the rest of the A.F.C. West give the Chargers a run for the division title? Not this year. For all the off-season turmoil - whither Vincent Jackson and his holdout? - San Diego has the most talent by far. The passing game, even without Jackson, is deep and explosive and figures only to get better now that teams have to pay attention to Ryan Mathews instead of LaDainian Tomlinson, who led the 31st-ranked rushing offense last season. Still, you get the feeling the window is about to close on this team. Several big names, like linebacker Shawne Merriman and returner Darren Sproles, are in their contract years, and the Chargers simply can't keep racing through the regular season (they won their final 11 games in 2009 and have one of the easiest schedules this season) only to collapse in the playoffs. Last season's lackluster playoff loss to the Jets might be pinned on Norv Turner's insistence on giving the ball to Tomlinson, but the excuses, and the Chargers' dominance, are running out. San Diego should win the division again with ease, but every other team is aggressively trying to improve in the meantime.

The United States Open title has eluded Rafael Nadal, who, like Bjorn Borg before him, dominated the European clay-court season and was able to adapt to grass and win Wimbledon a few short weeks later. I would argue that Borg's feat was the tougher one to accomplish because the grass back then played faster, the bounces were unreliable and there were also many serve-and-volleyers who reveled on the slick, low-bouncing grass, John McEnroe chief among them.

The Ravens spent the off-season shoring up their offense, handing quarterback Joe Flacco the best receiving corps he has had by adding Anquan Boldin and Donte' Stallworth, who recently broke his foot but is expected to return in October. Combine them with running back Ray Rice's explosiveness, and the Ravens have real scoring potential - a good thing after they managed only 3 points against the Colts in the playoffs last season. That would usually be enough to make the Ravens a Super Bowl favorite without reservation.

Our gubernatorial projections took a little longer than I expected. The original idea was that we could just take our Senate model, tweak a few of the parameters, and be ready to go. Indeed, our gubernatorial forecasting model shares a lot of the Senate model's DNA. The basic blueprint of taking a robust average of polls, supplementing them with some demographic information and then using them to project the final standing of the candidates remains the same.

It has been a long time since their rival in New England did not enter the season as the A.F.C. East favorite, but the Jets may engineer a hostile takeover. If the new cornerback Antonio Cromartie can return to his 2007 form and Darrelle Revis ends his holdout, the Jets will have the best secondary, and the best defense, in football. The first-team offense struggled in the preseason; Mark Sanchez still makes too many mistakes, and the offensive line looked spotty. But the surprise was how much life appeared in LaDainian Tomlinson's legs. The real issue is that with so many big mouths and big egos, the Jets have raised expectations wildly and made themselves a target. In a closely bunched division, how well all those big names work together may determine whether the Jets are a well-publicized boom or bust.
