I check my checking and credit card account statements nearly every day to make sure there are no fraudulent charges. For me, no amount is too small to fight -- whether it's the $300 in fraudulent debit card charges I noticed last month or more recently, a $10.95 "travel center" charge I realized I mistakenly made.

On Thursday, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar had a meeting with the only people  outside the gulf region whose waters had been opened to offshore oil exploration. He was in Barrow, Alaska, the capital of the North Slope Borough, where people have the same conflicted feelings about the oil industry as residents of the gulf states do. The energy industry centered in Prudhoe Bay is the economic engine of the North Slope, helping preserve the Inupiat culture, but it also presents a potential threat to that culture. Mayor Edward Itta of the North Slope Borough e-mailed answers to our questions about these conflicts. (The transcript of the exchange has been edited and condensed.)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, August 21st 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Perennial sellers are not actively tracked. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. All four children’s lists appear each week on the Book Review’s Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children’s titles.

The men stole the limelight last weekend at a Jazz Age lawn party on Governors Island organized by Michael Arenella and His Dreamland Orchestra. At a moment when popular fashion is oversize and casual, these men were the exact opposite. While the dress shirt was worn without a jacket for business this summer, with the cuff turned back above the wrist, the men here had on fitted shirts with the sleeves neatly folded above the elbow under snug vests or sleeveless sweaters. Neckties or bow ties proliferated. Another strong look was the revival of suspenders. Many of the men were referencing style of an earlier time to find a new style for today.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week are Isabel Wilkerson on her account of the Great Migration, ''The Warmth of Other Suns''; Sean Wilentz on his book ''Bob Dylan in America''; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Paper Cuts The Book Review's blog covers books and other forms of printed matter.

WOOLWICH--Masha Switzen Wise, September 1, age 91 died at home. A life long New Yorker, predeceased by husbands Robert and Joseph. Truly a women of valor. A hard, but glorious life will live on through our thoughts and our memories. Survived by her son, Leigh, daughter-in-law Suzie, granddaughter Abigail, sisters Ruth and Edna, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Donations may be made to: Hadassah or ORT.

For our summer series, ''Around the Grill,'' Raymond McCrea Jones of The Times has touched down at cookouts throughout the city and returned with photos, video and articles. The series has also resulted in a trove of user-generated barbecue photos from around the world. All confirm one universal truth: People love barbecue. With Labor Day in sight, a bit of backyard inspiration in the form of reader-submitted recipes from near and far. Below, a sampling from New York City grillers.

The Ferrari 458 Italia, a midengine 560-horsepower sports car that sells for well over $200,000 and drew rave reviews after its 2009 introduction, has proved to be a lot hotter than its owners anticipated. The machine apparently has a tendency to burst into flames and is now subject to recall by its Italian manufacturer.

THOUGH she is little known today, Ethel Scull, a Pop art patron who threw fabulous parties, was great fodder for the gossip pages in the '60s. She was also a remarkable clotheshorse, as evidenced by ''Notorious & Notable,'' a show at the Museum of the City of New York that features fashion and accessories from 80 of the most talked-about women of the 20th century. Among the finery on display: Ms. Scull's swanky striped jersey Stephen Burrows evening dress; Mona Von Bismarck's ice-blue silk gazar Balenciaga coat, dripping with hot pink silk petals (above right); Sunny von Bulow's filmy Christian Dior minidress; a pleated Mary McFadden tunic owned by Geraldine Stutz (below right); a gold minaudière given to Jackie Onassis by Haile Selassie (which she ought to have given back to the State Department, but instead bequeathed to her sister, Lee); and a fish-shaped Schlumberger lighter owned by Diana Vreeland (top). Could these women reappear, it would make for one heck of a cocktail party. ''Notorious & Notable'' runs Sept. 14 to Jan. 3 at the Museum of the City of New York; mcny.org.

To the Sports Editor: Congratulations to the players of the Liberty, who have reached the W.N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals. Great game and clutch play by Cappie Pondexter gave Madison Square Garden basketball fans something to celebrate -- for a change.

ISRAELOW--Ruth. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Ruth Israelow, beloved mother of our board member Marvin Israelow and mother-in-law of Dorian Goldman. Marvin and Dorian display true dedication to the Jewish community and true kindness toward those in need through their unwavering commitment to philanthropy. We extend our sympathies to Marvin and Dorian and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO
Theater Steven McElroy

WARD--John Gerard Jr. ("Jack"). Died September 3 at the age of 66. A graduate of Fordham University Law School, Jack was an attorney who provided estate services to many New Yorkers during the last 40 years. As the grandson of William J. Ward, founder of The Bank of Coney Island, he managed Ward Realty, representing the last of the original families owning property in Coney Island. He was a former president of the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce, a member of the school board and Water for Life committee at Our Lady of Mercy parish in Forest Hills, and a board member of Camp Mark Seven in Old Forge, NY. He will be dearly remembered by his wife, Mary Beth; three children, John Ward of Huntington, Long Island, Faith Ward of Baltimore, and Kathleen Whitaker of Los Angeles; three sisters; three grandchildren; extended family; and devoted friends. In lieu of flowers, donations to Camp Mark Seven, 144 Mohawk Hotel Road, Old Forge, NY 13420, or the Archdiocese of San Antonio Catholic Deaf Ministry, P.O. Box 7783, San Antonio, TX 78207, would be greatly appreciated.

''Central bankers alone cannot solve the world's economic problems.'' Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who said the Fed couldn't conjure up a recovery just by manipulating interest rates and the money supply. ''The reliance on album sales is very 20th century.'' Cliff Chenfeld, an owner of Razor and Tie, an independent record label in New York. Recently, album sales have plummeted, sales of singles have surged and new sources of revenue have emerged like fees for online music that are changing the definition of a hot artist.

LEARSON--Kate. Our beloved friend, Kate Learson, died on Tuesday. Her heartbreaking absence from our lives will leave us forever diminished. But through our tears we know that we have been forever graced by her love, her unfailing kindness, and her contagious passion for art, poetry and opera. Kate found delight in life and never stopped fighting for more, even when up against impossible odds. She loved her family above all; her sons, Doug and Lucien Foster, her daughter-in-law, Rebecca Foster, and her precious grandson, Rowan, who was her joy. During her final years, Kate also felt blessed by the steadfast love of Nita. We will deeply miss everything about Kate; especially her irreverent humor and spontaneous wit which never left her and was integral to her joie de vivre. While Kate reveled in her exotic travels to places like Antarctica and Angor Wat, she was just as happy in front of her fireplace with family or friends, or watching Max, her black standard poodle, fly down the beach in Chatham, Massachusetts. Kate loved the Cape and her boundless love, like the ocean she cherished, was, and will continue to be, an endless source of strength for us all. Ann Marie Cunningham, Jurate Kazickas, Laura Palmer and Cookie Rumely.

BEACH--Denny. Passed August 31 after reaching her 100th birthday. She represented many famous theatrical personalities and worked with Leland Hayward, Baron Poland, and Burt Martinson. She was active in the movies, theater. and the New York City Ballet. Her elegance, charm, and sharp wit will be missed by all who knew her. Howard Zipser, Trustee

A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions on Aug. 22 misstated the number of works in the exhibition ''Acquired Riches: Highlights from the Hofstra University Museum Collection'' in Hempstead. There are 53 works on display -- not 5,000, which is the number in the entire collection. The listing also referred incorrectly to the age of the earliest works in the show. They date from 100 B.C. to the year 800 -- not from the 18th century.

ADMIRING Meret Oppenheim's fur-covered bangle in 1936, Pablo Picasso remarked that anything could be covered in the material. Apparently Phoebe Philo agrees. To accompany her clean-lined fall collection for Céline, the designer took a pair of classically elegant black suede sandals and lined the inner sole with rabbit fur remnants. The results are strange. And surreal. And outrageously decadent. But, worn with a pair of slim ankle-length trousers and a simple blouse, also pretty fantastic. Céline suede sandals with fur lining, $770 at Kirna Zabête,96 Greene Street; (212) 941-9656.

GREITZER--Herman, 90 of Kripplebush, NY, formerly of Manhattan and Ocean Beach, FL. Adored by wife Sarah Draney, daughter and son-in-law Elizabeth Greitzer and Jeff Durrell, grandchildren Matthew and Katherine Durrell. CCNY, Columbia Law, founding member Village Independent Democrats, their first candidate for Greenwich Village District Leader against the Tammany Hall machine in 1957. He met Sarah in 1985 when buying her artwork in Soho. Enjoyed books, birds, family, and friends. Private cremation.

A GNÈS BOULARD, a k a Mademoiselle Agnès, host of ''Girl on the Run,'' which has its premiere on the Sundance Channel and fullfrontalfashion.com on Sept. 8. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW This is my way of being bourgeois: a camel coat from Phillip Lim. Everyone has to have a camel coat this season. An old pair of jeans from Gerard Darel, and a blouse from Balmain. The shoes are old YSL ones that I love. The bracelet is Fendi from a couple seasons ago, and the pouchette is Jimmy Choo.

SALEN--Fran. Teacher, loving daughter, mother, wife, grandmother. Artist, dancer, writer, altruist, thinker, free spirit, great soul. Survived by her adoring family and many hundreds of people whose lives she changed. Donations to HIAS, Hadassah.

DAVIS--Lewis F.,97, died peacefully at home on August 31. Charming and gentlemanly to the end, he will be missed by his wife, Audrey Landau (Judy Tobias) Davis, his children, Laurie Gilkes and Peter Davis, his grandchildren, Amy Gilkes Loe (and Brad Loe) and Conner Davis, and his great-granddaughter, Olivia Gilkes Loe. A memorial service will be planned. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Visiting Nurse Service Hospice.

It's a lot easier to have harder conversations when I 'roll the robot,' MIKE BELTZNER, of Toronto, director of the Web browser Firefox, who uses a mobile robot to conduct performance reviews with employees in California. [22]

About a decade ago transplanted Manhattanites began reviving the late-18th-century whaling town of Hudson, N.Y., two hours north of New York City, along the Hudson River. Initially, proximity, great building stock and cheap rents spurred a healthy antiques district. More recently galleries, bars and vintage shops have opened; along with them a general feeling of bohemianism has emerged. The latest wave to hit, particularly along the main drag of Warren Street, has been music. Already home to established musicians like the neo-soul singer and musician Meshell Ndegeocello, the D.J. Tedd Patterson, and the bassist Melissa Auf der Maur, formerly of the band Hole -- as well as a recording studio housed in an 1869 church -- Hudson now boasts a robust grassroots music scene. ''It's just like a smaller version of Brooklyn to me,'' said Ms. Ndegeocello, a two-year resident who was attracted by the convenience and the progressive community. CARRIE NIEMAN CULPEPPER

The first month of a college football season is filled with teams from lesser-known conferences traveling to play teams from powerful ones. They are known as guarantee games, in which the road teams receive a guaranteed paycheck and often a guaranteed loss. When Boise State faces Virginia Tech on Monday, it will be a different kind of guarantee game. The Broncos are receiving $1.25 million to travel to FedEx Field in Landover, Md., a neutral site much closer to Tech's Blacksburg campus. But Virginia Tech will not return the favor by traveling to Idaho next year. Of course, Boise State is also ranked No. 3 and favored to win the game. The Broncos have become an elite team, but it remains maddeningly difficult for Athletic Director Gene Bleymaier to secure a home-and-home series with a team from a Bowl Championship Series conference.

A review last Sunday about ''The Pain Chronicles,'' a study-cum-memoir by Melanie Thernstrom, misquoted a word in a sentence from the book. The sentence reads, ''Light began to fill Kurt's bedroom, and pain filled the house of my body like smoke,'' not ''with smoke.''

LEVINSON--Saul, age 92, died peacefully at home. He is survived by his devoted wife of nearly 60 years, Gloria, and his cherished children, Paul and Susan Levinson, Jayne and Chuck Maller, and Nancy and Benjamin Aryeh. He was adored by his grandchildren Tara, Nicole, Lauren, Brandon, David, Lexi and Andrew. He is also survived by his dear sister, Shirley Schaffer, and his caring and compassionate aide, Bola Mixen. A humble man of integrity who, after graduating from New York University School of Business, served his country with distinction as a Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps in the Pacific Theater in World War II, and then enjoyed a long and successful career in the lace industry. Funeral private.

The Ravens spent the off-season shoring up their offense, handing quarterback Joe Flacco the best receiving corps he has had by adding Anquan Boldin and Donte' Stallworth, who recently broke his foot but is expected to return in October. Combine them with running back Ray Rice's explosiveness, and the Ravens have real scoring potential -- a good thing after they managed only 3 points against the Colts in the playoffs last season. That would usually be enough to make the Ravens a Super Bowl favorite without reservation. But their reliable defense has some problems, particularly in the secondary. Safety Ed Reed (neck) is on the physically unable to perform list, so he will miss at least six weeks. At cornerback, Domonique Foxworth is out for the season and Fabian Washington and Lardarius Webb are returning from serious knee injuries. Maybe the rest of the defense -- with Haloti Ngata, Terrence Cody, the 35-year-old Ray Lewis and a slimmed-down and quicker Terrell Suggs -- is still special enough that it will not matter.
SWEIG--Murray. Terribly missed on your 90th birthday. Without you Dad, each day is a struggle. Forever loved. Susan

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel heads to Louisiana Cajun country, where he hits the swamps and has one heck of a shrimp-and-oyster po' boy. Then it's on to New Orleans for an all-nighter that includes high school football, Abita beer and jazz.

Now that checked bag fees seem here to stay, two hotel companies have decided to build promotions around them to provide travelers some relief. The InterContinental Hotels Group is offering a rebate for up to $850 in checked bag fees to guests who book a two-night weekend stay by Dec. 25 for travel through Dec. 30 and pay for it with a Visa card. But before booking a stay, read the fine print: The process isn't simple: you have to download and submit a form, along with a receipt for checked bags and a hotel bill - and a receipt from a third party like Expedia, if applicable - that shows your payment method. The rebate arrives about six weeks later in the form of Visa prepaid cards (which can be used anywhere). The offer is good at all 4,500 InterContinentalGroup hotels, which include InterContinental, Holiday Inn, and Crowne Plaza, Staybridge Suites, Candlewood Suites and others.

Jan Benzel, a New York Times editor who is being reassigned to Paris, wrote on the City Room blog last week about celebrities she has seen during her decades of living in New York. Dozens of readers responded with accounts of their own sightings. Following are excerpts. In 1980, on a trip to the Whitney, I had lunch with my girlfriend in a diner around the corner. People were pointing in my general direction and I was unsure why. Turned around and there was the entire cast of ''Saturday Night Live'' at a round table in the back, two tables from me: John Belushi, Dan Ackroyd, Laraine Newman, Garrett Morris, Jane Curtin, Bill Murray. I was so star-struck, my head was spinning, but I swore I saw Woody Allen with them too.

McEWAN--Jane Hamilton. Born in Philadelphia, PA in 1916, Jane passed away peacefully on August 25, 2010. A resident of Santa Monica and the Pacific Palisades since 1964, Jane was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Thomas Johnson McEwan. Jane served for many years as Docent and as President of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art Docent Council. She was also Docent for the Getty Museum, served many years as a volunteer for Head Start and was on the Board of Directors for the Santa Monica Public Library. Jane was an avid writer of poetry. Jane is survived by her four sons Thomas Jr., Robert, David and Charles and seven loving grandchildren Marisha, Louisa, Angus, Nicholas, Elise, Ian and Jenna. In lieu of flowers, please donate generously to the charity of your choice in Jane's name.

SEDITA--Nina M, August 27, 2010 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Born Buffalo, NY, 1931. SUNY Buffalo, BA, MA Phi Beta Kappa. Television writer, artist. Former resident Manhattan Plaza and Jewish Home and Hospital. Sadly missed by family and friends.

HOME FIRES The weight of my daughter strapped into her carrier felt familiar: it was about the weight of an Interceptor with both SAPI plates inserted. These types of connections pass through my thoughts on an almost daily basis. I often think of how fresh World War II and the wars in Korea and Vietnam are in the minds of Americans who fought in and witnessed them. We carry these wars inside of us. They tag along in our lives as sea stories and memories, dreams and nightmares, living just below the surface, raging back at times, most times living in quiescence.

SCHNEIDER--Florence Lehman, August 23rd at age 87. Beloved wife of the late Murray C. Schneider. Devoted mother of Janet, Cathy (Alan) and Gary (Nilcee). Grandmother of Jeffrey (Suzanne), Dara, Josh, and Kyllie.

I TRY to ignore this view. When I'm at my writing desk I turn my back to it. When I look up -- though these days one no longer looks up from his work, but merely past the monitor -- I see only the spines of books along their shelves. What I don't see is the pitched window of the attic, the bend that the Spree, Berlin's main river, makes behind me, the distant facade of the magnificent Bode Museum; above all I don't see the three bridges with their streams of cars and pedestrians under which pass huge barges headed in both directions. Some of the barges carry freight, while others blast music as people dance and raise beer bottles on the deck, although on most of them sit tourists with their cameras, attentive as schoolchildren. I always wonder what they are photographing. The majority probably photograph the so-called Palace of Tears, that glass border-crossing station that once sat between East and West Berlin; today it is empty, although it will soon become a dance club. A few will also photograph the Berlin Ensemble, originally a theater founded and run by Bertolt Brecht; it is to the left of my window and visible only if I lean out. The most important thing, however, cannot be photographed: the invisible line where the Berlin Wall once stood. Absence can't be captured, not even with the best camera, and so the tourists turn their helpless devices to the gray facades of the new buildings, to the rows of identical windows, one of which, high up near the roof, stands open, and behind it a barely visible figure quickly turns away and goes back to work at his desk.

CATCHEN--Harvey, Ph.D, MPH -- Professor at SUNY at Old Westbury. Passed away on September 1. Loved and missed by his two daughters, Molly and Rachel Catchen, Alice Sardell, nieces, nephews, students and friends.

THOMPSON, UTAH, MAY 28, 2010 My dad, aunt and uncle visited from South Korea to celebrate my college graduation (Go U. Penn 2010!) with a cross-country road trip. On our way to Moab, Utah, we saw this giant red sand dune that looked inviting. It seemed easy enough to climb, and we figured we needed the exercise after 10 hours of sitting in the car. We parked and headed toward the dune in our bare feet. The sand was impossibly soft to the touch -- great for our soles, but, as we soon found out, not great for our muscles. The sand was so fine that we sank backward with every step. My attempts to convince my family to turn back only increased their eagerness to reach the top. The three of them pushed through, and we made it to the top just in time to watch the sun set behind Utah's great sandstone walls. SONG-I YANG

MIROPOL--Dr. Harold S.,95, of Boca Raton, FL, died peacefully at home surrounded by his family on September 3. Served honorably as a Naval Commander with the Pacific fleet for the duration of WWII, dedicated physician at Booth Memorial Hospital in NY and St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, practicing medicine until the age of 81. Loving husband of Carol nee Fassler, devoted father to Wendy Benoist (Gray), Cindy, James, and Elizabeth Posner (Ross), beloved grandfather of five. Loyal brother to Shirley Silver and the late Florence Leon. Dear brother-in-law to Betty and Michael Shaffet. At Dr. Miropol's request, there will be no service. Donations in his memory can be made to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL.

The N.F.L. has planned a parade in New Orleans on Thursday, the day of the season opener, which is a good way to remind the Saints that the party is over. As loaded as they remain, the Saints will have to guard against complacency and the fact that every opponent that will be trying to take down the champions. The Saints' task will be made easier by the virtually intact offense of Drew Brees and his nearly unstoppable passing game. Brees was transcendent in the Super Bowl, and the Saints led the league in points last season. They also topped the league in scoring differential, despite a defense that finished 20th in points allowed. We will know plenty about the way the Saints handle the hangover when they open against Minnesota in an N.F.C. championship game rematch. After that, the schedule is manageable enough to at least ensure a return playoff trip, if not the division title. The only real competition for the Saints in the division is the Falcons, who are sure to be improved because the odds are against having their two most important offensive players hurt again. Most crucial to the bounce-back is Matt Ryan, who threw 14 interceptions and 22 touchdown passes last season. Running back Michael Turner, who was hurt for the second half of 2009, is also back, joining a strong three-pronged running attack. The Falcons' biggest off-season move was the signing of cornerback Dunta Robinson, a needed upgrade for the pass defense. Atlanta also got a break when defensive tackle Jonathan Babineaux, who had six sacks last season, was suspended for only one game after violating the league's substance-abuse policy. That game is against Pittsburgh, which will be without the suspended quarterback Ben Roethlisberger. The Falcons won nine games with Ryan and Turner missing time. Ten victories and at least a wild-card spot seem in easy reach.

CAVIANO--Michael L. Today is your 60th birthday. We still can not believe you are not here to celebrate it and constantly grapple with how few years you were given. However, it has been said that life is not measured by the number of breaths we take, but by the moments that take our breath away. You took our breath away more moments than we can count. So we concentrate on those moments and remember them and you forever. Dolores and all of us who love you so very much

Did 49ers Coach Mike Singletary annoy someone in the scheduling office? The Niners open with three of their first four games on the road, with the home game against the Saints. Still, this is a team on the rise after finishing 8-8 last season, coupling a premier N.F.L. defense (fourth best in points allowed in 2009) with the hope that quarterback Alex Smith will make a big leap by playing the same offense for two consecutive years. Smith is surrounded by plenty of talent, including tight end Vernon Davis and the emerging receiver Michael Crabtree. Do not look for Smith to finally get to use the spread offense he prefers, though. Singletary wants to be an old-school, smash-mouth team - he defined that style as a player - and the Niners upgraded their offensive line in the draft to that end. Their schedule will not make it easy - they also play a ''home'' game in London and play the Cardinals twice late in the season - but the Niners should get above .500 for the first time since 2002, and that may be enough to win the division. You have to wonder if the Cardinals have begged Kurt Warner to put his retirement papers through a shredder instead of in the mail to the league office. Arizona was being written off because of Warner's departure and the roster churn that included the losses of Antrel Rolle, Anquan Boldin and Karlos Dansby. Then Matt Leinart failed in his latest chance to secure the starting quarterback job. Derek Anderson offers the possibility of explosive plays, but the Cardinals are unlikely to generate Warner-like point totals. So it will be up to the running tandem of Beanie Wells and Tim Hightower to power the offense. Weeks 4 and 5, against the Chargers and the Saints, will show whether Arizona can score enough to remain in the playoff picture.

SHMERLER--Paula. The Board and Staff of the JCC of Mid-Westchester mourns the passing of Paula Shmerler. The Shmerlers have been long-time JCC leaders and benefactors and we want to extend our sincerest condolences to Ed, Cindy, Ford and the entire family.

The ''Living In'' article on Aug. 15 about Fair Haven, N.J., misstated the names of two schools. They are the Rumson Country Day School, not the Rumson Day School, and the Rumson-Fair Haven Regional High School, not the Fair Haven-Rumson Regional High School.
BECKER--Barbara. Beloved wife of the late Stuart. Loving mother of Richard (Fran Tenorio) Becker and Susan (Joseph) Nicholson. Proud and cherished grandmother of Douglas and Anne Nicholson.

ROSSKAMM--Stephen, 93, died peacefully on September 3, at Crane's Mill in West Caldwell, NJ. He fled Nazi Germany in 1937 and lived for many years in Flushing, NY. He leaves his much loved and loving family: his wife of 63 years, Margaret, his children Evelyn Rosskamm Shalom (Stephen Rosskamm Shalom) and Vivian Rosskamm (John Lewis), his grandchildren, Jessica Shalom Greenberg (Richard Greenberg) and Alexander Rosskamm Shalom (Andrea Delbanco), and his great-grandchildren Emma, Anna, Nathaniel, and Rosie. He rose from stock boy to executive at Bernhard Ulmann Company, and kept on a first-name basis with everyone. After retirement he devoted himself to his family, work for various charities, his unique collages and hutches, his painting, and his kidding. Steve will be dearly missed. Funeral services are private.

An article last Sunday about the Donmar Warehouse, a British theater company, misidentified the designer of the sets and costumes for the Donmar production of ''Mary Stuart'' that transferred to Broadway in 2009. He is Anthony Ward -- not Christopher Oram, who has designed other Donmar shows, including ''Red.'' The article also misstated Donmar's annual income. It is £3.8 million (about $6 million) for budgeting purposes, not £3.8.

ISRAELOW--Ruth. We send our deepest condolences to Marvin, Dorian, Ed, Arlene, Jacob, Ben, Asher, David and Hannah. We too, have lost our Grandma Ruth. She will always have a special place in our hearts as her mandlebread will have at our table. Grandma Ruth was a classy lady with a heart big enough to include us as her own. She was one of a kind. Always seemed to see the bright side of things and she always saw the best in her children and grandchildren. In her own unique and wonderful way she was always "simply stunning". We will miss her dearly. Katja, Michael, Joya, Forest, Isaac and Sophia.

MILLER--Lisa, on June 16, 2010, following a valiant struggle with cancer. She served for 20 years on the board of Metro Hort Group, an organization of horticultural professionals. As an educator for Cornell University Cooperative Extension, she was instrumental in creating numerous community gardens in Manhattan. Passionate balletomane, gifted photographer, serious yoga practitioner, talented art scholar, and ardent feminist, she is much missed by family and friends. See the full obituary online.

9 P.M. (HGTV) ALL AMERICAN HANDYMAN Don't let the title fool you. Five women will join 15 men to compete in an assortment of fix-it challenges in this search for the country's best nonprofessional Jack (or Jill) of all trades. The grand prize: a $10,000 shopping spree at Sears and a development deal with HGTV. The contest begins as the 20 finalists (one, Matthew McGuire, is above) are winnowed to 10 after their ingenuity and construction skills are sized up by the show's judges, Mike Holmes and Scott McGillivray. The guest judge is Bill Kiss, the chief marketing officer for tools and hardware for Sears. After the first cut, the remaining competitors will undertake a challenge in which they must identify the elements of a botched construction job; a power-tool test to determine their accuracy at measuring and cutting; and a trivia quiz. Molly Culver hosts. And Part 1 of Mr. Holmes's new two-episode special, ''Lien on Me,'' in which he helps a couple whose contractor has walked off the job, leads in at 8. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURIn conjunction with the publication of his autobiography, ''A Journey: My Political Life,'' the former British prime minister Tony Blair reflects on taking his country to war in Iraq, the fight against extremism and his biggest fears. He also shares his thoughts on American leaders, including the former presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush and the former vice president Dick Cheney, as well as his impressions of Princess Diana and Queen Elizabeth II.

Now that we're practically on a first-name basis with Doutzen, Lakshmi and Anja, it's time we meet Bambi, Fei Fei and Kat. They are some of the new and almost-like-new faces we'll be seeing next week at the New York fashion shows. This is crunch time for casting directors, with meetings over the weekend, as more new models arrive in town and people start making decisions about whom they want on their runways. On Thursday, after I spoke in the morning with the casting director Ashley Brokaw, whose New York clients include Narciso Rodriguez, Proenza Schouler and Rag & Bone, she reported in an e-mail message: ''Just saw a girl Jessica Clarke @DNA. VERY excited about her. Classic supermodel material from New Zealand.''

LA CHAUX-DE-FONDS, Switzerland -- Louis Chevrolet, the namesake of the famed automobile, was not French. Yes, he did spend a number of his formative years living in France. But he was, in fact, Swiss, and born in this town in the Jura Mountains of northern Switzerland on Dec. 25, 1878. But he is largely unremembered here; the house in which he was born has long since been torn down. And folks at the tourist office responded with ''who?'' when I asked about him on a recent visit. But on Aug. 27 and 28, a small but ardent band of admirers gathered here to remember him and to hold an event in his honor that was attended by an estimated 3,000 people.

VARADI--Dr. Marilyn (Meyrow), age 67, on September 1, 2010 of Great Neck and Floral Park. Beloved wife of the late John, loving mother of Lisa, adored sister of Dr. Arnold Meyrow (Mary), aunt of Sarah (Daniel) and Seth. Loving soulmate of Charles "Chick" Rudy. Special friend to Nancie Rudy Rosen (Dan), and "step-grandmother" of Justice and Bodhi Rosen. She was a supervising psychologist in the NYC Board of Education, Adjunct Professor at NYU and Queens College. We deeply mourn the loss of a woman of spirit, inner strength, love and genuine loyalty to friends and family. Her courage, kindness and generosity inspire those who knew and loved her. Services will be held Tuesday, September 7 at 1pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck.

An article last Sunday about Morgan J. Freeman, executive producer of the television shows ''16 and Pregnant'' and ''Teen Mom,'' erroneously included a British documentary among films he produced. It was Bill Jones, not Mr. Freeman, who was the executive producer for ''49 Up,'' the most recent movie in Michael Apted's series of ''Up'' documentaries, which follow the lives of British children born in 1964.

KATZ--Stanley J.,passed away peacefully, July 22, 2010. Pilot, musician, businessman, photographer, animal lover and bon vivant, he was a man of many talents and strong convictions, all accompanied by irrepressible good humor and wit. We sorely miss and deeply mourn the passing of this very special man.

VARADI--Dr. Marilyn. To my "Mar." There will never be another you. We tried to beat the odds, but couldn't. Your beauty, spirit, love and encouragement will always be with me. You will live in my heart forever. Love, Chick

BROWN--Townsend, of West Palm Beach, FL, died August 31, 2010. Born June 6, 1930 in Chicago, IL to Charles Edward and Helen Deshler Brown. Survived by companion of 30 years Philip Tilearcio. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Good Sam Inpatient Unit, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

A report in the In Transit column last Sunday about Continental's being the first domestic carrier to introduce the new Boeing 787 Dreamliner gave an outdated date for the introduction of the new aircraft by a foreign carrier. After the section had gone to press, Boeing said it expected delivery of the first 787s in the middle of the first quarter of 2011. ANA will therefore not introduce the 787s ''later this year.''

BLINK and you might have missed Nicolas Ghesquiere's nod to Cindy Sherman in his fall collection for Balenciaga. But printed on several of the papery trapeze tops are pull-quotes and excerpts from published reviews of her art. ''I have always loved the work of Cindy Sherman,'' Mr. Ghesquiere said. And the admiration is, of course, mutual. In 2008, Ms. Sherman created a series of six self-portraits featuring herself as over-the-top fashion characters -- the intimidating magazine editor, the ardent party-hopper -- all dressed in head-to-toe Balenciaga. And, as part of Fashion's Night Out, Balenciaga will give the series its United States debut at its Chelsea boutique.

RUBIN--J. Gordon. His death on August 25 in Sarasota, FL leaves the world a poorer place. Gentle, gracious, generous, he was all of those. A man without pretension or artifice despite his vast accomplishments, he is missed by Andrew, the son who adores him; by Judy Cory, his loving and loved companion to the end; and by his brother Miles, brothers-in-law Ernie and Stanley Bogen; their wives: Nancy, Rita and Roberta; and their children. Donations may be made to Didi Hirsch Mental Health Services, 4760 South Sepulveda Blvd., Culver City, CA 90230.

LEARSON--Katherine, 67, passed away August 31, 2010 in Manhattan, NY. The cause was complications related to leukemia. Kate was an accomplished artist, author, model, adventurer and most of all -- beloved mother. She will be dearly missed by her family and many friends. Her endless kindness, love and caring live with us all. She is survived by her three sisters, two sons, a grandson and beloved dog, Max. Services and reception will be held at 3pm at St. James church in Manhattan on Friday, September 10th.

ISRAELOW--Ruth (September 23, 1920 September 2, 2010) died peacefully at home with all of her children and grandchildren at her bedside. A wartime bride, she was pre-deceased by her husband of 51 years, Louis Israelow, Founder and CEO of Royal Foods Inc., Woodbridge, NJ. A proud UJA Lion of Judah, she was also an active member of Hadassah and volunteer at Daughters of Israel (West Orange, NJ) and Metro West JCC. Loved and admired by all who knew her, she lived with grace and dignity. She inspired us with her courage, warmth and open heart. She was everyone's "Grandma Ruth." Ruth is survived by sons, Marvin and Edward; daughters-in-law, Dorian Goldman and Arlene Gardner; and grandchildren, Jacob, Asher, Benjamin, Hannah, and David Israelow. We will miss her love in our lives, her smile and her caring. The funeral service is on Sunday, September 5th at 11am in the Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston. Contributions may be made to MetroWest UJA, Daughters of Israel and B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, NJ

My wife and I have occasionally celebrated our wedding anniversary, Dec. 31, in Europe, once in London at Rules and once in Paris at a small cafe near the Eiffel Tower. This year we are contemplating Vienna, and would like some suggestions for dining in a very Viennese style, but not at a luxurious price. K. G., New York A.I contacted Sarah Wildman, who has written several articles about Vienna for the Travel section, including ''36 Hours in Vienna'' (June 15, 2008). In an e-mail, she recommended the grand New Year's Eve Kaiserball (kaiserball.com) at the Hofburg Imperial Palace, which she mentioned in her article, ''Putting on the White Tie and Gown'' (Dec. 23, 2007), about Vienna's ball season. Tickets start at 140 euros, without table reservation; admission at 9:45 p.m. (students are 60 euros). She also suggested dinner at Vestibul (vestibuel.at) in the Burgtheater. It offers ''high style, great food, new Austrian cuisine, in the former dining room of the Hapsburgs,'' she wrote in the e-mail. The price for the five-course menu will be about 130 euros, without drinks.

To the Sports Editor: I feel that the statistics in tennis are flawed. In particular, I feel that analysts would do well to track how many serves are returned but not in play. If the opponent gets a racket on a serve but sends it into the stands or hits it off the frame, that should be reflected positively in the accounting of the server's performance.
PINE--Seymour. Loving father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Always there when you needed him. Rest In Peace. All our love, Connie, Eddie and the Katz kids
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Williams's Injury Needs Explanation,'' Aug. 27: Serena Williams does not lose the right that we all have under federal law not to share information regarding medical care.

Eight of the last 11 Super Bowl losers failed to qualify for the playoffs the next season. Get serious. As long as Peyton Manning is upright, the Colts are a Super Bowl contender. Bill Polian, the Colts' president, has surrounded Manning with superb talent, so much so that Indianapolis's 2007 first-round draft pick, Anthony Gonzalez, could be the odd man out in a fabulous group of receivers. The offensive line has gotten much bigger with the hopes of establishing a ground game, but how much does that really matter? Manning threw 571 passes last year and was a coach's decision from leading Indianapolis to a likely undefeated regular season. The defense, which allowed fewer than 20 points a game, should be better in Year 2 under Larry Coyer because Bob Sanders, a supremely gifted safety, is healthy again. The only problem the Colts face is that the expectations are so high, if they don't win it all, the season will be a huge disappointment. They will reach at least the A.F.C. championship game. Assume that the Titans are not going to start the season 0-6 again. Vince Young will be the quarterback from the first snap, and the Titans managed an 8-2 run to finish last season. Chris Johnson is unlikely to run for 2,000 yards again, and losing tight end Alge Crumpler and his blocking to New England could hinder Johnson. Still, the offense is good enough to overcome a defense that was a disaster last season after losing the coordinator Jim Schwartz and defensive tackle Albert Haynesworth. Tennessee loaded up on defensive players in the draft. They will have to come together quickly to make up for the losses of linebacker Keith Bulluck and defensive end Kyle Vanden Bosch to free agency, but if they do, the Titans could be a wild-card team.

THRAVALOS--Vasilios H.,passed away peacefully at his home in Riverdale, NY, on September 2, 2010 at the age of 81. He was born March 2, 1929 in Kardamyla, Chios, Greece to Haridimos and Katherine Thravalos. Fluent in Greek, English, French, Italian and Spanish, he was educated at Universita Scienze Marittima e Commerciale in Genoa, Italy and Saint Helen's School of High Commerce in London, England. Having served in the Greek military as a member of their special operations forces, he followed in the family tradition by embarking on a career at sea, which culminated in his elevation to the rank of Captain in the Greek Merchant Marine. In 1969, he immigrated to the United States and began a successful career as a shipping executive in New York City. A loving husband and wonderful father, he is survived by his beloved wife of 35 years, Evangeline, and their devoted son, Haridimos.

Stephen and Laurie, members of our Board of Directors, are dear friends whose commitment to Jewish social and humanitarian causes touches the lives of millions in New York, in Israel, and around the world. SCHLAFF--Marvin Allen, longtime United Nations official, died August 18 at his Greenwich Village home, of prostate cancer. He was born in Manhattan on August 14, 1926; public schools in the Bronx, and Birch Wathan; two years Columbia University's School of Engineering; U.S. Army, radio/radar mechanic; under G.I. Bill, Columbia College, B.A. 1948, and study in Paris; two years in Labor Division of the Marshall Plan. In 1952 returned to the U.S. with intent of becoming a union leader. Assembly-line worker in plants in California; communications equipment installer at Western Electric; active member of the Communications Workers of America. In 1953, he refused to sign a loyalty oath as required by the Bell System and told union members that they did not have to sign it as it was not a condition of employment; though he retained his job he lost his next union election and subsequently abandoned a union career. Moved to New York, M.A., Columbia's School of International Affairs; International Confederation of Free Trade Unions; International Labour Organisation, in Geneva and Addis Ababa. In 1965 joined the UN Secretariat, rising to the level of Director. As its Executive Officer was a prime mover in introducing word processing into the Department of Conference Services, which included the translation, printing, and publications sections. As Director of Program Planning worked on study recommending the creation of an integrated management information system in the UN. After retirement worked parttime as secretary of the joint appeals board/disciplinary committee, the UN's internal justice system. Survived by wife, Marcia; children Elizabeth of South Glastonbury, CT, Anthony of Brookline, MA, Abigail of Ann Arbor, MI; sister Ruth Meyers of Riverdale, NY; four grandchildren. Donations may be made to the New York Public Library, the neighborhood libraries.

When will the rest of the A.F.C. West give the Chargers a run for the division title? Not this year. For all the off-season turmoil -- whither Vincent Jackson and his holdout? -- San Diego has the most talent by far. The passing game, even without Jackson, is deep and explosive and figures only to get better now that teams have to pay attention to Ryan Mathews instead of LaDainian Tomlinson, who led the 31st-ranked rushing offense last season. Still, you get the feeling the window is about to close on this team. Several big names, like linebacker Shawne Merriman and returner Darren Sproles, are in their contract years, and the Chargers simply can't keep racing through the regular season (they won their final 11 games in 2009 and have one of the easiest schedules this season) only to collapse in the playoffs. Last season's lackluster playoff loss to the Jets might be pinned on Norv Turner's insistence on giving the ball to Tomlinson, but the excuses, and the Chargers' dominance, are running out. San Diego should win the division again with ease, but every other team is aggressively trying to improve in the meantime. The Broncos would have had a much better chance of challenging the Chargers if the Pro Bowl linebacker Elvis Dumervil, the league's sack leader in 2009, had not torn a pectoral muscle in training camp. That season-ending injury will put extreme pressure on a superb secondary that includes Brian Dawkins and Champ Bailey. Denver's run defense ranked 26th last season, and the front seven has been made over. Still, the biggest question marks are all over the offense after the Broncos traded Brandon Marshall and Tony Scheffler, then drafted Tim Tebow. And left tackle Ryan Clady tore a patellar tendon in the spring, endangering his chances of being ready for the first game. Kyle Orton received a preseason contract extension, a testament to his fine performance and an attempt to forestall what seemed an inevitable quarterback controversy. Orton will be the starter this year, with Tebow used in designated situations, including at the goal line. For Orton and a reconstituted offense, that might be a hollow victory.

This was not some action film or video game, but a mental exercise in the imagination of the boy, Philip Califano.

How concerned should the Cowboys be about preseason injuries, particularly on the line for an already somnolent offense? Plenty. The Cowboys are deep, talented and balanced, built to win a title, but injuries could quickly derail all of that. The Cowboys have a powerful running back group, and quarterback Tony Romo has many receiving options, especially if the rookie Dez Bryant returns to full speed after his high ankle sprain early in training camp. The Dallas defense remains a powerhouse, with linebacker DeMarcus Ware among the N.F.L.'s best defensive players. The Cowboys even shed their dreaded postseason curse last season, winning a wild-card game. But the N.F.C. East is always brutal, and the Cowboys' out-of-division schedule includes games at Minnesota, Green Bay, Indianapolis and Arizona, and a home game against New Orleans. The Cowboys may win the division, but getting the best conference record to gain home-field advantage and a first-round bye in the playoffs will be much more difficult.
Television Neil Genzlinger

A rather eventful day in Yankee-land Saturday began with Alex Rodriguez and Andy Pettitte facing each other in a simulated game; continued with Javier Vazquez laboring through four and two-thirds innings in his return to the rotation; and, at least on the field, came to an end after everything went the Yankees' way in a crazy seventh inning. With two on and no outs, Joba Chamberlain caught Jose Bautista looking at a slider for strike three - except that the pitch appeared to be several inches outside. Bautista erupted and was ejected, and the next hitter, Vernon Wells, grounded into a double play. With two outs in the bottom of the inning, Marcus Thames hit his seventh homer in 10 games, and the Yankees went on to win, 7-5.

Back in July, on a meditation weekend at the Omega Institute in Rhinebeck, N.Y., I spied flaming-red bunches of sumac fruit standing out from the branches of a tree like tiki torches. They were so dramatic I was surprised I hadn't noticed them earlier. I spent the rest of the morning, when I was supposed to be meditating, gazing out the window at the fruit and ruminating over the great lemonade-like beverage it would make.

DRECHSLER--Dr. Max, eminent Manhattan psychotherapist, died August 27 while vacationing in Santa Fe, NM. Friends and colleagues will miss him deeply. A celebration of his life is being planned. Queries: 212-243-4970.

THIS article about the new World Trade Center is already out of date. The pace of construction is so swift that any status report these days gets overtaken rapidly by the arrival of new beams and columns, rebar and concrete, pipes and conduit. About 2,000 construction workers are on the job, weekends included, officials said, and that number will just keep rising. Visiting the site brings to mind the tumultuous first impressions of arrival in New York City: people, vehicles and objects are headed toward you from every direction at startling velocity, and the only prudent thing to do is to keep moving.

GREENE--Dawn M. The Jewish Museum joins in mourning the loss of Dawn Greene. We are privileged to be the beneficiary of Dawn's generosity, a legacy that grew initially from the interest of her late husband Jerome L. Greene, and one that became equally her own during the past decade. Their magnificent capital and endowment support has an enduring impact on the Museum's exhibitions and collections and on the audiences we serve. We deeply admired her as a woman of intelligence and insight, a lover of the arts, and a figure of elegance and style. We send our heartfelt condolences to Chris and Maggie, to Dawn's philanthropic colleagues, and to her friends. Joshua Nash, Chairman; Robert Pruzan, President; Joan Rosenbaum, Director

Watching Favre-a-thon 2010 unfold, the Packers might have stifled a giggle. They should not even pay attention. Green Bay is a Super Bowl-caliber team no matter what Favre does because General Manager Ted Thompson made the right bet at the right time on Aaron Rodgers, who is one of the top five quarterbacks in the league and looked particularly sharp in the preseason. If his line does not get Rodgers killed, the way it nearly did early last season, the offense will again be one of the most productive in the N.F.L. (The Packers were third in points scored last season.) The defense was seventh in points allowed, and although Al Harris and Charles Woodson are among the best cornerback tandems in the league, they are each at least 33 and injuries are taking a toll. Harris (knee) is on the physically unable to perform list and unavailable for at least six games. The best news for the Packers is that the schedule offers a relatively easy first six games before they play the Vikings, the Jets and the Cowboys in a row. After a bye, they face the Vikings, the Falcons and the 49ers. The Vikings do not particularly care that the rest of the league was astonished at the spectacle of their sending three players to cajole a colleague to come to work. If Brett Favre is anything close to what he was last season (33 touchdown passes, 7 interceptions) and if they can get Adrian Peterson to stop fumbling (seven last season), Minnesota has a chance to go deep in the playoffs. But Favre's job will probably be much tougher this season. His ankle is not well; his go-to receiver, Sidney Rice, is out for at least six games after hip surgery; and the speedy receiver Percy Harvin struggled during the preseason with migraines that have plagued him since childhood. The Vikings have to bank on offense because the defense is aging, the Packers are young and stacked, and the schedule is brutal (games against the Saints, the Jets and the Cowboys in the first six weeks). If this is Favre's last season - get back to us at this time next year - the Vikings are the ultimate win-now team. But they will need more than a wild card and a playoff road game to finally win a championship.

GITTLESON--Mildred. At 94 on September 2. A memorial service will be held at Commack Abbey, 96 Commack Road, Commack on September 12 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd. Woodbury, NY 11797.

He was a member of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, New York Yacht Club and North Hempstead Country Club. Services will take place 10:30am, Wednesday, September 8 at Westbury Friends with reception afterwards at Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to NYU Melanoma Research Fund.

LEVINE--Ellis, formerly of Boynton Beach, Florida and Great Neck, New York. Beloved husband and best friend of Betsey Strahl Levine for 65 years; devoted father of Robert and Rosemary Levine, Gary and Carol Levine, and Nancy Olson; loving grandfather of Matthew Levine, Lisa and Lenny Saavedra, Michael Olson, Daniel Olson and Benjamin Levine; delighted great-grandfather of Henry Ellis Saavedra. Veteran of WWII; graduate of Columbia College (1947); member of Phi Beta Kappa; retired major, U.S. Army Reserves; bridge life master. He treasured his family, his faith, his community and his country. A truly good man who will be missed.

The most taxing mental task that you'll undertake at many all-inclusive resorts is deciding between a margarita and a pina colada. But the Taheima Wellness Resort & Spa, just north of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, gives its guests more to ponder in a number of lectures by members of the faculty of the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute at the University of California, Berkeley. In the next weeklong session (''Cultural Legacies: Mexico Across Borders,'' Nov. 13 to 19), lectures will focus on the cultural relationship between the United States and Mexico. That session is followed by another, in which environmental scientists survey Mexico's biodiversity via field trips (''Flora, Fauna and the Politics of Biodiversity,'' Dec. 4 to 11). And in ''Mexico, Media and Democracy,'' Jan. 22 to 29, journalists from each side of the border gather to present lectures.

The picture of Mr. Obama, shown saluting as the remains of an Army sergeant killed in Afghanistan arrived at Dover Air Force Base, was taken by Susan Walsh, not Walse, of The Associated Press.

It has been a long time since their rival in New England did not enter the season as the A.F.C. East favorite, but the Jets may engineer a hostile takeover. If the new cornerback Antonio Cromartie can return to his 2007 form and Darrelle Revis ends his holdout, the Jets will have the best secondary, and the best defense, in football. The first-team offense struggled in the preseason; Mark Sanchez still makes too many mistakes, and the offensive line looked spotty. But the surprise was how much life appeared in LaDainian Tomlinson's legs. The real issue is that with so many big mouths and big egos, the Jets have raised expectations wildly and made themselves a target. In a closely bunched division, how well all those big names work together may determine whether the Jets are a well-publicized boom or bust. During training camp, one of the Patriots said, with eyebrows arched, ''Have you bought your Jets Super Bowl tickets yet?'' New England will not go quietly. The offense got the best news with the stunningly quick return from knee surgery of receiver Wes Welker, the outstanding training camp of Randy Moss (yes, he is in a contract year), the revival of the running game, and the impressive preseason of the rookie tight end Aaron Hernandez. But New England has issues on the offensive line, where guard Logan Mankins shows no sign of ending his holdout, and his backup, Nick Kaczur, had back surgery that could end his season. The defense, in search of a consistent pass rush, has suffered huge blows, with defensive end Ty Warren (hip) and cornerback Leigh Bodden (shoulder) lost for the season. The Patriots' young defensive backs, now thrust into more crucial roles with Bodden gone, looked promising in the preseason, a good sign considering the defense uncharacteristically struggled to hold late leads last season. But whether Bill Belichick can devise another slightly under-the-radar blue-collar special like the three that won Super Bowls will determine if the torch gets passed to the Jets.

My husband and I are traveling to Venice in December for six days, then heading on to Naples. Could you give me some tips to keep down my expenses - perhaps an inexpensive hotel in Venice? And what's the best way to travel to Naples? Is six days in Venice too long? Perhaps we should go on to Florence, Rome, then Naples? Jon and Harriett Clouse, Ashland City, Tenn. A.I suggest splitting your time between Venice and Florence, as Rome requires at least a week to see properly (and this will give you an excuse to return). The best way to travel in Italy is by train or car. From Venice's Santa Lucia station, it is a two- or three-hour train ride to Florence (raileurope.com). Or you can rent a car after you leave Venice and make the three-hour drive to Florence. From Florence you can take the train to Naples. The drive from Venice to Naples is seven to eight hours.
Classical Vivien Schweitzer

KASPAR--Paul J.,died on August 25th at age 74. His beloved wife Tamara and daughter Kelsey were by his side. He is also survived by sons David, Daniel and sister Joanna. With dedicated passion, Paul managed his dress manufacturing business founded with late father Joseph Kaspar. A star basketball player for UConn and on the courts of New York City, he also spent winters teaching skiing and summers fly-fishing. With ever-present wisdom, integrity and humor, Paul was a mentor and father-figure to many. His life was lived with steadfast faith and compassion. Paul's ashes will be scattered by family in his favorite river. Donations can be made to the ASPCA.
Pop/Jazz Nate Chinen

A few weeks ago, while working as a freelancer at a Manhattan advertising and marketing firm - in a job that was somewhat similar to my old job on the staff at a marketing firm in Fort Lee, N.J. - I got to wondering why so many people were still there after 8 p.m., and why there was a settled air of monotony suggesting that this was the way it was and always would be. How long ago was it that the working man wore a solid blue suit with a white shirt and a tie, carried an attache case instead of a knapsack or messenger bag, got to the office at 9 a.m. and left promptly at 5 p.m.? The 1940s? The '50s? The early '60s? Don't the sitcoms of yesteryear show him going home to a lovely wife in a cocktail dress and pearls who has a martini at the ready and dinner on the table?

Because of an editing error, a column last Sunday about the proposed high-speed rail system that would connect San Francisco and the major cities of California misstated the surname of a member of the board of the High-Speed Rail Authority. He is Rod Diridon, not Didiron.

In today's satellite-blanketed world of precise, GPS-determined maps, a splash of watercolor and some hand-written advice are nice, personal touches to pull out of your pocket while traveling. A la Carte Maps offers just that. The company was founded in 2009 by a pair of Swiss entrepreneurs and self-described ''flashpackers'' (backpackers with some extra flair -- and cash) who were tired of lugging overweight, out-of-date guidebooks around on their travels. So they started a company, contracted artists in major cities across Europe, Asia and the United States, and produced a line of hand-painted, neatly packaged city maps. And next month, they are adding another five destinations to their roster.

‘‘The ’57 Thunderbird is elegant, sporty — it’s a gentleman’s sports car,’’ says Evan Yurman, the design director of men’s jewelry and watches for David Yurman, not to mention a vintage car buff. Evan, who is the son of David Yurman, might very well be describing the company’s brand-new Classic 1957 Limited Edition watch, a sporty, elegant and, yes, gentlemanly timepiece that was inspired by cars from the ’50s and the Thunderbird’s instrument panel in particular. ‘‘I drive these kinds of cars a lot, and I’m always staring at the speedometer to see where I’m at,’’ he says. For Yurman, the ’50s were the golden era of American design, and not just in the automobile industry. ‘‘I tip my hat to it and hope I can only add to this legacy.’’ When it comes to cars, however, it’s ultimately what’s under the hood that gets him revved up: he loves the ’57 T-Bird for its beauty more than its brawn. ‘‘It is a cruiser, a cream puff,’’ says Yurman, who instead owns a ’66 Bel Air and a ’69 Ford Mustang. ‘‘I go for the one where some guy in the factory said, ‘Let’s make this car as fast as we can.’ ’’

MONTICELLO, N.Y. -- Altar is the project-name of the American duo Sunn O))) and the Japanese trio Boris, convened in front of five enormous stacks of amplifiers. By the end of its show Sunday night at All Tomorrow's Parties, it had grown to 10 members; a singer, Jesse Sykes, drifted in and drifted out. There were no rhythms, just drum beats that ended before they really started, like arrested lead-ins to a great song. There was a duet between bowed cymbal and bowed double-bass, and frequent use of a large gong.

Mikhail Youzhny used superb anticipation to read John Isner's powerful serve in his impressive four-set win. Over the last few months there has been an increase in the concern and discussion over a possible double-dip recession, particularly after unemployment reports over the summer showed that the nation was shedding tens of thousands of jobs. However, a key element lacking in the talk of double-dip recessions is what actually caused past recessions - that is, what are the primary reasons an economy slows to the point where its growth contracts for at least two quarters - followed by an analysis of whether those conditions exist in the current economic environment. And judging from a variety of indicators, the potential for a double-dip recession seem small.

The rapper and producer Kanye West posted a series of messages on his Twitter account in yet another attempt to explain his behavior at last year’s MTV Video Music Awards.
The former British Prime Minister Tony Blair was greeted by a barrage of plastic bottles, flip-flops and eggs at the first public reading of his new book on Saturday in Dublin.
Heading into the Labor Day weekend, the summer cable telecasts “Jersey Shore” and “Camp Rock 2” were the two television standouts.
The songwriter Kara DioGuardi is leaving “American Idol,” the Fox singing competition, after only two seasons.
The actress and playwright Lisa Kron (“Well”) is set to host the 2010 IT Awards, which recognize the achievements of Off Off Broadway theater.
Jennifer Saunders, the creator, producer and star of the tart British comedy “Absolutely Fabulous,” has been hired to write the book for the musical, “Viva Forever,” Playbill reported.

The conductor Seiji Ozawa scored a triumph of a limited sort at the Saito Kinen Festival in Matsumoto, Japan, on Sunday as he returned to the public stage for the first time since surgery for esophageal cancer in January.
Cornell University agricultural experts and others worry that the emerald ash borer has the potential to kill ash trees throughout North America.
The Tannery Pond summer concert series in New Lebanon, N.Y., included performances of Beethoven, Liszt, Schoenberg, Czerny and Cage.
Photos from the music festival in Monticello, N.Y.
The Brazilian pop star Ivete Sangalo sold out Madison Square Garden on the Brazilian Day festival weekend.
With nudity and more, Ann Liv Young’s “Cinderella” at the Issue Project Room in Brooklyn meant to be provocative, but this critic found it dull.
The Mets, who have struggled to score runs all season, set season highs for runs (18) and hits (21), and took advantage of the sloppy Cubs.
At the All Tomorrow’s Parties festival in the Catskills, Iggy and the Stooges played “Raw Power.”

Mafia II is full of scenes reminiscent of “Goodfellas,” “The Godfather” and other pop-culture takes on organized crime.
From one deal in the White House Top 12 event, two very different contracts.
“We Are Family,” a film based on “Stepmom,” is about a hard-to-believe relationship between two women.
Existential concepts like authenticity and selfhood, and people’s ability or inability to apprehend reality, lie at the heart of Tom McCarthy’s disappointing and highly self-conscious new novel.
New CDs from Sara Bareilles, Vijay Iyer and the Steeldrivers.
A New York dominatrix taught Domination 101 to Sutton Foster and others in Second Stage’s “Trust” so they could portray S&M accurately.
The Ghetto Film School in the Bronx aims to broaden the pool of filmmaking talent by providing opportunities for young people who might otherwise be overlooked.
Alex Rodriguez was in the lineup for the first time since Aug. 20 and beat out a slow groundball for an infield hit.
For Mark V. Hurd, landing a top position at Oracle would be a quick rebound after a tumultuous exit.
Movie attendance was down, but some films — like “Toy Story 3” and “Inception” — made out very, very well.
Minnesota Vikings defensive back Husain Abdullah is a Muslim who fasts during Ramadan, despite the physical demands of the preseason.
It was unclear how much money nervous depositors withdrew Sunday as fears of bankruptcy spread for the fourth consecutive day.
Venus Williams, Kim Clijsters and Rafael Nadal put away what were expected to be tough challengers, but fourth-seeded Andy Murray lost to Stanislas Wawrinka.
Palestinian and Israeli leaders expressed hope in their first public utterances since last week’s round of peace talks in Washington.
A coordinated attack on one of the main military commands in Baghdad punctuated a sharp rise in violence as the United States declared an official end to its combat mission.

Grandpa we loved you so much and you will be deeply missed but always in our hearts. Melissa, Bradley & Gavin

SHANGHAI -- Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications equipment giant, made its first big move into the global smartphone market on Thursday by announcing the release of Ideos, which the company calls an affordably priced device preinstalled with Google's Android 2.2 operating system. The phone goes on sale next Friday in Hong Kong and is expected to be available later this year in North America, Europe, Latin America and other parts of Asia. Huawei calls it an''entry-level'' mobile phone, priced at $100 to $200.

WIGHT--Richard James. September 4, aged 61. Beloved husband of Jennifer Sutherland, devoted father of Stewart Wight (Katherine), Falls Church, Va; Russell Wight, New York; and Christine Wight, Atlanta. Doting grandfather of Elena Wight. Born in San Diego and raised in Paradise, CA., he received an A.B. from UC Berkeley, M.Sc. from the London School of Economics, and J.D. from Columbia. For 32 years he worked as an associate and partner at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley, and McCloy, in New York, training two generations of banking attorneys in the intricacies of loan documentation. In 2008 he taught a course in American legal principles at Brest State University in Belarus. His book The LSTA's Complete Credit Agreement Guide received a Burton Award for legal writing. Visitation at Robert Gray Funeral Home, 49 Jordan St., Skaneateles, NY, September 6, 1-3pm. Funeral at St. James Episcopal Church, 96 E. Genesee St., Skaneateles, September 7, 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation.

UDON THANI, Thailand -- In front of the charred ruins of the municipal hall here, a huge poster carries the photographs of 76 people being sought in an attack on the building more than three months ago, on the day the antigovernment ''red-shirt'' protests were crushed in Bangkok. Only 11 have been caught. Scores of people are in hiding, many of them sheltered by a mostly sympathetic population. Scores more, arrested at the scene, are being held without bail.

THRAVALOS--Vasilios H.,passed away peacefully at his home in Riverdale, NY, on September 2, 2010 at the age of 81. He was born March 2, 1929 in Kardamyla, Chios, Greece to Haridimos and Katherine Thravalos. Fluent in Greek, English, French, Italian and Spanish, he was educated at Universita Scienze Marittima e Commerciale in Genoa, Italy and Saint Helen's School of High Commerce in London, England. Having served in the Greek military as a member of their special operations forces, he followed in the family tradition by embarking on a career at sea, which culminated in his elevation to the rank of Captain in the Greek Merchant Marine. In 1969, he immigrated to the United States and began a successful career as a shipping executive in New York City. A loving husband and wonderful father, he is survived by his beloved wife of 35 years, Evangeline, and their devoted son, Haridimos.

The Advertising column on Thursday, about the revamping of Scholastic Books' marketing, misstated the nature of the Web site teachforus.org, a site for which the Scholastic Book Club is the national sponsor. It is a blog for Teach for America teachers and alumni, not a network for alumni alone.

Consumer Watchdog, a consumer group, has long been critical of Google and some of the comments that Eric Schmidt, the company's chief executive, has made about privacy online. On Thursday, the group took its objections to a new level with a 540-square-foot video advertisement in Times Square in New York that shows Mr. Schmidt as an unctuous ice cream truck driver who knows everything about everyone and happily offers free ice cream in exchange for full body scans. (The video is available on YouTube, which is owned by Google.)

Loving husband of Carol nee Fassler, devoted father to Wendy Benoist (Gray), Cindy, James, and Elizabeth Posner (Ross), beloved grandfather of five. Donations in his memory can be made to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL.

Eric Alpenfels, the director of instruction at the Pinehurst Golf Academy in North Carolina, has spent hundreds of hours researching how average golfers putt. Alpenfels has noticed, as many of us with children have, that kids often sink almost all of their short putts while older players - like teenagers and adults - will struggle to make every knee-knocking four-footer. This is probably true because to a child, playing with a general sense of golf innocence, a short putt is simple. You're just roll that little ball into a bigger hole.

An article on Friday about BP's concerns over a proposed ban on its future drilling in the Gulf of Mexico misspelled the surname of the executive vice president of BP America. He is David Nagel, not Nagle.

WARD--John Gerard Jr. ("Jack"). Died September 3 at the age of 66. A graduate of Fordham University Law School, Jack was an attorney who provided estate services to many New Yorkers during the last 40 years. As the grandson of William J. Ward, founder of The Bank of Coney Island, he managed Ward Realty, representing the last of the original families owning property in Coney Island. He was a former president of the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce, a member of the school board and Water for Life committee at Our Lady of Mercy parish in Forest Hills, and a board member of Camp Mark Seven in Old Forge, NY. He will be dearly remembered by his wife, Mary Beth; three children, John Ward of Huntington, Long Island, Faith Ward of Baltimore, and Kathleen Whitaker of Los Angeles; three sisters; three grandchildren; extended family; and devoted friends. Visiting at Fox Funeral Home Forest Hills, Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at our Lady of Mercy Church Thursday 10:45am, interment Chestertown Rural Cemetery Chestertown NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Camp Mark Seven, 144 Mohawk Hotel Road, Old Forge, NY 13420, or the Archdiocese of San Antonio Catholic Deaf Ministry, P.O. Box 7783, San Antonio, TX 78207, would be greatly appreciated.

Ever wonder if new golf balls bought on sale in September will still be as good as new the following spring or summer? Ever wonder if new balls bought two or three years ago have lost any of their distance or performance capabilities? The answer is that new golf balls - if stored under normal conditions - will last many years without deteriorating. In fact, the United States Golf Association's Research and Test Center stores every one of the thousands of balls it tests each year in massive file cabinets for five years. At the end of the five years, testers keep one model of each ball for future reference and donate the remaining thousands to junior golf programs.

Perched high above an industrial stretch of East Williamsburg, a menacing robot nine feet high and seven feet wide surveys the street below, watching cars steal past graffitied factory buildings as if they were prey. Its fierce head sways and dips when a wooden rudder protruding from the back of its neck catches the breeze. This is the Brooklyn Griffin. It almost never was. An earlier edition was destroyed on orders from an unsympathetic building manager.

ISRAELOW--Ruth (September 23, 1920 September 2, 2010) died peacefully at home with all of her children and grandchildren at her bedside. A wartime bride, she was pre-deceased by her husband of 51 years, Louis Israelow, Founder and CEO of Royal Foods Inc., Woodbridge, NJ. A proud UJA Lion of Judah, she was also an active member of Hadassah and volunteer at Daughters of Israel (West Orange, NJ) and Metro West JCC. Loved and admired by all who knew her, she lived with grace and dignity. She inspired us with her courage, warmth and open heart. She was everyone's "Grandma Ruth." Ruth is survived by sons, Marvin and Edward; daughters-in-law, Dorian Goldman and Arlene Gardner; and grandchildren, Jacob, Asher, Benjamin, Hannah, and David Israelow. We will miss her love in our lives, her smile and her caring. The funeral service is on Sunday, September 5th at 11am in the Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston. Contributions may be made to MetroWest UJA, Daughters of Israel and B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, NJ

For my 13th and final week on the road, the agenda was packed with three great destinations: Birmingham, Ala., for its rich civil rights history and darn good barbecue; Savannah, Ga., for its enchanting squares and gracious 19th-century homes, and Washington, for its 6-year-old Leo and 3-year-old Grady, otherwise known as my nephews.

In the 2004 film “A Day Without a Mexican,” all of California’s Mexicans suddenly disappear. The state wakes up to a world with no gardeners, nannies, strawberry pickers, maids, cooks, dishwashers. Through extreme exaggeration, the mockumentary makes point that without the Mexicans, the economy would essentially grind to a halt, and it satirizes those who want to send immigrants back across the border — or stop them from coming in. Presumably, if these abandoned low wage jobs were filled by legal workers making legal wages, everything would cost a whole lot more.

The cases in which we are most drawn to philosophy are precisely the cases in which we feel as though there is something pulling us toward one side of a question but also something pulling us, perhaps equally powerfully, toward the other.

LANDOVER, Md. — With a little more than two minutes left in Monday night’s game, Boise State seemed headed to a loss against Virginia Tech that would inevitably energize the skeptics. The 10th-ranked Hokies had the ball and a four-point lead. The third-ranked Broncos had two timeouts and a prayer. But after a defensive stop, a punt and one more memorable drive, Boise State emerged with a 33-30 victory.

The artistic team of Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla will represent the United States at the 2011 Venice Biennale. The duo, who have been working together since 1995 and live in San Juan, P.R., were chosen by the Federal Advisory Committee on International Exhibitions, a group of arts professionals organized by the National Endowment for the Arts to advise the State Department. Their work explores relationships among art, politics and international identity through performances pieces, sculpture, photography and sound-and-video. This will be the first time a collaborative, rather than a single artist, will represent the United States and the first time that a combination of performance and installation will occupy the pavilion. The Indianapolis Museum of Art was selected as the commissioning institution for the 2011 United States pavilion and Lisa Freiman, chairman of the Indianapolis Museum of Art’s contemporary art department, will be the commissioner. She will organize the exhibition, which will include six new works by the collaborative team developed specifically for the United States pavilion, a 1930s Palladian-style structure designed by the architects Delano & Aldrich.

There’s no lack of cultural references in the architect turned men’s wear designer Siki Im’s life — he was born in Cologne, Germany, to Korean parents; had a classical German education; studied at Oxford; and now lives in New York. So when the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award winner sets out to create a symbolic mash-up, he’s got the chops to do it. His collections make tongue-in-cheek literary references, blur the lines between masculine and feminine attire, and even manage to slyly subvert Savile Row tailoring. Not bad for someone who says he got into fashion by accident. The Moment stopped by Im’s studio recently for a preview of his spring 2011 collection, which he’ll unveil in a presentation tomorrow night.

BAGHDAD — This chrome-plated Kalashnikov AK-47 assault rifle, with a pearl hand grip and receiver, was manufactured by an Iraqi weapons factory which produced personalized assault rifles for Saddam Hussein’s family and friends. Bearing a tiny image of the dictator near the sighting mechanism, it was looted after the 2003 invasion and has been returned to Iraq along with hundreds of other items, as Steven Lee Myers reports.
