Charles Yu’s first novel, “How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe,” was reviewed for us this past weekend by Ander Monson, who called it “a complex, brainy, genre-hopping joyride of a story, far more than the sum of its component parts.” He also compared the book (narrated by a time-machine repairman who lives with a virtual dog and a neurotic piece of software) to the work of Douglas Adams. “Like Adams,” Monson wrote, Yu is “very funny, usually proportional to the wildness of his inventions.”

Parents of girls are 5 percent more likely to divorce than parents of boys. Economists first analyzed the data that way in 2003, when Gordon Dahl at the University of Rochester and Enrico Moretti at U.C.L.A., identified that gap, and noted that it widened as you added boys or girls to a family. Parents of three girls, for instance, are 10 percent more likely to split than are parents of three boys. And, they found, an unmarried couple is more likely to marry if they learn their unborn child will be a boy than a girl.

A week from Tuesday will be the second anniversary of Lehman Brothers’ bankruptcy and the ensuing panic that helped spawn the deepest recession since the Great Depression. Yet two years on, a mystery remains about the fateful weekend before Lehman’s fall, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

The National Football League, National Science Foundation and NBC have teamed up to show how pro football is full of cool science principles.

Two shows begin this week on CW: “Nikita,” an adaptation of “La Femme Nikita,” and “Hellcats,” about cheerleaders.

Republicans now have approximately a one-in-four chance of winning enough Senate seats in the Nov. 2 elections to claim an outright majority of the chamber, FiveThirtyEight's latest forecasting model shows.

Last week Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, unveiled a new version of the Apple TV, which is smaller and, at $99, less expensive than the previous model.

Geely Automobile Holdings said Tuesday that the Geely brand would be gone by 2012. However, the Chinese auto company will soldier on with its Gleagle, Emgrand and Shanghai Englon brands. In other words, Geely will no longer market a car that bears the parent company's name.
An 860-square-foot unit on the top floor of a 19th century apartment building with two bedrooms is on the market for 4.5 million kronor ($620,000).

Steven Lee Myers writes in The New York Times that two American soldiers were killed Tuesday when a firefight erupted inside an Iraqi Army base. They were the first American casualties since President Obama declared an official end to the combat mission in Iraq.

Bill Parcells, the former Giants and Jets coach who has rebuilt five franchises as either a coach or a general manager, will no longer run the Miami Dolphins. On Tuesday, the team abruptly announced in a two-sentence statement that Parcells, who in one season turned a one-win team into the American Football Conference East champion, would remain with the club as a daily consultant but that Jeff Ireland, his protégé, would assume full control over all aspects and decisions relating to the team and its support staff.

While Andrea Collarini moves through the boys singles draw at the United States Open, discussion is jump-starting again about his move earlier in the year from the Argentine tennis association to the United States Tennis Association.

His career as an Internet guru began with being interrogated by federal agents while in high school. Now the Web entrepreneur Sean Parker is about to be portrayed on the big screen by Justin Timberlake.

Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky said on Tuesday afternoon that he had asked the Justice Department to assign observers to New York City for next week's primary election because he was concerned that the use of a new voting method might result in "voter confusion and disenfranchisement."

This week's restaurant review is of Fornino Park Slope, Michael Ayoub's return to the Brooklyn neighborhood he helped shape with Cucina, and to the very spot on Fifth Avenue where he ran that restaurant nearly 20 years ago. It's a polished-up neighborhood joint, not at all glitzy or glam, and it manages to invoke a Brooklyn that has very little interest in apartment prices in the Flatiron, or black radio cars taking anyone home to Chelsea or the Upper West Side.

The top-seeded women's doubles team of Gisela Dulko of Argentina and Flavia Pennetta of Italy fell in surprisingly easy fashion to Vania King of the United States and Yaroslava Shvedova of Kazakhstan.

As the 2010-11 school year begins in New York City on Wednesday morning, we invite you to submit your photographs from the first day. Parents, show us your kids, their teachers and your fellow parents as pencils are sharpened, new backpacks donned and tales of summer camp recounted. Teachers, share the scene around your classroom and in your school's hallways.

Yes, Pakistan leads the report again on Tuesday, with photographs by Carl De Souza, Damir Sagolj and Asif Hassan, because the news is unrelenting - and almost unrelentingly bad. After scathing criticism that they were unprepared for the disaster and inept in their initial response, Carlotta Gall reported, government officials, ministers and even President Asif Ali Zardari are crisscrossing flood-affected areas of the country in a frantic effort to ease public anger and despair. Pakistani officials, diplomats and aid workers warn that while civil unrest has so far been averted, the aftermath of the worst-ever flooding in Pakistan could destabilize the country in the months to come and aggravate the already deep regional, sectarian and class fissures.

Businesses owned by women and members of minorities still struggle to secure city contracts, despite nearly five years of legal mandates and targeted goals set by the city, says a new City Council report [pdf - see also below].

This week, A. O. Scott explores the American Dream and its paradoxes with Jonathan Demme's "Melvin and Howard." The film tells the story of Melvin Dummar (Paul LeMat), a working man, who finds Howard (Jason Robards) in the desert after a motorcycle accident and gives him a ride into town. Howard turns out to be the reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes, who leaves Melvin a significant inheritance in his will. The movie asks questions about the complexities of our relationship to money and Mr. Scott calls it an "affectionate, authentic portrait of a typically contradictory American character." Have you seen "Melvin and Howard?" Please share your thoughts.

When it comes to environmental degradation, those who live and work in the open air are more exposed than most. Someone strumming a guitar for tips on the sidewalk or reading tarot cards at the curb or operating a pedicab cannot help but breathe in the pollution in the air.

It sounded a lot like amateur hour as a long-awaited radio debate began on Tuesday between Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, the nine-term incumbent from Manhattan and Queens, and her challenger in the Democratic primary, Reshma Saujani, a 34-year-old who was a lawyer for a hedge fund.

Talk about your celluloid jams: at the start of the summer, Richard O'Brien, the author and composer of the cross-dressing cult classic "The Rocky Horror Show" (and its midnight movie incarnation, "The Rocky Horror Picture Show") applied for residency in New Zealand, where he planned to retire to the coastal town of Katikati. But like a statuesque man-monster climbing a small replica of the RKO Pictures tower, the British-born Mr. O'Brien, 68, was shot down: New Zealand immigration officials said he did not meet the criteria, which include being age 55 or under and having a job offer.

European health officials seem to be in the same boat as those in America who are having trouble deciding whether the chemical BPA, or bisphenol-A, is safe.

Shoppers looking for a bargain along Connecticut's heavily developed Route 1 corridor may not realize it, but their wheels are turning on historical ground. According to Eric Jaffe's absorbing new book, "The King's Best Highway," the road that is now cluttered with gas stations, outlet shops and fast-food restaurants was in the 17th century a narrow wilderness trail, and the traveler making the round trip between New York and Boston would probably want to budget a month for the journey.

The N.F.L. sent a memo to teams Tuesday outlining what it hopes will be the final tweaks to the umpire move to the offensive backfield. The move has provoked criticism, particularly from the Indianapolis Colts, because of concerns that the move slows down hurry-up offenses.

The Lewis Chessmen are the most famous and important chess pieces in history. They have a long historical and scholarly record, part of which is that they were made in Norway roughly 800 years ago. But now two Icelandic men are challenging that belief and trying to prove that the pieces came from their country.

In a hard-fought, straight-sets victory, Caroline Wozniacki defeated Maria Sharapova 6-3, 6-4, to advance to the quarterfinals. The match presented a contrast in styles, with Sharapova dictating with aggressive play while Wozniacki worked to outmaneuver Sharapova and force errors. In the end, Sharapova hit 32 clean winners, but her 36 unforced errors gave Wozniacki enough of a margin to pull ahead in each set.

How much does malpractice cost the medical system? About $55.6 billion a year, or 2.4 percent of annual health care spending, according to a study on medical liability published today in Health Affairs.

Elvis Presley may not have been known for car songs the way that, say, the Beach Boys were (despite the ridiculous "(There's) No Room to Rhumba in a Sports Car" from "Fun in Acapulco"), but he certainly was known for cars: buying them, driving them, giving them away. Now one of his more impressive cars, a 1970 Mercedes-Benz 600, is being auctioned off in Surrey, England, at a Bonhams year-end event colorfully known as the Important Motor Cars and Fine Automobilia sale.

Six authors, including Tom McCarthy for his novel "C" and Emma Donoghue for "Room," were named on Tuesday to the shortlist for the 2010 Man Booker Prize for Fiction, the most prestigious literary award in Britain.

Tony Stewart, in a Chevrolet, raced away from the Ford of Carl Edwards on a late restart after a caution period and held on to win the Nascar race at Atlanta on Sunday night by 1.3 seconds. Jimmie Johnson, the defending series champion, was third in another Chevrolet. Stewart and Edwards were among 10 drivers whose finishes to date have gained them a position in the final 10-race drive for the season championship, which begins Sept. 19 at Loudon, N.H. Two of the 12 spots available in the chase remain open and will be decided next weekend at Richmond, Va., ostensibly among Greg Biffle, Clint Bowyer, Ryan Newman and Jamie McMurray. McMurray was the winner Saturday night of the Nationwide series event, edging Kyle Busch.

Lest the distinction of an honorary Academy Award contradict his reputation as a film-making provocateur and a feisty founding member of the French New Wave movement, Jean-Luc Godard has found a way to have his cake and eat it too: he will not appear in person to accept the award at a ceremony in November, but will likely send a colleague to receive it in his place, The Australian reported.

Torrential rains and flash floods that swept through cities and villages in West Africa in late August have intensified a food crisis in the region, leaving upwards of 10 million people suffering from severe food shortages, the United Nations and relief organizations warned last week.

President Obama, after seeing his daughters off for their first day of school, will spend the day in meetings with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the NATO secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen.

The phrase TLC, or "tender loving care," can mean many things to different people. A plant that needs a little TLC may want for water and sunlight. Someone who is coming down with a cold and needs a little TLC may want chicken soup and some extra blankets at night. Then there are homes that need TLC and the brokers who promote them.

If you're finding yourself in a post-Labor Day funk and feeling as if you have an uneasy relationship with your job, try putting yourself in the position of Norm Macdonald. On the one hand, Mr. Macdonald, the veteran "Saturday Night Live" performer and deadpan "Weekend Update" anchor, has a thriving stand-up comedy career and is a late-night television guest to look forward to when he makes his occasional appearances. On the other, Mr. Macdonald says he's still trying to shake the reputation he was tagged with in 1998, when he was fired from "S.N.L." by an NBC executive who didn't find him funny.

Macquarie Group, the Australian investment bank, warned that profit in a number of its deal-making and trading divisions would be down by a quarter compared to the year before.

The United States Justice Department is looking into Google's takeover of airline ticketing software firm ITA Software, to determine whether the deal would exert too much influence on the online travel industry, Reuters said, citing a report in The Wall Street Journal.

The scientific rebel, J. Craig Venter, made headlines - and drew comparisons to Dr. Frankenstein - when he announced in May that his team had created what, with a bit of stretching, could be called the first synthetic living creature, The New York Times's Andrew Pollack writes.
British Airways and Iberia have identified possible acquisition targets to pursue once their own merger completes, with Asia seen as a key region for expansion, Reuters reported.

Ireland's finance minister, Brian Lenihan, met Monday with European Union regulators to discuss the crisis over Anglo Irish Bank - a day before talks that could lead to the creation of a system to shield taxpayers from paying for similar costly collapses in the future, The New York Times's James Kanter reported.

The European "stress tests" that looked at the viability of the continent's major banks under a number of hypothetical scenarios, underestimated the amount of potentially risky government debt held by some of the institutions tested, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The primary investor of 3Par, Menlo Ventures, is looking to raise $600 million to $800 million for a new fund that would surpass Battery Ventures' and Institutional Venture Partners' $750 million funds raised this year, according to a report by Bloomberg News.

Dubai Holding's main unit will delay repayment on a $555 million loan until Nov. 30, the company said on Tuesday, the second time it has failed to meet a repayment deadline, Reuters reported.

Petronas of Malaysia has filed a draft prospectus for an initial public offering of its entire petrochemicals business, moving a step closer toward creating country's second largest I.P.O. after Maxis.

Gartmore Growth Opportunities may be breaking away from its namesake hedge fund management firm, The Financial Times reported. The fund notified Gartmore it might not be managing its assets any longer, a move that comes just days after one of Gartmore's top executives, Gervais Williams, resigned.

Executives from some of the world's leading banks are due to gather for a conference in Frankfurt later this week as lenders seek to avoid what they see as overly harsh regulation following the global financial crisis, Reuters reported.

American International Group is leaning toward a new sale of its Taiwan unit, according to one of the original buyers, opening the way for a number of Taiwanese banks that have expressed interest, Reuters reported.

RAMEY--James Thomas 1914-2010. Cherished father of James N. and Drucilla Ramey, adored grandpa of James, Sarah and Margaret Ramey, Jessica Stender and Caitlin Vaughn and predeceased by his breathtaking wife Estelle and siblings Leon Ramey, Evalyn Ford, Tish Ramey and Nita Ramsay, Jim graduated phi beta kappa from Amherst College ('37) and Columbia Law ('41), was Executive Director of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, longest-serving AEC Commissioner, architect of the nuclear Navy, pioneer of nuclear safety, defender of equality, advisor to Presidents, crack golfer and generous, wise and loving friend and family man.

The research has been going on for more than 10 years. Studies number in the hundreds. Millions of dollars have been spent. But government health officials still cannot decide whether the chemical bisphenol-A, or BPA, a component of some plastics, is safe. The substance lines most food and drink cans, and is used to make hard, clear plastic bottles, containers and countless other products. Nearly everyone is exposed to it. Concerns about BPA stem from studies in lab animals and cell cultures showing it can mimic the hormone estrogen. It is considered an ''endocrine disruptor,'' a term applied to chemicals that can act like hormones. But whether it does any harm in people is unclear.

FREIDLAENDER--L. Martha (Marty). Died on September 3, 2010 at age 78 after a long battle with various health issues. The daughter of the late Rye and Georges Freidlaender; who taught her that despite a handicap she could accomplish all; and she did. She graduated from Colby College and receive a Masters Degree from Columbia Graduate School of Social Work, where she was honored as an outstanding alumnus. After a year in London on a Fullbright Scholarship, she had a successful social work career, ending as Director of Social Work at St. Lukes/Roosevelt Hospital. An avid traveler she had many visits with friends and family throughout Europe and Israel. A lifetime member of Ethical Cutural Society, Colby College and Fellowship for Reconciliation; she devoted her life to helping others and was an inspiration to all who knew her. Our thanks to her devoted aides and medical staff. She is survived by brother Charles, sister-in-law Judi, niece Geri (Ed), nephews Jeff (Susan), Robert (Diane), six grandnephews, one grandniece. A celebration of her life will take place at a later date.

Every September, millions of parents try a kind of psychological witchcraft, to transform their summer-glazed campers into fall students, their video-bugs into bookworms. Does Junior's learning style match the new teacher's approach? Or the school's philosophy? Maybe the child isn't ''a good fit'' for the school.

Andy Murray's four-set loss to Stanislas Wawrinka on Sunday came as terrible news for fans of the Scottish player's all-court counterpunching style. But fans of Rafael Nadal, another speedy counterpuncher, can now breathe a little easier. Murray hasn't been at his best after losing in the finals of the Australian Open to Roger Federer and looked vulnerable in his third round match. Perhaps he would not have been able to stop Nadal, who has not dropped a set in New York, even against the dangerous Gilles Simon. But Murray has been Nadal's toughest road block in hard court Grand Slams the past two years, crushing the Spaniard at the United States Open two years ago and at the Australian Open earlier this year.

Over the last two decades, John Coleman Darnell and his wife, Deborah, hiked and drove caravan tracks west of the Nile from the monuments of Thebes, at present-day Luxor. These and other desolate roads, beaten hard by millennial human and donkey traffic, only seemed to lead to nowhere. In the practice of what they call desert-road archaeology, the Darnells found pottery and ruins where soldiers, merchants and other travelers camped in the time of the pharaohs. On a limestone cliff at a crossroads, they came upon a tableau of scenes and symbols, some of the earliest documentation of Egyptian history. Elsewhere, they discovered inscriptions considered to be one of the first examples of alphabetic writing.

CARROLL--Philip. On September 4, 2010 Philip Carroll of Ellicott City, MD, 86, died after a long illness. Loving father of Camilla Carroll and Philip Carroll. Grandfather of Philip and Harper Carroll. He was born in New York City on August 9, 1924 to Nina Ryan and Philip Acosta Carroll. He attended Harvard (class of '46) and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. He served as a combat engineer in the second World War. He was a member of the bar of New York and later of Maryland. A private service was held.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: VIVIEN LEIGH Considered by many to be the movie industry's most beautiful actress, Leigh, left, preferred working in the theater and made only 20 films. But though her life appeared to be charmed, with a 20-year marriage to Laurence Olivier and two best actress Oscars, she battled bipolar disorder and eventually died of tuberculosis at 53. This 15-film tribute, shown on Tuesdays in September, begins with ''Vivien Leigh: Scarlett and Beyond,'' Gene Feldman and Suzette Winter's 1990 documentary, featuring archival footage of Leigh addressing British troops during World War II and relaxing with Olivier at their country estate. The evening continues with ''Dark Journey'' (1937), at 9, starring Leigh in her first leading role, as a French spy who falls for her German counterpart (Conrad Veidt); the screwball comedy ''Storm in a Teacup'' (1937), at 10:30, in which she plays a headstrong heiress tamed by love; and ''St. Martin's Lane'' (1940), at midnight, about a street performer (Charles Laughton) who helps an enticing pickpocket (Leigh) forge a new career as a dancer. That film, originally released in 1938 as ''Sidewalks of London,'' was Leigh's final steppingstone to winning the role of Scarlett O'Hara opposite Clark Gable in ''Gone With the Wind'' (1939). 8 P.M. (NBC) MINUTE TO WIN IT Bernard Berrian of the Minnesota Vikings and Amber Wright, a cheerleader for the San Francisco 49ers, play for charity. In ''America's Got Talent,'' at 9, the Top 10 acts try to make it into the final four.

In hospitals, there is a special kind of communication among doctors and nurses, an essential skill not easily learned. I've come to call it the Rattle. In the Rattle, speed matters far more than style. It tends to be filled with jargon incomprehensible to an outsider - medical gobbledygook carefully arranged to present a patient's story.

Patrick McEnroe announced his resignation as the American Davis Cup captain on Monday, effective after the United States team's next match, against Colombia in Bogota Sept. 17-19. McEnroe said he wanted to concentrate on his work with the young player development program he leads for the United States Tennis Association, as well as his television commentary and spending more time with his family. ''It's mixed emotions for me because of what Davis Cup has meant to me for 10 years, to the players that have supported it,'' McEnroe said at a news conference at the United States Open on Monday. ''But I feel now is a good time for a transition, and I can focus my professional energies on player development.''

BUSINESS DAY A report in the Reuters Breakingviews column on Thursday about the sale of Burger King misstated the company's net debt and, as a result, its valuation in relation to earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization. Its net debt is $650 million, not $1.8 billion, which is its gross debt of $1.6 plus cash. Its valuation is thus $3.2 billion, or 7 times Ebitda, not $4.3 billion or 9.5 times Ebitda.

ISRAELOW--Ruth (September 23, 1920 September 2, 2010) died peacefully at home with all of her children and grandchildren at her bedside. A smile for all, a heart of gold The very best the world can hold Those we love don't go away They walk beside us everyday Today marks 10 years since you left us. You are forever in our hearts. You are our angel. We miss you and love you. Love, Mom and Heather.

LUSTIK--Susan Zane. Bon voyage to our beloved friend and colleague Susan Zane Lustik, who passed away on Friday, September 3rd. She will be remembered for her extraordinary courage, tenacity and kindness. God bless her always. Michael Simon Interiors.

BERNSTEIN--Florence Newman, died in her home in Lauderhill, Florida at age 95, on September 1st, after suffering a brain hemorrhage. She leaves a close, loving family with two sons and their wives, six grandchildren and their five spouses along with 12 great-grandchildren. Florence was born into a large, extended family in Brooklyn, NY and after a brief singing career and song plugging for the Irving Berlin Music Company, married Jack J. Bernstein during the Depression. Their family thrived. Florence was a loving mother, grandparent and great-grandparent who was especially concerned, to the very end, about their welfare and happiness. She couldn't have been a better "Nana." She made sure that Jack was healthy and happy during retirement and when he died made many new and diverse friends. She continued to grow, was upbeat and loved to make people laugh. She had no place for racial, religious, gender-oriented or ethnic prejudices. She will be dearly missed by many.

What are we hankering for at T as Hermès prepares to unveil the refurbished leather floor in its Madison Avenue flagship next Tuesday? The Hermès So-Black collection, of course. For the first time, a select number of blacked-out and gloss-finished Birkin bags and Kelly clutches - available in leather or crocodile and wrapped in a commemorative black box that is as impeccably chic as the bag - will be delivered to Hermès boutiques worldwide. Not surprisingly, the battle to procure these black beauties has resembled handbags at dawn. "The reaction has been quite exciting," says Hermès's C.E.O., Robert Chavez. "Our very eager clients are ready to get their hands on them." It's a comment that's as understated as the bag.

Two oil workers were missing and more than 30 others were rescued from a rig off China's northeast coast that was damaged in a storm on Wednesday, the BBC reported. Helicopters and rescue boats searched for two people who fell from the platform, which was listing at a 45-degree angle in the Shengli oil field, operated by Sinopec, which is the second-largest in China. Sinopec said no oil has been spilled and that powerful waves generated by Typhoon Malou were the likely cause.

Though any reference to Estonian cooking generally draws a blank stare from even well-traveled gourmets, Alexander, one of the best and most interesting new restaurants in Europe right now, is found on the tiny and stunningly beautiful Estonian island of Muhu, a two-hour drive south from Tallinn, the country's capital. It's still rather confidential, but a gastronomic awakening is occurring in the countries that surround Europe's other great sea, the Baltic, which has long been dismissed as a region of marginal culinary interest by a world besotted with everything Mediterranean.

You always knew that Mary Katherine Gallagher was going to make it to Broadway one way or another. That overeager Catholic schoolgirl and aspiring entertainer may remain in semiretirement, but Molly Shannon, the "Saturday Night Live" alumna who portrayed her (along with characters like Sally O'Malley and a parody version of Ann Miller) on that program, is slated to make her Broadway debut in "Promises, Promises," the musical's publicists said on Wednesday. Ms. Shannon will take over the role of the barfly Marge MacDougall from Katie Finneran on Oct. 12; Ms. Finneran, who won a Tony Award for her portrayal of that character this year (and who is pregnant with her first child), will leave the production after Oct. 10. The leads of "Promises, Promises," Kristin Chenoweth and Sean Hayes, will remain in the show through Dec. 26, when Ms. Shannon will also depart; no permanent role has yet been found for Ellen DeGeneres.

One day in 1917, Henri Matisse persuaded his son to drive him into the country in the family car. He set up his easels and painted a view of the road and trees, seen through the windshield and out the car windows. He established a tradition of viewing the world from the car, whose latest flowering is visible in a show of photographs.

When Tory Burch was last in Europe, she came armed with a voice recorder, which she used to capture her observations. The designer then traveled to Seoul, South Korea, to open her new boutique in Cheongdam-dong. (It's like the South Korean Rodeo Drive.) Once there, she handed off the voice recorder to the filmmaker Van Neistat (of viral video fame), who gave himself the unusual task of pairing Burch's commentary on her European jaunt - about cypress trees in Tuscany, a sunset over the Seine - with scenes from Seoul. The seemingly awkward conceit comes off cleverly, but it did leave us wondering what Burch thought of Seoul itself. "The city is very international and progressive," she says. "I loved everything from the chic women to the interesting architecture. Walking into the Leeum museum was so exciting - there were three spider sculptures by one of my favorite artists, Louise Bourgeois. The stores are also fantastic, like Boon, Mue and 10 Corso Como. I definitely want to go back. There is so much more I'd love to see."

I recently received an e-mail from a father who said that his daughter had taken the SAT and ACT, and was contemplating retaking both exams. Should she? With the hope that this might prove a teachable moment for readers of The Choice (and me), I farmed the question out to Gwyeth Smith Jr. He is a longtime college counselor, now in private practice, who is the main character in David Marcus's book "Acceptance: A Legendary Guidance Counselor Helps Seven Kids Find the Right Colleges - and Find Themselves'' (recently published in paperback by Penguin.) Mr. Smith's answer follows the question. -- Jacques Steinberg

Michael Nevin is founder and editor in chief of The Journal, a curated art and culture quarterly that began in 1999 as a photocopied snowboarding 'zine. He is also the director of the Journal Gallery, situated in a converted garage on North First Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, next to the magazine's office. Entry 29 of the journal is about to hit newsstands with a few surprises, including a supplement created by Nate Lowman titled "Life's a Beach and Then You Die." The accompanying exhibition, "Wish You Were Here," goes up at the gallery on Sept. 16.

Mention "new lighting technology" and what leaps to mind is probably a compact fluorescent curlicue. Shaped like a soft ice cream cone, it is viewed as a replacement for the ubiquitous 60-watt incandescent light bulb, which looks almost like it did 90 years ago.

If you happen to be in Venice this week for the Film Festival, a quick hop over to the Giardini is also highly recommended. The public park at the tip of the lagoon, overlooking the Lido, is host to most of the national pavilions of this year's Architecture Biennale, which runs through Nov. 21. Perhaps the best way to tour the pavilions is to plunge straight in, literally, at the Polish Pavilion, which won the Golden Lion for National Pavilion in 2008.

The XX, a British trio that dresses all in black and plays stark, hushed songs about stifled desire, has won the Barclaycard Mercury Prize for its album "XX." The Mercury, a £20,000 prize (about $31,000) for the best album by a British or Irish act, is voted on by a small group of journalists and music industry professionals, and is regarded as one of Britain's most prestigious music awards. In the past it has gone to PJ Harvey, Talvin Singh, Pulp and Portishead, but was criticized last year when it was won by Speech Debelle, a little-known London rapper who was soon dropped by her record company.

President Obama swoops down in Cleveland today to sell his policy prescriptions for strengthening the economic recovery. Jackie Calmes writes that Mr. Obama will take a partisan (yet personal) tone as he pitches a centrist batch of tax cuts and new spending. Though the proposals are unlikely to be approved by Congress before November's midterm elections or in the lame-duck session that follows, they provide Democrats an agenda as they head into the home stretch of this election season.

Thanks in part to its vast corps of state employees, New York remains the most unionized state in the country, with nearly 25 percent of workers belonging to unions, double the national rate, our colleague Steven Greenhouse reports on Economix this morning. Dr. Nicolis was the former Chief of Endocrinology at the Bronx V.A., and Associate Professor of Medicine at the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9pm Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday, September 9 at 10am. BARTON--Jo Jeanne Millon, age 82, of New York City died peacefully on September 2, 2010. The daughter of the late Jean-Pierre Millon and Josephine Irish Millon. She is survived by her husband of 58 years Thomas H. Barton and by her daughters Brooke Millon Barton, MD of Los Angeles, California and Avril Barton Moore of Princeton, New Jersey and her grandchildren Thomas Barton Moore, Diana Millon Moore and Juliet Avril Moore. She was graduated from the Spence School and 1949 from Vassar College. She made debut at the Junior League Debutante Ball and at The New York Infirmary Christmas Cotillion. Her great-grandfather Charles Lassalle, founded the French language newspaper in New York. Le Courier des Etats-Unis, and organized the subscription for the base of the Statue of Liberty. Her mother was descended from John Irish who was left several shillings in the will of his neighbor Miles Standish in the Plymouth Colony. She spent a lifetime in community service in the leadership of volunteers. She served as President of the Junior League of the City of New York and later as Vice President and Director of the Association of Junior Leagues of America. She was President of the Drama League, the United Nations Hospitality Committee, the City Gardens Club and Regent of the Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the DAR. She served the Spence School as President of the Alumnae Board and a member of the Board of Trustees. Member of the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society and the Colony Club. She loved the company and camaraderie of her friends and fellow volunteers. Her great affection for people, her willingness to do the hard work in organizations, her parliamentary and organizational skills will be long remembered. She loved laughter, all things French, The New York Times Sunday crossword puzzles, Cole Porter and Sherlock Holmes. A memorial Mass will be held in the Fall at the Church of St. Thomas More where she was married in 1952.

An article on Tuesday about the effectiveness of various study habits described incorrectly the Heisenberg uncertainty principle in physics. The principle holds that the act of measuring one property of a particle (position, for example) reduces the accuracy with which you can know another property (momentum, for example) -- not that the act of measuring a property of the particle alters that property.

Senator Lisa Murkowski, who was defeated in the Republican primary in Alaska last month, said Tuesday that she was exploring ways to run in the general election, including as a write-in candidate or as a Libertarian. Ms. Murkowski spent more than an hour Tuesday with David Haase, the Senate candidate from the Libertarian Party, and discussed the possibility of his allowing her to replace him on the ballot. It was unclear whether such a switch would happen, but Ms. Murkowski, who has about $1 million left in her campaign account, also signaled that she could pursue a write-in candidacy.

There were the gusts that turned the ball toss on serves into an act of faith and then there were the sudden shifts of momentum. Sam Querrey, the last American man standing in the United States Open, did his best to weather both, but in the end was swept away. He lost in the fourth round to Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland in a five-set match at Arthur Ashe Stadium that alternately captivated and crushed the partisan crowd. The United States Open has been the stage of many dramatic fifth sets. There was John McEnroe versus Bjorn Borg in the 1980 final; Pete Sampras becoming sick on the court en route to a quarterfinal victory against Alex Corretja in 1996; Andre Agassi and Marcos Baghdatis battling beyond exhaustion in the second round in 2006; Juan Mártin del Potro outlasting the tireless Roger Federer in last year's final.

10 P.M. (Sundance) FULL FRONTAL FASHION In its latest tribute to New York Fashion Week, the Sundance Channel offers six nights of sartorial-theme programming, as well as a new online magazine, FullFrontalFashion.com. Stepping off: Diane von Furstenberg, above, in the first of six new episodes of ''The Day Before,'' a documentary series from the director Loïc Prigent (''Signé Chanel'' and ''Marc Jacobs & Louis Vuitton'') that follows final preparations for runway presentations by high-profile fashion houses. Some are more relaxed than others. With only 36 hours until she presents her collection, Ms. von Furstenberg plays with her grandchildren as she figures out the V.I.P. seating chart, practices yoga while fitting models and intones the mantra ''Be proud to be you!'' Other episodes go behind the scenes with Versace (Thursday), Alexander Wang (Friday), Narciso Rodriguez (Saturday), Nina Ricci (Sunday) and Jeremy Scott (Monday). In ''Girl on the Run: Winter 2011,'' at 10:30, Mademoiselle Agnès, the French fashion commentator, high-tails it from Chanel and Céline to Manish Arora and Olympia Le-Tan at the Paris collections while offering her take on Anna Wintour, Carine Roitfeld and the mysterious codes of leg-crossing in the front row. 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL The theme of this 15th cycle is high fashion, and the winner's spoils include a photo spread in Italian Vogue. The competition begins as 32 contestants converge in Palm Springs, Calif., where all but 14 will be hastily eliminated. Then it's off to a party hosted by the designer Cynthia Rowley, the first in a crop of fashion types -- among them, Diane von Furstenberg, Zac Posen, Roberto Cavalli, Patrick Demarchelier, Patricia Field, Karolina Kurkova and Margherita Missoni -- to grace the season. Tyra Banks, André Leon Talley and Nigel Barker resume judging duties.

Businesses owned by women and members of minorities still struggle to secure city contracts, despite nearly five years of legal mandates and targeted goals set by the city, says a new City Council report [pdf - see also below]. City agencies handed out more than $5.3 billion in contracts between July and December 2009, but only $87 million, or 1.6 percent, went to businesses owned by women and minority candidates, the report says. Fifteen agencies met none of their contracting goals for this period. The number of contracts secured by such businesses continues to be less than half the mandated number.

BERNSTEIN--Richard Kent. His devoted wife of 56 years, Denise, his three children Marc, Claire and Robin and his grandson Alex are saddened to announce Richard's passing on September 1 following a stroke. Richard was born in Trenton, NJ in 1929. He earned a degree in philosophy from the University of Chicago at the age of 18 and continued his studies in philosophy and languages in Paris, where he met Denise. They were married in Chicago, returned to Europe during Richard's military service and finally settled back in NYC in 1955. Richard earned his law degree from NYU in 1961 while working to support his family. He was also an accomplished pianist and loved poetry. He practiced law until the day of his illness. Richard was loved and respected by friends, family, colleagues and clients alike. He will be greatly missed.

The Patient Money column on Saturday, about ways to reduce exposure to foodborne pathogens, referred imprecisely to a requirement for organic labeling. As the N.F.L. prepares to kick off its 2010 season, nearly all of the league's 31 football stadiums are financed with public money. On average, more than half the reported building costs of all active stadiums has been paid for with tax dollars -- for a collective total of $8 billion -- and in several instances, taxpayers have footed the entire bill. In contrast, the new Meadowlands Stadium was financed solely with private money, although taxpayers still owe on its predecessor, which was demolished this year. Unwinding the public cost of subsidized stadiums and arenas is difficult because of the complex mix of financing and accounting involved. Bonds, grants and other sources of taxpayer money may have been tapped to build a facility. Multiple levels of government may have pitched in. In most cases, the initial debt is refinanced one or more times, pushing the payback into the future. And frequently, millions more are spent to improve the original structure.

The Pew Research Center asked people this summer to identify the current chief justice of the United States from among four possibilities: John Roberts, Thurgood Marshall, John Paul Stevens and Harry Reid. An earlier post highlighted the evidence that in many arenas, purposeful practice is the key to high performance. In other words, top performers in complex fields like medicine, math and chess become that way through repeated and focused practice that builds their skills until their performance seems almost super-human - rather than being born with highly exceptional skill.

With the world quickly using up its fossil fuels and driving itself further toward irreversible climate change, it's easy to fall into despair about the future of domestic life. Cheap energy, land, water and building materials have made the last century of American homebuilding a story of ever-expanding luxury. Arguably, all of these will become scarce and expensive over the next 50 years. Will our children's homes be anything as comfortable and expansive as our own?

I'm back up in Cape Cod, feeding what has for several years been a smoldering mania for beach plums (prunus maritima), with an eye to making not jelly but rather a homemade liqueur I stumbled onto quite coincidentally. I happened to be here while researching an article on sloe gin a number of years back. I learned that sloe berries are a type of wild plum, the fruit of a shrub called a blackthorn tree that grows in hedgerows in England. The English have never been able to cultivate them, and the fruit - being mostly pit surrounded by a thin pulp that is equal parts bitter, sour and astringent - is used, when it is used at all, for making sloe gin. It's macerated in the strongest gin available, and sugar is added to the final result to create a homespun liqueur.

A year after a disastrous 27 percent decline that prompted layoffs, salary freezes and a halt to some campus expansion, the Harvard endowment on Thursday reported a solid 11 percent increase in its $27.4 billion endowment portfolio for its fiscal year ended June 30.

One of the joys of Fashion Week is when designers leave little notes along the front row seats explaining their inspirations for the season. Christian Siriano, at his 2 p.m. show (view complete runway show), included a photo that showed the feet of one of his models. There was also a description of the shoes he had designed for Payless, inspired by "African, Indian and Chinese influences mixed with measures of elegant opulence."

It is difficult to account for the many effects on a community of having access to a clean and consistent supply of drinking water. Through a comparison of two umudugudus (villages), one with an improved source of water and the other without, I will try to document some of the themes that have occurred to me thus far. But before I begin this analysis I want to give a brief comparison of the two umudugudus.

With just a few weeks to go until "Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps" hits theaters, there's a lot to talk about: the portrayal of the financial crisis, accurate or not; the acting; the symbolism. (And the cameos!)
Need another sign that Democrats are facing rocky political terrain this year? Prominent party members are taking it upon themselves to compare and contrast this year with 1994.

Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal look unstoppable, meaning a meeting between the two at the U.S. Open in the final is a strong possibility. The Times's Thomas Lin breaks down the possibilities from Flushing.
Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal look unstoppable, meaning a meeting between the two at the U.S. Open in the final is a strong possibility.

José Manuel Carreño, the veteran American Ballet Theater dancer, has announced he is retiring in August 2011. A special farewell evening for Mr. Carreño, who joined the company as a principal in 1995, will take place on June 30 at the Metropolitan Opera House and will feature a special performance of "Swan Lake" with Mr. Carreño in the role of Prince Siegfried, dancing opposite Julie Kent as Odette and Gillian Murphy as Odile. Mr. Carreño, who was born in Cuba, joined the English National Ballet in 1990 and the Royal Ballet in 1993. With American Ballet Theater, he has danced many roles, including the title character in "Apollo," Albrecht in "Giselle," Des Grieux in "Manon" and Solor in "La Bayadère." In a 2000 review of "La Bayadère" Anna Kisselgoff wrote: "Mr. Carreño as Solor, the warrior who leaves Nikiya to marry Gamzatti, the rajah's daughter, plumbs his role with depth and brilliance. He was a sensitive hero, troubled but commanding." Following his retirement from American Ballet Theater, he plans to continue performing as a guest artist.
After voting for George W. Bush in 2004, Tuscarawas County in Ohio went for President Obama four years later. Republicans are counting on regaining support in areas like this.
Despite pleas from parents whose children have been killed by cars on the beach to ban the practice, driving on the sand remains a favorite activity on some Florida beaches.

In a T Magazine exclusive, Prabal Gurung gives us a sneak peek at his spring/summer 2011 collection before it is shown on the runway at New York Fashion Week this Saturday. If you're wondering what the springboard for the collection is, Gurung mentioned on the day of his recent T video shoot that he has been more than a little obsessed with the protagonist in the coming Maggie Betts documentary and with Tilda Swinton's bougie turn in "I Am Love." "It's a study in the power of femininity," Gurung said, "but not in a clichéd way. I like the nuanced - and, you know, a really powerful woman can say so much with a nod or simply a word or two. All the women I love have that quiet strength."

What goes together better than musical numbers and Canada's national sport? The Toronto International Film Festival will be celebrating both when it opens Thursday night with "Score: a Hockey Musical." The film, directed by the Toronto-based filmmaker Michael McGowan, tells the story of a teenage hockey player (Noah Reid) and features Olivia Newton-John, along with a variety of Canadian personalities. The above clip gives a taste of the movie's approach to the sport.

TORONTO-The change is palpable, as the giant annual film festival here shifted its weight downtown, toward its new Bell Lightbox center in the entertainment district and away from the high-toned hotels and eateries of Yorkville. Good-bye Four Seasons, hello, Hooters, the Fox and Fiddle, and the Canadiana Backpackers Inn. All are a stone's throw from the Scotiabank Theater, now a primary screening place for festival films. This reporter stopped into a restaurant just across the street from the Lightbox on Wednesday night, thinking to have dinner. The hostess pointed toward a nicely situated four-top near the window, and even cleaned up half of it. "Oh, O.K.," she said, on being asked if the dirty glass and tableware might disappear from the other half as well.

Last September, my best friend, Susan, told me that I didn't make enough music anymore. She was right; between 1996 and 2003, I put out a new record every year, played a few shows a month and did quite a bit of composing, mostly for solo musicians or small ensembles I'd met over the years.
The number of American children being raised by their grandparents rose after the recession began, according to a report from Pew Social Research.
The fall television season brings a full serving of new crime fighters and comedies.

Small donations via text message raised millions of dollars for Haitian earthquake victims. Are museums next? The Phillips Collection in Washington on Thursday announced a campaign to solicit $5 and $10 donations via text message to raise money for repairs to its building after a fire on Sept. 2. No artwork was damaged, but the museum's offices were harmed.

6:44 p.m. | Updated In his Political Times column on Wednesday, Matt Bai asserted that President Obama had missed an opportunity to rally the public behind his long-term initiative to restructure the economy. He is answering readers' questions about the president's approach and other top political issues this week.

Ever wonder how clothing designers dress their homes? The Council of Fashion Designers of America and Assouline are publishing "American Fashion Designers At Home." Written by Rima Suqi, a contributor to T and The New York Times, the coffee-table book ($65, which benefits the CFDA Foundation) looks at the homes of 115 CFDA members, from heavyweights like Diane von Furstenberg and Kate Spade to relative newcomers like Band of Outsiders' Scott Sternberg. The interiors, which range from luxurious - like Eva Chow's gold-leafed Los Angeles living room or Tory Burch's opulent, surprisingly conservative Manhattan apartment - to industrial-funky, like Rachel Comey's Long Island weekend house, may seem glamorous to those of us on the outside looking in. But as Suqi points out, even fashion designers "are not immune to the pitfalls of decorating or renovating. They have nightmare contractors, too."
Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia aired his first television commercial in his bid for the state's open Senate seat on Wednesday night and it wasn't one of those fluffy biography ads.

A Michigan lithium-ion battery developer, which is working on new technology the company says can give electric cars greater range, plans to announce on Friday that it has received $3.2 million from General Motors Ventures. G.M. said the new batteries could eventually end up in the company's cars.
In July, the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston released a paper quantifying how much credit rewards cost the poor.
The Rome skyline with St. Peter's Basilica in the center.
When is a band reunion not really a reunion? When the members changed with every record in the first place.

No matter how urbanized New Yorkers like to think we are, the reminders of our natural world are constant. Canada geese, raccoons even skunks have brushed up against humans recently in a somewhat rude manner. Or at least it was rude to us.
Martha Plimpton stars in the new Fox sitcom.
An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.
Though a fringe pastor in Gainesville, Fla., has suspended plans to burn Korans, The Associated Press wire service said Thursday that it would not have shared any images of a Koran being burned.
Yes, that stuff floating in the water last week was reddish, but no, it was not red tide. Nor was it toxic, environmental officials from New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday.

Deutsche Bank has begun approaching other banks about a potential stock sale that could raise as much as 9 billion euros, or $11.4 billion, Bloomberg News and The Financial Times reported on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.
3G Capital wants the Whopper now.

The cookbook writer Grace Young recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers' questions about stir-fries and wok cooking. Ms. Young's new book, "Stir-Frying to the Sky's Edge," was recently published by Simon & Schuster.

A bio-fueled road trip from Unity, Maine, to the nation's capital is aiming to press President Obama to put solar panels back on the White House. President Jimmy Carter had installed the first set of panels in 1979, but they were removed during the Reagan administration. Students from Unity College and allied climate campaigners, most notably Bill McKibben, are toting a treasured artifact owned by the school -- one of the Carter-era solar hot water panels -- to make the point.

Last night, Viktor & Rolf hosted an intimate gathering of beauty editors and a smattering of models - Erin Wasson, Shalom Harlow, Elisa Sednaoui - to commemorate five years since launching its first fragrance, Flowerbomb (an occasion famously celebrated with a Grace Jones performance in March across the pond). The soiree was held in a Grove Street town house that looked quite like the tuxedo-jacket-clad designers' Amsterdam headquarters and featured a huge Flowerbomb bottle replica in pink flowers.

Barnes & Noble, the object of a proxy battle by the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle, sent shareholders a letter urging them to vote for its board nominees and to reject Mr. Burkle's candidates, Reuters reports.

No doubt, the iPad has caused quite a stir. (If you don't have one, you want one.) While some of us may be waiting for the next gen before diving in, a handful of fashion designers are already outfitting their iPads in the chicest of cases - no Swarovski bedazzling necessary. "The iPad suits our needs: it's practical, versatile and mobile," says Oscar de la Renta, who is smitten with his device and has already designed a pearlized taupe clutch for his well-wired fans. All casing aside, what are de la Renta's latest apps? "I recently downloaded Netflix and Pandora," he says. "I hope I am the first person to create a Bizet station." You may not have created your own "Carmen" channel, but surely you can be an early adopter of the first iPad clutches and get a head start accessorizing the holiday season's must-have gift.
When a patient signs a surgical consent form, is he or she agreeing to more than just surgery?

PARIS -- Charlie Rose was made a knight in the Legion of Honor on Thursday in a ceremony at the French Finance Ministry. Christine Lagarde, the finance minister, lauded Mr. Rose as a great journalist, interviewer and friend of France. Mr. Rose, 68, declared himself a longtime devotee of Paris and singled out for special thanks Martine Frank, the widow of the photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson; and the heart surgeon Alain Carpentier, who performed what Mr. Rose said was life-saving open heart surgery in 2006. Both were among a cluster of friends gathered to fete Mr. Rose; others included the French philosopher Bernard-Henri Lévy, the political analyst Dominique Moisi and the director Danièle Thompson.

At 3-3 in the first set of their quarterfinal match last night, Roger Federer broke Robin Soderling with three smart shots into the wind, the last a breathtaking inside out forehand drop shot on break point that died in the wind for a winner. Before that, Soderling had been in control, holding serve easily and nearly breaking Federer twice.

To most in the technology industry, Larry Ellison's latest adventure -- the rapid-fire hiring of Mark V. Hurd, ousted Hewlett-Packard chief executive, and the resulting Silicon Valley fireworks -- is entertainment.

This summer ArtsBeat has been inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. So far our guests have tackled the topics of comedy, ethics, "don't ask, don't tell", immigration and how to define a hit show.

It's always nice to see the music industry make room for a talented newcomer. On Wednesday, the Roc Nation entertainment company announced that it had signed a recording deal with the 9-year-old pop singer Willow Smith, whose debut single, "Whip My Hair," has become a viral sensation after hitting the Web earlier this week. In a news release, Roc Nation said that Willow Smith, who is the sister of the "Karate Kid" actor Jaden Smith and - oh, yes - the daughter of the superstars Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith, will shoot her debut video in Los Angeles later this month. Jay-Z, the Roc Nation founder and president, said in a statement, "It's rare to find an artist with such innate talent and creativity at such a young age. Willow is about to embark on an incredible journey and we look forward to joining her as she grows in all aspects of her career."

We've said it before, but we'll say it again: There is more to New York Fashion Week than the Marc Jacobs show. The editors of T reveal what events they've underlined in their agenda books. Follow us on Twitter for dispatches from these and other #NYFW events.
Honda has just released prices on its new 2011 Odyssey minivan, ranging from $28,580 for the base LX up to $44,030 for the top-of-the-line Touring Elite. The Elite trim level is new to Honda.

Gov. David A. Paterson suggested on Thursday that the imam hoping to build an Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan had raised the possibility of moving the planned center, which will house a mosque, an auditorium and a pool.

The architect and designer David Rockwell has joined the board of the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in Manhattan, part of the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Rockwell, who has been on the museum's exhibitions committee since 2006, is the founder and chief executive of Rockwell Group. Among the firm's projects are W hotels in Union Square and Paris, the Elinor Bunin-Munroe Film Center at Lincoln Center and the new restaurant at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Mr. Rockwell recently designed the Imagination Playground at the South Street Seaport, which is meant to encourage children to design their own play space.

A study by a German military think tank leaked to the Internet warns of the potential for a dire global economic crisis in as little as 15 years as a result of a peak and an irreversible decline in world oil supplies.

My friend Marty and I used to fantasize about a gracious old apartment building in the center of our New Jersey town. It would be great to grow old with a cluster of friends, we told each other, in a place only a few steps from movies and shops, the YMCA and the bus into Manhattan. One day we'd buy it and create the Montclair Old Newspersons' Home, taking seats on the co-op board so we could approve as residents only people we actually wanted to live with. All it would take was $30 or $40 million that nobody had.

Joe Mantello, the Tony Award-winning director who had an acclaimed run as an actor in the 1993-94 Broadway production of "Angels in America," will perform on stage for the first time since "Angels" in an Oct. 18 benefit reading of Larry Kramer's play "The Normal Heart," in which Mr. Mantello will play the central role of Ned Weeks.

Google is rolling out a new advertising campaign on Thursday for its display advertising platform. The campaign, called Watch This Space, will run in advertising trade magazines and in other print and online media. The "space" to watch makes reference to the blocks of display advertising users see on the Web pages they browse.

This is the fourth and final post in a series on how to use The New York Times across the curriculum. Last Friday we provided ways to use The Times in any class, followed by Tuesday's post on social studies and history and yesterday's on science, health, math and technology.

In his seminal work "Afghanistan," first published more than 35 years ago, Louis Dupree describes the real-life 19th-century Afghan campaigns near Kandahar, immortalized in Sherlock Holmes's first meeting with Dr. Watson. Mr. Dupree then goes into how, amid the real death and injuries of the Second Anglo-Afghan War of 1878-1880, one fictional wound came to bewilder Afghan tribal elders.

After graduating from the University of North Carolina in 2000, Tripp Phillips went on to compete at the highest levels of professional doubles, reaching the semifinals of the United States Open in 2006.
At 33 and retired from professional tennis, Tripp Phillips is back at the Open scouting talented juniors as an assistant coach for the North Carolina men's tennis team.

The French writer Michel Houellebecq may or may not agree with the description of him that appears on Wikipedia, which characterizes him as "a writer in the tradition of literary provocation that reaches back to the Marquis de Sade and Baudelaire" (to admirers) and "a peddler of sleaze and shock" (to detractors). But Mr. Houellebecq defended his right to copy material from the French edition of that online encyclopedia for his latest novel, calling it an artistic appropriation that he hopes "contributes to the beauty of my books," The Independent of London reported.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Gerry Marzorati: Good morning, Michael. I thought talking about weather conditions incessantly was something you only did if you were an airline pilot or a wedding planner but, No! You do it when you toss a small, fuzzy ball in the air and try to strike it cleanly as it descends. At one point yesterday, I watched poor Gaël Monfils watch one of his tosses end up completely out of his reach -- nearly halfway to the service line. Maybe that's what led him to try the most ridiculous -- and thoroughly entertaining -- shot I've ever seen: A splay-legged jump tweener facing the net from the baseline. He's too young to have watched A.B.A. games, right?

President Obama may say from time to time that he has no idea who Snooki is, but Judge Damian G. Murray of Seaside Heights Municipal Court in New Jersey certainly seemed to recognize her. On Wednesday he handed Nicole Polizzi, the diminutive "Jersey Shore" star better known as Snooki, a $500 fine and a sentence of two days community service after she pleaded guilty to disturbing people at a New Jersey beach on July 30, The Associated Press reported. From the bench Judge Murray called Ms. Polizzi "a Lindsay Lohan wannabe" and invoked a few lines from "Animal House," telling her, "Rude, profane, obnoxious and self-indulgent is not the way to live your life." A lawyer for Ms. Polizzi told the judge she "was under the influence of some alcohol" when the incident occurred, during taping for a coming third season of "Jersey Shore."

The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 1. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below, and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.
President Obama is making another financial investment in the battle to hold the Democratic majority, sending $4.5 million to help the party's candidates for House, Senate and governor.

Anyone who has flown over the American West on a clear day has probably noticed the enormous effect that irrigated farming has had on the landscape of the country. Fields of corn, potatoes and other crops can be seen dotting land that would otherwise be semi-desert, and the spray from some types of irrigation systems creates perfect circles of green in these parched landscapes.

Once the signature accessory for Karl Lagerfeld, who reportedly used them to ward off cigarette smoke, the fan - or éventail, as it is known in French - arguably reached its fashion zenith around the heyday of Oscar Wilde's Lady Windermere. But fears of appearing démodée never stopped Raphaëlle de Panafieu from toting one around. "I always carried fans my father brought back from his trips to Asia," recalls de Panafieu, who, along with Eloïse Gilles, recently bought the long-dormant French fan maker Duvelleroy. "They were bamboo throwaways, very simple. But they never left my purse."
The United Steelworkers say they plan to file a legal case accusing China of violating World Trade Organization rules by subsidizing exports of solar panels and other clean energy equipment.
Jonathan Schwartz, the former chief executive of Sun Microsystems, has put down his servers, chips and software and decided to tackle something new - health.

President Obama is stepping up the rhetoric as the midterm elections draw near, delivering his most partisan speech of the campaign on Wednesday and adding his voice this morning to the chorus condemning the Florida pastor who plans to burn copies of the Koran on the anniversary of 9/11.

In the Spanish section of the men's draw, Rafael Nadal will face his countryman Fernando Verdasco, who is coming off a five-set marathon against David Ferrer. Nadal, by contrast, is fresh off a relatively routine straight sets win over Feliciano Lopez.

The Obama administration appoints an "Asian carp czar" to oversee the federal response to keeping the invasive species out of the Great Lakes. "When it comes to the Asian carp threat, we are not in denial. We are not in a go-slow mode. We are in a full attack, full-speed-ahead mode," says Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois. "We want to stop this carp from advancing." [Chicago Tribune]

Private equity executives are facing a major tax increase as a crucial lawmaker on Capitol Hill who has previously blocked the legislation now appears to condone the introduction of a tax that would double the amount they have to pay when withdrawing cash from their firms, The New York Post reported.

Airgas on Wednesday got a split decision from two important proxy advisory firms in its battle against Air Products and Chemicals, including a recommendation by Institutional Shareholder Services favoring the three Air Products director nominees over the incumbent board members.

The EADS chief executive, Louis Gallois, said his company was in talks with a few other firms in defense, services and security areas for potential deals and could comfortably make an acquisition of around 1 billion euros ($1.27 billion), Reuters reported.
Most hedge funds lost money in August as hundreds of managers, including some of the industry's best-known names, stumbled when stock markets swooned anew, Reuters reported.
Cerberus Capital Management is believed to be the firm that made an offer worth up to $2.5 billion for the wine business of Foster's Group, The Australian newspaper reported.

Craig Henderson of Bellingham, Wash., which is about 90 miles north of Seattle, planned to drive his home-built car from the Canadian border to Mexico without stopping for fuel. Before leaving on Aug. 29, he'd carefully calculated that his streamlined car could travel the more than 1,400 miles on 14 gallons of diesel.
Two Supreme Court decisions making it tougher to pursue lawsuits may have begun to bear fruit for corporations fighting investor claims or employee litigation, Bloomberg News reported.

Writing checks is about the most loathsome activity in which I engage. I need a glass of white wine, tranquilizing music, a cleared dining room table and a half-dozen delays before sitting down to the nasty tasks of writing in cursive, subtracting with decimals, addressing envelopes with a pen and remembering how much a stamp costs.

The HSBC chief executive, Michael Geoghegan, should stay in his post and spurn any offer to become chairman, according to banking analysts, Bloomberg News reports.
Today's idea: Economists would do well to learn the modesty of historians, a columnist says. They better understand human complexity and the limits of social science.

Swiss hedge funds have "reinvented themselves" this year as the country attracts new managers by offering lower tax rates than rival financial centers, Bloomberg News said, citing a Zurich University study.
With the N.B.A. set to announce the opening of an office in Moscow, the Nets have made plans for a stopover in the Russian capital.

John A. Paulson, who became a billionaire by betting against the American mortgage market, has lost 11 percent this year in his firm's biggest hedge fund, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person briefed on the returns.
Vilified by the public and the media though they may be, Goldman Sachs's employees still like the bank.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission blocked National Australia Bank's $12 billion bid for AXA Asia Pacific for a second time, dashing the bank's efforts to cement its dominance in the world's fourth-largest wealth management market, Reuters reported.
Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is an author of "13 Bankers."

Few events could so completely satisfy an escapist fantasy of a life lived in luxury than the Biennale des Antiquaires. Now in its 25th decadent year, the festival brings together exceptional antique art, jewelry and furniture at the glorious Grand Palais from Sept. 15 to 22. Art dealers, collectors, jewelers and anyone curious about great art can wander exhibitions as refined as the objects on display. And expect crowds: the last Biennale drew about 80,000 people.
Ian Nicol, a reader from Fort Collins, Colo., was a frequent (and incisive) commenter during the early-summer doldrums. He accepted our offer to write a short post looking toward the new season.

The Singapore sovereign fund Government of Singapore Investment Corp. began the initial public offering of its logistics unit on Thursday, aiming to raise up to $3 billion in what could be the city-state's biggest offering, Reuters reported.

"The Favre Indecision" may sound like a Robert Ludlum novel, but it's really the story of the Vikings' off-season. Brett Favre is back in the Vikings huddle, but the Vikings have major questions that go beyond Favre's gimpy ankle. Their receiving corps is thin in the wake of Sidney Rice's injury, their big-name offensive line looked like a colander during the preseason, and the star running back Adrian Peterson is coming off a three-fumble performance in the Vikings' 31-28 loss to the Saints in the N.F.C. title game. Despite his age and eroded approval rating, Favre retains the power to relegate the defending champions to the second paragraph.The Saints are as unassuming as Super Bowl winners get. Minor scandals nip at their heels (Reggie Bush's Heisman trophy is being melted by the N.C.A.A. and recast as a Yoke of Shame), but the most succulent story to stick to the team has been Sean Payton's affinity for fruit-flavored gum. "Get me Juicy Fruit - not (bleeping) Spearmint," Payton yelled at the assistant Adam Bailey at the Super Bowl; you can picture Payton later channeling Joan Crawford in "Mommie Dearest" and bludgeoning Bailey with a carton of Dentine.

Bank of China's Shanghai-listed shares languished on Thursday, reflecting lingering concerns over the health of the sector after the bank obtained regulatory approval for an $8.8 billion share placement in Hong Kong and Shanghai, Reuters reported.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has defended its proposed $75 million settlement with Citigroup, saying the penalty reasonably accounted for the seriousness of the bank's alleged misconduct, Reuters said, citing a document filed in court on Wednesday.
Norway, which has amassed the world's second-biggest sovereign wealth fund, says Greece won't default on its debts, Bloomberg News reports.

Here in New York City, over a million kids went back to school yesterday, and The Times published both stories about budget woes and joyous first-day photos from readers. What's notable about school year 2010-2011 for you? What are you looking forward to? What are you dreading? Why?
For centuries, residents of Guardia Sanframondi have marked the Feast of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary with a procession behind her statue through its medieval byways.
UBS has hired two bankers to join its team serving ultrahigh-net-worth individuals Singapore, the bank said in an internal memo, Reuters reported.

Lloyds has agreed to sell its stake in the home builder Crest Nicholson to the American investment company Varde, continuing to shed noncore assets and refocus on its core lending activities, Reuters reported.

9 P.M. (History) 9/11 STATE OF EMERGENCYCondoleezza Rice, the national security adviser for the Bush administration on Sept. 11, 2001; Donald H. Rumsfeld, the former secretary of defense; and Gen. Richard B. Myers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, recount the decisions made and obstacles faced -- including failed communications inside the White House bunker and a heated phone conversation with President George W. Bush -- in the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Andrew Card, the White House chief of staff at the time, tells the story of interrupting the president's visit to the Emma E. Booker Elementary School in Sarasota, Fla., to whisper the news that a second aircraft had flown into the twin towers (above, Mr. Card with President Bush at that moment). The special also features interviews with air-traffic controllers and F-16 pilots involved in the response that day and with Deena Burnett and Alice Hoglan, whose loved ones were on board the hijacked United Airlines Flight 93. 7:30 P.M. (NBC) N.F.L. OPENING KICKOFF 2010 The National Football League begins its 91st season as the reigning Super Bowl champions, the New Orleans Saints, face off against the Minnesota Vikings at the Superdome. This pregame celebration, simulcast on the N.F.L. Network, honors the Saints and their hometown with performances by the Dave Matthews Band and Taylor Swift. The game kicks off at 8:30. A special edition of ''N.F.L. Total Access,'' at 4 p.m. on the N.F.L. Network, will feature an interview with the Saints' head coach, Sean Payton, as well as a remote interview with Rex Ryan, the head coach of the New York Jets.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the end of the life of a tree made famous by the author E.B. White, in his 1949 book ''Here Is New York,'' misspelled the surname of a three-year-old boy shown sitting on the tree's stump in his backyard. He is Nico Bernstein, not Burnstein.

PITT--William H. Oct. 16, 1926 Sept. 9, 2000 It has been 10 years, and every day I miss his humor, wit and good sense. I will miss him forever and his unbending love and loyalty towards me. He, too, is missed by so many friends and business associates. What a very special man he was. Pauline

Even though he was trying to protect a one-run lead, Baltimore Orioles closer Koji Uehara was bold enough to throw a first-pitch fastball to the Yankees' Alex Rodriguez in the bottom of the ninth inning Wednesday afternoon. Rodriguez lashed a single. Nick Swisher made a mental note. After Robinson Cano flied out and the Yankees were two outs from being swept by the last-place Orioles, Swisher strode to the plate, looking for just one fastball to drive. Swisher soon got one, and his 26th home run of the season lifted the Yankees to a dramatic 3-2 victory at Yankee Stadium.

Moviegoers have been trained to treat 3-D glasses as disposable products. When the movie's over you're supposed to chuck the glasses into the bins sitting outside the theaters. The glasses are usually cleaned and recycled, but would consumers be more likely to want to see a 3-D film if the glasses fit more like their own and less like a pair you'd pick up in a Halloween costume store?

An article on Monday about the hiring of a former Hewlett-Packard chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, as co-president of Oracle described incorrectly a finding of an H.P. board investigation that led to Mr. Hurd's departure. The board found that Mr. Hurd concealed his relationship with a marketing contractor by not naming her in some reports covering the meals the two had together; he did not remove her name from his expense reports.

As Bruce Springsteen, who is currently the subject of a special exhibit at Cleveland's Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, sang in ''Badlands,'' there's ''trouble in the heartland.'' And a lot of political action as well, which could bode well for the Buckeye State's bid to land the 2012 Democratic National Convention. Cleveland is one of four cities competing to host the Democratic gathering. Charlotte, N.C., Minneapolis, Minn., and St. Louis, Mo. are the other possibilities, with a decision possible by the end of the year. At the moment, Ohio seems to be scoring points in terms of buzz.

KLUGE--John. We are deeply saddened by the passing of John Kluge, Columbia College class of 1937, whose generosity and commitment to Columbia enabled us to pursue our dreams. Mr. Kluge often said "Columbia made a difference in my life and I really want to ensure that it will continue to make a difference for others." He will always have our deepest gratitude for the difference he has made in all of our lives. Our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Tussi, his son, John Jr., Columbia College class of 2005, and his entire family. Columbia College Kluge Scholars Past and Present

KLUGE--John. Troutman Sanders LLP mourns the loss of John Kluge, board member and elder statesman of The Shubert Organization, Inc. and The Shubert Foundation, Inc. Thanks to his wise counsel and tireless devotion, The Shubert Organization remains at the forefront of the American theatre. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Kluge family.

An obituary on Monday about the Roman Catholic theologian Raimon Panikkar referred incorrectly to the dissertation that earned him a doctorate in theology from Lateran University in Rome. It compared the interpretation of the Brahma Sutras by the eighth-century Hindu philosopher Adi Sankara with the work of St. Thomas Aquinas, not with St. Thomas Aquinas's interpretation of the Brahma Sutras.

An article on Sunday about a deal to stabilize Afghanistan's largest bank overstated, in some copies, the role of the United States in the effort. White House officials said the United States was providing technical assistance, not bailout money.
