KLUGE--John W. We are saddened by the loss of our dear friend, John Kluge. John's generosity as a philanthropist, a visionary, and a teacher will have a lasting impact on our lives and so many others. But as great as John's philanthropy and generosity were, and they were historic, they pale in comparison to the pleasures of his company. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Tussi, to his children, Joseph, Samantha, and John, and to his entire family and friends. Lee C. Bollinger and Jean Magnano Bollinger

GREENE--Dawn. Calvary Hospital mourns the passing of Dawn Greene. We will never forget the passion and dedication she brought to her philanthropy, and her commitment to providing quality palliative care in New York City. A great friend to the patients and families of Calvary Hospital, her good works leave a legacy that will immeasurably benefit the health and wellbeing of New Yorkers, and enrich the cultural wealth of our city. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Richard E. Meyer, Chairman, Calvary Fund Frank A. Calamari, President & CEO Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director

KLUGE--John W. The Dean, Dean Emeritus, faculty, students, and alumni of Columbia College mourn the passing of John W. Kluge, Columbia College class of 1937. John Kluge was a towering figure whose commitment to Columbia and to higher education sets a standard for us all. He will be dearly missed, even as future generations continue to benefit from his historic generosity and his devotion to Columbia and Columbia's students. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Maria "Tussi" Kluge, son John Jr., Columbia College class of 2005, and the entire family. The Columbia College Community

MAUER--Anthony Sheridan, of Virginia Beach, VA, passed away peacefully at home on September 3, 2010. Born in Detroit on March 5, 1943 to the late Gertrude S. and Raymond J. Mauer, Tony grew up in Old Greenwich and Riverside, CT, and attended St. Mary's High School in Greenwich, CT. An avid outdoorsman, at the age of 13 Tony became an Eagle Scout, at the time the youngest ever in Greenwich. Tony graduated from the University of Connecticut where, as a walk-on, he played four years of college football, both offense and defense. A newspaper clipping quotes his coach as saying, "Pound for pound, Tony is as tough as anyone on this team." Upon graduating, Tony moved to New York City, and tried his hand at acting. He appeared off-Broadway in Friends, and later appeared in movies such as Goodbye, Columbus and The Godfather, as well as on television in such dramas as The Edge of Night. Moving to the other side of the lens, Tony proved to be a gifted, internationally recognized photographer. His professional credits include pieces published in Life, McCall's, Redbook and many other consumer and trade magazines, and portraits of many distinguished public figures and dignitaries. Tony was the official photographer for the Theater Hall of Fame in New York City, where he photographed many celebrities such as Lillian Gish, Grace Kelly, Al Pacino, Geroge C. Scott, etc. He also photographed The Christopher Awards for many years in NYC. His portraits are remarkable in that the subject always seems to express something very personal. After 20 years in New York City where he raised his daughter Lara, Tony moved his photography business to Virginia Beach, where he married the love of his life, Ann Russell Hines. In addition to his photography, he and his wife, "Russ", operated a real estate management business in Virginia Beach. He also was the official photographer for the Norfolk Forum for 10 years. Tony approached life with a rare positive intensity. His natural goodness, easy warmth and wit, and limitless kindness affected everyone who knew him. He will be terribly missed by those who survive him, including his wife "Russ" of Virginia Beach, VA; daughter Lara Mauer of Claxton, GA; foster child, Tatiana Rotolo of Benicia, CA; brothers Paul of Conroe, TX and Michael of San Francisco, CA; sisters Patricia Fitzpatrick of Rolling Hills Estates, CA and Sherry Petersen of Stratford, CT; and numerous nieces and nephews. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Friday, September 10, 2010 at 2:00pm at the Church of the Holy Family, 1279 North Great Neck Road, Virginia Beach, VA. Friends and family will be received on Thursday, September 9, 2010, between 6:00 and 8:00pm at 229 87th St. in Virginia Beach. Flowers are welcomed at the church, and memorial contributions may be made to the International Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia Foundation (IWMF) or to the University of Connecticut Football Program. H.D. Oliver Funeral Apts. Laskin Road, VB is handling services and online condolences may be made to the family at hdoliver.com.

An article on Tuesday about efforts to determine the safety of bisphenol-A, or BPA, a chemical component of some plastics, described the history of such research incorrectly. The idea that drugs or chemicals could act like hormones has been around for decades, but advocacy campaigns in the 1990s drew public attention to the issue; the idea did not emerge in the 1990s.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Moving Sounds festival at various sites in Manhattan misstated the given name of the soloist who performed a new electronic keyboard concerto by Edmund Campion on Friday at the Czech Center New York. She is Joanna Chao, not Jennifer.

GREENE--Dawn. The volunteers and staff of the American Cancer Society mourn the loss of Dawn Greene. Her vision, leadership and generosity made possible the naming of our Hope Lodge NYC, Jerome L. Greene Family Center in Manhattan. Her passion and caring spirit for our mission helped to create a lasting legacy that will provide lodging and support services to cancer patients and caregivers for decades to come. We are all the better for having known her. Our deepest condolences to Christina McInerney and the family. Dr. Herb Zaretsky, President Don Distasio, CEO Karen Radwin, Sr. Executive, Hope Lodge NYC Jerome L. Greene Family Center Hope Lodge NYC Guests, American Cancer Society

KLUGE--John W. The President and Trustees of Columbia University mourn the loss of a beloved member of the Columbia community and our greatest benefactor -- John Kluge, Columbia College class of 1937. John, who passed away at the age of 95, always retained his first-hand understanding of the catalytic effect a Columbia education could have on a young person's life, and he was determined to ensure that as many students as possible benefit from a similar opportunity. His gifts have funded, and will continue to fund, the education of thousands of deserving students who, like John himself, come from modest backgrounds. His historic 2007 gift of $400 million, still the largest ever to any college or university for financial aid, provides $200 million in financial aid endowment for undergraduates in Columbia College and another $200 million for students in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, Graduate School of Journalism, School of the Arts, and School of International and Public Affairs. John had made prior gifts totaling $110 million, the bulk of which was used to establish the Kluge Scholars Program to ensure access for talented and diverse Columbia College students of limited financial means. A recipient of an honorary doctorate from the University and the John Jay Award and Alexander Hamilton Medal from Columbia College, John will forever remain a figure of signal importance in the life and work of this University. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Maria "Tussi" Kluge, his three children, Joseph, Samantha, John Kluge II (Columbia College class of 2005), and the entire family. Lee C. Bollinger, President, and The Trustees of Columbia University

If you want to watch Web-enabled video on your television, you could buy a number of gadgets that will hook up directly to your TV set. But most of these contraptions offer only a narrow hallway of content and don't allow full access to the Internet or a Web browser. Now Warpia offers a device that plugs directly into a laptop and lets you stream everything from the computer wirelessly to a television or computer monitor.

KUHNS--Richard F. The Philosophy Department of Columbia University observes with great sadness the passing of Richard F. Kuhns, dear colleague, friend, and mentor to so many.

ROTHSCHILD--James. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, Jim. We will always remember the wonderful times our families shared together. He will be forever in our hearts. Our love and thoughts are with Vesna, Sophia and Lola. Bruce, Danielle and Miles Lifton

An article on Wednesday about a summit meeting in Washington on Tuesday at which prominent religious leaders denounced what they called the mistreatment of American Muslims during the controversy over the proposed Islamic community center near ground zero misidentified the Catholic priest who is executive director of ecumenical and interreligious affairs of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops. He is the Rev. James Massa -- not the Rev. Mark Massa, who is the dean of the School of Theology at Boston College.

Nikon has announced three Coolpix point-and-shoot cameras: the P7000 for demanding photographers, a midrange S8100 with a 10X zoom, and the sleek touch-screen S80. The $500 P7000 is aimed at those who want D.S.L.R.-like control and features. Its 10.1-megapixel sensor has larger photo diodes than most point-and-shooters, enabling it to deliver better low-light images. The camera has a versatile 7.1X zoom with a range of 28mm to 200mm and includes a new feature that lets users define favorite focal lengths and use them at the touch of a button. The $250 Coolpix S8100 employs a new backside-illuminated CMOS sensor to deliver fast shooting speeds (10 frames per second) and the ability to capture full 1,080p video. The S8100 also has a 10X optical zoom with a range of 30 to 300 millimeters.
CAMHI--Sonya. 9/18/1951 - 9/9/1995 Fifteen years today; In our hearts everyday. Her Loving Family

PITT--William H. Oct. 16, 1926 Sept.,2000 Real estate entrepreneur, community leader and philanthropist. "Educating the young is the make or break issue in this country. We can't count success just by counting office buildings. We have to build up people too, and the best place to start building is with the young who need help. If we don't, we'll find we built on sand." His spirit lives on in the many young lives he continues to touch through the William H. Pitt Foundation.

HARRIS--Dwight R.,92, Ohio farm leader and conservationist died August 26, a year after his beloved wife, Jean Brodbelt. Ohio USDA Director, WWII Veteran, US delegate to World YMCA, 1st World Council of Churches and postwar UN observer. He loved "tickling the ivories". Family was his first charity. All five children and six grandsons survive. Burial September 11th, at Darrtown.

CHALEFF--Lynne, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, died on August 24, 2010, two days after her 87th birthday. "Lou" was a dedicated and inspiring teacher and an ardent political activist who militated for progressive causes throughout her long and meaningful life. She will be dearly remembered by the students, friends, and family members whose lives she deeply touched and enriched. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 25 at 1pm at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture; 53 Prospect Park West; Brooklyn, NY.

ARNOLD--Selma, 96. A union organizer, activist and lawyer, she devoted her life to social justice. She helped people stand up for themselves. She was beloved for her honesty and esteemed for her fierce will. A meticulous book editor, adventurous cook, insatiable reader, and lover of laughter, she will be dearly missed by Bobby, David, Abby, and many family members and friends. Memorial Saturday 12pm, 185 West End Ave. Donations can be made to Project Open at Lincoln Towers.

BERNSTEIN--Richard K. The Institut Pasteur expresses condolences to his wife Denise and children Marc, Claire and Robin. A founding director of the Pasteur Foundation, Richard was a trusted, wise, witty colleague who will be missed enormously.

Senator Lisa Murkowski's unexpected Republican primary defeat in Alaska just became moderate Republican Mike Castle's wake-up call in Delaware. Mr. Castle, a nine-term congressman from the state's only congressional district who is hoping to become the Republican nominee for Delaware's open Senate seat, went on the attack against his primary opponent, Christine O'Donnell, in an ad released Tuesday.

Revere America, a conservative advocacy group dedicated to repealing the health care law enacted earlier this year, announced on Wednesday that it is undertaking a multi-million-dollar television advertising campaign aimed at ousting Democrats in Congress who supported the law. The ad campaign was announced by former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican who is now serving as chairman of Revere America. At a news conference at the National Press Club in Washington on Wednesday, Mr. Pataki said the group hoped to raise and spend at least $5 million on the effort by Election Day.

An Op-Ed article on Saturday, about Americans and Japanese building a dam after World War II, incorrectly described the significance of Sept. 2, 1945. That was the day Japan formally surrendered to the Allies, not the day a peace treaty was signed.

The Advertising column on Tuesday, about real companies entering the online market for virtual goods, misstated the number of users of Mall World, a Facebook social game that offers a virtual replica of the singer Beyoncé's diamond ring. It has 4.75 million users a month, not 400,000.

ON Tuesday, a balmy night at the end of a golden late-summer day, Manhattan's literary Elysium -- novelists, editors, writers, publishers and agents -- proceeded up a marble staircase to the glass-windowed salons and brick terrace of the Bowery Hotel. They'd come to witness the apotheosis of Jonathan Franzen, author of ''Freedom'' (his fourth book), the most feted novel of the season. Minutes after the party's outset, guests already had gathered around the bar at the landing, including Mr. Franzen himself, calm and genial in a dark gray suit and pale blue shirt, equably chatting with his girlfriend, Kathryn Chetkovich; and Mark Costello, the novelist husband of the editor in chief of Scribner, Nan Graham. Ms. Graham, in a chic cloud-blue dress, stood at the bar, talking with Deborah Treisman, the New Yorker's elegant fiction editor, who helped secure Mr. Franzen's inclusion in the New Yorker's showcase of emerging novelists in 1999, in an issue called ''The Future of American Fiction.''

When Sha Zukang, the most senior Chinese official at the United Nations, rose to make a toast to Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon last week, his colleagues were no doubt aware of the fact that he has a history of making undiplomatic remarks.

Lucas Roman was not photographing for the ages. He was simply making a keepsake of his arrival in New York, where he was beginning a new life in film production. There was only one better spot from which to capture the city's sweep than the observatory of the Empire State Building, where he stood on the night of Monday, Sept. 10, 2001. And that was from Windows on the World, atop the World Trade Center, where he was headed the next morning.

While the opening week of college football brought with it all the requisite excitement of another season beginning, this weekend unquestionably features a better group of games. Most of the action comes out of the conference, notwithstanding an intriguing SEC matchup. Penn State and Alabama renew a rivalry, one that has conjured up memories of Joe Paterno coaching against Bear Bryant. Two first-year coaches (Florida State's Jimbo Fisher and Notre Dame's Brian Kelly) face big challenges, with the Seminoles traveling to Oklahoma and the Irish hosting a Michigan team that looked extremely dangerous in beating Connecticut in the season opener. But the marquee game on Saturday looks to be Miami at Ohio State. The Buckeyes' Terrelle Pryor and the Hurricanes' Jacory Harris are two of the most exciting quarterbacks in the country. Expect the winner of this game to vault right to the top of the Heisman discussion. But, enough talk. Let's get on with the picks.

Trying to capture some momentum in Ohio's Senate race, Lt. Gov. Lee Fisher, the Democratic candidate, has called in reinforcements this weekend - former President Clinton, who has proven to be a popular presence for Democrats on the campaign trail this year.

Christopher Clarey, International Herald Tribune/The New York TimesWith Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal still in the mix, this should be a remarkable final weekend at the US Open. To mark the occasion, I've brought together some of the world's leading tennis writers for a special edition of the forum. We have Philippe Bouin, who has covered more than 100 Grand Slam events for L'Equipe in France. We have Neil Harman, a leading voice of the sport in Britain for The Times of London. We have Juan Jose Mateo, who has chronicled Nadal's rise and reign for El Pais in Spain. We'll focus on Rafa and Roger and the business end of the men's tournament, beginning with Saturday's semifinals between Nadal and Mikhail Youzhny and between Federer and Novak Djokovic. Let's start with the man whose country actually has a player left in the men's tournament.

Alimentation Couche-Tard, the Canadian convenience store operator, said late Friday that it would consider raising its unsolicited offer for Casey's General Stores once again and it asked Casey's to postpone its annual meeting on Sept. 23 for two to three weeks in order to "complete a full and fair sales process."

Days after three Mets skipped a team trip to visit wounded war veterans at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Jeff Wilpon, the team's chief operating officer, declined to rebuke the players, saying that any discontent that stemmed from their absence should be worked out in the clubhouse.

A twilight view of the World Trade Center site taken Thursday evening shows 1 World Trade Center (with two cranes at top), now one-third of the way up to its 1,368-foot height, and the diaphanous 7 World Trade Center, to the immediate right, which was finished in 2006. In the right foreground is an area between the No. 1 subway line and Church Street, where two more skyscrapers and the PATH station will go.

It's amazing how quickly the debate over print vs. digital can erupt into a heated argument. There are those who love their newspapers and books and those who adore their digital counterparts. But of all the issues that are usually debated - the tactile feel of paper, the immediacy of a screen - fly-swatting is usually missing from the list.

There was a tense moment on Doo-Ri Chung's runway at the Eyebeam Gallery in Chelsea when the sound cut out in the middle of the show. It happens. Technical glitches in fashion are far more common than you might think, so not one model batted an eye when David Bowie's "Sound and Vision" sputtered out somewhere amid the "blue, blue, electric blue."

This is the fourth in a five-part series, "War and the City," by the Iraq war veteran Roy Scranton, chronicling his path from youth to soldier to civilian writer in New York City. To read from the beginning, go to the first installment, "March Song."

The other day a man crossing Park Avenue at 70th Street stopped at the feet of a 12-foot tall, sloe-eyed schoolgirl. She smiled down at him. He peered back. She didn't respond - but how could she? She's a ghost. A "White Ghost," to be exact, one of two glossy fiberglass statues by Yoshitomo Nara that the Art Production Fund installed on the Park Avenue median this week. (The other is at 67th Street.)

Melanie Stiassny, an ichthyologist at the American Museum of Natural History, surveyed and collected freshwater fish during an expedition to the Malebo region of the Congo and Kasai Rivers.

Romain Duris possesses every one of the irresistible  - and maybe a little stereotypical - qualities of a French sauvage: the swagger, the scruff, the inimitable unruly head of hair that would take hours of practice and pomade for a normal human being to pull off. Duris, 36, has been building on his considerable natural acting talent ever since he was picked off the street in 1994 by the director Cédric Klapisch for "Le Peril Jeune." He's played a gangster-turned-pianist in "The Beat That My Heart Skipped" (2005), France's best-known playwright in the 2007 period piece "Molière" and a hopeless romantic in the durable study-abroad idyll "L'Auberge Espagnole" (2002). (He was also a T cover star in 2006, as the pride of our portfolio on French leading men.)

As I noted in an article in Thursday Styles this week, a new generation of designers is rising in New York, the first in decades to have the power to change what we think of as American fashion. Just what that change will be remains to be seen.

The Obama administration has chosen a Treasury Department lawyer to replace Kenneth R. Feinberg, its special master for executive compensation, who stepped down Friday, ending a contentious 14-month tenure, The Associated Press reports.
F. Gwynplaine MacIntyre's science fiction writing drew acclaim -- he was a favorite of Isaac Asimov -- but at home in Brooklyn, he was known as an eccentric pack-rat.

Google is rolling out a new advertising campaign on Thursday for its display advertising platform. The campaign, called Watch This Space, will run in advertising trade magazines and in other print and online media. The "space" to watch makes reference to the blocks of display advertising users see on the Web pages they browse.

No guidebooks, no maps, no plan. In a new series, "Getting Lost," Matt Gross will try to lose his way all over the globe. His first installment takes him to Tangier and its medina, an ancient and befuddling labyrinth.

The whistles and catcalls that in the past accompanied questionable line calls at major tennis events have now been largely replaced by a new sound: an almost involuntary and collective "Waaaaoooooh." Call it the Hawk-Eye sound effect. Once criticized as a technological wet blanket that would slow down the game, the Hawk-Eye system, with its 10 cameras and ability to virtually replay any challenged shot, is now a new source of entertainment. As the animated ball retraces the shot trajectory, all eyes transfix on the screen to see if it was in or out, and by how much. The closer the ball is to the line, the louder the audience expresses its amazement. "It's important to show the fans and the players quite how close it is," said Luke Aggas, tennis operations manager for Hawk-Eye Innovations.

The twins Mike and Bob Bryan derailed the Indo-Pak Express on Friday at the United States Open, winning the men's doubles final over the team of Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan and Rohan Bopanna of India, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (4).

If you haven't heard yet, Karl Lagerfeld is in town, mostly to receive a F.I.T. Couture Council Fashion Visionary Award at a luncheon today, but also to celebrate the new Chanel SoHo store with some very notable friends last night. The roomier digs, designed by Peter Marino, are actually an expansion - the brand took over the former Eres store next door - and they boast all your usual Chanel trademarks: plenty of black and cream bouclé, and Coco's signature camellias here and there.
A break in a gas line on Thursday night in San Bruno, set off a gigantic fireball that engulfed an entire neighborhood, killing 4 people, injuring more than 50 and destroying dozens of homes.
The new HBO period drama is set in Prohibition-era Atlantic City.
Traffic deaths last year in the United States fell to the lowest level in 60 years, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Apparently the Samurai Shopper is the last woman alive to indulge in something called a blowout. I'd heard of blowouts before, in their antiquarian sense: huge sales at the end of a retail season, a wholesale slashing of prices where shoppers teetered on the edge of sanity, lunging headfirst at trendy leftovers withering on the fashion vine.

Kenneth I. Starr, the onetime investment adviser to the likes of Al Pacino and Sylvester Stallone, has pleaded guilty in federal court in Manhattan to charges that he diverted tens of millions of dollars of his clients' money to pay for his own lavish lifestyle. Read more in the Business section.

Regular readers may remember that I've spent more than a year trying to knock down the idea that the United States dare not get tough with China, because we need them to keep buying our bonds; as I wrote way back in May 2009, given the fact that we're in a liquidity trap, a decision by China to buy fewer of our bonds would actually be doing us a favor -- it would weaken the dollar, and help our exports.

Emily Weinstein is learning to bake with the food writer and cookbook author Dorie Greenspan. This week, Sarabeth Levine, of Sarabeth's Kitchen, steps in as a special guest instructor, per Dorie's suggestion. She is an expert in all things pie. Dorie will return next week.

The Pentagon has agreed to revise some of the rules that have restricted what journalists are free to report on from Guantánamo Bay, resolving a conflict that peaked in May when four reporters were expelled from the naval base there.
We canvassed the latest in medical literature and consumer magazines so you don't have to.

Most New Yorkers may not know exactly where they come from or who turns them on and off. But almost everyone in the New York region who has gazed into the night sky on Sept. 11 in recent years has come to expect to find twin beams of bluish-white light reaching from Lower Manhattan heavenward.
Jim O'Neill, the Goldman Sachs economist best known for coining the BRIC acronym, has been named chairman of the firm's asset management business.

School is back in session. And depending where you live, you've had days or weeks to get back in the routine. Which means you are probably still foundering around every morning trying to get out the door, right?

As my colleagues Anahad O'Connor and Liz Robbins report, a fire killed four people and destroyed dozens of homes after an explosion fueled by a ruptured gas line tore through a San Francisco suburb Thursday night.

On Tuesday, Eleven Madison Park reopened after a week of minor renovations and a substantial overhaul of its approach to fine dining. The restaurant also rethought coffee. It now has a dedicated barista working a La Marzocco in the back, as well as tableside coffee service: if you so desire, your meal will end with the spectacle of coffee prepared on a siphon or Chemex set up on a cart wheeled across the restaurant's terrazzo floor.

One of the more interesting revelations stemming from the arrest Thursday of Thomas A. Doyle on charges of fraud related to a 19th-century portrait was the existence of numerous inaccuracies in a lawsuit filed a week earlier related to the same painting.

The balcony is reopened: less than a month after the final episode of "At the Movies," the long-running cinema criticism show, was broadcast, Roger Ebert said he would bring back a version of the series that will be shown on public television next year.
Scott Shane on a new report that warns of homegrown terrorist threats, reaction from Kabul to a Florida pastor's wavering plans to burn the Koran and an Arts and Leisure fall preview.

Consumers who are shopping for their own health insurance have the option of hiring a broker -- someone who will, free of charge, help you price and compare various plans, as explained in today's Patient Money column.

Russia's 26-year-old veteran, Vera Zvonareva, shook off four broken strings to surge to a victory over top-seeded Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, 6-4, 6-3, on Friday to enter the women's singles finals at the United States Open, her second successive final in the world's four most important championships.

A federal judge in California ruled Thursday that the "don't ask, don't tell" policy toward gay members of the military is unconstitutional. As John Schwartz reports, Judge Virginia A. Phillips of Federal District Court struck down the rule in an opinion issued late in the day. The policy was signed into law in 1993 as a compromise that would allow gay and lesbian soldiers to serve in the military.
Barclays Capital has hired seven sales executives from BP, in a move meant to bolster its energy trading business in North America, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

In any other sport it's ridiculous to claim that anything that happens in the second week of the season can win or lose a championship. But college football is not like any other sport, and the second week of the season features some of the biggest games of the year. Ohio State puts its national championship hopes (and Terrelle Pryor's Heisman hopes) on the line as a tough and hungry Miami team comes to the Horseshoe in a rematch of the 2003 national championship. Last year's national champion Crimson Tide hosts Penn State in a matchup that may be a little more lopsided, but features two of the nation's most recognizable programs. Speaking of recognizable programs, how about Florida State traveling to Norman to take on Oklahoma? Oh, and there's also Notre Dame hosting Michigan. Then like a cherry on top, we get an intriguing SEC East tilt between Georgia and South Carolina.

Thursday night, to celebrate the debut of New York Fashion Week and the 50th anniversary of the nation's largest arts center, actual food was served - and actually consumed - for the first time at Lincoln, the $20 million, 150-seat new high-end restaurant housed in an alien-looking, wedgelike building at Lincoln Center. Our colleague Glenn Collins was there and has the story in Diner's Journal.

On Thursday, September 2, we welcomed about 100 developers to the 15th floor of the Times building for the first in a series of TimesOpen 2.0 events. Our goal was to bring together software developers, technologists and hackers to discover and discuss the latest and greatest on a variety of topics. Mobile/Geolocation turned out to be a great place to start.

Bill McKibben, an environmental campaigner from Vermont with a flair for showmanship, was rebuffed Friday morning in his effort to get the White House to reinstall one of the solar panels that President Jimmy Carter had placed on the White House roof.

So begins my latest essay in The New York Times Magazine this weekend. It's a look at the most interesting of questions -- what is our purpose here? And also at the more practical ramifications of the varied answers to that question. Is it our biological goal to become the best version of ourselves that we can be? Or is it to raise children to be the best that they can be? Or perhaps these are one and the same?

The Tate Modern museum, the planned site earlier this week for a launch party for Tony Blair's memoir that was canceled in fear of protests, became the site of a different demonstration on Friday when artists gathered in front of the museum to rally against possible government cuts to arts spending, The Associated Press reported.

While genetically modified crops have been the focus of pitched battles in Europe for nearly a decade, they have slipped into America's fields and onto its tables with hardly a peep. Although the technology was only developed in the 1980s, more than three-quarters of the nation's corn, soy and sugar beets are now genetically altered. The figure is close to zero in many European countries.
NEW ORLEANS - Brett Favre eased off the dais Thursday night, looking more bewildered than beaten by the Vikings' 14-9 loss to the Saints in the National Football League's season opener.

President Obama held his first full-scale White House news conference in three months and the first of the fall campaign season. He announced his promotion of the White House economist, Austan D. Goolsbee, to succeed Christina Romer as chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, and also addressed other issues of the day, including the Middle East peace talks and the debate over extending the Bush tax cuts.

On Thursday in Australia, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne announced a ban on the playing of pop music at funerals, which, he said, are not to be described as "a celebration of the life of" the deceased.

Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. Well, Rafael Nadal made quick work of Fernando Verdasco, who did not play badly. Note to parents: Want your son to grow up to be someone who can play tennis in a wind tunnel? LOTS of soccer. It's the FOOTWORK, stupid. Rafa, for instance, stormed the net last night with little, little steps -- and not only got there but made tiny, last-second, microclimatic adjustments. And unlike, say, Stanislaw Wawrinka or Mikhail Youzhny, he did not dump his resulting volleys into the net.

Rosh Hashanah, the two-day festival that marks the start of the Jewish year, draws to a close today, while the Muslim faith begins its observance of Eid al-Fitr, the three-day finale to Ramadan.

It's the cinematic equivalent of seeing Halley's Comet twice in a lifetime: it looks as if moviegoers will actually be getting a new film from Terrence Malick in a mere six years since his previous release. Fox Searchlight announced that it had acquired "The Tree of Life," the latest film by Mr. Malick, an auteur unencumbered by conventional measurements of time and who took a 20-year hiatus between his features "Days of Heaven" (in 1978) and "The Thin Red Line" (in 1998).

Officially and forever, the position of the New York Police Department has been that there is no such thing as quotas and that any driver who complains of receiving a summons only because officers are forced to write a certain number of tickets per day or week or month is simply trying to shift blame.

JPMorgan Chase may soon let employees use iPhones for corporate e-mail, making it an alternative to Research in Motion's BlackBerry  for the first time, two people familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

Whether you fancy yourself a rugged individual, or simply want to dress like one, this is your season, and our fall men's issue is here to guide the way. It starts with our cover star, Stephen Dorff, who in the course of his career has played a Beatle, a vampire, a transvestite, and in Sofia Coppola's upcoming film, "Somewhere," an actor whose career is on cruise control but whose life is about to veer into a ditch. Elsewhere in the issue, Jim Lewis visits the legendary photographer Bruce Davidson, whose Brooklyn Gang series from the 50's still clicks today; Holly Brubach revisits the work of Gay Talese, the man who practically reinvented sports writing; and David Knowles hops in a truck with Mister Mort and Jay Carroll in search of great American style. And speaking of trips, Steve Pulimood drops in on the artists Justin Lowe and Jonah Freeman as they transform an icon of modernist design into a swinging LSD safe house.

Reading David Brooks today, I couldn't help thinking of Bob Solow's old line that efforts to explain Britain's relative decline always end up in a "blaze of amateur sociology." That's not an attack on David; everyone does it -- although I might point out that the reason so many smart kids go into finance, not manufacturing, is that the pay is much better.

Regular readers may recall that back in May I fulminated about the OECD Economic Outlook. The Paris-based OECD is Conventional Wisdom Central; and in May, it dutifully relayed the conventional wisdom that advanced nations should start cutting spending and, even more remarkably, raising interest rates right away. As I pointed out, this made no sense even in terms of the OECD's own forecasts, which said that unemployment would remain very high and inflation very low for years to come.

Nokia, the cellphone maker, replaced its chief executive, Olli-Pekka Kallasvuo, on Friday with the head of Microsoft's business unit in a bid to turn around the handset maker's struggling smartphone lineup and stop a decline in market share in the United States, The New York Times's Kevin J. O'Brien writes.

The clock in the Windows 7 task bar gives you the time of day when you click on it, but you're not stuck with just one time zone. To add more clocks, go to the Start menu, choose Control Panel and click on Clock, Language and Region. Next, click on Date and Time. (You can also click in the time in the Taskbar to open up the clock and calendar display and then click on "Change date and time settings.")

Deutsche Bank, the largest German lender, is set to announce a share issue of up to 9 billion euros as it prepares for more stringent banking regulations and seeks to acquire a larger stake in Postbank, a person with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook.

Italy's flourishing craft brew scene has so seized the capital that it's tempting to predict that beer may soon eclipse wine as the Roman drink of choice. In the past 15 years, a smattering of small producers based primarily in the north has grown into a strong crop of more than 250 small microbreweries representing every national region. Names like Birra del Borgo, Birrificio Italiano and Le Baladin have gained international acclaim, and there are plenty of other noteworthy producers to look out for and no shortage of places in Rome where you can find their beers.

In the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into the fall of Lehman Brothers, scrutiny has turned to an accounting maneuver that artificially lowered the bank's debt levels, The Wall Street Journal reported.
National Pension Service, South Korea's biggest investor, said it was open to teaming up with Hana Financial Group or joining others to buy a stake in Woori Finance Holdings, Bloomberg News reported.

Today's idea: Fashion has fallen for the gap -- as in teeth, an article says. In an age of digitally and cosmetically assisted perfection, flawed chompers, not to mention scars and tattoos, denote authenticity.
A judge on Thursday reinstated eBay's 28.4 percent stake in Craigslist, but allowed the classifieds site to keep eBay off its board, Reuters reported.

Dubai World, the emirate's state-run investment arm, said Friday that 99 percent of its creditors had agreed to the terms for restructuring $24.9 billion worth of debt, less than a year after the troubled conglomerate spooked global markets when it stopped paying interest on loans accumulated before the financial crisis.

AIA, an Asian arm of American International Group, has signed a distribution deal with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, affirming its position as China's top foreign life assurer as it prepares for its November scheduled initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, has suggested a punishment for members of the euro zone that contravene the financial laws of the region, a temporary ban from political decision-making in the region,  The Financial Times reported.

In its bid to become a top global brand, the Japanese investment bank Nomura is steadily expanding into North America, setting up offices in Houston and Toronto this month and employing a team of natural-resource bankers, The Wall Street Journal reports.

Shanghai Pharmaceuticals, the Chinese partner of Roche Holding, said Wednesday it planned to raise at least 8 billion yuan ($1.2 billion) through a public share offering in Hong Kong to fund acquisitions, Reuters reported.
Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, poured cold water on reports it had raised its offer for Genzyme, saying it was sticking to its bid of $18.5 billion, or $69 per share, Reuters reported.

Sinopec Group and Cnooc of China are bidding for stakes in assets owned by Brazilian oil and gas start-up OGX in a potential $7 billion deal, sources with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters on Friday.

The largest brokerages in the United States say a provision in the regulatory reform legislation passed in July could hurt their lucrative sales of shares in initial public offerings, Reuters reported.

QR National, Australia's largest transport and logistics business, will likely agree to about 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) of loans from as many as 10 lenders next week ahead of a planned share listing, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

The mailbot brought restaurant questions from Alberta this week, from eastern Connecticut and the wilds of parenthood. As ever, I did my best to give good advice. Send me your questions and follow along on Twitter. Q. We are eight gals from Calgary, Canada, who will be in New York in mid-September and would love some advice from you about the evenings we have show tickets. First, do New Yorkers eat after the theater or before? If the answer is after, do you have any recommendations for restaurants in the theater district? Our tickets are for 8 p.m., and with a 2-hour 45-minute show we are a bit concerned about being too late for some of the better restaurants. Thank you for your help.

KUHNS--Richard, died on September 6, 2010 in New York City at the age of 86. He was Professor of Philosophy Emeritus at Columbia University and the author of numerous books and articles on aesthetics and literature. During the Second World War he was a member of the U.S. Army's 84th Infantry Division serving in Europe. Loving and beloved husband of Margaret Kuhns, devoted father of Frederick and father-in-law of Paula, adoring grandfather of Abigail and Samuel. Dear brother-in-law of Irene Winner and uncle of Ellen and Lucy Winner, loving grand-uncle of Kyla Winner-Connor and Benjamin Gardner. He will be deeply missed.

Please make checks to Trustees of Columbia University and mail to: Barbara Charbonnet, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, PO Box 1000, Palisades, NY 10964.

O'Connor of New Canaan, CT, Marjorie (O'Connor) and Nat Furman of New Canaan, CT, Catherine (O'Connor) and Matt Williams of New York, NY, John O'Connor of New York, NY and thirteen nieces and nephews who he adored and adored him back. Jerry was a graduate of Bronxville High School, Harvard College and the Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College. An article on Saturday about Joe Miller, who pulled off a surprise victory over Senator Lisa Murkowski in Alaska's Republican primary, described incorrectly a ballot initiative that passed with 85,000 votes. The measure requires parental notification -- not parental consent -- for abortions for children under 18.

An article on Wednesday about the decision by Richard M. Daley, the mayor of Chicago, not to run for re-election misstated the candidate filing deadline for the mayoral race. It is Nov. 22, not Nov. 30.

WEEKS--Diane Kathryn, Esq. passed away on September 6th, 2010 in Morristown, New Jersey, after a brief but fierce struggle with ALS. Diane was born in New York, NY on June 20, 1953 to Ann C. Polchak and Kenneth E. Weeks. A 1975 graduate of Princeton University, Diane received her Juris Doctorate from NYU law school in 1979. Her distinguished career as an attorney includes Enforcement Attorney for the SEC, Assistant Commissioner for Environmental Enforcement for New Jersey Department Environmental Protection Agency, Assistant United States Attorney, District of New Jersey and most recently an independent attorney in private practice. Diane is survived by her brother Kenneth, sister-in-law Kathleen, and her nieces and nephews, Scott, Sharon, Paul and Kelly of Chapel Hill, NC. Memorial service is at 2pm this Saturday, September 11th at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 70 Maple Ave., Morristown, NJ. 07960. In lieu of flowers, it is suggested that donations be made to the ALS Association of Greater NY/NJ in Diane's honor: www.als-ny.org

The Sports of The Times column on Tuesday, about Spanish players' success at the United States Open this year, erroneously attributed a distinction to the six Spaniards who reached the Round of 16. They tied Australia for the highest total by a country other than the United States since 1969; they did not tie the highest total by one nation since that year. (The United States had 11 players reach the Round of 16 in 1979.)

AFTER Sept. 11, 2001, street murals depicting the World Trade Center began to appear in poor neighborhoods across America. Artists approached store owners with their ideas, and in many cases finished their paintings within weeks of the attacks. Although some of them have disappeared, those that are left have rarely been defaced. In New York City, the murals frequently show firefighters, police officers and emergency medical personnel -- often local people known to the painter or to the merchant who commissioned the work. In one Bronx mural, monumental images of a firefighter and a police officer echo the lost twin towers.

Schedule information on Thursday with a music review of Barbara Cook and Michael Feinstein at Feinstein's at Loews Regency, using information from a publicist, misstated the date the engagement ends. It is Oct. 2, not Sunday.

KLUGE--John W. The Director, Board and staff of The Rogosin Institute are deeply saddened by the passing of John W. Kluge, a man whose intellectual brilliance and practical acumen, combined with his broad-ranging vision for, and commitment to, the betterment of humanity, made him one among a great many. His compassion and selfless generosity of spirit and resources have enriched the lives of countless individuals and institutions, both here and around the world. With respect to healthcare, his keen interest in improving the understanding and treatment of two major scourges of our world today, diabetes and cancer, have led to potential new treatments that are now in, or close to, human trials. Discussions of scientific issues with him were always a special treat. The full extent of his legacy in health has yet to be written, but it will be significant. We will miss his kind and gentle humor, but also his constant encouragement to reach higher, to achieve more. This was a man of many parts and for all seasons. Humanity has lost one of its very best, but the good that he has done will live on and only grow in scope and accomplishment. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Tussi, his children, and his entire family. Barry H. Smith M.D., Ph.D. and The Board of Directors of The Rogosin Institute

MARWELL--Edward M.,88, died at his long-time home in Mount Kisco, NY on September 7. He is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Grace, children Stuart (Vicki), Emily, David (Judy), and Josh (Chitra), as well as eight grandchildren. Edward, a WWII vet, co-founded Curtis Instruments, Inc. in Mount Kisco, a global company now celebrating its 50th year.

An article on Wednesday about the spread of bedbugs referred incorrectly in some copies to the founding of bedbugregistry.com, a Web site that reports infestations. It was started in November 2006, not this past November.

ROSS--Eric. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum deeply mourns the passing of Eric Ross, a refugee from Nazi Germany who was devoted to the cause of Holocaust education and remembrance. A leader in business and philanthropy, he was singularly generous in his support of the Museum. He and his late wife Lore were the institution's largest individual benefactors and inaugural members of the Chairman's Circle. The Museum's Ross Administrative Center is named in memory of his parents, Albert and Regina Rosenberg, who perished at Auschwitz. He was a long-standing member of the Museum's Council and an unwavering partner inspired by memory to change the future. The Museum extends its deepest condolences to Eric's children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Fred S. Zeidman, Chairman Joel M. Geiderman, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director United States Holocaust Memorial Museum

An article on Saturday about the last train to Montauk, Long Island, before the arrival of Hurricane Earl, misidentified two scientists from Durham, N.C., who were on the train to visit relatives in Bridgehampton. They are Katie and Mark Vignola -- not Margo and Tony Vignola, who are Mr. Vignola's parents.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the hiring of a writer for the book of a musical based on the songs of the Spice Girls, ''Viva Forever,'' erroneously attributed a Broadway credit to Simon Fuller, who has been developing the Spice Girls musical with Judy Craymer. Mr. Fuller, a former manager of the group, did not join Ms. Craymer in bringing the musical ''Mamma Mia!'' to Broadway in 2001.

FROMER--David, b. 1924 in Brooklyn, NY, died September 6, in Santa Monica, CA, at home, surrounded by his adoring family; his wife, of 60 years, Shirley, and his daughters Lisa Gelber, Amy Coane, Dori Fromer and Jana Cook. Also left bereft are his grandchildren, Jett and Wylie Gelber, Max and Cassie Coane, Simon and Emma Frank, and Hunter Cook, and his sons-in-laws Barry Gelber, James Coane and Harley Frank. He was a man of peace who fought valiantly in WWII, earning three Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star. David enjoyed a lengthy and varied business career in Los Angeles, London, Saudi Arabia, New York, and New Jersey. He was particularly proud of his role as co-creator of the redevelopment of the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City. However, he will be remembered most for his generosity, his gentleness, his wit and willingness to embrace every new idea. He mentored many, and saw the good in everyone he met. Life is less without him. There will be a memorial in NYC on Sunday, September 19th.

Funeral Mass 9:30am, St. Thomas Aquinas R.C. Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visitation Thursday and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at funeral home.

Since his election, Barack Obama's approval ratings have slid steadily - as they often do for presidents during their first term - presenting a sharp contrast to the last election season. Just two years ago, most Democrats did all they could to associate themselves with Mr. Obama. During the midterms, however, Republicans are using his name as ammunition against their opponents. Below, Mr. Obama's approval ratings in two states with close Senate races, and how candidates there are using his name in their campaigns. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the overlap of Fashion Week and Rosh Hashana carried an incorrect credit for the photographer, Tina Fineberg. She is a freelance photographer, not a New York Times staff photographer.

(ABC, Bio, CBS, Current, Discovery Health, E!, Fox, G4, HBO, HBO Latino, MLB Network, MUN2, NBC, Showtime, Smithsonian, Style, TV One, VH1) STAND UP TO CANCERMichael Douglas, who recently learned he has throat cancer, joins A-list survivors including Christina Applegate, Michael C. Hall, Maura Tierney and Lance Armstrong in this annual telethon, which has raised more than $100 million for research since its inception in 2008. Denzel Washington, Renée Zellweger, George Clooney, Will Smith, Seth Rogen, Jake Gyllenhaal and Reese Witherspoon also lend their star wattage to the cause. The news anchors Katie Couric, of CBS; Brian Williams, of NBC; and Diane Sawyer (above left, with Ms. Couric and Mr. Williams), of ABC, host and report on medical progress. 8 P.M. (Disney) THE SUITE LIFE ON DECK The singer and rapper Sean Kingston, playing himself, falls for London (Brenda Song) when he boards the S. S. Tipton, while Cody (Cole Sprouse) and Bailey (Debby Ryan) tour a chocolate factory. In ''Wizards of Waverly Place,'' at 8:30, Alex (Selena Gomez) uses her magic to transform Harper (Jennifer Stone) into a girlfriend for Justin (David Henrie) to help mend his broken heart. And in the premiere of ''Pair of Kings,'' at 9, Mitchel Musso and Doc Shaw play Brady and Boomer, 16-year-old fraternal twins -- one white, one black -- from Chicago who are crowned kings of the island of Kinkou, but not before destroying a sacred ruby during the coronation ceremony and causing a volcano to erupt.

KLUGE--John Werner. John Kluge's philanthropy touched every aspect of UCP. He served on the board, Business Advisory Council, and as Chairman and President of the UCP Research and Educational Foundation. He was a recipient of UCP/NYC's Humanitarian Award, an honor he shared with Princess Diana, Mohamed Ali, Bob Hope, Henry Kissinger, Margaret Thatcher, Barbara Walters, six U.S. presidents and four First Ladies. Only he, Frank A. Bennack, Jr., and Nancy Reagan received it twice. In the 1970s his Metromedia Company, through WNEW and its celebrity DJ Scott Muni, helped to create UCP/NYC's Bike-athon and supported it for over twenty five years, encouraging thousands of New Yorkers to reclaim Central Park, Prospect Park and Silver Lake Park. WNEW also hosted annual concerts and holiday toy drives. Over the years, his former wife Pat chaired the UCP Gamboling Gala and his daughter Samantha co-chaired the Junior Committee. The Board of Directors, staff, volunteers, adults, children and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City join his many friends in offering our heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathy to his wife Tussi, his children Joseph, Samantha, and John, and the entire Kluge family. Martin C. Hausman, Chairman Jerome Belson, President United Cerebral Palsy of New York City
WALKER--Lucius, Rev. Beloved friend. Friend of Cuba and ambassador for world peace. Dearly loved and missed. Don and Elaine Sloan

Devoted to family and friends, Howard was the managing attorney of the Manhattan office of staff counsel for Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, and earlier for CIGNA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Columbia University ALS Center: www.columbiaals.org. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY, 10am, September 12.

Elizabeth Jenkins, a novelist whose biographies of Jane Austen, Lady Caroline Lamb, Henry Fielding and Elizabeth I established her as one of Britain's foremost women of letters, died on Sunday in Hampstead, London, where she had been in a nursing home for several years. She was 104. Her death was confirmed by Michael Jenkins, her nephew.

An article on the Square Feet page on Wednesday about the growth of a medical campus in Orlando, Fla., misstated the city's ranking as a destination for medical meetings. RENARD--Pauline Saporta. Age 90. Died peacefully September 7, 2010, following a long illness. Adored wife of the late Neil Renard. Devoted mother of son, Jeffrey Saporta and daughter-in-law Adrienne of Old Westbury, NY, daughter Janet Adler and son-in-law Bruce of Upper Nyack, NY, and daughter Rita Singer Salzman of Philadelphia, PA. Loving grandmother of six. Great-grandmother of two. Her talent for creating beautiful surroundings for all she loved and her spirited personality will never be forgotten. There will be a graveside funeral on September 12, 2010 in Boynton Beach, FL.

WILLIAMSON--Mary, age 85, died at the home of her daughter, Patricia Duff, in New York City, on August 30, 2010 after a long illness. Mrs. Williamson was born in Arizona. She earned a Master's Degree in International Relations from Boston University. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and the Mayflower Society. She is survived by her children, Melanie, Thomas, Patricia and Nancy Orr, step children Robert, Richard, Katherine and Edward Williamson and by six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was preceded in death by her husband, Robert Williamson. She is to be interred at her husband's side at Arlington National Cemetery.

President Obama is making another financial investment in the battle to hold the Democratic majority, sending $4.5 million to help the party's candidates for House, Senate and governor. There was, of course, no recount or challenge at the end of the 2008 race, so the money has been sitting in the campaign account.

TORONTO-Mild-mannered, soft-spoken, and beaming broadly, the Microsoft chairman Bill Gates looked every bit the benevolent businessman as he took the stage at the Toronto International Film Festival on Saturday evening, to help plug the education-reform documentary "Waiting for 'Superman.'" Mr. Gates appears in the film, and, with his wife Melinda, heads a foundation that has invested heavily in improvements to education. But his aw-shucks manner couldn't hide the fact that some of the proposals he tossed off on stage at the Winter Garden theater here were volatile stuff. "We're investing in building these evaluation systems," Mr. Gates said. He was referring to systems that would evaluate the performance of public school teachers, with an eye toward ending the current tenure system under which many teachers now work, and providing a way to weed out the worst teachers, while, perhaps, rewarding the best. He also mentioned, at least twice, changes to teacher pension systems.

Lisa Leslie, who joined the W.N.B.A.'s Los Angeles Sparks for the league's inaugural season in 1997, was a three-time most valuable player and an eight-time All-Star before retiring last year. A former star at Southern California, she was in Manhattan recently to help promote the Capital One Cup, a new award in Division I college sports. It rewards athletic programs for their cumulative performance across multiple men's and women's sports.

At Duckie Brown's runway show yesterday, American Crew, the men's grooming brand, unveiled Curl and Boost, a new collection of specialized styling aids developed specifically for thinning and curly hair. Paul Wilson, the company's artistic director, created two distinct looks to demonstrate the line's versatility. While manipulating a model's thick, curly locks, Wilson said that the first style, which was sleekly molded and sculpted close to the head, showed off "shorter, groomed, tamed and really shiny hair." To sharply contrast that look, he created a second style that sported "full, lived in, dry-textured hair." A tandem exercise in style extremes, the models' hair complemented Duckie Brown's spring fashions, which ranged from tailored trousers in muted tones to eye-popping bug print shirts. The Curl and Boost system, which is comprised of Curl Control (tames rough, unruly hair), Curl Construct (defines and shapes curls), Boost Powder (mattifies and builds texture), and Boost Cream (lifts thin hair to new heights), sell for $17.95 each and will be available at authorized American Crew salons beginning in January 2011.

MONZA, Italy -- The qualifying session was interesting in more than just a few ways. For the first time since 2008 there is a Ferrari on the pole position, and the fact that it happened here in Monza for the Italian Grand Prix is not just special, it is magical. That it was Fernando Alonso who got it, while Felipe Massa took the third-fastest time was also certainly a nice feeling for the Spaniard who has been under fire so much since the team orders fiasco, where he has been accused of taking points for free from Massa.

Gucci Westman and Guido Palau imagined the spring makeup and hair (respectively) of the Rag & Bone downtowner as a bit of an afterthought following a rainforest adventure. The inspiration, Westman explained backstage, "was a combination of a real girl who's gone on a trip and Peter Lindbergh girls of the '80s." To wit, she used a taupe shadow (from Revlon's Multi Use Palette in Suede Rhapsody, available next month), cream blush (Revlon Berry Flirtatious) and Revlon Colorburst Lipstick in Fashion's Night Pout, which will only be available via the brand's Internet giveaways. Most fascinating was Westman's treatment of the brows: she brushed them through with Elizabeth Arden Eight Hour Cream and set them with Brilliant Diamant, a hairspray that she picked up in Paris. ("We only have one bottle to share between us!" she said.)

Orly Genger is an artist with strong ties to fashion. Literally. Using only her fingers as tools, Genger crochets chunky yarn and heavy industrial elastic into monumental geometric forms that evoke the seemingly contradictory traditions of minimalist sculpture and women's handicraft. In her collaborations with the jewelry designer Jaclyn Mayer, she transforms her signature forms into stunning statement necklaces that interweave metal with radiantly colored rope. This season, the Genger-Mayer team is creating runway accessories for Victoria Bartlett and Lela Rose. Here, Genger discusses her fashion designs and what led to her success.

After Levi Kreis, the Tony Award-winning star of Broadway's "Million Dollar Quartet," made the pilgrimage to the hotel suite of Jerry Lee Lewis, it was only fair that Mr. Lewis return the favor. On Friday night, Mr. Lewis, the last surviving principal member of a legendary 1956 jam session that also included Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Carl Perkins, came to the Nederlander Theater to play three encores with his "Million Dollar Quartet" counterparts. Video of Mr. Lewis's performance (which we hear also drew former President Bill Clinton, his daughter, Chelsea, and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky, to the theater) appears above. Is this the first time that two Jerry Lee Lewises have shared the same piano?

Science, art and fashion come together in the latest collaboration between Ohne Titel's Flora Gill and Alexa Adams and their friend, the first-time jeweler and longtime artist Tauba Auerbach. The accessories, which will make their debut this weekend on the Ohne Titel runway, were the result of much experimentation - with shapes, geometry, problem solving and visual equations, even a science lab. "Our creative processes are similar and both very technical," Gill says. "It made sense since our work shares a sleekness combined with underlying hand-wrought elements." Contorting acrylic tubing around colorful enamel chords, Auerbach created a spiraling sculpture-like necklace and chose polished lucite and elastic bracelets. "I wanted to use a lot of clear material so that I could make big pieces that wouldn't be too dominating," she says. "I thought it would be interesting to see the clothes through the jewelry, and to make certain parts of the pieces like the elastic on the bracelets appear suspended in the air around the models' wrists. I chose Lucite because it was durable and I could form it myself." Our hypothesis? We'll see bold graphics, wisps of bright orange and red alongside a looser silhouette with a play on sheer fabrics.

Despite breaking California's campaign spending record and running thousands of ads since the June 8 primary, recent polls show that Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, is still neck and neck with her Democratic opponent, Jerry Brown, who just this week broadcast his first television and radio ads. Ms. Whitman, the former C.E.O. of eBay, has spent $100 million, mostly her personal fortune, while Mr. Brown has spent less than $1 million through the beginning of August. Ms. Whitman's best chance of winning in November rides on whether she can capture the vote of independents, who make up a fifth of all registered voters in California. In 2006, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, won after taking more than half of the independent vote.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital. For the first time in 10 years, according to a recent report by Market Rates Insight, we're seeing the average interest rate drop below 1 percent on checking, savings and other deposit accounts. You're intimately aware of this fact if you're trying to generate income or live off the interest from your savings or money market account. The issue applies to the short-term bond market, too.

It was nearing midnight at the United States Open on Thursday and Rafael Nadal was late for his postmatch news conference because he was in the men's locker room shaving. In the vainglorious world of professional tennis, there are worse breaches of civility than a 12 o'clock shadow. But Nadal, the men's top seed from Spain, is his uncle's nephew. And Toni Nadal, his first and only coach, views his job as making sure Nadal puts his best face forward.

Most New Yorkers may not know exactly where they come from or who turns them on and off. But almost everyone in the New York region who has gazed into the night sky on Sept. 11 in recent years has come to expect to find twin beams of bluish-white light reaching from Lower Manhattan heavenward. Or are they descending from heaven down to Lower Manhattan?

MEHLICH--William O.,passed away September 8, 2010 at White Plains Hospital, White Plains, NY. He was 99. William was born on December 14, 1910 in the Bronx, NY. He was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School of Business. He served in the Navy as Lieutenant Commander during World War 2. He was a second generation commercial real estate broker and developer and joined his father's business in the late 1930's which is now located in Tuckahoe, NY and run by his son and grandson. He was an active Realtor and commercial real estate developer in both New York, Connecticut and Florida. William was one of the first members of the International Council of Shopping Centers back in 1958 which is now a world wide trade organization. He was the oldest and longest member of the Westchester Country Club. He is survived by his beloved wife who have been married 67 years, Astrid C. Mehlich, his daughter, Cheryl M. Schmitz of Lake Forest, Illinois, his son, Robert W. Mehlich of Scarsdale, NY, his daughter-in-law, Anne C. Shera Mehlich, his grandchildren, Roger W. Schmitz of New York City, Frederick M. Schmitz of Lake Forest, Illinois, Robert W. Mehlich, Jr of New York City and Peter C. Mehlich of Scarsdale, New York. Visiting Hours will be on Monday, September 13, 2010 at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY, from 5-7pm. A funeral service will be held at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Scarsdale, NY on Tuesday, September 14th at 2:00pm. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Project Hope, 255 Carter Hill Lane, Millwood, VA 22646.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) SHERLOCK HOLMES(2009) Robert Downey Jr., above right, and Jude Law, above left, adorn themselves with varying amounts of facial hair to play Arthur Conan Doyle's crack sleuth and his sidekick. Mr. Downey portrays Holmes, and Mr. Law plays Watson in this adaptation from Guy Ritchie, set in ''a smoky, greasy, steam-punk rendering of Victorian London, full of soot and guts and bad teeth and period clothes,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Rachel McAdams is Irene Adler, a dazzling thief ''inserted into the picture in a pretty, flouncy red dress to add a splash of color and dispel a few hints of homoerotic subtext,'' he added. And Mark Strong is an evil aristocrat, executed for a string of murders, who returns from the dead to mobilize an ancient secret society. The movie ''is kind of cool'' and ''intermittently diverting,'' Mr. Scott wrote. ''Best of all is the banter between Mr. Downey and Mr. Law, who is looser and more mischievous than he's allowed himself to be in quite some time. The mustache suits him.'' 10 A.M. (Fox News Channel) 9 YEARS LATER, THE 'REAL' COST OF FREEDOM Neil Cavuto reports on 9/11 commemorative events and discusses the state of the country with guests including former Gov. George E. Pataki; Richard A. Grasso, former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange; and John N. Lieber, president of World Trade Center Properties. ''9/11: Timeline of Terror,'' at 4 and 9 p.m., chronicles the day's events through interviews with former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice; former Vice President Dick Cheney; and survivors and rescuers from the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

Despite breaking California's campaign spending record and running thousands of ads since the June 8 primary, recent polls show that Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, is still neck and neck with her Democratic opponent, Jerry Brown, who just this week broadcast his first television and radio ads. Ms. Whitman, the former C.E.O. of eBay, has spent $100 million, mostly her personal fortune, while Mr. Brown has spent less than $1 million through the beginning of August. Ms. Whitman's best chance of winning in November rides on whether she can capture the vote of independents, who make up a fifth of all registered voters in California. In 2006, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, won after taking more than half of the independent vote. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print

Vermont's race for governor can finally move into gear after a recount confirmed that Peter Shumlin, the State Senate president pro tem, won the Democratic primary last month. The recount, completed Friday, gave Mr. Shumlin an additional 25 votes, putting him 203 votes ahead of his closest challenger, State Senator Doug Racine. Mr. Racine conceded on Friday and promised to help Mr. Shumlin in his race against Lt. Gov. Brian Dubie, a Republican.

Trying to capture some momentum in Ohio's Senate race, Lt. Gov. Lee Fisher, the Democratic candidate, has called in reinforcements this weekend - former President Clinton, who has proven to be a popular presence for Democrats on the campaign trail this year. Mr. Clinton is set to appear with Mr. Fisher on Sunday in Cincinnati, the home turf of Republican Senate contender Rob Portman, the former Bush administration official who has been leading Mr. Fisher in the polls and the bank account. Mr. Fisher has a long relationship with Mr. Clinton, dating back to Mr. Clinton's bid for president in 1992, and Mr. Fisher supported Hillary Rodham Clinton for president in 2008.

The twins Mike and Bob Bryan derailed the Indo-Pak Express on Friday at the United States Open, winning the men's doubles final over the team of Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan and Rohan Bopanna of India, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (4). It was the Bryans' ninth major men's doubles title and third Open crown. Qureshi and Bopanna, who handed the Bryans a rare defeat in Washington, D.C., last month, were appearing in their first Grand Slam final.

Because of an editing error, an article and a headline on Friday about a Brooklyn police precinct that appeared to be using quotas for summonses described incorrectly the number that officers were expected to write each week. In a recording of a meeting at the precinct, supervisors said that officers on a particular shift should write -- as a group -- 20 summonses a week; they did not say that each individual officer should write 20 a week. An article about the police's response to the accusations is on Page A15.

I check my checking and credit card account statements nearly every day to make sure there are no fraudulent charges. For me, no amount is too small to fight -- whether it's the $300 in fraudulent debit card charges I noticed last month or more recently, a $10.95 ''travel center'' charge I realized I mistakenly made. But while my wrong charge threshold is pretty low, it seems that everyone has a different level they think is worth fighting for, after taking into account the time spent checking the account, waiting on the phone with customer service and the stress from the whole process.

A report in the Antiques column on Friday about Adam Weitsman, who has been donating items from his collection of New York stoneware to the New York State Museum in Albany, misstated the amount of time he served in prison after being sentenced to a year and a day in 2004 for writing worthless checks. According to the records department at the federal prison in Otisville, N.Y., he spent nearly eight months there, then another two and a half months in a halfway house. He did not spend a year in prison.

Some airline pilots would be required to get nine hours of rest between one work day and the next, an hour more than now, under proposed changes in federal rules announced on Friday that are intended to prevent fatigue in the cockpit. But some pilots could end up putting in longer days, because airlines could schedule them to be on duty for 10 hours if they work during the daytime, two more than permitted now.

He had thought out every detail of the clothes and accessories, not least the kind of women whose glamour and personalities would express his ideas about dressing.

BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK -- Every crossword this week, from Monday to Saturday, has been created by a member of the Puzzling Association of Brown University. Founded in 2008, the club for students has about 30 members, who meet weekly during the school year to solve and discuss puzzles. Each spring, it organizes a campuswide crossword tournament. Other universities with crossword clubs include Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Texas Christian. Brown's club, though, has the most members with published puzzles.

TORONTO - The actor Philip Seymour Hoffman performed double-duty for his latest film, "Jack Goes Boating," which screened earlier in the year at Sundance, is now playing here in Toronto and will open on September 17. The film, about a slightly reclusive limousine driver who finds love on a blind date, is adapted from Bob Glaudini's 2007 play. The spring beauty references to world travel, tribes and art keep coming, and seem to offer endless interpretations. Backstage at Altuzarra, the hairstylist Paul Hanlon deviated from his first plan. "Originally, we did a lot of dreadlocks, but it looked too dirty," he said. "I wanted something very severe, but quite chic as well." The solution: Hanlon slicked back the hair at the crown using Tigi Catwalk Your Highness Thickening Gel Creme, then back-combed sections "the way punks would" and flat-ironed them, creating pointy tips "so they look almost like knives." For a final touch, each model got one of seven shades of Kryolan glow-in-the-dark gel painted on a thick stripe of hair above one ear. "We wanted the hair color to be a fluorescent accessory like a belt or a wristband," Hanlon explained.

Political theorists, lawyers and policy-makers sometimes assume that responses to emergency should - morally should - aim at a speedy return to a "normal" that predated the emergency. This is implicit in the metaphor of resilience often used by officials for emergency response. "Resilience" suggests that the preferred aftermath of an emergency is quickly regaining one's former shape, bouncing back. Presumably it is possible to bounce back with a few permanent bumps or scars, but at the limit we might speak of an invisible mending ideal of emergency response: when the response is genuinely successful, the effects of the emergency entirely disappear: before and after are indistinguishable.

Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. So this is it -- though the "it" isn't exactly what we expected, which is not to say it isn't more momentous than we expected. In the slanty-sun and dark shade of Ashe late yesterday afternoon -- the light evoked World Series games, which seems appropriate enough -- the world of men's tennis reached an inflection point, as we now like to say. What was before gave way. You know something is happening, and you do know what it is.

It seems like Alexander Wang took in a showing of the Tamra Davis documentary, "Jean-Michel Basquiat: The Radiant Child," which premiered this summer-backstage at his spring 2011 collection, the late artist was the most cited reference by makeup artist Diane Kendal, hairstylist Guido Palau, and Nonie Creme, co-founder of nail polish brand Butter London. Wang's downtown gallerina was clad in sheer fabrics, optic white denim and wide-cut pants, paired with a no-look look that had beauty editors scratching their heads. "There isn't really much makeup today," said Kendal with a wry grin. She bleached brows by applying Wella Wellite Powder Lightener with a makeup brush "to keep the girls looking cool"-with the exception of Agyness Deyn, who apparently wasn't up for a color change. And on the rest of the face? "Just concealer where needed and moisturizer. We wanted the skin to look shiny." Over at the hair station, Palau said he "didn't want hair color to stand out" and get in the way of the identity of Wang's "new-age traveler woman." To make the look uniform, he mixed Fuller's Earth Clay-a cosmetic clay often used in DIY skincare recipes and that is also the main ingredient in popular 1940's hair powder Minipoo-with white pigment and slicked the concoction through the hair. The resulting look was futuristic on models (including runway vets Karen Elson, Omahrya Mota and Karolina Kurkova), but in reality would look like someone in the middle of undergoing a double process (perhaps to emerge as the grey-haired woman seen earlier today at Cynthia Rowley). The nails, filed to a rounded shape, also appeared peculiarly half-done: manicurists applied one coat of Butter London Nail Foundation Flawless Basecoat followed by two coats of the brand's Matte Finish Topcoat. The overall effect was certainly a look, and indeed, one best pulled off by a young art star, down to the late-breaking addition of faux rose gold septum rings.

Part of the pleasure in watching the six documentaries that Albert and David Maysles made, beginning in the early 1970s, about some of the huge environmental installations by Christo and Jeanne-Claude, is seeing how the entire process of obtaining permits and winning over public opinion opens up a democratic debate on art. (A debate taking place right now about Christo's proposed project for the Arkansas River in Colorado.) In the latest film, ''The Gates,'' about a project that began in 1979 and ended in February 2005 in Manhattan when a golden river of banners floated over the walkways of Central Park for two weeks, we hear arguments that have become depressingly familiar to anyone who has followed the work of Christo and Jeanne-Claude. There's the defacement tack, epitomized here by a woman who says that allowing ''The Gates'' in the park is akin to Picasso painting ''Guernica'' over ''The Last Supper.'' (If the park were a work of art in that way, then allowing anyone to walk in it would be an act of vandalism.) And then there is the moralistic stance, that surely there must be a more useful way to spend the millions of dollars that Christo raises to finance each project.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''As Athletic Directors Compete, Big Money Flows to All Sports,'' Sept. 3: The University of Florida athletic director has a $1.2 million contract, a budget of almost $95 million and ''command of three private planes''; the softball coach makes $250,000. This is a world where college coaches are household names, college presidents anonymous. What does any of it have to do with education?
