It used to be that a great-looking guy hoped to hear the words, ''He looks cool.'' But the latest compliment goes back a couple of centuries: ''Death becomes him.'' Not since Johnny Depp gave his swashbuckling performance in ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' -- bandanna and dreadlocks on his head, skull ring on his finger -- have men veered so eagerly toward skulls and crossbones.

When an actor who has had great success in light, comic roles decides his work has been froth and sets out to do something with ''meaning,'' the results are often dispiriting. There are exceptions, like Steve Martin in ''Pennies From Heaven,'' but generally it's no fun to watch talented people undervalue the qualities that made them a pleasure to watch in the first place. ''None but the Lonely Heart'' could have been one of those missteps. Cary Grant, the former Archibald Leach, felt an affinity with Ernie Mott, the cockney vagabond hero of Richard Llewellyn's novel and hired his friend the playwright Clifford Odets to adapt it for the film (for which Odets also made his directorial debut). It's a remarkable movie, unfulfilled on some level but also uncompromised. You can see why it didn't attract audiences and why the people who have seen it speak about it in the tone reserved for films that imprint themselves on your memory.

KAPLAN--Charles S.,passed away Wednesday, September 8th, at New York Presbyterian Weill Cornell Medical Center from complications of cancer. He was 57 years old. Charlie, as he was known to his many friends, was a lifelong resident of Brooklyn and worked for many years as a proofreader. He will be remembered for his beautiful spirit, his unconditional friendship, his loyalty and generosity, his love of cats and his large heart and good nature. He will be terribly missed by all who knew and loved him. Charlie was the lifetime companion of Mark Winkler and the devoted son of Jean Kaplan. He is also survived by his sister and brother-in-law Sandy and Lennie Kantor, his nephew and wife Frank and Donna Kantor, niece and husband Ronnie and Alan Blaustein, his aunt Sylvia Schnabel and two cousins Michael Schnabel and Larry Katz. A service will be held this coming Sunday, September 12th at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., at 2:15pm.

A COMPANY MAN In 2008, when Kim Jones was named the creative director of Alfred Dunhill, the fashion establishment responded with a resounding ''Huh?'' Jones, as The Times of London put it, was ''more club kid than clubman.'' He loved big sneakers, loud prints, hip-hop and a wee bit of bling. He cavorted with Kate Moss, Lily Allen and Kanye West. He made neckties out of puffy nylon and once stamped black circles onto a model's nipples. Sure, he had bona fides -- Central Saint Martins, stints at Louis Vuitton and Hugo Boss. But this was Dunhill, a Jermyn Street staple, a heritage brand. Cathy Horyn, the New York Times fashion critic, was less than enthusiastic about Jones's first efforts, but after a tentative start he has consistently garnered raves. The British Fashion Council has awarded him men's-wear designer of of the year twice -- both as an independent designer and, in 2009, for his work at Dunhill. ''It's a beautiful brand, but it was sort of a sleeping beauty,'' says the 31-year-old Jones, whose eclectic edge has given the house a wake-up call.

THE NEWS The Iraqi government announced that hundreds of antiquities and museum pieces looted from the country had been repatriated from the United States. BEHIND THE NEWS The items, many of them smuggled out of Iraq during the Saddam Hussein era, included a 4,400-year-old statue, an even-older pair of gold earrings and 362 cuneiform clay tablets. Of more recent vintage: Mr. Hussein's chrome-plated AK-47 assault rifle with pearl grip. Whether the items are safe now is debatable: A senior official disclosed that 632 pieces repatriated last year were now unaccounted for.

Sheraton Hotels & Resorts is embarking on a wave of expansion in China, opening 8 hotels there by year's end, which brings its 2010 total to 11. It plans to add 26 more in the next four years, far beyond its average of 4 per year. The class of 2010 includes the 490-room Sheraton Shanghai Hong Kou Hotel, which has five restaurants, a fitness center and an indoor pool. The hotel, which is to open on Nov. 1, is about a mile from Shanghai's historic Bund district. In the central business district of Guangzhou, China's third largest city, a 445-room Sheraton will adjoin a shopping mall and metro station.

If Steven Shainberg's ''Secretary'' -- loosely adapted from a Mary Gaitskill story -- were just a nice little movie about spanking, it might easily be relegated to the kitsch dustbin. Instead it's a fairy tale about erotic love and the deepest mysteries of sexual desire, with a happy ending in which two sad, sorry misfits find they complement each other perfectly. Maggie Gyllenhaal plays an awkward, repressed young woman who has just been sprung from a mental institution. She's a cutter, and her favored implement is a relic of girlhood with sinister overtones, a plastic ballerina figurine whose toe shoe has been sharpened to a stiletto point. James Spader is the jittery lawyer who hires her to work in his small, extremely underpopulated office. All he wants her to do is answer the phones and type letters on a clackety old electric typewriter. Before long he's circling his new hire's typing mistakes with red marker and spanking her bottom soundly for each one. Her response surprises her. She experiences more joy than she's ever felt in her life.

An article on Aug. 29 about a trip to state fairs in Delaware, Ohio and Maine misidentified one part of the route the author drove through from Delaware to Columbus, Ohio. The route went through Cumberland, Md.; it did not go through the Cumberland Gap, which is near the juncture of Kentucky, Tennessee and Virginia.

My wife and I just spent 10 days on holiday in New York City. It was our first visit to New York - actually, our first visit to the United States. We had a wonderful time. There is only one issue I would like to comment on: air-conditioning. I live in a country where air-conditioning is part of everyday life. We have very hot summers in Spain, and we are used to air-conditioning in shopping malls and cinemas, and on public transportation. But what I've encountered in New York City exceeds anything I've known before. Luckily, I had been warned about it by some friends who had just been to New York.
HOCHHAUSER--Joyce. Your unwavering strength and caring heart will not be forgotten. We will miss you dear friend. Bobbie Kahn & Family

BARTON--Jo Jeanne Millon, age 82, of New York City died peacefully on September 2, 2010. The daughter of the late Jean-Pierre Millon and Josephine Irish Millon. She is survived by her husband of 58 years Thomas H. Barton and by her daughters Brooke Millon Barton, MD of Los Angeles, California and Avril Barton Moore of Princeton, New Jersey and her grandchildren Thomas Barton Moore, Diana Millon Moore and Juliet Avril Moore. She was graduated from the Spence School and 1949 from Vassar College. She made debut at the Junior League Debutante Ball and at The New York Infirmary Christmas Cotillion. Her great-grandfather Charles Lassalle, founded the French language newspaper in New York. Le Courier des Etats-Unis, and organized the subscription for the base of the Statue of Liberty. Her mother was descended from John Irish who was left several shillings in the will of his neighbor Miles Standish in the Plymouth Colony. She spent a lifetime in community service in the leadership of volunteers. She served as President of the Junior League of the City of New York and later as Vice President and Director of the Association of Junior Leagues of America. She was President of the Drama League, the United Nations Hospitality Committee, the City Gardens Club and Regent of the Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the DAR. She served the Spence School as President of the Alumnae Board and a member of the Board of Trustees. Member of the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society and the Colony Club. She loved the company and camaraderie of her friends and fellow volunteers. Her great affection for people, her willingness to do the hard work in organizations, her parliamentary and organizational skills will be long remembered. She loved laughter, all things French, The New York Times Sunday crossword puzzles, Cole Porter and Sherlock Holmes. A memorial Mass will be held in the Fall at the Church of St. Thomas More where she was married in 1952.

Singapore's Changi Airport recently unveiled the Slide@T3, the tallest slide in Singapore and, for the record, at any airport around the world. The slide is the latest addition to a long list of unusual attractions at this airport (changiairport.com), including a movie theater, rooftop swimming pool and Butterfly Garden (also home to a collection of 200 carnivorous or insectivorous plants). For every $22 spent in the airport, adrenaline addicts (or really brave little children) get tokens for two rides on the slide. Visitors who don't want to travel at the speed of 19 feet a second can take a ride down the shorter, one-and-a-half-story-tall slide at Terminal 3 Basement 2, which is free. ALLISON BUSACCA

11:40 a.m. | Updated To an informed political eye, the independent Nevada gubernatorial candidate Eugene DiSimone's platform is one part Tea Party and one part nativist. He wants to deport undocumented immigrants and make state documents available in English only. He complains about lawyers and judges, who, as he said in a telephone interview, ''litigate and govern our society away when what we want is freedom and commerce.''

A Michigan lithium-ion battery developer, which is working on new technology the company says can give electric cars greater range, plans to announce on Friday that it has received $3.2 million from General Motors Ventures. G.M. said the new batteries could eventually end up in the company's cars. The battery company, Sakti3, is headed by Ann Marie Sastry, chief executive and a professor at the University of Michigan, who is working on solid-state batteries that may offer higher energy density, lower cost and smaller size than conventional lithium-ion batteries.

Lisa Leslie, who joined the W.N.B.A.'s Los Angeles Sparks for the league's inaugural season in 1997, was a three-time most valuable player and an eight-time All-Star before retiring last year. A former star at Southern California, she was in Manhattan recently to help promote the Capital One Cup, a new award in Division I college sports. It rewards athletic programs for their cumulative performance across multiple men's and women's sports. Q. Do you miss playing in the W.N.B.A.?

BOULANGER--Jacques. Jacques Pierre Rodolphe Boulanger, age 68, died peacefully at home in New York, NY on September 10, 2010. Born in Paris, he was the son of Roger Auguste Boulanger and Marguerite Cesare Zavaroni Boulanger of Paris and Arnage, France and graduated from EDHEC Business School, Lille, France and Columbia Business School. After a long career in New York as an investment banker, in 1995 he founded and headed a pioneering catalog and internet wine retail business. Jacques was not only devoted to his business, but was also an inveterate international traveler and master of many languages. He was known for his intellect, his wit, and his flair in dress and all things aesthetic. Mr. Boulanger is survived by Carol Seabrook Boulanger, his wife of 36 years, his son Rodolphe of New York, NY and his daughter Adriana of South Woodstock, VT. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. on September 15 from 6-8pm. A memorial mass will be held on September 16 at 11am at St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Ave at 84th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation, 57 W. 57 St. New York, NY 10019 in order to further research in frontotemporal dementia.

Loving Aunt and friend. A graduate of Knox School, Cooperstown, NY and attended the University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, who became a successful businesswoman. Friends may call on Monday September 13, 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to The ASPCA (The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals), 520 8th Ave., NY, NY 10018, 7th floor.

No, these aren't the faces of harried magazine editors during fashion week. The jeweler Eddie Borgo, who is up for this year's CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award, based his Horror Collar on the Mayor of Halloween Town in Tim Burton's 1993 film, ''The Nightmare Before Christmas.'' ''His wild mood swings made his cone head spin around from a happy face to a scary one,'' Mr. Borgo explains. ''It's a figurative representation of a two-faced politician.'' The silver-plated brass and crystal necklace is $500 at Bergdorf Goodman. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Rather than making the pilgrimage to the Ferrari museum in Maranello, Italy, fans of Italian sports cars might want to head to Yas Island in the United Arab Emirates, where Ferrari World Abu Dhabi opens Oct. 28. The autocentric theme park, next to the Yas Marina Circuit racetrack, will offer more than 20 action-packed attractions under its manta-ray-shaped, two-million-square-foot roof. Sure to be a big draw is the Formula Rossa roller coaster, which the park claims will be the fastest in the world, with carts inspired by F1 race cars reaching grand prix-worthy speeds of 149 miles per hour. A flume-type water ride, meanwhile, passes through a supersize Ferrari 599 V12 engine. ''You go in through the grille and then get taken high up above the manifold,'' says Troy Lindquist, the park's sales and marketing director. ''At the end, you're shot out of the tailpipe.'' TIM MCKEOUGH

When Charles Lindbergh took off from Long Island's Roosevelt Field on May 20, 1927, en route to Paris aboard the Spirit of St. Louis, his wardrobe was a study in packing light: Army-issue breeches and ankle boots, an Abercrombie and Fitch flight jacket designed by Benjamin Willis (later of Willis and Geiger Outfitters fame), a brown A. G. Spalding & Brothers jumpsuit to keep out the cold, a wool-lined leather helmet, goggles, a white shirt and -- in a nod to his home base and to the monoplane that would, 3,610 miles and some 33 hours later, make him the most famous man in the world -- a blue-and-red striped tie from Vandervoort's department store in St. Louis. The accessories were minimal, too: a pair of quart canteens, cotton wadding in his ears and a St. Christopher medal, handed to him at takeoff by a well-wisher named Katie Butler. The day after Lindbergh landed at Le Bourget airfield, he stepped out onto a balcony of the American Embassy and greeted a throng of euphoric Parisians in a hastily borrowed double-breasted suit. He'd flown with little more than the flying togs that, captured in untold miles of newsreel footage, became the indelible sartorial image associated with Lindbergh, a man Will Rogers described as a ''slim, tall, bashful, smiling American boy.'' After the flight, Lindbergh wrote that ''no man before me had commanded such freedom of movement over earth.'' Indeed, ''freedom of movement'' was also a guiding principle in Lindbergh's wardrobe: wearable, masculine, sporty, enduring. In the generations since, countless men have embraced the ruggedness of the classic aviator look for the same irresistible reasons. ''At the end of the day, guys like to dress up [like the] military,'' says Nigel Cabourn, the British outerwear guru whose archive of 4,000 pieces encompasses everything from early R.A.F. uniforms to expedition gear worn on Sir Edmund Hillary's ascent of Mount Everest. ''With aviation, it's a whole look, with hats, gloves, fat belts. And everything was pure -- pure wool, pure cotton, pure silk. That's what they were wearing on those aeroplanes. Nothing synthetic.''

The return of the waistcoat (last seen, in white, on Tony Manero) gives you more to dress up -- and down. And versatility is the least of it: you also get some tailored gravitas. Which, in this market, is nothing to sneer at. BRUCE PASK

Cowboys at RedskinsSunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Cowboys by 3 1/2 Those who do not learn from history are doomed to work in the Redskins' front office. The team acquires big-name veterans every off-season, even though their overpriced acquisitions usually arrive with inflated reputations, baggage and ''headaches'' (quotes provided by Albert Haynesworth). The team spent this week trying to trade the malcontent savant Haynesworth, but he'll be in uniform on Sunday night, if not in the starting lineup. Meanwhile, the team discovered that new quarterback Donovan McNabb was actually a brittle 34-year old feeling the effects of 357 career sacks. Perhaps they should have read the label. McNabb will play on a sprained ankle this week. His weapons include Clinton Portis, Joey Galloway, Larry Johnson and other players whose extended warranties expired years ago. McNabb is 11-8 against the Cowboys in his career, but the last two losses -- 24-0 in the 2009 in the season finale, 34-14 in the playoffs -- were whoppers.

Maybe it's because I spent so much of my childhood rampaging through the woods pretending to be one of Robin Hood's outlaws or the last Mohican, but I think of old-fashioned knives (the sort you'd use to survive in the wild rather than slaughter rival drug dealers) as being noble rather than scary. I'm not alone. Anyone who wants to play spot-the-designer at the Milan Furniture Fair should skip the fair itself and head for G. Lorenzi, the lovely old coltellinaio, as the Italians call cutlery shops, on the Via Montenapoleone. You'll find lots of boldface men (and women) drooling over beautifully made handles and blades. The knife is a rare mix of precision and sensuality, two irresistible design qualities. Functionally, it's remorseless. If the blade isn't ground into exactly the right form, it won't cut. The same rigor is required of the handle and sheath, which have to be easy to grip even in extreme conditions. Yet knives can be made from very seductive materials: metal, bone, wood, leather. There is also the romantic symbolism. ''A knife is a tool -- one of the most ancient tools, in fact,'' said the German designer Konstantin Grcic. ''It can kill but also save lives. That's what's so fascinating about it.''

Whenever it feels like the sky is falling on men's fashion, it's warming to remember that one of Beau Brummell's London tailors, Meyer & Mortimer, is still dressing the hyper-fastidious. This fun fact is one of hundreds in ''Bespoke: The Men's Style of Savile Row'' (Rizzoli), a new tome as handsome as its subject. Up front, the author James Sherwood clears up any uncertainty fogging the much-abused term: To earn the label bespoke a garment must be measured, cut and sewn by hand; the pattern must also be hand-cut. When the pioneers of custom British tailoring took their first orders in the early 1800s, they were for clothes inspired by the ''honest'' wardrobe of the English country gentleman. In 1929 Hawkes & Co. did the unthinkable by introducing ''immediate wear'' to Savile Row, and by 1948, sales of the firm's off-the-peg suits surpassed those of bespoke. It's a trend that has never been reversed, though not for want of trying. In the '90s, Richard Anderson, Ozwald Boateng and Richard James opened shops, forming what Sherwood tags ''The New Establishment.'' And Edward Sexton, Spencer Hart and Timothy Everest are currently powering a ''Row Renaissance.'' ''Bespoke'' is especially good on the crazy language peculiar to the Row. Who knew that a ''tab'' is a fussy customer, or a ''crushed beetle'' a badly made buttonhole? CHRISTOPHER PETKANAS
An article last Sunday about the actress Cherry Jones misidentified the main female character in Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night'' that Ms. Jones once played. The character is Viola, not Violet.

CARLSON--Walter M. Born September 18, 1916, in Denver, Colorado, and passed on August 21, 2010, in Los Gatos, California. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Nancy Ellzey Carlson, six children, and ten grandchildren who will hold him in their memories. Walter, a Colorado native from one of the Pioneer Families of the State of Colorado, graduated from East High School in Denver, Colorado in 1934, and the University of Colorado at Boulder in 1939 with a Masters Degree in Chemical Engineering. During his years at CU Boulder, he served as the editor-in-chief of the campus Silver and Gold newspaper, where he met his future wife, Nancy Ellzey. He was first employed by the E.I. DuPont de Nemours Company in New Jersey, and then at the Louviers facility in Newark, Delaware. At DuPont he became a recognized expert in large scale computer applications for business uses. He guided DuPont to pioneering use of computers in its corporate business. He published articles in technical journals on computer applications and became well known in computing associations for his vision on the business applications of computing equipment. In 1963, Walter was appointed Director of the Office of Technical Information by the United States Department of Defense Director of Defense Research and Engineering. He successfully completed a project by 1967 in which he developed a fledgling intra-net communications network among both private and public defense research facilities across the country to prevent duplicate defense research. In 1967, he was hired by International Business Machines (IBM) to serve as a Technical Consultant to the Chief Scientist at its corporate headquarters in Armonk, New York. He was then transferred to the Corporate Marketing Department where he worked as a marketing consultant to the Vice President of Marketing. He was later able to transfer his responsibilities to San Jose, California. Beginning in the 1960's, Walter was also active in a number of professional computing trade associations, including the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM), International Federation of Information Processors (IFIP) and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE). In the early 1960's he was a founder of the American Federation of Information Processing Societies (AFIPS). From 1970-72, he was President of ACM, the world's largest educational and scientific computing society. One of Walter's longest lasting projects was the history of computing archives and project in the National Museum of American History at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C. His tireless promotion of this endeavor led to contributions to it by IBM and AFIPS. Walter retired in 1991 and continued to work on projects with ACM, AFIPS, IEEE, and other organizations for many years. Walter dearly loved golf and travel, enjoyed politics, and later in life, became an avid tennis fan. He particularly enjoyed bringing his family together to celebrate family occasions. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that, in Walter's memory, please make a contribution to Hospice of the Valley, 4850 Union Avenue, San Jose, California 95124. They can also be found at www.hospicevalley.org. A Memorial for Walter will be held at the Terraces of Los Gatos, 800 Blossom Hill Road, Los Gatos, California, on December 12, 2010, at 10:00am. Contact (415)459-1850 or Terry@terrycarlsonlaw.com for further information.

Gerry Beckley has some peculiar enthusiasms. A founding member of the '70s Cali-rock band America, he spends most of his days on the road reviving ''Sister Golden Hair.'' And each morning, like clockwork, he photographs the view from his hotel-room window -- a ritual he's kept up for about 15 years. Wherever Beckley happens to be -- a United States Air Force base in Japan, a street stall in Ecuador -- he's prowling for vintage treasures: classic tennis sneakers (Dunlop plimsolls), wristwatches (Bell & Ross) and especially eyeglasses made in the 1950s and 1960s by American Optical and others of that thick-framed ilk. ''My tastes tend toward the archival,'' says Beckley, 58, who has become so sophisticated about design that he can talk shop with an expanding clutch of artistically inclined friends, including the minimalist architect John Pawson and the fashion designer Steven Alan.

In Vienna's cobblestoned center, where horse carriages amble by and street signs are printed in gothic type, bygone artisans still flourish: some of the most beautiful storefronts belong to tailors and shoemakers that have been there for generations. And yet, with Helmut Lang and Raf Simons having done turns teaching at the city's fashion school, a nascent contemporary men's-wear scene has emerged, making no Viennese shopping expedition complete without experiencing old and new. MONICA KHEMSUROV 1. Knize: Since Josef Knize started his eponymous tailoring service 152 years ago, it has outfitted European kings, Viennese jockeys and the stars of Hollywood's golden era. Members of the modern gentry still flock to the Adolf Loos-designed showroom. Graben 13; 011-43-1-512-2119.

NEW DELHI -- Thousands of demonstrators staged a violent protest in Kashmir on Saturday, setting fire to a police office and other government buildings in the latest angry outburst after three months of almost daily Muslim protests against Indian rule in the Himalayan region. Security forces reportedly fired into the air to dispel the crowds. There were no deaths, but three civilians and two police officers were injured, according to the authorities.

HEDI SLIMANE Beginning in 2000, Hedi Slimane transformed Dior Homme into a men's-wear obsession. Rock stars and wannabes clamored for his sleekly tailored goods; Karl Lagerfeld reportedly lost 80 pounds just to fit into a Slimane suit. But these days, besides the odd collaboration -- a DVD compilation with MK2 called ''American Youth,'' an exhibition with the P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center -- Slimane has devoted himself to photography. ''It is like switching to a different language,'' he says. ''Not that it affects anything I have to say.'' Slimane keeps photographic ''diaries'' on his Web site, which includes portraits of Lindsay Lohan and Courtney Love (far right). For our cover story (''Somewhere Man,'' Page 114), Slimane cast fresh light on Stephen Dorff, the star of Sofia Coppola's forthcoming film, ''Somewhere.''

When grunge exploded onto the scene 20 years ago, it brought a renewed appreciation of two all-American classics: rock 'n' roll and the plaid flannel shirt. Worn oversize, wrinkled and torn, over smiley-face T-shirts or wrapped at the waist, flannel was a bold anti-fashion fashion statement, one that Marc Jacobs promptly paraded down the runway to instant acclaim. This fall, designers have gone to the other extreme, elevating those rustic shirts to sophisticated chic. Ralph Lauren is offering brushed cotton plaids with a matching tie, black leather jacket and black cords for city slickers. Michael Bastian features a tartan shirt under a three-piece corduroy suit, while the shirt makers Gitman Vintage and Gant are promoting a variety of weights and patterns.

DORTORT--David. President Lisa Staiano-Coico and the faculty, students and alumni of the City College of New York send their deepest condolences upon the death of our esteemed alumnus David Dortort, Class of 1936, to his son and daughter-in-law, Fred and Gael Dortort, and his daughter, Wendy Czarnecki. The creator, writer and executive producer of Bonanza, one of the longest running primetime dramatic series in television history, lasting 14 years, and The High Chaparral, he was responsible for breaking through television stereotypes of women and minorities in his sometimes controversial but always thoughtful scripts. Throughout his life, David Dortort brought to life characters and stories that became part of our folklore and our lives. At his Alma Mater, Mr. Dortort established the David Dortort Endowed Scholarship in Creative Writing and the David Dortort Endowed Lectureship in Writing for the Dramatic Arts: Stage, Film, and Television, which has supported presentations by Tony Kushner and Arthur Penn. Mr. Dortort and his late wife, Rose, also were benefactors of the CCNY Film Festival, CityVisions. Through his life, he exemplified his credo, "Once you establish the harmony that exists in the dramatic arts, you can entice, educate, and entertain."
To have and to hold on to. SANDRA BALLENTINE

''The '57 Thunderbird is elegant, sporty -- it's a gentleman's sports car,'' says Evan Yurman, the design director of men's jewelry and watches for David Yurman, not to mention a vintage car buff. Evan, who is the son of David Yurman, might very well be describing the company's brand-new Classic 1957 Limited Edition watch, a sporty, elegant and, yes, gentlemanly timepiece that was inspired by cars from the '50s and the Thunderbird's instrument panel in particular. ''I drive these kinds of cars a lot, and I'm always staring at the speedometer to see where I'm at,'' he says. For Yurman, the '50s were the golden era of American design, and not just in the automobile industry. ''I tip my hat to it and hope I can only add to this legacy.'' When it comes to cars, however, it's ultimately what's under the hood that gets him revved up: he loves the '57 T-Bird for its beauty more than its brawn. ''It is a cruiser, a cream puff,'' says Yurman, who instead owns a '66 Bel Air and a '69 Ford Mustang. ''I go for the one where some guy in the factory said, 'Let's make this car as fast as we can.' '' ALIX BROWNE

Since men's clogs are coming out of the kitchen this season, Christine Muhlke asked Anthony Bourdain what he really thinks of them: ''I wore clogs when I cooked for the same reason so many cooks have faithfully worn them through the years: because, in spite of their hideousness, they are perfectly suited to the job. They are comfortable. They provide optimum and all-important back and arch support. They allow maximum air circulation while still providing protection against dropped knives, pans, spilled boiling liquids. Because of their ugliness, when it's time to throw out one food-encrusted pair and buy another, there is no sentimental attachment. These days, I only wear my old kitchen clogs for (very) quick runs across the street for toilet paper or bagels. And I pray I'm not seen while doing it.''

Vanessa Redgrave gives an indelible performance in the lovely romantic charmer ''Letters to Juliet,'' which arrives on Tuesday and also features Amanda Seyfreid and her gorgeous peepers. The next week (Sept. 21) there's the restored collection of the French director Louis Feuillade's silent serial ''Fantômas,'' about the masked thief who engulfs Paris in a reign of terror; and Neil Jordan's enchanted sea fable, ''Ondine,'' starring Colin Farrell. A big delivery on Sept. 28: Jon Favreau's ''Iron Man 2'' with Robert Downey Jr. heading the cast; the amusing Bob Hope comedy thriller ''My Favorite Spy''; Marcello Mastroianni, Gina Lollobrigida, Melina Mercouri and Yves Montand in ''The Law,'' directed by Jules Dassin; and, for trash aficionados, Jacqueline Susann's ''Once Is Not Enough.'' But that's not all. On the same day two World War II dramas arrive from Criterion: Nagisa Oshima's ''Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence'' and Terrence Malick's ''Thin Red Line.''
LEE--Sang-Ho. Theologian and Artist. Former Yonsei University Dean and Minister. He leaves his wife, four children, and 11 grandchildren.

For those who've never had the opportunity to party like a rock star and felt like they were missing out, ''Please Take Me Off the Guest List'' (Akashic Books) may very well smooth over those regrets. A collaboration between the writer (and singer and Beauty Bar Brooklyn bartender) Zachary Lipez, the photographer (and Yeah Yeah Yeahs guitarist) Nick Zinner and the designer (and former design director of Artforum) Stacy Wakefield, the book chronicles the side effects of a hyperactive night life, including rambling cocaine narratives, a job as a disgruntled clerk at the Strand bookstore and the joys of being sent to fetch a straw from the bodega for your girlfriend's morning P.B.R. ''I call dibs on the indefensible,'' Lipez says. Sobriety may not figure, but when consciousness raises its head, it is acerbic, anarchic and definitely not for the faint of heart. SHONNI ENELOW

Harry Nilsson pioneered his own special genre of the rock 'n' roll bender. It often began with a phone call at an odd hour and ended, in the case of Micky Dolenz of the Monkees, three days later at a massage parlor in Phoenix. Robin Williams, whose 1980 film ''Popeye'' was scored by Nilsson, covers his face when recalling a similar spree with the songwriter: ''Did I really? A weed whacker?!'' There's no end of booze and drugs -- and famous friends -- in John Scheinfeld's documentary ''Who Is Harry Nilsson (And Why Is Everybody Talkin' About Him?),'' which opened Sept. 10 in New York. But the film is more than a catalog of the singer's exploits, the extent of which almost certainly contributed to his early death, in 1994 at age 52. Randy Newman compares him to Schubert. ''John loved him, too'' Yoko Ono says.

SOLOMON--Sandra Epstein, passed away on Friday, September 10, 2010, following a long illness. Sandra was the devoted wife of Alan for 50 years; the loving mother of David, Andy, Jeff, Mary and Michele; the adoring grandmother of Katie, Carrie, Samantha and Lyla. Founder of Solomon-Shotland Audiology in White Plains, NY, Sandy was passionately devoted to her patients who relied on her for their hearing. The funeral service for Sandra Solomon will be held on Sunday, September 12, 2010 at 11:00am at Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home in Great Barrington, conducted by Rabbi Deborah Zecher, spiritual leader, Hevreh of Southern Berkshire. RUSH/ (rush) /n. / A hurried state that aptly describes the blitz of Arctic-explorer outerwear, e.g., ''Designers are in an adrenaline-charged rush to get men to buy polar''; [slang] an exhilarated feeling experienced upon taking a drug, as in, ''What did they serve at the opening of the LSD safe house installation? The critcs were so giddy that the reviews read like a collective rush.'' IMPRESSTAURANT/ (im pres te ränt) /n. / A portmanteau used to describe an eatery chosen not for the food but in order to make a good impression (usually on a first date), e.g., ''He went all-out -- a three-piece suit, a corsage and a corner booth at the new Danny Meyer impresstaurant.''

''We must not let Harvey Pekar's brilliance be diminished by pettiness. As talented as the artists were, especially R. Crumb, the writing was Pekar's magic. He will be missed.'' Epaulet makes custom shirts, this right? ''selvedge'' appears more frequently on Web and appeared in Critical Shopper column selvage jeans and corduroys in a shade of lime called ''go-to-hell green.'' Welcome to D.I.Y.-crazed Brooklyn. The emphasis at this modest Cobble Hill storefront is on fabric and fit: Epaulet's button-fly chinos (from $135), which have inspired cultish devotion, fit snugly, like a perfect pair of jeans. ''We run on the Louis Vuitton model,'' says Michael Kuhle, who opened the store two years ago with his wife, Adele Berne. ''We never do markdowns because all our stuff sells out.'' Their latest offering is an urban safari shirt (left; $245) created with Hamilton, the Houston-based heritage label. It has easy-to-roll-up sleeves, the better to show off a wry tattoo. Go to epauletshop.com. STEPHEN HEYMAN

CONSIDER the Polaroid picture. When taken by a great artist, does it somehow become more than just a dull and grainy impression? Last year, this question prompted a shouting match on The Moment, with readers arguing about the artistic merit of a series of Andy Warhol Polaroids shown at Danziger Projects. Now the artist and filmmaker Julian Schnabel shows us his Polaroids in a new book by Prestel creatively titled ''Julian Schnabel: Polaroids.'' In addition to shots of his Montauk, N.Y., studio, his family and a series of rephotographed late 19th-century images called ''Crazy People,'' Mr. Schnabel pointed his rare 1970s-era Polaroid camera at Lou Reed, Placido Domingo, the Beastie Boys and his pal Mickey Rourke (left). No doubt about it, the red wash and hand-lettering are value added. SARAH LEON

Paul Thek (above left) was a practicing Catholic and renegade homosexual, a lover of the photographer Peter Hujar and companion to Susan Sontag (who dedicated ''Against Interpretation'' to Thek), a sculptor and creator of immersive environments so devoted to the ephemeral in art that his major works were lost and his reputation eclipsed within his lifetime. On Oct. 21, the Whitney and the Carnegie Museum of Art will present ''Paul Thek: Diver, A Retrospective'' the first major United States survey of works by this legendary and complex artist, who died of complications from AIDS in 1988 at the age of 54, after a creative life spent shuttling nomadically among points as diverse as Amsterdam, Paris, Rome, the East Village and a remote corner of Fire Island. Included in the lineup are ''Untitled (Buzzard)'' (1968; above right) and the ''meat pieces'' he began exhibiting in 1964 -- uncannily realistic wax depictions of hunks of flesh, dotted with flies and encased in Plexiglas, which were his ''hot'' answer to the art world's prevalent trend of ''cool'' Minimalism, and which anticipated the works of Robert Gober and Damien Hirst by decades. ''We accept our thing-ness intellectually,'' he said of these works, inspired by his 1963 visit with Hujar to the catacombs of Sicily, ''but the emotional acceptance of it can be a joy.'' LESLIE CAMHI

ON THE SCREEN The Unknown Hipster is a bearded urban everyman, one of those well-dressed wallflowers who populate the city's high culture events. He appears in every post, an unnamed character, in crayon and gouache -- a thick watercolor -- floating through the art scene and New York's streets with an ear for social mores and an eye for fashion. ''Everybody looks famous and everybody looks interesting, but are mostly unknown,'' the hipster's creator, Jean-Philippe Delhomme, a French artist, graphic designer and author, said in an interview. ''Usually, a hipster wants to be known.'' The blog, at unknownhipster.com, is a work of days rather than minutes, inspired and carefully constructed. Mr. Delhomme paints or draws, then writes, then scans and posts. ''I take the time for it,'' he said.

DITZIAN--Michael David, age 69, of Manhattan, NY, passed away on September 10, surrounded by his adoring family: his devoted wife of 38 years, Barbara, his children Jaime and Eric, Eric's fiance', Fleur, and his sister Maralyn. Michael grew up in Rockville Centre, graduated cum laude from Amherst College, earned his law degree from Cornell University and his Master of Laws from New York University. In 1968, he served as an active-duty member of the United States Army in Vietnam. He joined Davis & Gilbert in 1971, rising to Managing Partner and being recognized as one of the leading attorneys handling mergers and acquisitions in advertising, public relations and marketing. He was proudly and continually committed to the Lymphoma Research Foundation and Amherst College. Donations may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation. Services will be held Monday, September 13 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 W 76th St. He will be remembered always for his kindness, honesty, generosity and devotion to his friends and family.

A review on Aug. 22 about ''The Tenth Parallel: Dispatches From the Fault Line Between Christianity and Islam,'' by Eliza Griswold, referred incorrectly to the Philippines. It is not ''the only Christian country in Asia'' -- among countries situated entirely in Asia, the population of East Timor is also predominantly Christian.

An article last Sunday about the overhaul of the Houston Astros' roster referred incorrectly to the status of the team's players who were in the 2005 World Series. Wandy Rodriguez, who pitched for the Astros in the World Series that year, is still with the team; it is not the case that all of the players from that series have moved on.

JERUSALEM -- Israel Tal, who as one of Israel's most influential military strategists designed and developed its main tank, the Merkava, refashioned battleground doctrine and served as an adviser to prime ministers, died Wednesday. He was 85. His death came after a prolonged illness, the Israeli Army announced.

Timex took a trip back to the future to honor its 156-year history of timekeeping by introducing a small collection of watches with inspiration coming straight from its own archives. By recreating period design details like color, typeface and finish, Timex is paying homage to classic watch faces of the 20th century. The 1970s style features that serpentine, expandable, flexible metal watchband that was all the rage. The revolutionary band of interlocking links allows it to be stretched and slid over the hand, providing for one-size-fits-all functionality. Timex is taking a trip back in time to prove its credo that it does indeed take a licking and keep on ticking. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Q.My two brothers, mom, dad and I are all considering a trip to San Juan, P.R., over the holidays. None of us have been before, and that is part of the allure. We haven't traveled to a new destination as a whole family in many years. Thoughts on this island as our choice? Andy Kitaeff, PhiladelphiaA. Late December is past the official hurricane season in Puerto Rico, which runs from June 1 to Nov. 30. But it is also peak season, which means you will pay more for flights and hotels; make sure to secure reservations well in advance.

Lars von Trier's films are so aggressive toward the audience that he has often seemed determined to make moviegoers hate him, and for much of his career I've been happy to oblige. But his ''Antichrist'' is, like ''Blue Velvet'' or ''The Night of the Hunter,'' one of those primal moviegoing experiences that return you to the wonder and fear that, when you first encounter them, make movies so thrilling and terrifying. In the guise of a horror movie Mr. von Trier has made a wrenching portrait of a marriage devastated by grief. A couple (Willem Dafoe and Charlotte Gainsbourg) lose their son in an accident that can't help but burden them with guilt. Ms. Gainsbourg's character is riven with crippling anxiety and depression, and Mr. Dafoe's, a psychologist, is foolish enough to believe he can cure her. When they retreat to their cabin in the woods, her treatment begins -- and hell bursts forth. But it's a recognizable hell: the chaos of nature, which cares nothing for humanity. Shooting in muted greens and browns that recall the Gothic realism of Albrecht Dürer, the cinematographer Anthony Dod Mantle makes the woods as furtive and alive as in the most vivid of fairy tales. Because Ms. Gainsbourg's character identifies being a woman with the anarchy of nature, and because she initiates the carnage in the film's harrowing final half-hour, there have been clumsy attempts to paint the movie as misogynistic. But emotionally the film is on her side. Male nature, epitomized by Mr. Dafoe's certainty that everything must have a rational explanation -- despite the contrary evidence before him -- is just as destructive. (Which is why the reviews treating the movie as a thesis to be judged are pathetically beside the point.) This is the film's tragedy: two people joined in grief but separated by the natures they can't transcend.

ROCKETT--Jack Ford, 75. Died September 3, 2010 due to complications from prostate cancer. Perfect husband and life partner to Joanne and wonderful dad to Jolie, Will, and Jennifer. Kind, generous, and thoughtful brother-in-law, uncle, and friend. Loved his homes in NYC and Lauderdale-by-the-Sea, FL. A gifted athlete, at Ft. Lauderdale High (Class of '53) he went to State Championships in both football and basketball, eventually becoming an All-American running back in football. His athletic prowess remained apparent throughout his life as evidenced in his mastering the 1st hole at New York's St. Andrew's Golf Club. Spent his summers during college working the oil rigs in Oklahoma before entering the U.S. Army, where he served honorably. With a career that spanned five decades, Jack was a respected professional in the insurance industry, revered by his colleagues. His spirit continues to inspire. A memorial gathering will be announced. Memories of Jack can be shared with the family at NYRocketts@gmail.com.

To watch Rita Hayworth in ''Cover Girl'' (1944) or ''Miss Sadie Thompson'' (1953) is to witness a magnetically appealing performer at her sauciest. Both are included in this set of five restored and remastered films. (Three -- ''Miss Sadie Thompson,'' ''Salome'' and ''Tonight and Every Night'' -- are being released on DVD for the first time.) But watching Hayworth in the 1946 ''Gilda'' is akin to standing on what you think is solid ground, only to learn that the earth has opened up beneath your feet. Movie stars generally have sexual charisma, but as Gilda, Hayworth creates such a captivatingly elusive fantasy that what she does can barely be called acting. It's more like witchcraft.

The resurgence of backpacks romanticizes collegiate sportswear -- frat-boy faux pas reconsidered as stylish staples. A more casual alternative to the borrowed-from-the-ladies man bags of recent years, the backpack was seen all over the fall runways, in both familiar interpretations (Louis Vuitton rediscovered the expedition-worthy rucksack) and new ones (Master-Piece's digitized Navajo print, below, and Prada's acidic camouflage). Consider the Japanese approach in introducing one to your wardrobe: a shot of pattern against a schoolboy uniform of classic khakis and a baseball jacket. JASON RIDER

My boyfriend and I want to take a vacation to an international urban destination over Christmas break (late December/early January). We were thinking of Turkey, but a quick scan of airfares showed high prices (more than $850). And I read that winters in Turkey are cold. Would you suggest some places that we should consider? Whitney Robinson, Ann Arbor, Mich.A.I contacted Jennifer Conlin, who wrote ''36 Hours in Istanbul'' (Feb. 7, 2010), which she reported last fall. In an e-mail, she warned that it does get cold, so winter is not an ideal time to enjoy some of her favorite activities, like drinks at a rooftop bar, boat rides on the Bosporus, and walks in the gardens - but she did add that you will encounter smaller crowds. I found one-stop round-trip flights from Wayne County Airport (Detroit) to Istanbul in late December for about $900.
HOCHHAUSER--Joyce. We will always remember the times we shared together. We will miss you. The Spanbocks

The Austrian-born artist Gottfried Helnwein is perhaps better known for his Johnny Cash-like sartorial style (black everything, including the ever-present bandanna) and his neo-Gothic Irish castle (site of the star-crossed union of Marilyn Manson and Dita Von Teese) than he is for his own startling body of work: macabre paintings with photographic resonance played out on a grand scale and often in public settings. Throughout his career, Helnwein has glided easily between watercolor, oil and installation work, but his big subject has always been childhood, and not the happy sort. Opening Sept. 16 at New York's Friedman Benda gallery, ''Gottfried Helnwein: I Was a Child'' is the 62-year-old artist's first major exhibition in New York; it's a curiously overdue showing for an artist who enjoyed a retrospective at San Francisco's Fine Arts Museum in 2004 and who shows regularly in Europe (including at the State Russian Museum). But Helnwein has always flirted more with art rock stardom (quite literally, having done work for the Scorpions and hung out with the Rolling Stones) than with a conventional career path to museum-grade respectability. Some might say the artist's work is much like the artist himself: all flash and image. With titles like ''The Murmur of the Innocents'' (above) and ''God of Sub-Humans,'' these works -- executed with obsessive, old-master-worthy technique -- can be as bludgeoning as, say, a Rammstein riff, but you can't take your eyes off them. MARK ROZZO

Last week, the screenwriter Peter Morgan pointed out the similarity between his imagined account of Tony Blair's first meeting with Queen Elizabeth in the film ''The Queen''(''You are my 10th prime minister, Mr. Blair. My first was Winston Churchill.'') and Mr. Blair's account in his new autobiography (''You are my 10th prime minister. The first was Winston.''). ''There are three possibilities. The first is I guessed absolutely perfectly...the second is Blair decided to endorse what I imagined as the official line; and the third is that he had one gin and tonic too many and confused the scene in the film with what had actually happened.''--PETER MORGAN

Rake, a new men's line of suit separates made to mix and match, fancies as its customer ''a gentleman of rogue habits.'' The owner, Clive Darby, late of the Savile Row outfitter Kilgour, marries the precision of English tailoring with the louche sexiness of Serge Gainsbourg. ''He didn't follow some dictated idea of what a suit should be,'' Darby says. ''He wore it with jeans, with sneakers or with fabulous brogues.'' The whole collection -- reversible waistcoats, wrinkle-resistant jersey jackets that pair well with booze-stained undershirts -- targets global gadabouts who travel light. Jackets from about $1,545. Go to rakestyle.com. STEPHEN HEYMAN

The ''In the Region'' article last Sunday, about new housing equipped with solar technology that generates savings for homeowners, misstated the unit of measure in a Solar Renewable Energy Credit, the means by which residents accrue the savings. It is one megawatt-hour (consisting of 1,000 kilowatt-hours); it is not ''1,000 megawatts.'' And because of an editing error, the article also misstated part of the name of an apartment building with photovoltaic panels in New Brunswick. It is Riverwatch Commons, not Riverwalk Commons. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.
BLUMBERG--Leonard. At 95, Leonard of Bridgewater, New Jersey died peacefully on September 10, 2010.

SNYDER--Stephanie Lynn, died at age 38. Adored daughter of Linda A. and Gilbert L. Snyder. Cherished sister of Jennifer Lee. Niece of Janice J. and Jeffrey M. Adlman and cousin of Lisa A. Pryor and Karen A. Adlman. Stephanie was a shining bright light. She touched many people with her generosity and warmth and she will be dearly missed by extended family and her many friends. Interment private. Memorial service Tuesday, September 14, 2010 at 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Friends of the Israel Museum, 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10110 in her memory or your favorite charity. The family will receive friends at home on Tuesday September 14, 3-9pm and on September 15, 4-7pm.

To create their new collection of hyper-masculine curiosities, the glass-blowing studio Esque and the art and design firm No. 1 Son (both based in Portland, Ore.) pilfered ideas from millennia past. Aptly named (Bar)barian, the collaboration was inspired by what Andi Kovel and Justin Parker of Esque call the ''noble savage'': objects that were once made from horn, wood and stone are reimagined in glass and leather. Why serve drinks from an ordinary decanter when you could present (Bar)barian's Flagon, a swirling glass vessel that resembles the horn of some mythical beast? Or why not go all out with the Travel Bar (right): two hornlike glasses, a bone-shaped stirrer and a leather studded case in which to lug them? Just don't go hunting for dinner with the OB-J slingshot. Rendered in wood-colored glass with an inelastic leather strap and fragile handle, it's entirely nonfunctional. But that's entirely the point: by allowing utility and convenience to go the way of the woolly mammoth, (Bar)barian has transformed objects from the past into up-to-the-minute pieces of pure decadence. TIM McKEOUGH
WILLIAMS--Samuel Dunstan. A Memorial Service will take place on Thursday, September 16, 2010 at the Church of Saint Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street at 3:30pm.

WOLF--Harriet nee Malina, 90, of Ridgewood, NJ, died on September 10, 2010. Formerly of Teaneck, NJ and originally from the Bronx. Graduate of Hunter College High School and New York University. Pre-deceased by her husband, Barnet. Survived by her children Robert (Chantal), twins Marilyn (David) and John (LouAnne); brother Gerald, sister Marilyn; and grandchildren Daniel, Rachel, Alex, Amy, Russell and John. Service Sunday, 1:30pm at Cedar Park/Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations may be made to: Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.

Cowboys at RedskinsSunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Cowboys by 3 1/2 Those who do not learn from history are doomed to work in the Redskins' front office. The team acquires big-name veterans every off-season, even though their overpriced acquisitions usually arrive with inflated reputations, baggage and ''headaches'' (quotes provided by Albert Haynesworth). The team spent this week trying to trade the malcontent savant Haynesworth, but he'll be in uniform on Sunday night, if not in the starting lineup. Meanwhile, the team discovered that new quarterback Donovan McNabb was actually a brittle 34-year old feeling the effects of 357 career sacks. Perhaps they should have read the label. McNabb will play on a sprained ankle this week. His weapons include Clinton Portis, Joey Galloway, Larry Johnson and other players whose extended warranties expired years ago. McNabb is 11-8 against the Cowboys in his career, but the last two losses -- 24-0 in the 2009 in the season finale, 34-14 in the playoffs -- were whoppers.

For many city folk there's no scarier place than the country, with its Victorian gingerbread houses, its lonely moonlit ponds, its crickets. That's part of what makes Charles Laughton's bucolic film noir ''The Night of the Hunter'' so terrifying. The night has 1,000 eyes, but in the city, at least, you know people are looking at you. Robert Mitchum is a switchblade-carrying, self-styled preacher who rolls out of prison and into a small town in search of a grieving widow to bilk. He has his eye on a doleful-looking Shelley Winters, whose husband (Mitchum's former cellmate) has just been hanged for robbery and murder. Angling for the hidden dough, Mitchum dazzles both Winters and the townsfolk with his fire-and-brimstone crazy talk about a vengeful God, but Winters's young son and daughter (Billy Chapin and Sally Jane Bruce) become the chief target of his unremitting, drawling evil.

A picture on Aug. 22 with an appraisal of Harold Connolly, an Olympic champion hammer thrower who died on Aug. 18, was printed in mirror image. The photograph, of his first wife, the discus thrower Olga Fikotova, should have shown her throwing with her right hand. Agence France-Presse -- Getty Images released the picture, taken at a track and field meet in London in 1957, showing her throwing left-handed.

CATENACCIO--Frank. The partners, associates and staff of Davidoff Malito & Hutcher express their sorrow at the passing of their client and friend of many years, Frank Catenaccio. His dedication to providing excellent cuisine in New York's Little Italy constitutes a meaningful contribution to the culinary and cultural life of New York City. We extend our deepest sympathies to his sisters Vivian and Camille, and his brother Alexander. Davidoff Malito & Hutcher LLP

He is also survived by his son Robert, grandchildren Benjamin and Joshua and their mother, Judy Weil. He served as a US Army tank commander in Europe during WWII. A true gentleman, he will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

Each August, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park gets a sprucing up. Lots of police officers show up and the Unisphere fountains are turned on - they have been renovated and this year look especially spectacular. ''We joke that they do it for us,'' said Jesus Rodriguez, 29, a Mexican immigrant who was playing eight-on-eight soccer last weekend in a not-so-grassy patch a lob away from the south entrance of the National Tennis Center, where the United States Open was in its fourth round.

Bent Larsen, a Danish-born chess grandmaster who was a perennial challenger for the world championship during the 1960s and '70s, died on Sept. 9 in Buenos Aires, where he had lived for many years. He was 75. His death was announced on the Web site of the Danish chess union. No cause was given, but he was known to have suffered from diabetes, according to Chessbase, a chess news Web site.
Winding down memory lane.

An article last Sunday about ''Ahead of Time,'' a documentary portrait of the journalist Ruth Gruber, misstated the name of a restaurant and misidentified its owner, who is an executive producer of the film. The restaurant is My Most Favorite Food -- not My Most Favorite Dessert Company -- and it is owned by Doris Schechter, not Patti Kenner, who is another executive producer.

Two years ago, a shopping trip to the dusty, dowdy Mar Mikhael district of Beirut would have netted you little more than a tire change and some vacuum cleaner parts. But the emergence of the adjacent Gemmayzeh neighborhood to the west as the city's central night-life district has begun to have a spillover. Independent fashion boutiques, design showrooms, bookshops and music bars are sprouting up among Mar Mikhael's auto garages and appliance outlets, creating a new enclave for the city's arty and alternative set. SETH SHERWOOD FLIPSIDE

Ever wonder how clothing designers dress their homes? The Council of Fashion Designers of America and Assouline are publishing ''American Fashion Designers At Home.'' Written by Rima Suqi, a contributor to T and The New York Times, the coffee-table book ($65, which benefits the CFDA Foundation) looks at the homes of 115 CFDA members, from heavyweights like Diane von Furstenberg and Kate Spade to relative newcomers like Band of Outsiders' Scott Sternberg. The interiors, which range from luxurious - like Eva Chow's gold-leafed Los Angeles living room or Tory Burch's opulent, surprisingly conservative Manhattan apartment - to industrial-funky, like Rachel Comey's Long Island weekend house, may seem glamorous to those of us on the outside looking in. But as Suqi points out, even fashion designers ''are not immune to the pitfalls of decorating or renovating. They have nightmare contractors, too.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

It was bound to happen. Inevitable, really. With Madonna and Lady Gaga already honored, the television series ''Glee'' had to get around to another pop star in this sorority, one whose triumphal cheesiness, campy earnestness and combination of lightness (on the surface) and darkness (just a few cat scratches beneath) more perfectly capture this musical comedy's essence. So in the next few weeks, as new episodes come along, so does Britney Spears -- in spirit, like her predecessors, and in the flesh, unlike either of them. Her guest appearance will reportedly be brief. But her video oeuvre will be well represented, as the ''Glee'' club poses and preens in sequences taken from Britney's greatest hits. These exertions (and those for another episode) involved the elaborate choreography for which the show is known, and which the photographer Todd Heisler documented at a studio lot and at two Los Angeles-area high schools over five days in August. ''Glee'' is now a bona fide phenomenon, credited with inspiring a resurgent interest in musical theater among young people and singled out for praise by no less influential critics than the Obamas. The show's appeal is widespread, because so are its characters' fantasies: that when they put their minds, voices and feet to it, they can slough off their awkwardness and shine like the gaudiest stars. -- Frank Bruni

BARTLETT--W. Scott, Jr. - Editor, Book Publisher; February 17, 1920 - September 7, 2010. W. Scott Bartlett, Jr, former Editor in Chief and Vice president of E.P. Dutton & Co, passed away in New York City (Manhattan) on Tuesday September 7, 2010 - surrounded by family and love ones. Born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin in February, 1920 to Ruth Fitch and Walter Scott Barlett, he grew up in New York City and attended Saint Bernard's School, Millbrook School and Loomis School in Windsor, Connecticut, graduating form the University of Wisconsin in 1942 and from the Harvard School of Business Administration. He is survived by his loving wife Barbara Forman and children W. Scott III, Nathaniel Eliot and Diana Chase Bartlett, by his brother Paul H. Bartlett and by three grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife Miriam Davie Bartlett, their son Mark Emerson Bartlett, by his brother Eliot Fitch Bartlett and niece Amy Wyllys Bartlett. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, September 19th, 2010, 2pm, at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. Remembrances in lieu of flowers to Poets House or Doctors without Borders.

BERNSTEIN--Florence Newman, died in her home in Lauderhill, Florida at age 95, on September 1st, after suffering a brain hemorrhage. She leaves a close, loving family with two sons and their wives, six grandchildren and their five spouses along with 12 great-grandchildren. Florence was born into a large, extended family in Brooklyn, NY and after a brief singing career and song plugging for the Irving Berlin Music Company, married Jack J. Bernstein during the Depression. Their family thrived. Florence was a loving mother, grandparent and great-grandparent who was especially concerned, to the very end, about their welfare and happiness. She couldn't have been a better "Nana." She made sure that Jack was healthy and happy during retirement and when he died made many new and diverse friends. She continued to grow, was upbeat and loved to make people laugh. She had no place for racial, religious, gender-oriented or ethnic prejudices. She will be dearly missed by many.
Dates are subject to change. SEPTEMBER

CHARLESTON still has its cannons aimed at Fort Sumter, where the Civil War began, and has elected the same mayor, Joseph Riley, since 1975. It even has some of the country's most aggressive historic preservation. But that doesn't mean this charming Southern city has nothing new to offer. There are new galleries on Broad Street, and a festoonery of restaurants, bars and boutique bakeries have transformed the once-struggling design district on upper King Street. Charlestonians, governed by laws of hospitality as incontrovertible as those of gravity, cannot help themselves from sharing their new finds, even if you are ''from off,'' as those who grew up on this once swampy peninsula refer to outsiders. Friday

FRANK GEHRY designed his first fish lamp in 1983, when Formica sought uses for its laminate, ColorCore. Mr. Gehry broke a piece, which looked like a fish scale, and the rest is design history: fish lamps swam into the collections of cultural grandees like Jasper Johns. ''Fish Forms: Lamps by Frank Gehry'' at the Jewish Museum was inspired by the glass fish lamp in the museum's collection. The eight lamps shown are engaging objects, but they have a deeper meaning. The fish form fascinated Mr. Gehry for its purity and dynamism, and became a major theme in his architecture, a point made nicely in a video at the exhibition. PILAR VILADAS ''Fish Forms'' is on view until Oct. 31 at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue.
Theater Charles Isherwood

IT took panache to gain entry to Max's Kansas City, Mickey Ruskin's steak and beer house. In the 1960s and early '70s, it was a refuge for artists and outliers of every stripe, a kind of gated community where men in suits and chunky Rolex watches were about as welcome as termites. A defiant originality could get you in the door, past the bar and into the fabled back room, where Dan Flavin's neon sculpture cast visitors in a hellish but curiously flattering glow. ''The room was red, so everybody looked gorgeous,'' said Bebe Buell, who modeled and sang rock tunes at the time. She described the scene as an eclectic gathering, a magnet to visitors as disparate as Salvador Dalí, Lou Reed and Alice Cooper, ''or maybe some night some brilliant sculptor,'' Ms. Buell recalled. ''It was a room of beauty where a lot of elegantly wasted people were holding court.''

The fashion world is gathered in New York for nearly 300 designer shows, many of which are at Lincoln Center. Clothes are the main event, but on the first two days, all eyes were focused on the shoes on the guests as well as those of the models. Chadwick Bell, one of the first to show, went for a high, belted shoe. A common sight on the street is the switch from heels to the relative safety and comfort of flats. As the shows of the spring collections opened, mannequins (right, second row) lined up for a grand exit from their summer home, Broadway.

In one of his periodic 1970s flashbacks, Marc Jacobs tonight seemed to point to Jodie Foster, the teenage prostitute Iris in "Taxi Driver," and to images of women in mauve and flowers, perhaps especially those of the illustrator Antonio Lopez. Iris was an obvious allusion, because of the turn-back-brim hats, the curly hair, and the number of high-waist shorts and small knit tops in Mr. Jacobs' spring 2011 collection. It was Ruth Morley who designed the costumes for "Taxi Driver."

The living room has long been the basic set of the American sitcom, from "I Love Lucy" to "Everybody Loves Raymond." Most of them are unmemorable, transitional spaces; every front door seems to open directly onto a generic sofa. Many of them are all but repeated from show to show (quick: what's the difference between the living rooms on "Raymond" and "King of Queens"?). They're invariably decorated in a neutral palette, acting as a quiet, passive backdrop to the action.

Oprah Winfrey, who is closing down her talk show after 25 years to build her own cable network, kicked off her final "farewell" season on Monday with an extravaganza of old faces and new prizes. Among other wonders, she told members of her studio audience that she would take all 300 of them with her to Australia, along with her pal John Travolta, who is to fly the Qantas Airways jet (he's a pilot and a Qantas goodwill ambassador). Cue screaming.

The group contends that proposed new rules, in response to the stock market flash crash on May 6, would increase costs for all investors and make markets less liquid.

TOKYO - Could it be that the Japanese view of robots as friendly helpers - and not as the rebellious, violent machines that populate much of Western science fiction - is rooted in the Shinto religion, which blurs the boundaries between animate and inanimate? To the Japanese psyche, this theory goes, a humanoid and sentient robot may simply not feel as creepy or threatening as it does in other cultures.

You wouldn't expect to see Victoria Beckham wearing bright purple eyeshadow, so it was a bit of a surprise to see models wearing it in her presentation yesterday. (Another departure for the sexy star turned real-deal designer: the number of floral prints in the collection.) Using Lancôme products, Charlotte Tilbury created a dewy face, sans blush - a nice break from the contoured looks seen at Altuzarra and Thakoon - and added a thick layer of L'Absolu Rouge lipstick in pinky-beige Rich Cashmere followed by gobs of clear gloss. This was punctuated by the aforementioned indigo shadow, a blend of Lancôme Color Design shadows in Trendy and Drama - perfect shade names for a former Spice Girl. As if that wasn't enough color, nails were painted with a bubblegum pink from Butter London. Didier Malige slicked models' hair behind their ears (a style also seen at Cynthia Steffe, where Avon's Tippi Shorter was going for "Virgin Suicides"-meets-Marcia Brady) and added a few crimps around the nape of the neck, held in place with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray.

Considering how things go in Argentina - military coups, economic insolvency and, most recently, a coin shortage - the fantastically posh Buenos Aires neighborhood of Recoleta is still going strong. Its bosky streets are lined with embassies, museums and belle époque mansions that occupy entire blocks. It's one big architectural pageant. And so, as legacy would have it, Recoleta remains a magnet for upscale boutiques and hotels like the new Algodon Mansion, which opened last month.

Thin lips, button noses and beady eyes are all it took for Yoshitomo Nara to create the passive-aggressive brats and eagerly menacing pups that catapulted him to international art stardom in the 1990s. In serious need of love, they simultaneously attract and repel, typifying the culture of twisted cuteness endemic to Japanese manga comics. But the real revelation in "Nobody's Fool," the Asia Society's arresting retrospective of the artist's two-decade career, is how much he was influenced by punk bands like the Ramones - and the cover graphics of 1960s rock albums. His own collection of vintage King Crimson, Geoff Muldaur, Norman Greenbaum and Carole King albums anchor the museum-wide show, where his pyromaniac girls and orphaned dogs appear in lonely wooden shacks. One of them replicates his drawing studio at home - and is as endearingly angst-ridden as his art."Nobody's Fool" is on view through Jan. 2, 2011, at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue.

Two weeks ago, Google introduced a  Gmail feature that sorts incoming mail -- not the spam, but the stuff you actually want -- into important and unimportant messages. The Priority Inbox is a super-inbox that, based on your own past behavior with e-mail, places what it calls "important and unread" messages at the top of the list. For example, it could flag a shipping notice that contains a FedEx tracking number from an online retailer as important, while pushing the same merchant's weekly newsletter down into the less-important section.

The government has pledged roughly $35 million toward the new building.

I was well into my 30s before I heard my mother utter a four-letter word. My children will not be waiting that long. I have never been one to curse constantly, and when I became a parent, I cleaned up my language even more, at least for a while. As my sons entered their tweens and then their teens, though, and it became clear that they knew far more "bad words" than I did, I loosened my tongue a bit. It began to feel Pollyanna-like to tell them, "Those are not nice words," or even, "We don't curse," and my message instead became, "We don't curse in certain situations." Like in front of your teachers. Or your grandmother (even though I now know she knows those words). Or at a job interview. And, as one who uses words for a living, I tried to stress that curses are lazy. They are a unimaginative default in a language that has so many more interesting possibilities.

As the New York spring collections began, just five days ago, the main question on the minds of fashion editors was how much Céline would there be on the catwalks. We knew it would be in the audience - that stripe-y tunic dress with zip shoulder (so Agnès B and yet so not) is ubiquitous at Lincoln Center, as are the wide-leg pants, the khaki shirt with gold zipper pulls, the soft square tote. But how much of the Céline designer Phoebe Philo's tailored conceptualism, her hand with stripped-back superhot sportswear, would find its way into American clothes remained to be seen. We - fashion editors - all remember the Marni-fication of the industry a decade ago. We know very well what one cool brand can do to women's closets. And, let's face it: sportswear is the hallmark of American fashion. Bringing Céline back is like lugging coal to Newcastle.

N.F.L. Rule 8, Section 1, Article 3, Item 1: Going to the ground. If a player goes to the ground in the act of catching a pass (with or without contact by an opponent), he must maintain control of the ball after he touches the ground, whether in the field of play or the end zone. If he loses control of the ball, and the ball touches the ground before he regains control, the pass is incomplete. If he regains control prior to the ball touching the ground, the pass is complete.

O'CONNOR--Jeremiah, William III, 34, died suddenly on September 9, 2010. Beloved husband of Karina Lagos O'Connor, devoted father of Emiliano and Sophia Marie, adored son of Joan and Jerry O'Connor of Bronxville, NY. Jerry is also survived by a wide circle of family and friends including his five beloved siblings, Bill (and Eileen) O'Connor of Rye, NY, Chris (and M.E.) O'Connor of New Canaan, CT, Marjorie (O'Connor) and Nat Furman of New Canaan, CT, Catherine (O'Connor) and Matt Williams of New York, NY, John O'Connor of New York, NY and thirteen nieces and nephews who he adored and adored him back. Jerry was scheduled to serve as best man in his brother John's wedding to Erin Dougherty of Middleburgh, VA on December 4, 2010. Jerry was a graduate of Bronxville High School, Harvard College and the Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College. Jerry worked at O'Connor Capital Partners, a real estate investment firm in New York. Jerry was a brilliant person and a larger than life personality. He was a voracious reader, an avid sailor and spent summers racing with his brothers on Cape Cod. He loved being on the water and the challenge of the waves. Jerry was devoted to his family and his friends. He had a laugh, a smile, a twinkle in his eye and a spirit that brightened the lives of all who knew him. A wake will be held at Fred McGrath Funeral Home, Sunday, September 12, 3-5pm, Monday, September 13, 2-4pm and 7-9pm (914)337-6770. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held at St. Joseph's Bronxville, NY at 10am, September 14, 2010. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Catholic Relief Services: 917-587-5726.

A picture on July 30 with an article about the unearthing of what is believed to be an 18th-century brigantine in Lower Manhattan was published in error. It showed an example of a brig, which has two square-rigged masts -- not a brigantine, on which only the front mast is typically square-rigged. A reader raised the issue in an e-mail message at the time the article was published, but the error was confirmed only after extensive research and much debate -- as explained in a corrective article on Page A25 today.

Mr. Perry wrote the screenplay, not Ms. Shange.

8 P.M. (TCM) TCM REMEMBERS PATRICIA NEALShe was born Patsy Lou Neal in 1926 in a Kentucky coal-mining town and at the age of 10 wrote a letter to Santa Claus that said, ''What I want for Christmas is to study dramatics.'' By 21 she had won a Tony for her Broadway debut in the Lillian Hellman play ''Another Part of the Forest.'' At 39, a year after capturing the best actress Oscar for her performance as a shopworn housekeeper who resists Paul Newman's charm in the 1963 movie ''Hud,'' she had a series of strokes that put her into a coma for three weeks and left her semiparalyzed and unable to speak. Her husband, the British writer Roald Dahl, oversaw her recovery, and she returned to the screen in 1968, earning her second Academy Award nomination as the bitter mother in ''The Subject Was Roses,'' adapted by Ulu Grosbard from Frank Gilroy's play. That film is one of five that pay tribute to Neal, who died at 84 on Aug. 8. The evening begins with ''Private Screenings: Patricia Neal'' (2004), in which she discusses her career with Robert Osborne, and continues at 9 with ''The Fountainhead'' (1949), King Vidor's adaptation of the Ayn Rand novel, with Gary Cooper as an idealistic architect who refuses to compromise his vision and Neal (above with Cooper) as the woman he loves. At 1 a.m. Neal appears in ''A Face in the Crowd'' (1957) as a television executive who turns a folk-singing drifter (Andy Griffith) into a media darling. The salute ends with ''In Harm's Way'' (1965), at 3:15, with Neal as a Navy lieutenant alongside John Wayne's aging captain, who is assigned to a desk job after a botched mission against the Japanese. 8 P.M. The Season 4 opener of ''Gossip Girl,'' at 9, finds Blair (Leighton Meester) and Serena (Blake Lively) reveling in the Parisian summer and banishing thoughts of New York boys from their pretty little minds -- until Blair spies Chuck (Ed Westwick).

RYAN--Dr. John D.,of Delray Beach, Florida, Newport, Rhode Island, and formerly of Stamford, Connecticut, passed away peacefully last Monday, September 6th at the age of 95 years. He was born in Stamford, CT, the eldest son of Rose (Tooher) and William A. Ryan. A long time resident of Stamford, CT he graduated with honors from Stamford High School in 1932. After attending college at New York University College of Arts and Pure Sciences, he graduated from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1941. After an 18-month internship at New York University Bellevue Medical Center, he entered World War II with the Bellevue Affiliate Unit of the U.S. Army's First General Hospital. He served in both England and France attaining the rank of Major. In 1945, he married Kathleen M. Masterson, RN of New York City at the Church of the Madeleine in Paris, France. While serving in France, Dr. Ryan worked at the American Hospital in Paris and was honored with the French Croix de Guerre. After the war, he completed his surgical residency at Bellevue Hospital. He was certified by the American Board of Surgery in 1950 and was a fellow of the American College of Surgeons. He entered private practice in 1951 returning to Stamford, where he was appointed as attending surgeon at the Stamford Hospital and at the former St. Joseph Hospital in Stamford. He practiced General Surgery until his retirement. He was Director of the Surgical Division of St. Joseph's Hospital from 1960 to 1966, President of the Medical Staff of that hospital from January, 1969 until December, 1971, a member of their Board of Directors in 1971 and joined the Executive Board in 1975. For his service to church and community he was honored as a Knight in the Order of St. Gregory by Pope John Paul, II. He is remembered as a kind, generous, wise man; a loving husband, father and brother; a wonderful listener, a mentor to family and friends. He is not only survived by his wife of 65 years, but also by his seven children; John Dennis Ryan of Stamford, CT, Michelle Hubbard Simonds of New Canaan, CT, Dr. Richard G. Ryan, of Old Lyme, CT, James B. Ryan of Delray Beach, FL, Michael D. Ryan, of West Palm Beach, FL, Yvonne Ryan Cusick of Kensington, CA, and Dr. Terrence W. Ryan of Litchfield, CT, and ten grandchildren, and one great-grandson. He is also survived by his two sisters, Mrs. Rosemary Magner of Boca Raton, FL and Mrs. Alice Devine of Norwalk, CT. He was pre-deceased by his two brothers, Vincent A. Ryan and William A. Ryan and his sister, Rita (Ryan) Lacovo, all formally of Stamford, CT and Delray Beach, FL. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at The Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Stamford on September 18, 2010 at ten o'clock in the morning.
