EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- For more than 100 years, fans of major league baseball in New York have taken the subway or the train to the game. But no such option has existed for football fans for the past quarter-century because the Giants and then the Jets played in the swampland of New Jersey. Since last season, though, fans have been able to take New Jersey Transit to Giants Stadium and now New Meadowlands Stadium. The ride usually takes 13 minutes from the Secaucus Junction station, but given how much time drivers spend stuck in traffic before and after games, it is equal to warp speed.

Readers still buy reference books, even in the mobile Internet age. Top sellers include study aids for the SATs and ACT college admissions tests, and ''What to Expect the First Year,'' the closest thing that tired, anxious parents of newborns have to a user's guide. Readers seeking a more lighthearted and quirky experience can pick up ''The 2011 Old Farmer's Almanac,'' which went on sale on Sept. 7, or ''Guinness World Records 2011,'' which will be released on Tuesday. BROWN--Yetta Piper. Beloved wife of Abraham Brown, mother of Marsha Brown and the late Stanley Brown, aunt and great-aunt to numerous nieces, nephews and grandnieces and nephews, died peacefully on Thursday, September 9, 2010 at the age of 87, from Alzheimer's disease. Yetta worked as a medical assistant at the LaGuardia Medical Group of HIP for over 25 years, and was instrumental in unionizing it in 1968. She contributed to many liberal and Jewish charities, and to wildlife and conservationist causes. Yetta's unfailing wit and humor were a constant source of merriment for her friends and family; she loved and valued her family above all. She will be missed. The funeral will be held on Monday, September 13, 2010, at 1:00 pm, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills. The family will be sitting shiva at home: 68-24 Utopia Pkwy., Fresh Meadows, Queens, (718) 463-5164. Donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, and mailed to Neil & Shari Piper, 8 Vista Lane, Selkirk, NY 12158.

With its latest product release, the chip designer ARM may find it tough to maintain its tradition of understated British talking points. It would seem that some pomp and circumstance has been put on order. The Eagle products should end up in most of the world's smartphones and a host of other hand-held devices. They'll run about five times faster than today's high-end ARM chips and handle meaty stuff like movies and pictures far better than current smartphone chips, while still consuming hardly any power.

DITZIAN--Michael David, age 69, of Manhattan, NY, passed away on September 10, surrounded by his adoring family: his devoted wife of 38 years, Barbara, his children Jaime and Eric, Eric's fiance', Fleur, and his sister Maralyn. Michael grew up in Rockville Centre, graduated cum laude from Amherst College, earned his law degree from Cornell University and his Master of Laws from New York University. In 1968, he served as an active-duty member of the United States Army in Vietnam. He joined Davis & Gilbert in 1971, rising to Managing Partner and being recognized as one of the leading attorneys handling mergers and acquisitions in advertising, public relations and marketing. He was proudly and continually committed to the Lymphoma Research Foundation and Amherst College. Donations may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation. Services will be held Monday, September 13 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 W 76th St. He will be remembered always for his kindness, honesty, generosity and devotion to his friends and family.

GANS--Manfred, born April 27, 1922 in Borken Germany died peacefully at his home in New Jersey on September 11, 2010. He was our hero and the hero of many others. In response to the Nazi regime, his parents sent him to England at the age of 16. At 18 he was chosen to join the elite group of British Commandos, known as, X-troop. He landed with the allied armies on D-day and fought through out the European campaign. He rose to the rank of captain and was among the troops who liberated his home town. After the armistice was signed, he and a driver drove to Czechoslovakia and were the first Allied soldiers to arrive at the Terezenstadt concentration camp where he found his parents alive. He then organized their return to Holland. Through much of the war he corresponded with his childhood sweet heart, the late Anita Lamm, whose family left Germany for New York City in 1938. They were married in New York in 1948. Manfred recorded this in his memoirs, Life Gave Me a Chance, published in 2009. After the war, Manfred studied Chemical Engineering at the University of Manchester and then went on to MIT where he completed a master's of science. He joined the chemical engineering firm, Scientific Design specializing in design and start ups. His career took him all over the world and was part of the first wave of professionals to conduct business in China and East Germany in 1973. In 1976 he started consulting for the UN and went on many assignments that included Cuba, Turkey, Vietnam, and Pakistan. During his professional career, he was awarded patents and authored technical papers. He was a Fellow of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers and was the winner of the 1993 "Chemical Engineering Practice Award." He has been an inspiration and will be sadly missed by his brother, Gershon Kaddar in Israel, his son, Daniel Gans, his daughter Aviva Gans Rosenberg, their spouses Linda and David, his grandsons: Aaron, Jeremy, and Dylan, his sister-in-law Lilo Goldenberg Thurnauer, his close friend, Esther Okin, and an extended family and friends throughout the world. Funeral services will be held: Tuesday, September 14th at 11:00am at Wein and Wein Memorial Chapel, 402 Park Street, Hackensack NJ.

Forget whether it was brig or brigantine. The archaeologists who are trying to decipher the 18th-century ship recovered this summer from an old landfill at the World Trade Center site had to agree first on whether they were looking at its bow or its stern. Only about half the vessel - 32 feet - survived the construction of a retaining wall roughly along the line of Washington Street, close to what was once the edge of the Hudson River. To unseasoned eyes, the fanlike array of ribs at one end of the mud-encased craft strongly suggested that it was the stern.

Jack Sock, an American player with a big serve and a bigger forehand, beat his countryman Denis Kudla for the United States Open junior boys singles title Sunday. With every flick of his wrist, Sock, who won, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2, made 10 years vanish. In 2000, Andy Roddick, a big-serving, forehand-ripping Nebraska native, defeated Robby Ginepri, 6-1, 6-3, in the last all-American junior boys final. Three years later, Roddick won the United States Open and ascended to No. 1 in the world. Ginepri made the Open semifinals in 2005 on his way to a career-best year-end world ranking of 15.

BERG-SCHLESINGER--Sarah. 84 of Boca Raton Florida passed away Sunday September 12th in New Brunswick. Born in Elizabeth she lived in Carteret, Woodbridge, then moved to Boca Raton Florida six years ago. Sarah was the founder of Schlesinger Associates Global Marketing Research Company where she served as a chairperson for the past forty five years. She was a former member of Congregation Adath Israel and Congregation Neve Shalom. She was the president of the sisterhood, very active in the U.J.A., she was on the Board of Directors of the New York Chapter of Marketing Research Organization, and was Business Woman of the Year in Middlesex County. Sarah is predeceased by her parents Samuel and Sylvia Berg, a sister Sophie Rudnick, and a brother Jack Berg. She is survived by her children Howard Schlesinger and his wife Laurie of Livingston, Jude Shaw and her husband Gary of Wayne, Debby Hellman and her husband Allen of Los Angeles California, Steve Schlesinger and his wife Ava of Summit, two sisters Betty Saltiel of New Brunswick, Lillian Richman of Somerset, ten grandchildren Michael, Jaime, Jennifer, Jason, A.J., Jarod, Eric, Alison, Brianna, Skyler, two great grandchildren Ryan and Zachary. Funeral services will be held Tuesday 11:00am at Congregation Beth Hatikvah 635 Chatham Rd., Summit with interment to follow at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin. Services are by the Gerity & Chubenko Funeral Home 411 Amboy Ave. (Route 35) Woodbridge. To send online condolences please visit www.gerityfh.com.

DITZIAN--Michael. The law firm of Davis & Gilbert suffered a great loss with the passing of its Managing Partner, Michael Ditzian. Michael was a great leader, teacher and friend. To his clients, he was a highly regarded counselor and adviser. To his partners, attorneys and staff, he was a guiding force and inspiration. To his family, Michael was a loving husband, devoted father and close friend. Michael will always be remembered for his intelligence, integrity and spirit, and for being a fighter against the disease that ultimately took him from us. We are proud to continue in the spirit in which he led his life. Our heart and support goes out to his beloved family his wife, Barbara, his children, Jaime and Eric, Fleur, and Michael's sister, Maralyn. The Partners, Attorneys and Staff of Davis & Gilbert

ALTSCHULER--Bernard M. (89). Born April 6th, 1921 and a resident of Maplewood, NJ and Palm Beach, FL. Died on September 11, 2010 following a brief illness. He was a long time resident of Bayonne, NJ. A graduate of Tulane University and its medical school, he served as Naval lieutenant and physician during WWII and the Korean War. He then practiced Obstetrics and Gynecology in Bayonne for more than 35 years, caring for his adoring patients and serving as Chief of Obstetrics and President of the Bayonne Hospital Medical Staff before retiring. He was a clinical faculty member of the College of Medicine & Dentistry of New Jersey. He was for many years a trustee of Temple Emanuel of Bayonne. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Doris; three son's, Jeffrey (Lynn), Mark and Steven; three grandchildren, Faryn, Sydney, and Samantha; and a brother, Myron (Ruth). Services will be 11am today at Temple Emanuel of Bayonne. For more information call Bernheim Apter Kreitzman of Livingston 973-422-0600.

Two new photography books cast an eye on the American cultural landscape. Over the last 15 years, the legendary photographer Lee Friedlander has shot in almost all 50 states, employing the windows and mirrors of his rental cars to frame parts of the country that are often sped past - the churches, motels, bars and bridges. Those black-and-white pictures, collected in ''America by Car'' (D.A.P./Fraenkel; $50), are timeless in their shabby grandeur. And to coincide with this month's survey exhibition at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, ''From Here to There: Alec Soth's America'' (above; Walker Art Center; $60) is an anthology of past and new work that takes us through the country's sad and dreamy subcultures, including ''Broken Manual,'' portraits of men who live off the grid. ''I've had the opportunity to photograph all over the world,'' Soth says, ''but I keep coming back to America. I find it endlessly rich.''

My wife, Jackie, recently spent a week visiting a friend in Warsaw, which included an edifying lesson in how to make pierogi leniwe, or so-called lazy pierogi. The idea is that they are dough and (cheese) filling in one mass, not the usual two: a wrapper and a stuffing, one of which has to be painstakingly folded and sealed around the other. In fact, they are cheese dumplings or gnocchi, but it's a nice conceit of nomenclature that you can get the pierogi experience in streamlined form.

The Studio 54 style of Anjelica Huston, Pat Cleveland and Jerry Hall inspired Marc Jacobs this season. The designer's beauty dream team - François Nars, Redken's Guido Palau and Elisa Ferri for Creative Nail Design - didn't disappoint. (Not that they could have: Arnold mentioned there was a six-hour beauty test the night before.) "We kept a few of the iconic things from the '70s, like no eyebrows - we're bleaching all the brows," Nars said backstage. "Then a dark, reddish-brownish matte lipstick, a little bit of shiny, peachy color on the cheeks to give them a healthy look and deep forest green on the eyes with Vaseline on top." A spring shade from Creative Nail called Perfectly Bare blended with mattifying top coat was applied to nails to "blank them out," according to Arnold, mimicking the treatment of the brows. Toes, however, were painted a dark red. "Marc wanted deep, dark, shiny berry toes," Arnold said. "When he saw Bloodline, he was like, 'That's it!'" Models were given one of four side-parted, texturized hairstyles ranging from Marcel waves to major Biba-esque frizz, depending on their natural hair type. "Marc hates hair extensions," Palau said. "We wanted to capture that period, the decadent loucheness of the '70s supermodels. You know, that kind of woman who reeks of perfume." Ah, but would it be Daisy, Lola or even Bang?

It's not only men who are fanning the flames of Tel Aviv's hot dining scene. Recently female chefs have started taking over the city's normally testosterone-fueled kitchens and bakeries. (There are at least three new cupcake shops owned by the ladies.) Tamar Cohen-Tzedek opened Cucina Tamar (HaTsfira 10; 011-972-3-639-0407; entrees about $17 to $26) two years ago, and it's now one of the top Italian spots in town. ''When I decided to open a restaurant, I didn't think, Oh, I'm doing this in a man's world,'' she says. ''I just did it.'' So did Einav Berman, who turns out plates like tomato tarte Tatin at her new restaurant, Asif (Lilienblum 18; 011-972-3-516-5198; entrees $16 to $31). At her home kitchen in the Florentin quarter, the American transplant Rima Olvera (above) cooks up a dinner feast for 14 guests every month ($125). And at Joz ve Loz (Yehuda HaLevi 51; 011-972-3-560-6385; entrees $10 to $22), Niva Eshed heads a team of four women chefs (plus one guy) who serve Mediterranean fare like chicken liver ravioli with horseradish sour cream. Unlike in male-dominated kitchens, she says, ''there is no ego. More than for the food, we cook for the experience.''

The actress Sophia Loren, the pianist Maurizio Pollini and the sculptor Rebecca Horn are among the five winners of the 2010 Praemium Imperiale arts awards, the Japan Art Association announced on Tuesday. The awards, which recognize lifetime achievement in areas of the arts not covered by the Nobel prizes, come with a cash prize of roughly $169,000. The other winners this year are the Italian painter Enrico Castellani and the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. The association also named the Asian Youth Orchestra as the winner of its annual Grant for Young Artists award, which comes with approximately $56,000. The Praemium Imperiale awards were created in 1988 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Japan Art Association and to honor its longtime honorary patron, Prince Takamatsu, who died in 1987. The awards will be bestowed in a ceremony in Tokyo on Oct. 13.

This week, the hottest thing cooking at the Museum of Modern Art will be "Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen." The show, which opens Wednesday and runs through March 14, 2011, explores the 20th-century evolution of this pivotal room and its ongoing redesign as a barometer of a changing society. Drawn entirely from MoMA's own collections, "Counter Space" comprises more than 300 works, including design objects, architectural plans, posters, photographs, archival films (including one that shows the motion-study pioneers Frank B. and Lillian M. Gilbreth, of "Cheaper by the Dozen" fame, and nine of their children), prints, painting and media works. Included are an image of a 1931 kitchen, designed by Lilly Reich, that looks as if it had been completed yesterday, and a tape of the famous 1959 kitchen debate between Richard Nixon and Nikita Krushchev. The exhibition also explores the role of the kitchen in feminist critiques and art movements like Surrealism, Pop Art and Fluxus.

In 1927, Mies van der Rohe designed the innovative concrete-and-steel Weissenhof apartments in Stuttgart, Germany, which would become a landmark of International-style architecture; that same year, Gerrit Rietveld built the so-called chauffeur's house (above), a little-known but remarkably similar building in his hometown of Utrecht, the Netherlands, which leaked and had to be redone shortly thereafter. Trained as a cabinetmaker, Rietveld - an early member of the de Stijl movement known for his Red-Blue Chair and Schröder House - suffered many such disappointments in a career of more than 45 years. But a new retrospective at Utrecht's Centraal Museum illustrates how his groundbreaking ideas had a much broader impact than is generally acknowledged. ''In Holland you have this feeling that maybe he was a genius but he wasn't a good architect,'' says Ida van Zijl, the curator of ''Rietveld's Universe,'' which opens Oct. 20 as part of the Netherlands' Rietveld Year. ''People don't realize how many works he made and how experimental they were.'' The exhibition puts his furniture and architecture on an international scale, comparing it with Marcel Breuer, Le Corbusier and van der Rohe as well as showing its influence on contemporary designers. In a room dedicated to the Red-Blue Chair, the real thing will sit alongside a video of Maarten Baas's charred homage.

David Ushery has boldly gone where almost no other male anchors on local newscasts in New York seem to have gone before, at least not in the studio: into the uncharted territory beyond the jacket-and-tie look. Into tie-lessness. Mr. Ushery, an anchor on the Saturday night newscasts on WNBC-TV, tried the jacket-and-open-collar look last month. He dresses that way on ''The Debrief,'' a somewhat less formal program that he presides over on Sundays at noon. (It is also broadcast on Fridays at 6:30 p.m. and seven times over the weekend on WNBC's New York Nonstop cable channel.)

KLEINHANDLER--Florence, 94, beloved wife of 71 years of the late Nathan Kleinhandler, survived by a loving, devoted family of son's, Neil and Chester, brother Dr. Arnold Solomon, daughters-in-law Naomi and Solange and granddaughters Mariel and Ashley. She lived a life full of caring and love and will be deeply missed and lovingly remembered.

BOULANGER--Jacques. Jacques Pierre Rodolphe Boulanger, age 68, died peacefully at home in New York, NY on September 10, 2010. Born in Paris, he was the son of Roger Auguste Boulanger and Marguerite Cesare Zavaroni Boulanger of Paris and Arnage, France and graduated from EDHEC Business School, Lille, France and Columbia Business School. After a long career in New York as an investment banker, in 1995 he founded and headed a pioneering catalog and internet wine retail business. Jacques was not only devoted to his business, but was also an inveterate international traveler and master of many languages. He was known for his intellect, his wit, and his flair in dress and all things aesthetic. Mr. Boulanger is survived by Carol Seabrook Boulanger, his wife of 36 years, his son Rodolphe of New York, NY and his daughter Adriana of South Woodstock, VT. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on September 15 from 6-8pm. A memorial mass will be held on September 16 at 11am at St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Ave. at 84th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation, 57 W. 57 St., New York, NY 10019 in order to further research in frontotemporal dementia.

DITIZAN--Michael. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, Mike. No one loved our annual golf boondoggle to Kiawah Island more than you. We will miss your jokes, easy laughter and assistance in selecting the red wine. We will carry on, but it won't be the same without you. The Sweet Lou Committee

John Sainsbury, the former head of a British supermarket chain, has donated $38.5 million toward an expansion of the British Museum, the museum has announced. The gift is one of the largest private cultural donations ever made in Britain and comes at a time when arts institutions there are bracing for an expected 25 percent cut in state financing when the government announces the results of a spending review on Oct. 20. The British Museum is building a $360 million wing, designed by Richard Rogers, to house temporary exhibitions and a conservation center. The government has pledged roughly $35 million toward it.

SCHWARTZ--Leon. The Officers, Directors and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center extend their heartfelt sympathy to Michael Schwartz, our dedicated Board member, on the loss of his beloved father Leon. Our sincere condolences to Michael, Michelle and the entire family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert Friedman, Exec. V.P.

CHEVY CHASE, Md. -- She is unlikely to be mentioned at any 50th-birthday parties this year, but she is the reason many of those celebrations will take place. Dr. Frances Oldham Kelsey is 96 now, nearly deaf and barely mobile, as modest as her faded house in this Washington suburb. And though her story is nearly forgotten, she was once America's most admired civil servant -- celebrated for her dual role in saving thousands of newborns from the perils of the drug thalidomide and in serving as midwife to modern pharmaceutical regulation.

CAHILL--Lawrence J.,died Thursday, September 9, surrounded by his family. He is survived by three children: Jacqueline Cahill, Kathleen (Jerry) Heiss, Thomas P. Cahill, their mother Carole, his brother Thomas (Susan) Cahill, his sisters Patricia Holland, Anne Petralito, Mary (Ken) Reitz, Teresa (Frank) Lively, his granddaughter Madeline Heiss and many nieces and nephews. Larry was always a high energy person who loved music and being outdoors. A graduate of Xavier High School in New York, he attended Bellarmine Jesuit College graduating in 1964 with an AB. He spent the next two years at Loyola Seminary, Shrub Oak, NY before leaving for Fordham University. An expert marksman with the 4th Infantry Division, he served in the central highlands of Vietnam during the Tet offensive. A respected businessman, he was employed by Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, Connell Corp, Genesee & Wyoming, New York Cross Harbor Railroad, was consultant to Wevco Biodiesel. Larry was a man of principle who evoked personal ties with everyone he met. He will be deeply missed. Funeral Mass 10am September 16, Church of Notre Dame, 405 W. 114th St., New York. Private interment. Donations in memory of Lawrence J. Cahill '60 to: Xavier High School, 30 West 16th St., New York, NY 10011. On to the next horizon. Ad Jesu per Miriam.

Since 2002, the September Concert Foundation has organized free musical events during the week of Sept. 11, which now number around 200 concerts worldwide. On Saturday evening the organization offered a memorial concert featuring an eclectic selection of upbeat and patriotic choral works at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The New York Choral Society, conducted by John Daly Goodwin, opened the program with Harry Belafonte's cheery ''Turn the World Around.'' Next came Bernstein's ''Chichester Psalms,'' an optimistic work he called ''the most B-flat majorish tonal piece I've ever written.'' Bernstein composed it during a sabbatical from his duties as music director of the New York Philharmonic, a year in which he experimented with 12-tone composition.

McCOLLUM--Robert W.,MD, died September 13, 2010 at home in New Hampshire. Beloved husband of Audrey, father of Cindy and Doug, grandfather of Justin and Zach. Physician, researcher, educator, colleague, mentor and friend. A prominent infectious disease researcher, he was involved in the development and field trials of several vaccines, including polio and hepatitis B. After 30 years at the Yale University School of Medicine, he became Dean of Dartmouth Medical School in 1982 and played a key role in the creation of the new integrated Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, NH. He continued to teach and be active in medical school affairs for many years thereafter. He will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Donations may be made to the Dean Robert W. McCollum MD Scholarship Fund c/o Dartmouth Medical School Office of Development; 1 Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756 or the LeBouvier-McCollum Scholarship Fund c/o Martin Klein Yale School of Public Health; Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-0611.

ROSS--Eric F. Solomon Schechter Day School of Essex and Union mourns the passing of Eric F. Ross, benefactor and friend a Holocaust survivor who was extraordinarily devoted to Jewish education and continuity. The Schechter Upper School campus was named after Mr. Ross in 1995 in appreciation of Mr. Ross' contribution and generosity. The school's Neshama Israel program was renamed the Lore Ross Neshama program in 2009 in memory of Mr. Ross' wife, Lore. The Ross' annually provided travel grants to Schechter's 12th graders so all students could participate in the Neshama Israel program. Schechter extends its deepest condolences to Mr. Ross' family. Dr. Joyce Raynor, Head of School Joseph Bier, Chair, Board of Trustees

An obituary on Friday about Thomas Guinzburg, an editor and publisher who helped create The Paris Review, misstated the position held by William F. Buckley Jr. at The Yale Daily News when Mr. Guinzburg was managing editor. Mr. Buckley was chairman, not editor.
WILLIAMS--Samuel Dunstan. A Memorial Service will take place on Thursday, September 16, 2010 at the Church of Saint Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street at 3:30pm.

DITZIAN--Michael. The law firm of Davis & Gilbert suffered a great loss with the passing of its Managing Partner, Michael Ditzian. Michael was a great leader, teacher and friend. To his clients, he was a highly regarded counselor and adviser. To his partners, attorneys and staff, he was a guiding force and inspiration. To his family, Michael was a loving husband, devoted father and close friend. Michael will always be remembered for his intelligence, integrity and spirit, and for being a fighter against the disease that ultimately took him from us. We are proud to continue in the spirit in which he led his life. Our heart and support goes out to his beloved family his wife, Barbara, his children, Jaime and Eric, Fleur, and Michael's sister, Maralyn. The Partners, Attorneys and Staff of Davis & Gilbert

During basketball practice last year, 12-year-old Nicole Dehart was shooting the ball when a defender tried aggressively to block her shot. The two players made contact, and Nicole hit the floor headfirst. ''The way she was hit took her whole body out from under her, and she landed directly on her head,'' said her mother, Christine White, of Pataskala, Ohio. ''We immediately knew this was serious. She was very confused and looking at people like she didn't know who they were.''

An article on Friday about Matt Kuchar's lead after the first round of the BMW Championship golf tournament misspelled the dateline. And an article on Saturday about Kuchar's maintaining a share of the lead after the second round repeated the error. The tournament was at Cog Hill Golf and Country Club in Lemont, Ill. -- not in Elmont, Ill. (Dustin Johnson won the tournament; Kuchar tied for third.)

Michael, as a managing partner of law firm Davis & Gilbert, has been a longtime friend committed to philanthropy and strengthening Jewish community. An Op-Chart on Sunday that listed statistical trends in Afghanistan, Iraq and Pakistan carried an incorrect label in one category. The numbers for military casualties in Afghanistan represented United States and total foreign coalition deaths, not United States and other NATO coalition deaths. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/opinion.
MOORE--John McDonald. 1/11/19 - 9/14/99. Cherished.
Schedule information on Friday with an art review about ''Yoshitomo Nara: Nobody's Fool,'' at the Asia Society Museum, misstated the exhibition's closing date. It is Jan. 2, not Jan. 20.

ROSS--Eric. The board and staff of American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev (AABGU) are deeply saddened by the passing of one of our dearest friends and supporters. A national board member of AABGU, Eric Ross, with his late wife Lore, was a devoted benefactor of Ben-Gurion University. His generous contributions have provided scholarships for students, built classrooms, fostered educational programs for disadvantaged youth, and invested in a variety of capital projects. A dedicated philanthropist and humanitarian, Eric generously supported Jewish community and educational institutions in the United States, in Germany and in Israel, a commitment for which he was recognized with an honorary doctoral degree from BGU this past June. Eric's passionate commitment to philanthropy was made in appreciation for the life and success he had after fleeing Nazi Germany at the age of 19, and was a living memorial to his parents and those who perished in the Holocaust. Eric was an inspiration and a role-model and will be sorely missed. We extend our profound condolences to Eric's children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alexander M. Goren, President Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President

Tomorrow's primaries in New York and six other states - the last of the 2010 cycle, save for Saturday's primary in Hawaii and a runoff in Louisiana on Oct. 2 - originally looked as though they'd have little impact on the electoral landscape. Although some of the primaries were nominally competitive - like the Republican Senate race in Maryland, where a suite of 11 candidates will be on the ballot - they were typically not so in places where the nominee stood a strong chance of winning the general election. Two races, however, have changed that equation. And depending on how they are resolved, Republican chances of taking over the Senate could be enhanced or significantly diminished.
HARAN--Jacques. Always remembered, missed, loved. William

Quinn Funeral Home, Inc., 35-20 Broadway, Astoria, NY, Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday, Immaculate Conception Church, 10:30am. Interment - Calvary Cemetery. LOS ANGELES -- Lionsgate's African-American-focused film business, anchored by Tyler Perry titles, has become a gold mine for the studio. Movies with predominantly black casts that tell stories rooted in black culture -- surprise! -- bring out a sizable black audience. Now Lionsgate is trying to pull off the same trick with Hispanic-focused films.

The Talking Business column on Saturday, about the Hewlett-Packard board's handling of the ousting of Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive, misspelled the surname of one of the company's directors. He is Marc L. Andreessen, not Andreesen. The column also misstated the name of a company whose directors include Robert L. Ryan, another H.P. board member. It is Medtronic, not Medtronics.

ASHER--Helen S. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the passing of Helen Asher of Chicago, a visionary leader in Jewish philanthropy and a stalwart supporter of the Technion. Mrs. Asher's devotion to the ATS and the Technion provided the inspiration and means for dramatic scientific achievement, helping Israel become one of the few countries to launch a student-designed and built satellite. The transformational gift she made with her late husband, Norman, established the Norman and Helen Asher Space Research Institute (ASRI) in 1986, and effectively served to bring the Technion and Israel into the Space Age. Subsequent gifts by the Ashers were instrumental for building the ASRI Building, and for sustaining the world-renowned interdisciplinary research of Technion astrophysicists, aerospace engineers and other scientists. Committed to the Technion for more than 45 years, Mrs. Asher was a member of the Chicago Chapter, a member of the ATS national Board of Directors, a life trustee of the ATS Board of Regents, and an honorary life member of the Technion International Board of Governors. She was awarded an honorary fellowship and doctorate from the Technion, and the Albert Einstein Award from the ATS, its highest honor. Together with Norman, Mrs. Asher was a Technion Guardian, achieving the highest level of commitment. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her sons Donald, Gilbert and Robert Asher and the entire Asher family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

7:03 p.m. | Updated The recent campaign ad by Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor in California, was designed to create tension between her opponent, Jerry Brown, and the man featured in the ad, former President Bill Clinton. Mr. Brown's comments were a clear reference to Mr. Clinton's famous remarks during the Monica Lewinsky scandal, when the former president looked into the cameras and said -- misleadingly, it turned out -- ''I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Miss Lewinsky.''

GELBERMAN--Rabbi Joseph H.,98, born April 27, 1012 in Hungary, passed away peacefully, at home, September 9, attended by his beloved cantor Judith Steel and other friends. The Father of Interfaith, Rabbi Gelberman founded The New Synagogue, The New Seminary (For Interfaith Studies), The Rabbinical Seminary, Int, All Faiths Seminary and The Rabbinical Fellowship of America, Int. He will be remembered as a deeply Joyfilled being, who inspired everyone around him to live LIFE according to the Cabalistic interpretation: L- Loving unconditionally, I-Inspiring Unconditionally, F-Forgiving unconditionally, E-Excited unconditionally. His life blesses us every day. We will miss him always. Rest in Peace Rebbe. The New Synagogue Rabbi Roger Ross Rabbi Stuart Paris Cantor Judith Steel

SAINES--Libby, long time resident of White Plains, died at Greenwich Hospital on September 11, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Marvin. Loving mother of Philip and Andrew. As a former senator, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is intimately familiar with the Senate expression that there are show horses and workhorses. When it comes to the 2010 campaign season, Mr. Biden is definitely a workhorse. His appearance Monday night in Philadelphia alongside Representative Joe Sestak, the Democratic Senate candidate, will be the 44th political event the vice president has participated in this year. Mr. Sestak is running against Pat Toomey, a Republican.

WARE--Celestine, sister of Ayn Marie Stewart, cousin of Thella Brooks, Janice Ilerio, and William Ware, Jr., died in New York City on August 21, 2010. She was born in Cleveland, Ohio, and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1962. A black feminist theorist and a member of the Stanton-Anthony Brigade, she was the author of "Woman Power: The Movement for Women's Liberation" (published in 1970, when her first name was still spelled Cellestine). Writer, editor, and TV producer, a loving friend, a fount of memorable quotations, a brilliant recommender of newly-hatched novels, a beautiful, inventively dressed woman, and a world-traveler, Celestine was interested in film, art, literature, black studies, history, music, feminism, politics, fashion, and food, and she was knowledgeable about them all. She bore her increasing ill health with great fortitude. One appropriate epitaph for her would be the lyrics she quoted when a friend of hers died too young: "Didn't she ramble, till the butcher cut her down!"

Newt Gingrich said this weekend that President Obama exhibited ''Kenyan, anticolonial behavior,'' an observation that drew angry if puzzled responses from Democrats and questions about Mr. Gingrich's meaning and motivation. Mr. Gingrich, who is mulling a bid for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012, made the comments to National Review Online. He was quoted by the conservative Web site as saying: ''What if [Obama] is so outside our comprehension, that only if you understand Kenyan, anticolonial behavior, can you begin to piece together [his actions]? That is the most accurate, predictive model for his behavior.''

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about an agreement for CBS to continue televising the Tony Awards ceremony through 2013 erroneously included a Broadway trade association as a founder of the awards. While the Broadway League now presents them with the American Theater Wing, the league was not a founder. (The theater wing created the awards.)

DITZIAN--Michael David, age 69, of Manhattan, NY, passed away on September 10, surrounded by his adoring family: his devoted wife of 38 years, Barbara, his children Jaime and Eric, Eric's fiance', Fleur, and his sister Maralyn. Michael grew up in Rockville Centre, graduated cum laude from Amherst College, earned his law degree from Cornell University and his Master of Laws from New York University. In 1968, he served as an active-duty member of the United States Army in Vietnam. He joined Davis & Gilbert in 1971, rising to Managing Partner and being recognized as one of the leading attorneys handling mergers and acquisitions in advertising, public relations and marketing. He was proudly and continually committed to the Lymphoma Research Foundation and Amherst College. Donations may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation. He will be remembered always for his kindness, honesty, generosity and devotion to his friends and family. Services will be held Monday, September 13 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 W 76th St.

(ESPN) UNMATCHED The main thing Chris Evert, above right, remembers about Martina Navratilova, above left, when they first faced each other as teenagers on the tennis court in 1973 was that her competitor was fat and sullen. ''She was very emotional on the court, whining if she didn't feel she was playing well,'' Ms. Evert said. ''But I remember thinking, if she loses weight, we're all in trouble.'' Her only goal that day, Ms. Navratilova countered, was for Ms. Evert ''to remember my name.'' Eighty matches later, the women had become not only competitors but also true friends. In this latest entry in the ''30 for 30'' documentary series, Lisa Lax and Nancy Stern Winters interview these tennis superstars to tell the story of one of the sport's greatest rivalries and to get their opinions on the state of the game. 6 A.M. (MSG Network) BOOMER & CARTON Boomer Esiason, the former National Football League quarterback, and Craig Carton, a onetime host of ''Jersey Boys,'' an occasionally controversial talk show out of Trenton, bring their morning banter to television in a new program simulcast from their spiffed-up studio at WFAN (660 AM) headquarters in the South Village. ''Boomer & Carton,'' which replaced ''Imus in the Morning'' on WFAN, is now New York's top-rated morning show among men 25 to 54. ''Boomer & Carton in 60,'' a nightly hourlong program featuring the best of that morning's show, will be broadcast at 10.

WASHINGTON -- The Obama administration is considering appointing the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren to run a new consumer bureau on a temporary basis to avoid a potentially bruising confirmation battle in the Senate, according to people who have been briefed on the search. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a centerpiece of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street regulatory overhaul law that Mr. Obama signed in July, was established to prevent abusive, deceptive and fraudulent terms for mortgages, credit cards, payday loans and a vast array of other financial products. It is to be led by a director, appointed by the president to a five-year term with the consent of the Senate.

On May 15, 1985, trainers at Hawaii Sea Life Park were stunned when a 400- pound gray female bottlenose dolphin named Punahele gave birth to a dark-skinned calf that partly resembled the 2,000-pound male false killer whale with whom she shared a pool. The calf was a wholphin, a hybrid that was intermediate to its parents in some characteristics, like having 66 teeth compared with the bottlenose's 44 and the 88 of the false killer whale, a much larger member of the dolphin family. In 2006, a hunter in the Canadian Arctic shot a bear that had white fur like a polar bear's but had brown patches, long claws and a hump like a grizzly bear's. DNA analysis confirmed the animal was a hybrid of the two species.

I offer training in both philosophy and boxing. Over the years, some of my colleagues have groused that my work is a contradiction, building minds and cultivating rational discourse while teaching violence and helping to remove brain cells. Truth be told, I think philosophers with this gripe should give some thought to what really counts as violence.  I would rather take a punch in the nose any day than be subjected to some of the attacks that I have witnessed in philosophy colloquia.  However, I have a more positive case for including boxing in my curriculum for sentimental education.

Our two-week baseline assessment in Rwanda came to an end, and it was time for me to leave "the land of a thousand hills" and head back to New York. I have much data to sift through - my team interviewed 48 households, and collectively we surveyed 378 households in the three sectors. I leave the field with many research-type questions - more than when I entered. For example, how do we actually measure this complex activity known as water access in subsistence communities? I am also left wondering about the relationship between social inequality and environmental disparity, and the social impact that technological changes might bring about in these subsistence communities.

Sara Bareilles, whose single "Love Song" became a ubiquitous hit two years ago, reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with her second release, "Kaleidoscope Heart" (Epic). Her new album sold 90,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, beating out Eminem, Katy Perry, Disturbed and several new releases. It was the best week of album sales in Ms. Bareilles's career so far -- her first release, "Little Voice," peaked at No. 10 and has sold a total of 997,000 copies to date. But her album sales are still dwarfed by the success of "Love Song," which has had 3.2 million digital downloads.

Overview | What can we learn from animals that have accidentally been killed as a result of human activity? In this lesson, students use a map to navigate local roads from the perspective of a common animal. Then they analyze geographic data collected from animals killed in motor vehicle collisions and propose ways to reduce them. They learn how to analyze the layers of data included in interactive maps, think critically about the data and apply what they have learned to suggesting ways to improve roadway safety for wildlife.

I wanted to mention first the subjects that are really on people's minds here - the filming of a Drew Barrymore movie in Anchorage and the mass migration of the walruses to the shores of the northwest. The movie was drawn here by tax credits and has been accompanied by an explosion of beautiful young women in the downtown area. The walruses seem to be fleeing global warming. Best known for "The War Room," the 1994 documentary that went inside Bill Clinton's campaign hub in Little Rock, Ark., D.A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus have been co-directing since the mid-'70s. Next year, their work will be the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image. Their latest production, "The Kings of Pastry," makes its theatrical debut at Film Forum. Bon appétit. The movie takes viewers to Lyon, France, to follow the  Alsatian pastry chef Jacquy Pfeiffer, the co-founder of Chicago's French Pastry School, as he vies for France's most prestigious trade award, the M.O.F. (Meilleurs Ouvriers de France, or Best Craftsmen of France). Held every four years, the grueling competition is the artisanal equivalent of the Olympics - or rather, it makes "Top Chef" look like a slumber party. "In a way," Hegedus says, "television cooking shows have spoiled us for the possibilities of true drama in the kitchen."

For a decentralized, essentially leaderless movement (the best efforts of Dick Armey and Jim DeMint notwithstanding), the Tea Party has cut its swath through the Republican primary season with a great deal of strategic savvy. Beginning with Pat Toomey and continuing through Marco Rubio and Rand Paul, Sharron Angle and Joe Miller, the candidates propelled to victory by Tea Partier enthusiasm have often given the national Republican Party heartburn, but none of them have been clearly un-electable - and if this fall is as good to the G.O.P. as it's shaping up to be right now, most of them will probably end up winning. Whereas in those races where the "rightwardmost candidate" (to borrow William F. Buckley's phrase) couldn't possibly win a general election, the Tea Party hasn't gone all in: Thus Carly Fiorina rather than Chuck DeVore is the Republican nominee for the California Senate, John McCain rather than J.D. Hayworth is the nominee in Arizona, Mark Kirk is the nominee in Illinois, etc.

Sometimes forces beyond our control - rock bands, bloggers, fashion people - anoint a new epicenter of cool. Marfa, Tex., and Reykjavik, Iceland, had their moment, and now it's Lisbon's turn. The Walkmen named their latest album after the city. (J. Crew chimed in too, shooting a catalog there.) Hamilton Leithauser, the frontman, said the band traveled to Portugal while they wrote ''Lisbon'': ''Everything just worked there. The rest of Europe doesn't work as well for us - our horn players quit in Germany.'' The results are 11 songs that range from explosive anthems (''Angela Surf City'') to lonely dirges (''Stranded''). ''Lisbon'' also marks the Walkmen's debut on Fat Possum Records, based in Oxford, Miss., another drowsy town ripe for aesthetic reclamation any minute now.

London's bohemian vanguard has found a new home base in the twin neighborhoods of Kensal Rise and Kensal Green. The traditionally Portuguese district of Victorian row houses north of Notting Hill is home to buzzy gastropubs and incognito celebrities - Sophie Dahl and Jade Jagger live here - and the rents are still cheap enough that pioneering shop owners are hanging out shingles on Chamberlayne Road. Victoria Brotherson, the florist behind Scarlet and Violet (76 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-969-9446), sells vintage cut-crystal vases and chipped enamel pitchers alongside English blooms like cornflower and nigella. ''I thought I was just going to have a little workshop,'' she says. ''I was taken by surprise that we were that busy.'' In her wake, two vintage furniture stores, Howie & Belle (52 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-964-4553) and Circus Antiques (60 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-968-8244), have opened among the bookies' offices down the street. And a 10-minute walk away in Kensal Green, Retrouvius (2A Ravensworth Road; 011-44-208-960-6060)is the brainchild of the designers Adam Hills and Maria Speake, a space stocked with repurposed architectural salvage. There's quirky drinking and dining, too: besides the Chamberlayne Pub and Steakhouse (83 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-960-4311) and the wine bar Miro's (75 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-203-235-0003), the gastropub Paradise by Way of Kensal Green (19 Kilburn Lane; 011-44-208-969-0098) serves seasonal and organic dishes and a beloved sticky toffee pudding. It doubles as a lounge and performance space that may hide in its warren of rooms a burlesque show, a wedding or even the singer Lily Allen.

One of the weaknesses of our Senate forecasting model is that, for all the precision we apply to the general election forecasts, we only eyeball the primaries, making estimates about the likelihood of each potential matchup on the basis of the polling and other factors. Nevertheless, we try to be pretty careful. For instance, we had assigned a 25 percent likelihood that Joe Miller would defeat the Republican incumbent, Lisa Murkowski, in Alaska, as happened. We had also assigned small likelihoods to a number of other outcomes that did not come to fruition, like J.D. Hayworth ousting John McCain in Arizona (Mr. McCain won by 24 points) or Chet D. Traylor unseating David Vitter in Louisiana (Mr. Vitter won by 81).

In an experiment published last month, researchers recruited schoolchildren, ages 9 and 10, who lived near the Champaign-Urbana campus of the University of Illinois and asked them to run on a treadmill. The researchers were hoping to learn more about how fitness affects the immature human brain. Animal studies had already established that, when given access to running wheels, baby rodents bulked up their brains, enlarging certain areas and subsequently outperforming sedentary pups on rodent intelligence tests. But studies of the effect of exercise on the actual shape and function of children's brains had not yet been tried.

BLOCK--Muriel L. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our cherished friend and Benefactor. Mrs. Block, along with her beloved late husband Harold, was a longtime leading supporter of the College of Medicine. In 2003, Mrs. Block made an exemplary leadership gift to Einstein; her visionary gift helped advance biomedical research at the medical school through the construction of the state-of-the-art Harold and Muriel Block Research Pavilion. Mrs. Block previously established the Muriel and Harold Block Faculty Scholar in Mental Illness. A prominent member of our National Women's Division, she served on its national board and New York chapter executive board. In recognition of her vision and generosity, she received an honorary degree from Yeshiva University in 2004. We already miss her elegant and spirited presence and extend our deepest sympathy to Irving Baumrind, our esteemed Honorary Overseer, her beloved daughters Audrey Heckler and Joan Vernick, and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman Chairperson Board of Overseers

If would-be diplomats cannot name an American artist or specify where a major American river is located, R. Smith Simpson wondered (and worried), how can they properly represent the United States in other countries? He was 103.

McCOLLUM--Robert W.,MD, died September 13, 2010 at home in New Hampshire. Beloved husband of Audrey, father of Cindy and Doug, grandfather of Justin and Zach. Physician, researcher, educator, colleague, mentor and friend. A prominent infectious disease researcher, he was involved in the development and field trials of several vaccines, including polio and hepatitis B. After 30 years at the Yale University School of Medicine, he became Dean of Dartmouth Medical School in 1982 and played a key role in the creation of the new integrated Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, NH. He continued to teach and be active in medical school affairs for many years thereafter. He will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Donations may be made to the Dean Robert W. McCollum MD Scholarship Fund c/o Dartmouth Medical School Office of Development; 1 Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756 or the LeBouvier-McCollum Scholarship Fund c/o Martin Klein Yale School of Public Health; Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-0611.

A new voting system unveiled in New York City for the primary election on Tuesday was plagued by problems, with some polling places opening hours late and others verging on chaos as workers coped with malfunctioning machines. Some polling sites did not receive the optical scanners needed to read paper ballots by 6 a.m., when voting was supposed to begin. At other polling places, the scanners failed to operate properly when they were switched on, forcing voters to wait while election workers struggled to get the devices going.

Beating back an aggressive challenger, United States Representative Carolyn B. Maloney easily won the Democratic Party's nomination on Tuesday, according to early returns in one of the most expensive Congressional primaries this year. With about 90 percent of the precincts reporting, Ms. Maloney, 64, had about 81 percent of the vote, while her opponent, Reshma Saujani, 34, a lawyer who has worked with hedge funds, had about 19 percent. The victory makes Ms. Maloney a heavy favorite to win a 10th term in the general election in November.

Should New York City charter schools be required to have parent associations like regular public schools? From that basic question comes the first charter school controversy of the new school year. Those who back mandatory parent associations for charters see the issue as a matter of principle and of parents' rights. Those who oppose them do so either on technical grounds - that the New York City schools chancellor does not have authority over charter schools that he did not authorize (about 40 percent of the city's charters were authorized by the State University of New York) or on theoretical grounds: that the whole point of charter schools is that they should be free of such mandates.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- The Giants' Hall of Fame, inside the Legacy Club at New Meadowlands Club, contains an impressive collection of memorabilia, busts of the team's greatest players and all of its owners, and player videos accessible on touch screens. The artifacts range from Benny Friedman's leather helmet and Roosevelt Brown's Hall of Fame induction certificate to a $1 ticket to the first game against the Philadelphia Yellow Jackets in 1925 and original seats from the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium. Also: Frank Gifford's enormous 1956 Player of the Year trophy, Al Blozis's white No. 32 jersey and a 1949 season pass.

Would high-fructose corn syrup, by any other name, have sweeter appeal? The Corn Refiners Association, which represents firms that make the syrup, has been trying to improve the image of the much maligned sweetener with ad campaigns promoting it as a natural ingredient made from corn. Now, the group has petitioned the United States Food and Drug Administration to start calling the ingredient ''corn sugar,'' arguing that a name change is the only way to clear up consumer confusion about the product.

DITZIAN--Michael David, age 69, of Manhattan, NY, passed away on September 10, surrounded by his adoring family: his devoted wife of 38 years, Barbara, his children Jaime and Eric, Eric's fiance', Fleur, and his sister Maralyn. Michael grew up in Rockville Centre, graduated cum laude from Amherst College, earned his law degree from Cornell University and his Master of Laws from New York University. In 1968, he served as an active-duty member of the United States Army in Vietnam. He joined Davis & Gilbert in 1971, rising to Managing Partner and being recognized as one of the leading attorneys handling mergers and acquisitions in advertising, public relations and marketing. He was proudly and continually committed to the Lymphoma Research Foundation and Amherst College. Donations may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation. He will be remembered always for his kindness, honesty, generosity and devotion to his friends and family. Services will be held Monday, September 13 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 W 76th St.

RALSTON, Iowa -- Piglets hop, scurry and squeal their way to the far corner of the pen, eyeing an approaching human. ''It shows that they're healthy animals,'' Craig Rowles, the owner of a large pork farm here, said with pride. Mr. Rowles says he keeps his pigs fit by feeding them antibiotics for weeks after weaning, to ward off possible illness in that vulnerable period. And for months after that, he administers an antibiotic that promotes faster growth with less feed.

Timing is everything. I was at Casa Mono, in Manhattan, lapping up every drop of the sauce from a little cazuela of piquillo peppers stuffed with oxtails. The next day I was tasting Ribera del Duero wines (with the restaurant's wine director, as it happened) and could think of no better dish for them than those meaty, slightly fruity peppers with their alluring hint of bitterness. Andy Nusser, the chef at Casa Mono, provided the recipe, enough to feed the entire town of Peñafiel. I made drastic cuts (four quarts of stock down to two cups, for example) but still had enough for a party. My freezer holds the bonus. Though the oxtails are time consuming, they cook mostly unattended. FLORENCE FABRICANT

The Jaguars had a sellout for their opener on Sunday, the crowd boosted by the presence of the Broncos rookie Tim Tebow, who played high school football and college football nearby. While Tebow's No. 15 jersey -- in both Broncos and Florida Gators blue -- was the most popular one in the rarely filled stands, the one he actually wore barely got dirty. Tebow took the field for three plays, twice getting stuffed on inside runs and once lining up, implausibly, as a wide receiver. When a thunderstorm stopped the game for 33 minutes in the second half, the Orlando Sentinel columnist Mike Bianchi, who had needled Tebow on Twitter all afternoon, noted: ''Game is temporarily delayed for lightning. God is apparently unhappy Tebow is not playing more.''With a recent history of middling attendance and TV blackouts, not to mention whispers of a possible move to Los Angeles, the Jaguars are well aware of how important it is to sell tickets and to win games this season.

An obituary on Saturday about Irwin Silber, the longtime editor of the folk-music magazine Sing Out!, misstated the position he held at the radical weekly Guardian from 1972 to 1978. He was the executive editor, not the editor.

Credit Suisse agreed Tuesday to buy a minority stake in the hedge fund York Capital Management for $425 million. The bank, Switzerland's second largest after UBS, will acquire a one-third stake in York, which manages about $14 billion in assets, according to people with direct knowledge of the deal who were not authorized to speak publicly. The move comes as Wall Street firms wrestle with new federal laws aimed at preventing banks from making risky bets with their own money. The new regulations, including the so-called Volcker Rule, limit how much money banks can place in riskier investments like private equity and hedge funds. By structuring the deal as a noncontrol, minority stake in York, whose management team will continue to operate the business independently, Credit Suisse will comply with the new legislation. The investment ''is consistent with the recently enacted U.S. financial reforms,'' the bank said in a statement. Credit Suisse also said that it would not invest its own money into York's funds, though it would market the funds to its clients. Credit Suisse's asset-management group, led by Rob Shafir, has done a number deals in which it has taken stakes in outside investment firms. The bank has a majority interest in Hedging-Griffo, a large Brazilian asset-management firm. It also owns a stake in Global Infrastructure Partners, a private equity firm that invests in infrastructure deals. United States banks have taken different approaches to their investments in hedge funds and private equity firms. Morgan Stanley is considering spinning off a hedge fund, FrontPoint Partners, that it acquired in 2006. It also holds minority stakes in Avenue Capital, Lansdowne Partners and Traxis Partners. A Morgan Stanley spokeswoman declined to comment. Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said at an industry conference on Tuesday that the banking company planned to keep Highbridge Capital Management, a hedge fund with $21 billion in assets under management, as well as One Equity Partners, a private equity unit that manages about $8 billion in assets. And Goldman Sachs sponsors an investment vehicle, Petershill Fund, that takes minority stakes in hedge funds. York was founded with just $5 million in equity capital in 1991 by Jamie Dinan, a former investment banker who is sometimes confused with Mr. Dimon of JPMorgan Chase. York helped pioneer a strategy called ''event-driven investing,'' which grew out of the arbitrage funds of the late 1980s that placed big bets on mergers. York's investments include wagers on the outcome of deals as well as stakes in distressed investments. The firm has performed well during most of its existence, though like many rivals, it suffered during the financial crisis. It reported a 26.4 percent loss in its flagship Multi-Strategy Fund in 2008, according to a letter to investors. It bounced back the next year, reporting a 39.7 percent gain in 2009, according to Hedge Fund Research. York's success has made its founder very wealthy. In 2004, Mr. Dinan paid $21 million for a Fifth Avenue apartment sold by L. Dennis Kozlowski, the fallen former chief executive of Tyco International. Mr. Dinan also owns a horse farm in North Salem, N.Y., about 60 miles northeast of New York City. Under the terms of the Credit Suisse deal, York could receive additional ''earn-out'' payments based on its five-year financial performance. Mr. Dinan and several other principals of the firm also signed retention agreements with Credit Suisse. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

For 16 years, Marshall A. Cohen served as a director of the American International Group, stepping down just months before the company's near-collapse in 2008. Several months later, Mr. Cohen was again in demand, joining the board of Gleacher & Company, a New York investment bank. Gleacher expanded its board last year to include not only Mr. Cohen but Henry S. Bienen, who served as a director of Bear Stearns from 2004 until its rescue by JPMorgan Chase in March 2008. On the second anniversary of the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy, appointments like those of Mr. Cohen and Mr. Bienen highlight how the directors of the companies at the center of the financial crisis - A.I.G., Bear Stearns and Lehman itself - still play an active role in the governance of corporate America. ''In too many cases, the radioactivity of a board member of a collapsed company has a half life measured in milliseconds,'' said John Gillespie, a longtime Wall Street investment banker and the co-author of ''Money for Nothing'' (Free Press), a recent book on corporate boards. While in some cases investors are suing members of the boards of the failed companies, shareholder advocates have for the most part focused their energies on other issues. And public outrage over the financial crisis has been mainly focused on the executives in charge of firms like Bear and Lehman. Some, like James E. Cayne of Bear, have not re-emerged at other companies. Richard S. Fuld Jr. of Lehman, which filed for bankruptcy on Sept. 15, 2008, is running a small advisory firm. Yet the decisions that led to the collapse of the firms they steered were not theirs alone. Directors are elected by shareholders to oversee the activities of a company and play an important role in appointing senior officers and setting corporate strategy. In many cases during the real estate bubble, directors approved the strategy that paved the way for executives to make risky investments on borrowed money. These directors also approved pay packages that fed the risk-taking. ''The C.E.O.'s get most of the attention because there's so little expectation that the board should have done something,'' Mr. Gillespie said. ''In our corporate system the directors are supposed to be in charge, not the C.E.O., yet they rarely get any of the blame because they're typically dominated by the C.E.O.'' A Gleacher spokesman declined to comment. Mr. Cohen, a Toronto lawyer and businessman, did not return a telephone call and e-mail seeking comment. Mr. Bienen, president emeritus of Northwestern University, did not return a telephone call and e-mail seeking comment. Sam Greenwood/Getty ImagesMarsha J. Evans, a former director of Lehman Brothers who continues to serve on other corporate boards. Jay Mallin/Bloomberg NewsCharles Rossotti, a former board member of Merrill Lynch who became a director of Bank of America. Many directors of failed financial institutions have kept the other director posts they had before the financial crisis. Marsha J. Evans, a former Lehman director, has not landed any new board seats, but continues to serve as a director of Weight Watchers, Huntsman and Office Depot, positions that earned her about $500,000 in compensation in 2009. Ms. Evans declined to comment. Some directors were named to the boards of the companies that acquired their ailing firms. Bank of America named two longtime Merrill Lynch directors, Charles O. Rossotti and Virgis W. Colbert, to its board after acquiring the ailing investment bank for $29 billion. Mr. Rossotti and Mr. Virgis did not respond to requests for comment. Merrill's former chief executive, E. Stanley O'Neal, resigned from the firm in 2007 after billions of dollars of mortgage-securities losses, but he was soon snapped up as a board member by Alcoa. An Alcoa spokesman declined to comment. Mr. O'Neal did not respond to requests for comment. Some board members, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, say their experience on the boards of troubled companies, made them stronger directors, giving them hands-on experience that will help them stop other companies from repeating the same mistakes. ''Directors of these financial institutions may or may not have been asleep at the switch, and if they were, they had a lot of company,'' said Michael Klausner, a corporate law professor at Stanford. ''Leaving that question aside, they may well have gained valuable experience that will make them good directors today.'' Two months after Wells Fargo acquired Wachovia in a government-forced transaction, a former Wachovia director, Robert A. Ingram, was named to the board of the semiconductor company Cree. Mr. Ingram, the former chairman of OSI Pharmaceuticals, had served as a Wachovia board member since 2001. Cree will pay Mr. Ingram $303,000 in compensation for 2010, a filing shows. A spokeswoman for Cree declined to comment but cited a December 2008 press release on Mr. Ingram's appointment citing his ''wealth of experience.'' In 2008, the Outstanding Directors Exchange, a unit of the media company Pearson, named Stephen E. Frank an ''outstanding director'' for ''the masterful chairmanship of Washington Mutual's audit committee during a period of intense change.'' Mr. Frank, a longtime utility industry executive, had served on the board of Washington Mutual for more than a decade when the savings and loan - buffeted by excessive exposure to subprime loans - was seized by the government in September 2008 and sold off to JPMorgan Chase. Last year, the Las Vegas utility NV Energy elected Mr. Frank to its board and he earned $109,000 in compensation. A spokesman for NV Energy declined to comment. Mr. Frank could not be reached. In a 2008 interview with Agenda, a corporate-governance newsletter, referring to his experience at Washington Mutual, he said that ''to suggest, with 20/20 hindsight, that an audit committee or a finance committee could easily have prevented these things, I think, is naïve.'' Rakesh Khurana, a Harvard Business School professor specializing in corporate-governance issues, says there are legitimate questions surrounding these boards. ''When selecting individuals to oversee an organization, what criteria should we be using other than their previous performance on a corporate board?'' he said. ''If there's no accountability here, then what is the system of accountability?'' Inquiries into the 2008 financial crisis have spent relatively little time looking at the role of corporate boards. The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations held four hearings on the causes of the financial crisis, none of which focused on the role of directors. The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, appointed by Congress, has held myriad hearings and interviews with executives of failed institutions. Although the public sessions have not included testimony from any outside directors, the hearings did touch on corporate governance, and the commission has privately interviewed directors, according to Phil Angelides, the commission's chairman. ''I don't think there's any question that a dramatic failure of corporate governance was a central issue of the crisis,'' Mr. Angelides said. ''You're going to find when our report is released that this will be a major point.'' HOENGSEONG, SOUTH KOREA -- In the relative cool of midnight, Seo Seok-gu's workers break the seals on the kilns and, using long steel hooks, drag out what remains of the oak logs that were inserted a week before and have by now turned into smoldering charcoal. It gives off a hypnotic glow Mr. Seo calls ''my flower.'' The temperatures inside the clay domes reach up to 1,400 degrees Celsius. By dawn, the work is done, and the kilns are allowed to begin cooling down.

BLOCK--Muriel L. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our cherished friend and Benefactor. Mrs. Block, along with her beloved late husband Harold, was a longtime leading supporter of the College of Medicine. In 2003, Mrs. Block made an exemplary leadership gift to Einstein; her visionary gift helped advance biomedical research at the medical school through the construction of the state-of-the-art Harold and Muriel Block Research Pavilion. Mrs. Block previously established the Muriel and Harold Block Faculty Scholar in Mental Illness. A prominent member of our National Women's Division, she served on its national board and New York chapter executive board. In recognition of her vision and generosity, she received an honorary degree from Yeshiva University in 2004. We already miss her elegant and spirited presence and extend our deepest sympathy to our esteemed Honorary Overseer Irving Baumrind, her beloved daughters Audrey Heckler and Joan Vernick, and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman Chairperson Board of Overseers

The number of times one heard the statement "the 90s are back" during New York shows is a reminder of how potent minimalism is in American fashion. It did seem to make a return, in a variety of forms - from the abundance of white fabrics, some of them sheer, to loose and often floor-sweeping dresses and skirts that had little detail. Some of the minimalist designers, like Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein and Narciso Rodriguez just seemed to express themselves with greater precision. Mr. Costa's paneled dresses and coats seemed to hover between firm structure and airy volume.

When he popped in for a visit to the T offices, the native New Yorker identified his idealized customer as an avid boyfriend-jeans kind of girl who is discovering her ladylike sex appeal.
