I recently visited the artist Pae White in her Los Angeles studio, where she was busy working on a new exhibition for the Power Plant in Toronto. The exhibition, which opens on Oct. 9, will feature a number of her recent tapestry works as well as a new commissioned tapestry called "Sea Beast." White has called the show "Material Mutters" because, she explained, "it's about the exploration of process and the material is doing the talking." Smoke has been a recurring motif in her work lately, and she has been exploring ways to capture its elusive qualities in various media, including a series of carved paper works that she was finishing for the Toronto show. Because smoke moves so rapidly and changes form so quickly, White likes the way the image of something so immaterial contrasts with the physicality of fabric. "It's one material trying to understand another and it turns the fabric into something other than itself," she said. At the Whitney Museum's Biennial this spring, her monumental digitally woven tapestry "Still, Untitled" was a showstopper.

The International Energy Agency's primary focus is ensuring energy security for industrialized countries, particularly members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Founded in the 1970's during a period of oil shortages, the agency was meant to be a counterweight to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and serve as a kind of consumers' union of oil-consuming nations.

Some of the most common questions patients ask their doctors focus on the link between diet and health. But as Dr. Pauline Chen explains this week in her Doctor and Patient column, many of the nation's medical schools are failing to provide new doctors with adequate nutrition education. She writes:
Physicians still don’t know enough about food and diet, and some medical schools are seeking to change that.

Lehman Brothers asked a federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday to delay 50 lawsuits it had filed while it tried to reach settlements and focused on other parts of its enormous bankruptcy, Reuters reports.
Hyundai is the latest automaker to express confidence in its ability, going forward even in a down economy, to sell ever-greater numbers of vehicles in the United States.

The job market in New York City continued to recover more strongly than in the rest of the state and the nation through the end of the summer, according to figures released Thursday (pdf) by the State Department of Labor.
Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.
Google Ventures, the search giant's venture capital investing arm, has hired the man behind Google Voice to build a new start-up.

Alimentation Couche-Tard, the Canadian convenience store operator, took its takeover pitch to shareholders of Casey's General Stores on Thursday, ignoring Casey's rejection of its $2.03 billion offer and saying it was willing to raise its bid further, The Associated Press reports.
A rainbow after a thunderstorm in Tuscany.

Speaking of extending sympathy, isn't it time to rethink the whole "Martha Coakley was the worst candidate in all of human history" narrative that took hold - particularly among Democrats looking for a scapegoat, and a reason to push ahead with the health care bill - in the wake of Scott Brown's astonishing Massachusetts victory last winter? Obviously Coakley ran a lousy race, and deserved much of the opprobrium that was heaped upon her head. But with seemingly-unassailable incumbents dropping right and left in Republican primaries, and with once-safe Democratic seats in play from Washington and Wisconsin to Illinois and Connecticut, it seems pretty clear that she deserves to be remembered less for her own missteps and follies, and more as the first casualty of forces beyond any establishment candidate's control.
KABUL, Afghanistan - When I was first thinking about an appropriate and interesting opening subject for my first contribution to this blog, I was in a different place.

Overview | To what extent are arts and entertainment reviews useful? How are they created? In this lesson, students deconstruct short film and television reviews and consider their purpose and value. They then write their own brief reviews, focusing on performances in film, television, dance, theater or music.
It's hard to keep tab of the best food trucks in New York when they pop up faster than chefs ditching their toques or the latest Danny Meyer Shake Shack line. But the Vendy Awards help.

For no good reason the Internet recently got very excited about an audition video made by a young actor hoping to play the Joker in a coming "Batman" movie (despite the tragic history associated with that role and the fact that the filmmakers have no plans to include the character in the next movie).

As the post-Labor Day sprint -- from the start of school to the Jewish New Year to a raucous and at times frustrating day of primary voting -- slows into a comfortable fall news pace, a wide variety of what the French call "fait divers" pepper the margins of serious reporting.
There hasn't been an official sighting of a grizzly bear in the Pasayten Wilderness since 1968. However, wildlife biologists continue to search for the elusive animal.

3:40 p.m. | Updated Airgas lost an important battle in the takeover war on Wednesday as its hostile suitor, Air Products and Chemicals, elected three directors to its board at the company's annual meeting. In addition, Air Products' proposal to amend the Airgas bylaws to move the company's next annual meeting date to Jan. 18 was supported by most of the shareholder votes.

Boeing said on Wednesday that it is entering the space tourism business, Kenneth Chang of the Science Section of The New York Times reports. The flights, most likely from Cape Canaveral in Florida to the International Space Station, could start as early as 2015. They would be the first "to give nonprofessional astronauts the chance to go into orbit aboard a spacecraft launched from the United States," Mr. Chang reports. Seats on the flights would be marketed by Space Adventures, a tourism company that arranged for a tourist to fly with Soyuz. The company has not yet set a price.

The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Joan Smalls from IMG Model Management before (right) and after (left) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Garren. (Drag the orange bar right to reveal the full transformation.)
In 2007, Justin Kan, a San Francisco developer, decided he would start documenting every moment of his life and stream it to a Web site for anyone to watch.
It's not over until, well, it's not over.

Every two years since 2000, Mark David Chapman has sat down with members of the New York State Division of Parole and rehashed details of his Dec. 8, 1980, murder of John Lennon outside the Dakota. His sixth and latest hearing, on Sept. 7, was no exception, going step by step through his muddled planning as if being interrogated for the first time, according to a transcript released Thursday.
The opposite of re-birth.

Mr. Dingledine, an independent college counselor in Greenville, S.C., is responding to selected questions from readers of The Choice. His answers will continue throughout the week. We are no longer accepting questions. But you may post a comment using the comment box below, or on the original post. Some questions, and answers, have been edited for space and style. --Jacques Steinberg

On Thursday Diaspora, a social Web site that hopes to offer an alternative to Facebook, announced that its developers would be allowed to download the code used to build the new service and begin exploring and enhancing the Diaspora software.
Do regular civilians cook like chefs? Can we? Should we even try?

Carl P. Paladino, the Republican candidate for governor, has seemed to relish taking a scorched earth approach to his campaign. No one seems to be immune from his wrath, even members of his own party.
Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

The invitation to Isaac Mizrahi's show looked kind of cheap, as if it had been dashed off on a copy machine to save some cash. But it turned out to be part of the show, which the designer called "IM Xerox."
Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado was in a K Street conference room Thursday morning, the guest speaker at an insider's breakfast with two dozen Washington reporters and columnists.

An undercover investigation disclosed by the city on Thursday showed that vendors on a Long Island Indian reservation sold large quantities of cigarettes without paying city or state taxes, city officials said.
How will Boise State be affected by Virginia Tech's loss? And how much longer can Michigan's Denard Robinson carry the Wolverines?

Despite a steady rise in unemployment throughout 2009, America's poverty rate didn't rise as much as some analysts had feared. Still, at 14.3 percent, up from 13.2 percent in 2008, it represented 43.6 million people, the highest number of people in poverty since the Census Bureau began publishing estimates in 1959.
President Obama's chief spokesman, Robert Gibbs, sent a Twitter message this afternoon officially denying that Michelle Obama ever said she felt like she was in "hell."

Jacques Steinberg reports that MTV and the College Board are scheduled to announce that they are joining to stage a contest, the "Get Schooled College Affordability Challenge.'' In it, "current and aspiring college students'' are being asked to create "an innovative digital tool that helps more low- and middle-income students connect with money for school.''

Brian McNoldy, a meteorologist tracking Atlantic Ocean hurricanes at Colorado State University, just distributed this note from Phil Klotzbach, a colleague, about the unusual storminess in the Atlantic and Caribbean at the moment:

Fashion writers dream of the day when they get an exclusive sneak peek at a visionary designer's next collection. I'd rather be the first girl on the block to sample an iconic baker's latest creation. That is exactly what happened to me when I dropped by the New Museum for a preview of its latest attraction: a spruced-up cafe. As befits its offbeat location and forward-looking spirit, the New Museum teamed up with Maury Rubin of the City Bakery and its counterpart, Birdbath, Green Neighborhood Bakery - both of which are, he says, "a product of the creative mind-set of downtown New York." As a result, he adds, "New Museum feels like perfect, symbiotic territory."

I am traveling to São Paulo, Brazil, to work for a week (Nov. 22 to 26). My boyfriend and 15-year-old daughter are considering joining me for a long weekend. We would like to see a few of the sights outside São Paulo and have thought about Rio de Janeiro. We are open to air travel within the country, but prefer closer jaunts if possible. Any ideas would be much appreciated.
Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, heads uptown to Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem to get a taste of the up-and-coming drink spots in the neighborhood.
Today, President Obama's role in the "don't ask, don't tell" debate, a look at the media spotlight on Craigslist, and fashion reporter Eric Wilson reflects on the best from New York fashion week.
OnStar is officially joining the "there's an app for that" generation.
A new Broadway theater took its first bow on Wednesday night: the Stephen Sondheim, on 43rd Street.

Warner Brothers Entertainment has donated $5 million to the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History to convert the museum's auditorium into a film theater, The Washington Post reported. In the new theater, which is expected to be completed next year and will be named the Warner Brothers Theater, the museum will offer programming related to American film history. As part of the gift, the museum will have access to the film archives of Warner Brothers and the MGM film library, but it will not be restricted from showing material from other studios. The museum prominently displays many props and other materials from film and television history, including the ruby slippers from "The Wizard of Oz," a Warner Brothers property.

As my colleague Rachel Donadio reports, at the start of a four-day visit to Britain on Thursday, Pope Benedict XVI told reporters that the Roman Catholic Church's response to the sexual abuse of children by priests had not been "sufficiently vigilant" or "sufficiently swift and decisive." In remarks captured on video, he added, "It is difficult to understand how this perversion of the priestly ministry is possible."
A pack of idealistic bicyclists wove through the streets of Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens on Wednesday afternoon, honking their horns and shouting, "Paper girl!"
A new television advertisement that singles out McDonald's for obesity-related deaths is causing quite the stir.

The Mets announced Thursday that Jenrry Mejia would not pitch the rest of the season because of a rhomboid strain of the right shoulder blade. In a statement, the Mets said that Mejia, 20, had a magnetic resonance imaging test, which revealed the injury, and that he would not throw again until he made a full recovery. They gave no time frame.
Welcome to the transforming Arctic.

Howdy, pardners! Why, it's the eighth and final day of New York Fashion Week and Ralph Lauren got things off to a rip roarin' start with his Wild West-themed collection. It was all about the fringe - miles and miles of fringe as far as the eye could see - fringe on suede jackets, fringe on patterned cloth bags, fringe on deerskin vests, fringe on a frilly scarf and platinum-beaded fringe for evening.
Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Bryan Bedder for Getty Images.

Apple announced on Wednesday that it would give developers who create applications for the iOS platform access to a beta version of a new app, AirPrint, which will enable wireless printing on the iPad, iPhone and iPod touch.

My story in today's special section on retirement, "Looking Ahead to the Spend-Down Years," details some creative new thinking from behavioral finance experts trying to help people turn their retirement savings into retirement income.

TORONTO - Harvey Weinstein, the independent film mogul, has a movie here, but it is not one of his namesake company's entries in the still-underway Toronto International Film Festival. On Wednesday, IFC Entertainment said it had acquired rights to "Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project," a documentary biography of Mr. Weinstein from the Toronto filmmaker Barry Avrich.

My article in Thursday's Times looks at Europe's attempt to reduce its dependence on coal by ending state subsidies for coal plants and mines. Using coal for power generation results in high levels of local pollution as well as the greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change.

General Motors expects the United States government to be a major shareholder for "the next couple of years" even after it sells some of its shares in an initial public offering, the company's new chief executive told reporters on Thursday.

This morning's Census report showed that median income last year was on the high side of the expected range -- down 0.7 percent in 2009, to $49,777, from $50,112 in 2008. After adjusting for inflation, the 2009 level is the lowest since 1997.

The Census Bureau released on Thursday the latest figures on how many Americans were without health insurance in 2009: 50.7 million people, an increase of almost 10 percent from the 46.3 million people without coverage in 2008.

David Pogue follows up on his review of Vulkano, which purports to be both a TiVo (records TV shows effortlessly) and a Slingbox (lets you watch your shows over the Internet, on an iPhone, iPad, iPod Touch, BlackBerry, Android phone, Mac or PC), on Pogue's Posts.

Here's the plan, in one longish, timorous breath: the plan is to open the restaurant, and while nothing is written in stone or on stone crabs or any place else other than in our collective consciousness and on the blackboard above the bar, the plan is to open the restaurant called Southfork Kitchen on Sunday, Sept. 26, 2010 -- please do not read any religious meaning into opening on a Sabbath -- fully realizing that brand new restaurants are functioning, zoetic organisms, like stone crabs, forced to respond to a sea of shifting imperatives, which is why the plan is subject to change, and change, in this instance, means the date may be moved, this way or that, slightly.
It appears that Oprah Winfrey and Jonathan Franzen have kissed and made up.

Michael Jackson's mother has filed a lawsuit against the promoter of his planned concerts last year, saying that the company, AEG Live, failed to supply medical equipment and properly monitor Jackson's personal doctor, Reuters reported.

Backstage at Proenza Schouler, the makeup artist Diane Kendal and the hairstylist Paul Hanlon repeated the same directive from designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez: The Proenza girl has grown up - but not entirely. "The boys wanted to move on from the last season, where the hair was kind of bed head," said Hanlon, who used Frederic Fekkai Coiff Oceanique Touseled Wave Spray to create an unfinished French twist with what can only be described as a rattail hanging out the back. "I thought about when I was a kid on the school bus and a girl would fall asleep against a condensated window, and she'd get off with her hair all mish-moshed up." The look paired perfectly with the minimal makeup by Kendal, which was simply cheek contour (M.A.C. Pro Sculpt Powders) and a strong, square brow. "We're not even using any concealer, because we like natural discoloration around the eye," she said. "The clothes this season are much more ladylike, so they wanted to keep their signature girl - very model-looking and tough." With a cast including heavyweights Abby Lee, Karolina Kurkova, Liu Wen and Isabeli Fontani, that wasn't very difficult.

The knife-wielding man struck first on Aug. 7, robbing a woman as she walked off an A train at the 125th Street station in Harlem, the police said. He robbed a second woman on Aug. 27 after waving a knife at her on another A train in Inwood, they said.

On MTV's 27th annual Video Music Awards this week, Lady Gaga wore a meat dress, Chelsea Handler didn't make everyone laugh, and Taylor Swift and Kanye West finally confronted each other, sort of, about the unpleasant events at last year's show. The drama drew plenty of eyeballs: the show had its best ratings in eight years.

Out here in television land, a lot of us have memories of Edwin Newman, the longtime NBC News correspondent whose death was announced this week. We remember the big stories he had a hand in covering. The presidential debates he moderated. The grammar lessons he probably thought we all needed. The cameo appearance in the film "The Pelican Brief."

MTV, the network that brought you Snooki, the Situation and a platform for Lady Gaga to wear a dress made from raw meat, is teaming up with the College Board to create a contest in which current and aspiring college students are encouraged to create "an innovative digital tool that helps more and low- and middle-income students connect with money for school.'' John Legend is to officially announce the contest on Thursday; Jacques Steinberg has more at the Choice blog.

In my New York Times column Thursday, I reviewed a box called Vulkano, which purports to be both a TiVo (records TV shows effortlessly) and a Slingbox (lets you watch your shows over the Internet-on an iPhone, iPad, iPod Touch, BlackBerry, Android phone, Mac or PC).
From our colleagues at Green:

Reversing an earlier pledge to not lay off state workers before Jan. 1, Gov. David A. Paterson said on Thursday that he would dismiss government employees before the end of this year to close a persistent budget gap.
The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

Following "West Side Story" at the Palace Theater will be the new musical "Priscilla Queen of the Desert," based on the 1994 movie about three Australian drag queens traveling by bus across the outback.
Toyota plans to offer six new gas-electric hybrid vehicles worldwide by the end of 2012, plus a plug-in Prius in the United States.
"Let the punishment fit the crime," Gilbert and Sullivan wrote.

There's no doubt that the New York City Police Department's tactic of stopping and frisking people on the street can create tensions with those stopped, and within the neighborhoods where many of the encounters occur. Yet the department is loath to give up the tactic, calling it a core law enforcement tool.

Updated | 5:18 p.m. An Egyptian blogger has shown that an influential state-run newspaper published an apparently altered photograph of Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, this week, showing him at the front, rather than the back, of a group of leaders who met last week at the White House to talk about peace in the Middle East.
Set your digital video recorders: Bill O'Reilly and Jon Stewart are returning to each other's television shows.
As Ben Shpigel reported in Thursday's Times, Derek Jeter admitted he was acting Wednesday night when he pretended to be hit by a pitch in the Tampa Bay Rays' 4-3 victory over the Yankees.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

As the stern proctor of the hardly hip SAT exam, the College Board would seem an odd recipient of prominent attention on MTV. It is difficult to imagine a scantily clad, lip-synching Katy Perry - to say nothing of Snooki or the Situation - rolling on a beach with a No. 2 pencil and a bubble sheet.

On this week's Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Nick Bilton, the lead writer for the Bits blog, about his just-published book, "I Live in the Future and Here's How It Works." Mr. Bilton, formerly a researcher in the research and development labs of The New York Times, sees digital streams of information becoming increasingly personalized. People want not only content, he says, but also an online experience -- and they're willing to pay if the price is right.
From Dave Weigel's requiem for Mike Castle:

I'm not one to follow the fashion follies of Lady Gaga, but the meaty getup the singer wore to the MTV Video Music Awards the other night made me think of another artist who has been working in carnivorous creations for quite some time.
A hatch at an orphanage in Kuala Lumpur where people can anonymously abandon babies.

After you build an electric car, the next step is to sell it. So Kevin Czinger, the president and chief executive of Coda Automotive, trucked his from California to Washington this week to try it out on the General Services Administration, the purchasing arm of the federal government.

In our weekly "Poetry Pairing" series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem's themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

Dashiell Hammett could have written this tale: a missing painting turns up on the street - or did it? - and a complicated case gets even weirder. The painting, Corot's "Portrait of a Girl," was reported lost, prompting all manner of accusations. But the doorman who found it in Manhattan said he had no idea what it was. William K. Rashbaum of The Times tries to unravel the mystery, but the story ends up prompting even more head-scratching questions. Did you ever watch "The Maltese Falcon" and at the end say, huh? Well, it's kind of like that.

Despite several witty suggestions from readers about potential promotions to attract fans to this week's Mets-Pirates series, no one offered the one that came to pass on Wednesday: Come See Jenrry Mejia Hurt His Shoulder Night.

In addition to his signature line, Jason Wu has created a capsule collection for Tse, the knitwear company. He introduced the collaboration last fall with terrific sweaters, but for spring, he wanted to go in a different direction since it's basically the off-season for a sweater company and no one wants to look at heavy knits.
Nocturnalist goes to Fashion Week.
From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

We don't remember things working out so well when they tried to fit King Kong onto a New York stage in that classic 1933 film - something about bad opening-night reviews, a scramble up the Empire State Building and one massive cleanup job in Midtown Manhattan.

Economy on the Hill: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will tell House and Senate lawmakers today that China has kept the value of its currency, the renminbi, artificially low to help its exports and has largely failed to improve the situation, as it promised to do in June. The Times's Sewell Chan has the details.

David J. Ekerdt, who directs the gerontology center at the University of Kansas, has a knack for digging into aspects of aging that most of us register only in passing. I've been a fan since I read his work on the "busy ethic," a phrase he coined to describe our attitudes towards retirement.

When a brand ''goes global,'' that usually means the forces behind it will be racking up frequent-flier miles. Carolina Herrera Báez, the daughter of the designer Carolina Herrera, is doing exactly that as the creative adviser for CH Carolina Herrera, a casual lifestyle brand that is rolling out 18 boutiques this year. The first New York City boutique, which sells everything from silk dresses to cashmere travel blankets, opened earlier this month.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to take on banks' practice of temporarily lowering their debt levels at quarter end to look financially healthier than they may really be, a trick known as "window dressing," The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.
"I'm deeply embarrassed," Stephen Sondheim said Wednesday evening at a ceremony to officially light the marquee of the Broadway theater renamed in his honor. "Thrilled, but deeply embarrassed."

As anyone living in the Midwest can tell you, gasoline prices have been mighty high in recent days. Since a pipeline operated by the Canadian company Enbridge ruptured last week outside of Chicago, the second such incident concerning an Enbridge pipeline in the Midwest this summer, prices at the pump have spurted up as much as 30 cents a gallon around much of the region.

The strategists at the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which doles out money to candidates every election year, face difficult choices in the next seven weeks as they push to gain 10 seats and take over the Senate.

Vanessa Bley took to the stage at the Mercury Lounge on Aug. 28, in support of Josh Fox and his film "Gasland," which brings to the public eye the debate on natural-gas fracking in the United States. Bley, who is the daughter of the renowned jazz pianist Paul Bley, delivered a raucous set of danceable tracks, bringing an energy, technical prowess and a wildness rarely seen from young female artists today.

Recently Palm announced the release of its new Palm WebOS 2.0 software development kit - I know, be still my beating heart - but it matters, because it gives developers new tools that let their apps do some very cool things.
Thomas R. Nides, Morgan Stanley's chief operating officer and one of the firm's top executives, is in talks to join the State Department in a senior role, according to news reports.
--Howard Marks in his latest Oaktree memo: "No one should view the great popularity of bonds relative to stocks without reservation." (Hat tip to @Morgan_03)

Are food obsessives and gastronuts taking the fun out of restaurants? That was the question raised and answered by an interesting letter Diner's Journal received from a fellow named Brian, responding to our recent article about changes in the service and menu at Eleven Madison Park. I figured I'd pitch the conversation over to you, the reader.

The financial crisis dominated the short list of six books nominated for the 2010 Business Book of the Year Award, sponsored by The Financial Times and Goldman Sachs, announced on Thursday, Reuters said.
Alibaba may want to buy back Yahoo's stake in the Chinese Web company, but it seems the American tech giant has no intention of granting that wish.
The designer and Project Runway winner takes tea with Horacio Silva.

A great inside look at the battle between the Patriots and the Packers to land Randy Moss in 2007. Andrew Brandt of The National Football Post worked for the Packers at the time. Here are a few snippets, then read the whole thing.
Q.

Accor, Europe's largest hotelier, aims to raise as much as 343 million euros ($449 million) by selling its stake in Groupe Lucien Barriere, in an initial public offering that may be France's biggest this year.

After the wave of entry-level D.S.L.R. cameras of the past two years, many of us are itching to move up to something a bit more capable - and the coming Nikon D7000 looks like a very solid midrange choice.
Mapletree Industrial Trust's coming initial public offering is expected to raise about 800 million Singapore dollars ($598 million), Reuters said, citing sources briefed on the deal.

My most recent ShortCuts column discussing how often you need to change the oil in your car -- and stating that the need to change your oil every 3,000 miles is largely a myth -- elicited a great deal of reader response. I was surprised that so many people felt so strongly about the issue. Some readers were grateful for the information; others told me that I was full of baloney and that they were going to stick to the 3,000-mile changes no matter what.

Robert E. Grady, a former partner in the Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, is set to become chairman of the panel that guides investment policy for New Jersey's $68 billion pension fund, Bloomberg New reported, citing two people with knowledge of the plan.
Ramius has begun a hostile bid to buy Cypress Bioscience for $4.25 per share, an increase from the hedge fund's recent offer for the biotechnology company.
Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.
Joe Namath is offering analysis about the Jets at his Web site, on YouTube, on radio, on Twitter -- seemingly anywhere he can.

Goldman Sachs proprietary traders who created a hedge fund within the firm in 2007 have generated a return of about 3 percent this year, beating the industry average, Bloomberg News reported, citing people briefed on the gain.
The "Going to Ground" rule for catches in the N.F.L. can get a little complex.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's lenders have agreed to give the troubled studio its seventh extension to repay its nearly $4 billion of debt.
EMusic, the subscription digital music service, is close to wrapping up deals with the last two major labels in time for a planned relaunch in November, its chief executive told Reuters.

The transcript from Jets Coach Rex Ryan's talk with reporters on Wednesday. As he did last year, he urged fans to make a "great effort" against the Patriots, the kind of effort that quarterback Tom Brady found lacking in Patriots fans in New England's opener. Brady said, "I don't think the Jets fans leave early."

Wright Express, a payment processor for commercial and government trucking fleets, said Wednesday that it has completed its $318 million deal to buy the Australian fleet and prepaid card businesses of Retail Decisions, The Associated Press reported.

There is little aggregate change in the FiveThirtyEight gubernatorial forecast since the previous model run on Sept. 3. On average, over the course of 100,000 simulations, Republicans were projected to control 30.2 governorships after the Nov. 2 elections, up incrementally from 30.1 two weeks ago. Democrats were projected to control the governorships in an average of 19.5 states.

Alliance Medical, a British medical services business owned by a top Dubai private equity firm, has secured a two-month extension to restructuring talks as it continues to seek a buyer, Reuters reported, citing people close to the discussions.
Wilbur Ross, the billionaire investor, had boarded a consortium led by Dublin-based Cardinal Asset Management to bid for EBS, the Irish building society, Mr. Ross told CNBC on Wednesday.

A record number of homeowners lost houses to their banks in August as lenders worked through the backlog of distressed mortgages, the real estate data company, RealtyTrac, reported on Thursday, Reuters said.

A handful of buyout firms are submitting indicative bids for mental-health specialist the Priory Group, which seller Royal Bank of Scotland hopes could fetch about 1 billion pounds ($1.55 billion), people familiar with the matter told Reuters.
Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is an author of "13 Bankers."

Loan demand will remain sluggish and the economic recovery will proceed slowly, executives at U.S. Bancorp told investors on Wednesday, dampening hopes for a dividend increase in the near future, Reuters reported.
The upcoming 2012 London Olympic and Paralympic Games are less than two years away, but right now is a great time to see the the actual park area in all of its dusty, transitional, dug-up glory.

Sanofi-Aventis sees a reasonable chance of buying American biotech Genzyme at a fair price, but expects it will take some time to agree a deal that would further diversify the French drug maker and strengthen its United States foothold, Reuters reported.

Anshan Iron and Steel is moving ahead with its plans to take a stake in Steel Development, despite concerns by some United States lawmakers about the Chinese investment in the American steel industry, The Financial Times reported.

Test your reading comprehension with today's question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article "Looking This Way and That, and Learning to Adapt to the World."
Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan is trying to stitch together a consortium led by China to back a management buyout to trump BHP Billiton's $38.6 billion hostile offer, The Globe and Mail reported.

Actividades de Construccion y Servicios, the Spanish building company, is set to make an all-share takeover bid for its German counterpart Hochtief, in which it already owns a 30 percent stake, according to a statement on the Web site of the Madrid stock exchange, which suspended ACS's shares on Thursday.

There have been many articles in The Times recently about so-called factory farming and the controversial animal confinement and safety monitoring methods the farms employ. Major livestock producers argue that a direct link between these farms and human illnesses, like salmonella and E. coli, has not been proved, but many medical and health experts disagree. How much are you aware of news about food safety, like this summer's egg recall? How important is this issue to you in general? Do you care about where your food comes from and the conditions under which it was produced? Why or why not?

The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking to expand its powers to demand more financial disclosure from cities, states and municipal-debt issuers, a commissioner with the S.E.C., Elisse Walter told The Wall Street Journal in an interview.
Arbitrage: it's what makes markets efficient and proves they aren't.

Today's idea: Never mind the lone genius: new research suggests that because the "self" is a social animal, achievement flowers in collaborations -- from Emily Dickinson and her sister-in-law, to John Lennon and Paul McCartney.

Santander UK could be looking to do a £20 billion ($31 billion) I.P.O. on the London market in the near future, observers suggested, as the bank seeks new cash after a number of acquisitions in recent weeks, The Telegraph reported.

Teams from Virginia, North Carolina and Winterthur, Switzerland, with roots in the world of auto racing have won the first Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize, the $10 million competition aimed at advancing the technology for more fuel-efficient vehicles, The New York Times's Ronald Ahrens reported.

Europe's highest human rights court said Wednesday that it would accept a complaint by the international financier George Soros that his rights were impinged on by French courts in convicting him in an insider-trading case dating back more than two decades.
The Justice Department dropped fraud charges against a former Merrill Lynch banker five days before a scheduled retrial over his alleged role in an Enron Corporation scheme.
Stocks overcame an early slide Wednesday and closed higher as investors kept a September rally alive.

The designer and Project Runway winner takes tea with Horacio Silva. Among the topics discussed: Siriano's "Fierce Mamas" maternity collection, "trannygate," and his willingness to go very high and very low (as in shoes for Payless) with his designs. "I love that I have a $10,000 dress and a $40 shoe," says the 24-year-old.

FREEDMAN--Henry. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Dr. Henry Freedman and extend our sincerest condolences to his family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

MEYER--Richard E. Calvary Hospital mourns with great sadness the passing of our longtime friend and valued Board member, Richard Meyer. He advanced Calvary's mission through his distinguished service as Chairman of the Calvary Fund Board of Directors, and Vice Chairman of the Calvary Hospital Board of Directors. He will forever be remembered for his outstanding business and professional accomplishments, his many and wide-ranging philanthropic interests, and his deep and abiding faith. His visionary leadership of the Calvary Fund helped sustain our ability to provide the finest compassionate care to those most in need. In gratitude for his years of service and his dedication to our patients and families, he was awarded the Hospital's highest recognition, the Calvary Medal, in 2007. The beautiful Meyer Tree of Life at our Bronx campus remains a constant reminder of his quiet strength and grace. Dick spoke softly and counseled wisely, and we will miss him. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Frank A. Calamari, President & CEO, Calvary Hospital Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director, Calvary Hospital Vincent J. Spinelli, Executive Vice President, Calvary Fund

As City Room live-blogged the 9/11 ceremony held near ground zero for victims' relatives, the reader comments that poured in were, for the most part, moving and mournful, and tinged with hope. They were long on memories and condolences, and short on politics. Many were shiver-inducing in their poetry and gentle empathy. That was Sept. 11 of last year.

''In fashion, we don't often know the prices,'' said Olivier Theyskens, the designer who has taken a fashion sabbatical since leaving Nina Ricci in Paris last March. ''We don't have time to go into the stores.'' The price of luxury fashion has been out of line with reality for some time, and only since the recession have designers bothered to address that fact. Mr. Theyskens, while re-evaluating his place in this world, decided to try something different and designed a collection for Theory, the captain of contemporary fashion, for spring. The prices are a bit higher than those of Theory, but much less than Mr. Theyskens's work for Ricci, and for Rochas before that. Mr. Theyskens said he had moved to New York to develop the collection after meeting Andrew Rosen, the chief executive of Theory. ''Andrew is very quick reacting,'' he said. The clothes, under the label Theyskens' Theory, are remarkable because they reflect Mr. Theyskens's signature drainpipe style, but also look like Theory's urban wardrobe. Mr. Rosen said he was surprised when Mr. Theyskens made suit separates using stretch wool, the fabric of first-time-jobs that has been a Theory hallmark for years. Of course, his look much different. The jackets, for example, are cut with a deep notch in the back of the neck, so you can pull them down over the shoulders for a slouchy look, Mr. Theyskens said, ''or if you have long hair like me, you can tuck it in the back.'' The first outfit he showed was a narrow-sleeved leather jacket with a white cotton lining, over trim white jeans that had loose-fitting pockets and rolled cuffs that were sewn to stay rolled. They'll cost about $240. The jacket is under $1,000. Several of his floaty dresses, made of double layers of Japanese crinkle polyester, cost $690. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ENGELSTEIN--Stanley, 90, died September 15, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Phima, father of Laura, Daniel and Larry, father-in-law of Karen Levinson and Celia Radek, grandfather of Max, Sophie, Henry and Lena, dear friend of Sarah White. Poland born and Brooklyn bred, graduate of CCNY (1939) and Columbia Law School (1975); he and family members developed a successful innovative microfiche business. As an attorney, he worked on discrimination cases, defended American Indian activists, taught a clinic on Union Democracy at NYU Law School, participated in Human Rights Watch missions, and was involved with other social causes. An auto-didact extraordinaire, an amateur musician, a one and four wall handball enthusiast, he will not be forgotten. Services will be held Thursday, September 16 at 3pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 15 W. 16th Street, New York, NY 10011.

An article on Monday about conciliatory gestures between North Korea and South Korea referred incorrectly to Kaesong, the North Korean location near the border where officials from both sides plan to meet to discuss arranging family reunions. It is a large industrial town where South Korean manufacturers employ thousands of North Korean workers in joint ventures. It is not a ''village.''

SCHONFELD--Sidney, 87, passed away quietly on September 15. He was the beloved husband of Hildegard, proud and loving father of Gary and Elisabeth, Victoria and Victor, beloved grandfather of Jared, Remi, Zachary, Matthew and Sam. Sidney was devoted to Hildegard, who pre-deceased him by 10 years. He missed her every day. He came to America from Nazi Germany at the age of 12 and with determination and hard work built a fulfilling career and life. He never forgot the importance of family and charity and the miracle of Israel. He proudly supported local Jewish charities in every way possible and was very proud of his "good name" in the community. Sid was a kind gentle man who greeted everyone with a warm smile and kind word. He was beloved by so many people whose lives he touched, and will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Sidney Schonfeld Fund c/o Temple Emanu-El, 180 Piermont Road, Closter, NJ 07624 or to the Schonfeld College Scholarship Fund at the JCC on the Palisades, 411 E. Clinton Avenue, Tenafly, NJ 07670 or The Job Search Network at Jewish Family Services, 1485 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, NJ 07666. The funeral will be held on Friday at 10am at Temple Emanu-El, 180 Piermont Road, Closter, NJ.

Wayne Lee took her spring collection in a markedly different - and exciting - new direction that looked like the work of a designer who is finding her voice. Her label, Wayne, seems to have all the answers for what girls want, like her streamlined camouflage cargo pants for fall. But for spring, Ms. Lee is not only listening to her customers, but she is also listening to herself. The collection was mostly made up of layers upon layers of thin tanks, translucent button-down shirts, skimmy dresses and rompers that were folded over at the waist. Those pieces were like the petals of a flower coming together ''with a futuristic and gothic twist,'' Ms. Lee said. The colors were primarily a grainy tan and black, a combination that worked to great effect in a tan blouse with cargo pockets on the chest worn with a black leather corset and leather shorts. The flowers Ms. Lee had in mind were nothing like the garden variety shown by Carolina Herrera earlier in the day, but something more sinister - carnivorous plants.

A headline on July 22 with an article about a family that inherited a 43-room house in the Hudson Valley overstated the problem that the house presented to its heirs. As the article correctly noted, maintaining a house of that size and age is a struggle; it is not the case that the family lacks ''money to maintain any of it.'' (A family member who does not live full time in the house pointed out that a fund exists for ongoing restoration, but other family members say that fund does not pay for all the operating expenses.) Also, an accompanying picture caption misidentified one of the furnishings shown in the historic home. It is a painted panel, not a fire screen.

An article on Tuesday about hybridization among species reversed the number of teeth characteristic of a bottlenose dolphin and a false killer whale, whose offspring, called a wholphin, has 66 teeth. The bottlenose has 88 teeth and the false killer whale has 44.

On Friday, Apple announced that it would change the terms of the company's free-case giveaway for the iPhone 4. The following was added to one of the iPhone pages on Apple's Web site:We now know that the iPhone 4 antenna attenuation issue is even smaller than we originally thought. A small percentage of iPhone 4 users need a case, and we want to continue providing them a Bumper case for free. For everyone else, we are discontinuing the free case program on all iPhone 4s sold after September 30, 2010. We are also returning to our normal returns policy for all iPhone 4s sold after September 30. Users experiencing antenna issues should call AppleCare to request a free Bumper case.The quick take on this might be ''Apple to Discontinue iPhone 4 Case Program,'' but that is not quite what is happening here. The more accurate summation is ''Apple to Make You Jump Through a New Hoop to Get an iPhone 4 Case.'' Note the careful language in sentences two and three. Apple is not saying you can't have a free iPhone case anymore - it is saying that the company won't be distributing them as a matter of course. Furthermore, the iPhone app that people have been using to order their free case will no longer be available after Sept. 30. If you buy an iPhone after that date and feel that you're losing your signal, you can still call AppleCare and explain your situation. Those who are having signal dropouts can still get a free case from the company.

Panasonic has fused a professional camcorder with consumer Micro Four Thirds (MFT) lens technology, creating the first Micro Four Thirds interchangeable lens camcorder. The AG-AF100, which has a pro-level price tag of an estimated $6,000 (body only), is designed to easily deliver the look and feel of 35mm film, according to Panasonic. Its Micro Four Thirds lens mount will give videographers a new level of versatility by allowing them to attach comparatively low-cost MFT lenses that have been developed for digital still cameras. Panasonic is one of the two founders of the Micro Four Thirds format and has a pretty broad range of MFT lenses available. As with still cameras, an optional lens adapter will enable videographers to mount other types of lenses on the AG-AF100.

COTZIAS--Betty Ginos, 86, died on Monday, September 13, 2010 at Sunrise Assisted Living in Richmond, VA. Mrs. Cotzias was born in Springfield, Ill., but moved with her family back to their native country of Greece when she was five. Mrs. Cotzias grew up in Greece, where she worked for the Greek Underground Resistance during World War II and was imprisoned for a short time. She escaped from the Nazi prison during a lapse in security on Hitler's birthday, and shortly after returned to the United States. In 1952, she married George Constantin Cotzias and moved to Bellport, Long Island, NY. During the 1950s, Mrs. Cotzias worked for the Greek Consulate, where she had diplomatic status. She is survived by her son, Constantin; two granddaughters, Nikita and Zoe; and a brother, James Ginos. The family will receive friends 3-5pm. Friday, September 17, at the Central Chapel of Bennett Funeral Home, 3215 Cutshaw Avenue, Richmond, VA. Interment private.

COLBY--Vineta, 88, died August 24, 2010. Preceded in death by husband and soul mate of 57 years, Robert Colby. Vineta earned a Ph.D. from Yale in 1946 and was a Professor of English Literature at Queens College, NY for most of her career. Vineta's passion was the 19th Century English novel and women novelists, and authored numerous books and articles on these topics. She will be deeply missed by sister-in-law Carol Colby, Chicago, nieces Marilyn Rivkin and Susan Colby, Minneapolis, great-nieces and nephews, and long-time colleagues and friends.

Dell has become the first, but it will not be the last, to bid adieu to Microsoft's workhorse operating system, XP. On Oct. 22, Microsoft has mandated (with some exceptions) that PC makers stop offering ''factory downgrades'' in their current computer ranges, which means that Windows 7 will be the OS of choice.

ARNOLD--Leon. The Mount Sinai School of Medicine's Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery acknowledges the passing of Dr. Leon Arnold, a long-time friend and pioneer of the Department. HUDSON--William Hoffman, a resident of Dallas, Texas died in Dallas on Sunday, September 5th, 2010, age 80 of complications of prostate cancer. His passions were quail hunting and his love for the game of polo. Mr. Hudson was born in Oklahoma City on October 24, 1929 into a family with deep American roots. The family of his paternal grandmother founded Hartford Colony. His maternal grandmother's family, the Elder John Strong, arrived in America in 1630 on the "Mary and John." His grandfather was Major General Roy Hoffman, an aide to General Pershing in the First World War. General Hoffman received the Legion of Honor from Marshall Foch, the highest honor given to a soldier who is not in the French army. His father, Hubert R. Hudson, had owned the Oklahoma Ada & Atoka Railroad; a friend of Mr. Hudson's, Steven Bechtel saved the railroad from bankruptcy when his construction company rebuilt the two major railroad bridges that had been wiped out by the ravages from flooding. Subsequently, Mr. Hudson sold the railroad prior to the crash of 1929 to the Ingersoll brothers of Philadelphia. William Hudson attended Culver Military Academy in Indiana and Williams College, Massachusetts. His freshman year, he arrived at college with four feisty and agile polo ponies, which necessitated finding like-minded students who also wanted to have a polo team. Mr. Hudson's ponies were not his; he had played polo at the Broadmoor in Colorado Springs, Colorado, where his family had summered for two years. There he was taught to play polo by Lawrence Phipps, of Littleton, Colorado, who gave him four of his ponies to have for his years at Williams. Upon graduating from Williams (where he only started studying in his fourth year when he discovered "with surprise, how much his professors had to teach him"), Mr. Hudson decided to enlist in the army because of the Korean War. He was sent to the camp at De Ridder, Louisiana along with thousands of soldiers in preparation for going to Korea. Because he ranked first in the camps evaluation test, he was sent to OCS (Officers Candidate School). After returning from Korea with the rank of Captain, he resumed his interest in polo, spending the next ten years playing polo in America and Europe; in Italy, with Harry Cushing who was captain of the American team and then onto Madrid, Spain where he became close friends with Perico Domecq, and in Deauville, France with Baron Elie de Rothschild, whose team featured the three famous Gracida brothers from Mexico. As each spring turned to summer, Mr. Hudson would move on to England, where the captain of the American team, George Sherman, and his friend Allan Corey, a ten goal player from Westbury, LI invited him to join their team. In England the matches were with Prince Philip, who was captain of the British team. On his return to the United States, in Dallas Mr. Hudson founded the Lone Oak Polo Club, which hosted the first high goal polo tournaments in Dallas where Mr. Hudson was a driving force in Dallas polo; he knew only one speed, and that was faster. Bill Hudson was a veteran of the oil and gas business for over 50 years. He began his career at Tri-State Natural Gas Company, eventually becoming president, where he developed a significant portion of the San Juan field in New Mexico. His wildcatting spirit led to the discovery of the Rocanville field in Saskatchewan. He was also chairman of the American Stock Exchange - listed GNC Energy Corporation and president of TJ Service Company, a contract drilling company with a fleet of 27 rigs. He was Director of the Colorado Rocky Mountain School, Director and President of the Dallas Opera, and member of the Brook Hollow Golf Club, the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, and Doubles. An enthusiastic and avid tennis player where he excelled. Despite his difficult last year, Mr. Hudson exhibited grace, dignity and his inimitable sense of humor while comforted by his family and friends. Mr. Hudson was predeceased by his parents Dorothy and Hubert R. Hudson and his brother Hubert R. Hudson, Jr. He is survived by his beloved wife Cathy, his children Andrew Hudson, Chris Hudson, Eugenia King and her husband Frank Paul, Courtney Nyhuis, his step children Callie Kincaid, Maggie Kincaid, and Sam Kincaid, Lindsay Ganz and her husband Jason. He is also survived by his former wife, Betty Hudson, his sister in NYC Caroline Hudson Firestone, and five grandchildren. A memorial service was held in Dallas, Texas, and a private memorial service will be held in New York City in October.

An article on Aug. 10 about spinal fluid tests in Alzheimer's research left the incorrect impression that the test can predict the disease with 100 percent accuracy in all patients. (That impression was reinforced by the headline.) In fact, the test was found to be as much as 100 percent accurate in identifying a signature level of abnormal proteins in patients with memory loss who went on to develop Alzheimer's -- not in identifying patients who ''are on their way'' to developing the disease. The article also misinterpreted an element of the researchers' findings. Among a group of patients who had memory loss and developed Alzheimer's within five years, every one had protein levels associated with the disease five years before; it was not the case that ''every one of those patients with the proteins developed Alzheimer's within five years.'' And the article misstated the source from which the finding of 100 percent accuracy was drawn. It came from a separate set of patients that the researchers examined to validate the protein signature they had identified in an initial group. (In the initial group, as the article noted, nearly every person with Alzheimer's had the signature protein levels.)

Bathing suit season may be ending, but that is no reason to let your summer health and fitness gains to slip away. A new iPhone app, Intelli-Diet, takes a different approach to a healthy eating than most diet apps. Instead of proscribing what you should eat, the Intelli-Diet asks first what you prefer to eat, then assembles that into three meals and two snacks a day.

President Obama's history of public approval resembles that of Ronald Reagan's at the same points in their respective terms: both were sliding, according to nationwide polls conducted by The New York Times and CBS News. By contrast, both Bushes enjoyed early spikes in popularity -- the first after world events like the fall of the Berlin Wall, and the second for his response to the 9/11 attacks. Obama gets good marks from 45 percent of his public -- a testament to his charisma in bad times, according to the historian Douglas Brinkley, a professor at Rice University.''Obama has a high likability factor, like Eisenhower or Reagan,'' Mr. Brinkley said. ''I don't think it's bad that it's 45, but it's a day-glo warning sign. If you get into the 30s it's very hard to get out of that.'' Of more immediate concern to Democrats, Mr. Brinkley noted: ''His charisma isn't transferable to other candidates.''

GELBERMAN--Rabbi Joseph H. ("Chaim") April 27, 1912 September 9, 2010. Our beloved Rebbe A modern day prophet. Gatherer of differences, pioneer of peace, physician of the soul. A message of love from your students of All Faiths Seminary. You showed us how to see each other through the eyes of the heart, as brothers and sisters connected in divine, loving unity. How to live life to the fullest, how to face resistance with love, how to always be giving of spirit, how to accept all living beings as part of G-d, how to study scripture and interpret it on our own, how to break down walls of hate, how to build foundations of love, how to always be on a journey inward, how to respect all beliefs and celebrate the miracle of life in concert with them, how to be resilient in the face of despair, how to sing and dance at every chance, how to remember that fear is the greatest sin and the opposite of love, how to be victorious over the negative, how to be forgiving, how to wake up each morning grateful for life, and above all else, how to be joyful always joyful. Yes, Rabbi, We Are Ready for life. We Are Ready to do the good and the beautiful. You must have had faith that we are. Once again, our brother, you have brought us all together. Never instead of, always in addition to. Adonai. li, v'lo, irah.

Right-clicking on a file and choosing the Send To menu in Windows 7 gives you several options, like sending the file to a mail recipient or compressing it into a ZIP archive. If you want even more choices about where you can send the selected file, hold down the Shift key while right-clicking. When is a party not a party, but instead a marine echinoderm? The answer is, according to National Journal's invaluable Jonathan Rauch, when it's a Tea Party. "The tea party began as a network, not an organization, and that is what it mostly remains," he explains. "This is a coordinated network, not a hierarchy. There is no chain of command. No group or person is subordinate to any other. The tea parties are jealously independent and suspicious of any efforts at central control, which they see as a sure path to domination by outside interests ... Lava is a pretty good analogy. Ask the activists to characterize their organizational structure, however, and usually they will say it is a starfish."

On Friday, the editor of a newspaper owned by the Egyptian government admitted that a photograph published this week in its pages had been altered to make it seem as if Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, had led, rather than followed, a group of world leaders walking in to a media event at the White House last week.

A top Republican official in Washington said Friday that Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska has informed the party's leadership that she intends to run as a write-in candidate for re-election despite losing the Republican nomination in the primary earlier this month.

With its deep roots of Tex-Mex, breakfast tacos and barbecue, Austin, Tex., has always been considered a foodie town. Some recent additions have elevated the state capitol's profile in the world of the flavorful and the fabulous. Here are some of the latest offerings worth checking out.Uchiko, 4200 North Lamar, Suite 140; (512) 916-4808. Tyson Cole's newest venture features one of his trusted chefs, Paul Qui, at the helm. The similar Japanese influences that inspired Cole at Uchi (not surprisingly, "Uchiko" means "offspring of Uchi") can be found on the menu, as well as new inventions. During a recent dinner, the highlights included a tasty koviche, a ceviche of fresh diver scallops prepared with tomatillo, kalamata olives and black lime; and the ao saba, a grilled Norwegian mackerel with a delightful convergence of flavors that included bluefoot mushroom, onion and juniper huckleberry. For dessert, try the stunning sweet-corn sorbet.

This week the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Colorado issued a preliminary estimate of Arctic sea-ice volume for the year. The numbers will not become final until October, but the early calculation is that the summer minimum extent for Arctic sea ice hit its third-lowest level in the modern era, a bit above 2008 and somewhat above the record low of 2007.

"Lots of people ask me, 'Why do you need to show explicit sex in your movies?' " said the French-Argentinian film director, Gaspar Noé. And as he explains in this week's video interview, it's because "when I have sex, it's explicit. Life is graphic."

At first glance, this Saturday's schedule seems like a comedown from last week's. No Oklahoma-Florida State, no Ohio State-Miami, no Notre Dame-Michigan. In fact, there is only matchup between ranked teams this Saturday (No. 9 Iowa at No. 24 Arizona). But it would be remiss to think that the lack of marquee games means Saturday holds little intrigue. Several ranked teams will face serious early-season tests, some of them in hostile environments (just ask Texas Coach Mack Brown how much he's looking forward to going into Lubbock to play Texas Tech and its new coach, Tommy Tuberville). Eighth-ranked Nebraska will not only be up against Jake Locker, but it will have to contend with the always intimidating atmosphere in Washington. Florida State returns home after getting blown out at Oklahoma last week, but the Seminoles don't get much of a break when they host Brigham Young. Two A.C.C. teams, Georgia Tech and North Carolina, that have already seen their seasons go in a different direction than they wanted them to, play a game that is already critical for each. And Al Golden, the coach who has turned Temple around and is sure to be mentioned for some high-profile jobs at the end of the season, will see how his Owls fare against Connecticut of the Big East. What this weekend lacks in marquee value, it makes up for in intrigue. And that means that there is plenty of room for error when picking the games. As always, if you agree with the picks, disagree with them or simply find them laughable, feel free to chime in.
In this week's Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan discusses the many risks that college students face and how proper insurance can help reduce any potential damages.

"As the World Turns,'' the CBS soap opera with more divorces in its history than, surely, the entire city of Reno, ended for good on Friday after 54 years on television and a prior life on radio. At this commemorative moment it is worth pointing out that a number of now-famous actors appeared on the series including Meg Ryan, Julianne Moore, Steven Weber and Marisa Tomei. Amazingly enough, the last three appear together in this scene of love gone brutally, badly and tediously wrong: Not only does this clip egregiously fail to suggest the talent of Julianne Moore in "Vanya on 42nd Street;'' it fails to telegraph the talent of Steven Weber in "Wings.''

"Appetite," curated by the Herb Lubalin Study Center at The Cooper Union, explores the influence of design in the food industry in a free exhibition at 41 Cooper Gallery, 41 Cooper Square (East Seventh Street). The exhibition opens at noon on Saturday and runs through Oct. 9. The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, has also opened a food-themed exhibition: "Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen." It explores the transformation of kitchen design in the past century and how it played a role in women's lives and consumerism. It runs until March 14.

On a drizzly Sunday night, while most of the city's boldface names were sucked into the teeming nexus of Fashion Week, Uma Thurman took her first slippery steps down a metal ramp at Chelsea Piers and climbed aboard the Manhattan. The city seemed encased in a wet, almost scary gloom, and inside the cabin, all the windows were fogged up. Everyone worried about visibility. It wasn't just because the boat - one of those wooden 1920s-style commuter yachts from the upmarket Circle Line alternative Classic Harbor Line - was to sail past famous sights: the Statue of Liberty and the Brooklyn Bridge. It was because this private cruise for 34 was being guided by Ken Burns, the documentarian who has made important films about both landmarks.

Resort collections may be a passing thought as spring quickly engulfs the fashion-conscious, but that doesn't mean designers have all tired of wild cruise prints. Take the nascent Los Angeles designer Emily Jerome, whose Jerome label sells at Ron Herman, L.A., and is worn by Mamie Gummer, Jessica Collins and Catherine and Allison Pierce of the Pierces, among others. Not that you have to be a celebutante to wear it, but wallflowers need not apply. "The Jerome girl is a little bit of everything - the rocker, bohemian and a tad flamboyant at times," Jerome said via phone while working on her first look book (shot by Eric Ray Davidson) at the Chinati Foundation in Marfa, Tex., with Jessica Joffe. If the backdrop and the artful multiculti prints look familiar, it's because the estate belongs to Donald Judd, Jerome's godfather and a collector of ethnic textiles and African masks. "My prints this season derive from Christmas tree worms and ancient, ritual shoulder clothes from Bhutan," Jerome said. You can take the girl out of Marfa.

Beth Williams, one of the lead producers of "Promises, Promises," which is closing in January, said in a phone interview on Friday that the producers "considered re-casting, started putting lists together, but we didn't think there was a way to replace Sean and Kristin" and ensure extending the show's financial track record as well. Discussions about re-casting developed to the point where producers had some names in mind, but, Ms. Williams said, it never reached the stage of talking with actors or their agents about joining "Promises" to follow Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth.

On Saturday, Afghan voters will again head to the voting booth, this time to elect members to the Afghan National Assembly, known as the Wolesi Jirga. This election, the second in the history of the legislative body, was initially scheduled for late May. Ask critics of the campaign finance system how it can be fixed, and many answer quickly that it can't. Not without an infusion of public money, they say, as a way to neutralize the impact of deep-pocketed donors, who have pushed the cost of running for federal office into the tens of millions of dollars in recent election cycles.

In his novel "The Crying of Lot 49," Thomas Pynchon describes a suburb that is "less an identifiable city than a grouping of concepts - census tracts, special purpose bond-issue districts, shopping nuclei, all overlaid with access roads to its own freeway." The novel's protagonist, Oedipa Maas, "looks down a slope, needing to squint for the sunlight, onto a vast sprawl of houses which had grown up all together, like a well-tended crop, from the dull brown earth," Pynchon writes, "and she thought of the time she'd opened a transistor radio to replace a battery and seen her first printed circuit. The ordered swirl of houses and streets, from this high angle, sprang at her now with the same unexpected, astonishing clarity as the circuit card had." The architectural system unfolding in front of her held, according to Pynchon, a "hieroglyphic sense of concealed meaning."

The Serengeti-inspired color palette L'Wren Scott used for her spring collection was also the basis for the show's hair and makeup. The Academy Award-winning actress Nicole Kidman plans to return to Broadway in the fall of 2011 to star in a revival of the Tennessee Williams play "Sweet Bird of Youth," to be directed by David Cromer ("Our Town"), a spokesman for the production said on Friday. Ms. Kidman was last on Broadway, in her debut, in the 1998-99 season production of David Hare's play "The Blue Room." That show drew mixed reviews but was a hugely tough ticket to come by, given Ms. Kidman's star appeal.

One of Broadway's biggest commercial hits of the year, the Sean Hayes-led revival of the musical "Promises, Promises," will close on Jan. 2, the producers announced on Thursday night. The decision to close the show only nine months after opening is another reminder of the premium that producers put on star casting on Broadway - and the high costs and unpredictability of re-casting.

Regular readers may remember that I've written a few posts -- here and here -- about bond yields in Ireland and Spain. Both had big housing bubbles and busts; but their post-bust politics have been very different, with Ireland quickly adopting austerity, Spain being much more grudging. And for a while you saw many news stories asserting that Ireland's virtue had been rewarded by the markets.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed rules to require companies to disclose more about short-term debt. The idea, the commission says, is to let investors know whether a company is engaged in "window dressing" to make balance sheets look prettier at quarter's end than it really was during the quarter.

"Oscar and I were talking about debutantes, girls dressing up for the first time," said the hairstylist Orlando Pita at the Oscar de la Renta show. "I remembered Grace Kelly had this hairstyle at her wedding," he continued, referring to the doughnut-shaped bun atop the head of the model Caroline Trentini, sitting behind him. "We're exaggerating the volume a bit because we have to think about proportion - some of Oscar's dresses are quite big, and we didn't want it to look like a ballerina bun." Hair was put in a ponytail, around which was fastened a foam ring that back-combed pieces were pinned under, then coated with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray.

Future historians will marvel at the austerity madness that gripped policy elites in the spring of 2010. In a combination of blind panic and irrational exuberance, organizations from the ECB to the OECD suddenly abandoned everything we've learned, at bitter cost, about the economics of recessions, and raced to the conclusion that fiscal austerity was the way to go in the depths of a slump -- indeed, that it would actually be expansionary.

Today it's all about the storm. We warned of thunderstorms on Thursday but, boy, we didn't see that coming. We expect to hear sometime on Friday whether officials think it was a tornado that cut a deadly swath from Staten Island, through Park Slope and Bushwick in Brooklyn and into Queens. Service on the Long Island Rail Road, stopped on Thursday, was more or less back to normal Friday morning, although the Port Washington branch was still out of service, and all city schools were open, with the exception of John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens, which was pummeled by the storm.

On the surface, it appears that the Yankees have sustained their winning ways in 2010, their recent slump notwithstanding, simply by carrying over the momentum from last year's World Series championship squad. After all, the big-name stars, like Derek Jeter, Mariano Rivera, Alex Rodriguez, C. C. Sabathia and Mark Teixeira, are the same. New faces have been slotted in among the supporting cast. Among them, Marcus Thames replaced Hideki Matsui, Curtis Granderson replaced Melky Cabrera, and Brett Gardner's role grew with the departure of Johnny Damon. To the untrained eye, the Yankees have done what any repeat contender does: it maintains a strong core of high-priced talent and fills the gaps with complementary role players.

An article on Tuesday about Dr. Frances Oldham Kelsey, who received a Distinguished Civilian Service Medal from President John F. Kennedy in 1962 for her role in exposing the dangers of thalidomide, included a quotation that misstated the location of the medal presentation. The ceremony was at the White House, not in Maine.

ELKIND--Charlotte Woods, died on September 14, 2010 at the age of 84. Adored wife for 59 years of Morton Digby Elkind who died last month, she was a devoted mother to Elisabeth, Sam and Margaret, and a loving grandmother to Cordelia and Miranda Alquist, Eric and Will Van Gelder and Alexandra Elkind. Born in Evanston, IL, she graduated from the University of Rochester in 1947 and received MAs from Columbia and NYU. She worked at the Institute for International Education where she organized a union and helped negotiate the first contract, taught history at Packer and was an associate graduate dean at Long Island University, Brooklyn for 28 years. Memorial service: Friday, October 29th, 1pm, Green-Wood Cemetery Chapel, Brooklyn.

STANWOOD--Richard, passed away on September 12, in Palo Alto, CA. He graduated from Dartmouth College and was President, Chief Creative Officer and a member of the Board of Directors at Leo Burnett. He is survived by his wife Nancy, daughter Joanna Smith, sons Peter and Carson, several grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. Services will be at a family burial in Essex, CT.

Every two years since 2000, Mark David Chapman has sat down with members of the New York State Division of Parole and rehashed details of his Dec. 8, 1980, murder of John Lennon outside the Dakota. His sixth and latest hearing, on Sept. 7, was no exception, going step by step through his muddled planning as if being interrogated for the first time, according to a transcript released Thursday. ''I made a horrible decision to end another human being's life, for reasons of selfishness,'' Mr. Chapman, now 55, told two parole commissioners in Rochester in his video interview from the Attica Correctional Facility. ''I felt that by killing John Lennon I would become somebody, and instead of that, I became a murderer, and murderers are not somebodies.''

SEMMELMAN--Frida. The Board of American Friends of Shalva mourn the passing of Frida Semmelman, mother of board member and Secretary, Jacques Semmelman. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jacques and the entire family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. President, Ari Storch

10 P.M. (ABC) 20/20 In 1985, Kathryn Eastburn, an Army wife, and two of her three daughters were found dead in their home near Fort Bragg, N.C. Timothy B. Hennis, above, a master sergeant who had visited the home days earlier when he answered an ad placed by the Eastburns, was found guilty in 1986 of raping and murdering Ms. Eastburn and killing her daughters. He was sentenced to death. But when defense lawyers argued in 1989 that photographs of the grisly crime scene had been projected on a screen over the defendant's head, an appeals court declared that the case should be retried, and Mr. Hennis was acquitted. DNA later linked Mr. Hennis to Ms. Eastburn's body, and the military took up the case in 2006. In April a military jury found Mr. Hennis guilty and sentenced him once again to death. Elizabeth Vargas reviews the case and interviews Jana Eastburn, the youngest of the daughters, who was left alive inside the house. Ms. Vargas also speaks with Gary Eastburn, Jana's father, and with the lawyer who represented Mr. Hennis in his first two trials. 8 P.M. (Cartoon Network) SYM-BIONIC TITAN Teenage aliens crash on Earth while trying to escape an evil general in the premiere of this animated series, left. Season 3 of ''Star Wars: The Clone Wars,'' at 9, finds five clone cadets trying to muster team spirit to complete their training. Anakin and Obi-Wan defend Kamino and its factories against the separatists.

An article on Saturday about Rafael Nadal's uncle and tennis coach, Toni Nadal, misstated, in some editions, the name of the newspaper to which Rafael Nadal said, ''It's pressure to go to practice and know that you have to do well because, otherwise, there will be problems.'' It is El País, not La Pais.

CAMPS--Lowell C.,86, of Rye, NY, born February 19th, 1924, passed away peacefully, at home, September 13, 2010. It is with love and warmth that we remember the life and spirit of our father, grandfather and great friend. He will forever serve as model of strength and honest compassion to everyone that has had the opportunity to meet him. He was married to the love-of-his-life and best friend, Helen P. Camps for 58 years. Lowell, known as "Larry," graduated from Colgate University, served in the United States Army in World War II as a member of the Red Diamond Rangers and was a general agent for John Hancock for a loyal 25 years. He was a gentleman of greatness; a leader to his comrades, a smart and candid businessman, a man of humble class to his neighbors and a pillar to his family and family of friends. He survived by his daughter Linda L. Camps, his son Christopher L. Camps and son Jeffrey L. Camps; his loving daughters-in-law Judith B. Camps and Loren P. Camps, and dear grandchildren Ashley, Jackson, Brooke and Hunter Camps. Let us learn from his unfiltered kindness and his unbounded gratitude for honesty and hard work. A service of remembrance will be held on Friday, September 17th at 10:30am at the Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 8th Avenue, Seventh Floor, New York, NY, 10001.

SALIK--Sheldon, 86, passed away in Boynton Beach, FL on September 15.
