The house of Bill Blass, after sitting out Fashion Week for a few seasons while its new owners retooled the business, introduced a small spring collection Wednesday morning by the designer Jeffrey Monteiro. On a stage in a black tent at Lincoln Center, Mr. Monteiro's models wore a range of cocktail suits, graphically embroidered vests and a selection of red dresses, one of which was made of a loose knit. These were perfectly fine clothes for the day-to-evening crowd, but it is hard to imagine that they will spark a Bill Blass revival. Several talented designers (Peter Som, Michael Vollbracht, Lars Nilsson) have tried to revive Blass in the last decade, and none managed to get a pulse. Mr. Monteiro was probably smart to ignore the past. There was not much connection to Blass in his clothes at all -- no men's wear fabrics, no wild floral prints, no brassy sex appeal. His starting point was a book on Southern African tribes, barely evoked in the beaded trims on his jackets.

RASSMAN--Joel. It seems like yesterday I wooed you away from Kenneth Leventhal. We certainly had a great ride. I will miss your business acumen and your sage thoughts on life. Rest peacefully, my friend. Your job is complete. Bruce Toll

In addition to his signature line, Jason Wu has created a capsule collection for Tse, the knitwear company. He introduced the collaboration last fall with terrific sweaters, but for spring, he wanted to go in a different direction since it's basically the off-season for a sweater company and no one wants to look at heavy knits. At his presentation in the West Village on Tuesday, Mr. Wu showed a couple of paper-thin cashmere T-shirts that were printed to create the illusion of intarsia pastel stripes. Illusion was the theme here. A top that looked as if it was made of a loosely knit yarn was, in fact, made of 50 yards of chiffon. He had painstakingly cut long two-inch-wide strips of white chiffon, sewed them into tubes with the seams fully finished, then put his interns to work knitting them into what looked like a chunky knit sweater and a dress. They weighed nearly nothing.

An article on Saturday about the Obama administration's response to a court ruling that said the military's ban on gays serving openly is unconstitutional referred imprecisely to the Justice Department's mandate to defend federal statutes against constitutional challenges. The Justice Department has a general duty to defend statutes in court, but it is not ''compelled'' to do so in every case. (As the article noted, it may appeal the decision on gays in the military.)

Physically he's changed a lot, but mentally I haven't noticed any diminution of his ability. Which has to be pretty unique. JUDGE MONTI L. BELOT, on his 103-year-old colleague, Judge Wesley E. Brown of Federal District Court in Wichita, Kan.[A13]

After two days of staying mum, the state Republican Party chairman in Delaware said Thursday afternoon that the state party apparatus would work for the election in November of the party's candidates -- including, apparently, Christine O'Donnell, the party's nominee for the Senate seat formerly held by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. It is not unusual for party officials to suddenly back candidates whom they had opposed in a primary after those candidates win. But in Delaware, the state chairman, Tom Ross, had been especially vitriolic toward Ms. O'Donnell, calling her a ''liar'' and saying she ''could not be elected dog catcher.'' While most establishment Republicans opposed Ms. O'Donnell in her battle against Michael N. Castle, they had embraced her by early Wednesday.

BUONANNO--Louis A.,born February 4, 1922, died September 13, 2010, after battling many years of cancer. He died peacefully in his home surrounded by his loving daughter Christina. Louie was born in the Lower East Side of NYC. He married his teenage sweetheart Jennie at the age 21. They moved to 36 Mulberry St. where they had three children, Christina, Louis Jr. and Cecile. Louis and Jennie lived in New York City, Brooklyn, and Staten Island till he was 68 years old when they retired to Pompano Beach, Florida in 1991. As a young man, Louis served in the US Army but was called home abruptly at the news of the death of his 19 year old sister, Christine. Louie worked for The New York Times from 1955 till 1987 as a Mailer. Louis could be found every morning reading the daily paper and doing The New York Times Crossword puzzle while drinking his "black coffee". He enjoyed following baseball, football, listening to the music of Frank Sinatra and watching the Old Time westerns of John Wayne. One of his favorite things to do was to sit around the dinner table with his close family. Louis is the beloved son of the late Celia and Bonaventura. He was the devoted and loving husband of the late Jennie Buonanno, and the dear brother of the late sister's Annabelle and Christine. He was a loving uncle, nephew, cousin and friend. Louis is survived by his three children, Christina, Louis Jr. and Cecile and his seven grandchildren Kelly, James, Kristen, Tyler, Emmett, Harper, and Samuel. He is also survived by seven great-grandchildren Tiana, Elizabeth, Samir, James, Brendan, Cristiana, and Gavin. Louis had an infectious laugh and passed on his deep love for family life. One of his last words to each of his three children was, "Take care of your family, I love you". Services will be held at Matthew Funeral Home, 2508 Victory Blvd., Staten Island, NY. Services Friday, September 17th, 2010, 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass: Holy Family, Victory Blvd., Staten Island, 9:15am Saturday, September 18th, 2010. Burial to follow at Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island.

An article on Thursday about the phasing out of European Union subsidies for coal mining and coal-fired plants misstated the nature of a goal set by the union for reducing member nations' reliance on fossil fuels. The union is committed to using renewable sources to produce 20 percent of its energy, not 20 percent of its electricity.

BRYANT--Robert P.,of Coral Gables, FL, and Foulkeways in Gwynedd, PA, died on Monday, September 6, 2010. He was 88 years old. Born at Staten Island, NY on May 13, 1922 to Thomas Vincent Bryant and Rosanna McRoberts Bryant. Mr. Bryant was a highly respected corporate leader serving as Vice President of Marriott in Washington, DC, President of Dobbs in Memphis, and Vice Chair of Carson Pirie Scott in Chicago during a remarkable career in the hospitality industry. He was a committed civic leader with more than fifty years as a Rotarian (Paul Harris) and was honored by both the Anti-Defamation League of the B'nai B'rith in NYC and the NAACP in Memphis for his contributions to human rights. He was a graduate of Cornell University's Hotel School Class of 1944 and a US Army veteran of WWII. He is survived by his devoted wife of 57 years, Barbara Carlson Bryant, five children, nine grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Memorial contributions can be made to Second Growth, Inc., a nonprofit dedicated to helping young people and families prevent violence, substance abuse, and suicide. www.secondgrowth.org

A music review on Tuesday about a concert at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Saturday organized by the September Concert Foundation, using information from a publicist, misstated the age of Monica Soyemi, the vocal soloist in a performance of Stephen Foster's ''Beautiful Dreamer'' by the Young People's Chorus of New York City. She is 18, not 12. The review also omitted credits for the lyrics for the song ''Give Us Hope'' composed by Jim Papoulis, which closed the concert. Besides Mr. Papoulis, Leo Schaff and Regine Urbach also wrote the lyrics. And a picture caption with the review misidentified the conductor shown. He is Francisco J. Nuñez of the Young People's Chorus of New York City -- not John Daly Goodwin of the New York Choral Society, which also performed in the concert.

BATES--Margaret Schieffelin Pardee, July 22, 1918 - September 14, 2010. Philanthropist, conservationist, educator. Born New York City, died Carmel, CA. Daughter of Margaret Trevor Pardee and Irving H. Pardee, MD. Granddaughter of Margaret Schieffelin Trevor and Henry Graff Trevor and Ensign Bennett Pardee, MD and Clara Burton Pardee. Direct descendant of Elder William Brewster of the Mayflower (tenth descent). Married: New York City, 1938 to Talcott Bates, MD (deceased). Chapin School. BA Barnard College '40; MA Washington University '41. California State Board of Education 1960-1968. Trustee California State Universities and Colleges 1960-1969. Trustee Barnard College, member Accrediting Commission of Western Association Schools and Colleges. Her papers are in the Hoover Institution. Memberships: Casa Abrego Club Monterey CA, Junior League of the City of New York, National Society of Colonial Dames. Children: David Talcott. Seth Pardee, Anthony Stewart, Charles Carroll, Margaret Schieffelin (deceased). Service of remembrance is on September 26, 3:30pm at the York School, Monterey CA. At 3:30 p.m., the steps of the Chelsea Art Museum were cluttered with black-clad-clipboard-bearing publicists looking down on an obscene crowd of people who wanted to see the spring Marchesa collection. A car pulled up. The seas parted for Gabourey Sidibe, star of the movie ''Precious.'' A Marchesa-branded S.U.V. pulled up. The seas didn't budge. Who's that? Someone from ''90210.'' Oh. We skipped the line and followed the trail of two women who must have been V.I.P.'s, because their faces appeared to be the handiwork of the esteemed plastic surgeon Dr. Saran Wrap, and were led down a flight of stairs into the bowels of the museum. The space was decked out like a small labyrinth, its walls shielded by gray curtains. At the bottom of the stairs, three models stood like statues, one in a silvery strapless tulle gown, hand-painted to look like ombre. In the next room, a model wore a pearly white gown covered with what appeared to be a spider web of silver crystals around the bodice. In the next, there was a jumpsuit made of expertly draped black lace that loosely skimmed the body and revealed practically the entire anatomy of its model. These were clothes that scream, ''Wow-za.'' Marchesa, the label of the designers Georgina Chapman and Keren Craig, is known for intensely gorgeous dresses and the sense of drama they impart on a red carpet, like that unforgettable wacky, wadded-up tissue mini worn by Heidi Klum back at the Emmys. The spring collection did not disappoint, filled with dresses for people who don't want to hear that tired line from designers who say that a dress should not look like it is wearing the woman. Not a woman on earth has the poise to stand apart from a midnight blue silk tulle dress, hand-painted with flowers, so stiff that its skirt stood out nearly four feet wide. ''This is art,'' Ms. Sidibe said. ''It really is.'' View the full collection.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Tuesday about a donation of $38.5 million to the British Museum omitted the donor of half of the funds. With the Republican primary season in the books, and her field of endorsed candidates either heading off to the general election or going back to the drawing board, Sarah Palin is stepping up her presence on the campaign trail to help Republicans raise money. My Sunday column is a bit unusual: it's in the form of an apology to Muslims for all the hysteria and invective directed in their direction lately. As I write, I find the caricature on the airwaves to be deeply offensive, given the number of heroic Muslim peacemakers and aid workers I've seen around the world, risking their lives to make the globe a better place. According to a bipartisan chorus - right, center-right, and liberal - the victory of Christine O'Donnell in Delaware's primary proves that the race for the Republican nomination in 2012 is no longer wide open, because Sarah Palin is officially the front-runner. This strikes me as bunkum for many of the reasons that Ramesh Ponnuru and Daniel Larison discuss, and especially for this one: It is extremely unlikely that the political landscape in the winter and spring of 2012 will resemble the political landscape in the autumn of 2010. Even setting aside the unpredictability of economic developments, foreign-policy crises, and everything else that could shift the ground beneath our feet, the reality of having a more empowered Republican Party in Washington and a weaker President Obama in the White House will almost certainly work profound changes on the country's mood - and yes, in the mood of the Republican base as well. (It's hard to be quite so fired up and furious about socialism when Washington is mired in gridlock, and it's hard to be quite so outraged at RINO perfidy when you've kicked a lot of the RINOs out of office.) The temper of conservative politics in the fall of 1994, the off-year election cycle that most resembles this one (it was a year, as Rich Lowry notes, when a former homeless man defeated the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee), bore little resemblance to the temper of conservative politics in 1996, when Bob Dole cruised to the Republican nomination over more base-pleasing candidates like Pat Buchanan and Phil Gramm. And while it's likely that the Tea Parties will lend a greater resilience to the present anti-establishment spirit, 12-t0-18 months of divided government will almost certainly have a dampening effect on the impulses that carried Christine O'Donnell to victory.

Johnson & Johnson, the American health products company, said Friday that it was in advanced talks to bid for the 82 percent of Crucell, a Dutch biopharmaceutical firm, that it does not already own, in what would be a 1.75 billion euro ($2.3 billion) deal. The all-cash bid would give Crucell stakeholders 24.75 euros a share. Johnson & Johnson would acquire a company known for its research, manufacture and marketing of vaccines and antibodies. It bought its initial stake in Crucell for 300 million euros last year. Crucell shares rose 8.51 euros, or 54.19 percent, to 24.20 euros in Amsterdam on Friday, giving the company a market cap of nearly 2 billion euros. Fabian Smeets, an analyst at Rabo Securities, said he thought the bid might go higher. ''Johnson & Johnson could add a couple euros,'' Mr. Smeets said, citing Crucell's 500 million euros in cash. While other bidders may be in the wings, Crucell is bound by change-of-control clauses for certain products it makes and markets, including Quinvaxem, a vaccine against childhood diseases that it co-developed with Novartis and which is now a major revenue source for the Dutch company. Crucell could lose rights to the drug if it were sold to certain pharmaceutical competitors. Should the deal go through, Johnson & Johnson would maintain Crucell's management, staff levels and headquarters in Leiden, the Netherlands, the company said. The expectation of such a limited restructuring in the event of a takeover is one reason why Crucell prefers Johnson & Johnson, Mr. Smeets said, adding that it would occupy a special place in a company that allows for entrepreneurship, unlike some other drug makers. The last time Crucell was in play was just last year, but the bid from Wyeth fell through after it was taken over by Pfizer. --Chris V. Nicholson Go to Crucell Statement>> This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Josh Perelman loves a piano - not just any piano, but the one on which Irving Berlin wrote ''I Love a Piano'' in 1915. He loves it so much that he is borrowing it for 14 months. Dr. Perelman is a deputy director of the National Museum of American Jewish History in Philadelphia, which is preparing for the November opening of its new $150 million home near Independence Mall. The piano - no high-tone baby grand, but an upright, and a distinctive one, at that - will be part of an exhibition called ''Only in America,'' about the Jewish experience in the United States.

Honeywood, an artist whose brilliantly colored collages, paintings and prints presented a warm, upbeat picture of black American life and whose paintings were prominently displayed in the living room of the Huxtable home on ''The Cosby Show,'' died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 59. The cause was cancer, Joyce Faye Allen, a cousin, said.

BETSY BURTON feels as if she dodged a bullet. At 64 and a co-owner of the King's English Bookshop in Salt Lake City, she has been in business for 33 years and employs 25. Her shop provides health insurance to seven full-time employees. But premium increases in recent years were so astronomical that health care costs had been eating up 30 percent of the store's revenue, about $78,000 a year. ''That's just not sustainable for any business,'' Ms. Burton said.

BURSON--Bette, 85 years of age, a 56-year Edgemont section of Scarsdale resident and life member of Scarsdale Woman's Club, died September 16, six months after being diagnosed with an inoperable brain tumor. She was married almost 63 years to Harold Burson, founder of the Burson-Marsteller global public relations firm, and mother of two sons, Scott (Wendy Liebow), of Lexington, MA and Mark (Ellen Jones), of Westlake Village, CA. Her grandchildren are Allison and Esther Burson of Lexington and Wynn, Holly and Kelly Burson of Westlake Village. The Scarsdale Woman's Club named its library the Bette Burson Library this past April. She was the club's longtime representative to the Westchester Federation of Woman's Clubs. Earlier, she was a board member of the Center for Preventive Psychiatry, the Edgemont Community Council and a Cub Scout den mother. She travelled extensively with her husband visiting Burson-Marsteller offices and clients on five continents including 30-plus trips to Europe, a dozen to Asia, and several to Australia and Latin America. Born on Manhattan Island, she graduated from Horace Mann School for Girls in 1943 and attended University of North Carolina Woman's College at Greensboro, and Katherine Gibbs School in New York. She was office manager for the predecessor firm to Burson-Marsteller for five years following her marriage on October 30, 1947. For more than 30 years she was a dedicated bowler at the Scarsdale Golf Club and in Westchester County leagues. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Scarsdale Woman's Club, 37 Drake Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583 or Edgemont Scholarship Fund, c/o Edgemont High School, 300 White Oak Lane, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

Ask critics of the campaign finance system how it can be fixed, and many answer quickly that it can't. Not without an infusion of public money, they say, as a way to neutralize the impact of deep-pocketed donors, who have pushed the cost of running for federal office into the tens of millions of dollars in recent election cycles. The idea of publicly financing Congressional candidates has many opponents, particularly among Republicans who see it as yet another federal intrusion. But supporters on the left were encouraged this week when the House Administration Committee scheduled a vote for next Thursday on a proposal to provide federal matching funds for Congressional candidates who get money from smaller donors.

An editorial published on Sept. 11 about a Congressional measure creating a compensation fund for 9/11 cleanup workers misstated how it applies to workers who already accepted money from another lawsuit. Those workers could be eligible for additional compensation, which would be offset against their previous court award. The bill would not bar their participation.

Almost immediately after being named general manager of the Mets in late 2004, Omar Minaya initiated and came to symbolize a team movement that celebrated baseball's Caribbean and Hispanic cultures and tied them to the identity of the club. One term came to encapsulate a strategy that included the acquisition of high-profile, Spanish-speaking players, a marketing campaign aimed at Latinos and the buzz surrounding a new era: Los Mets.

8 P.M. (TCM) STARRING MAURICE CHEVALIER This French music-hall performer, born in 1888 and awarded an honorary Oscar in 1959, is given a five-film retrospective, starting with ''Gigi'' (1958). Written by Alan Jay Lerner, with a score by Frederick Loewe, this musical stars Leslie Caron in the title role of a young Parisian woman who hopes to find a husband. Chevalier plays Honoré Lachaille, whose nephew has an up-and-down romance with Gigi. At 10:15 Billy Wilder directs Chevalier in ''Love in the Afternoon'' (1957); he plays a detective hired to follow a wife suspected of a dalliance with an American (Gary Cooper). The detective's daughter (Audrey Hepburn) falls in love with the playboy and tries to save him. In ''Man About Town'' (1947), at 12:30 a.m., Chevalier portrays a film director who competes with Jacques (François Périer) for the affection of Lucette (Dany Robin). This French-language movie is notable for its use of an English voice-over by Chevalier, in lieu of subtitles. At 2:15 a.m. Count Danilo (Chevalier) wants to keep a wealthy widow (Jeanette MacDonald, above left with Chevalier and Minna Gombell), a great source of tax revenue in his country, from marrying a stranger in Paris in ''The Merry Widow'' (1934). And at 4 a.m. Chevalier plays a guitar-strumming priest in Sicily, where an American midwife (Angie Dickinson) causes a ruckus with her sex appeal in ''Jessica'' (1962). 10:30 A.M. EISENBACH--Elliot, 80, beloved husband of Judith, loving father of Steven and Ronit and five grandchildren, passed away at home September 16. He had an unparalleled adventurous spirit and a never-ending curiosity. Elliot, with an abiding commitment to public life, was involved in many Jewish and civic organizations. Many people were touched by his generous and kind spirit. He will be deeply missed.

Sharif el-Gamal, the real estate developer in the national spotlight over his plans to build an Islamic community center and mosque two blocks from ground zero, took care of a much more mundane task on Wednesday: paying his back taxes. Mr. Gamal walked into a Department of Finance business center at 66 John Street, went to a window and agreed on a plan to pay the more than $200,000 in taxes owed on the lot where the center is planned, said Owen Stone, a spokesman for the agency.

The Food and Drug Administration appears to have postponed an expected decision on whether to revoke the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer. In an article in Monday's New York Times, ''Search Takes a Social Turn,'' Jenna Wortham details how turning to friends for product recommendations is the latest rage in the Web world, with a growing number of companies trying to capitalize on the trend and bring such information to product searches. For instance, as she described in the article, users of Facebook can choose to see their friends' favorite books on Amazon, specify in their profiles what products they like and informally poll friends on Facebook or Twitter for product recommendations. The article also details some downsides of plain old reviews online, including reliability issues.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. - Gov. Charlie Crist on Friday was drawn into the ongoing financial scandal with the Republican Party of Florida after the party released an audit that says that the party spent thousands on the cost of trips to New York City and Walt Disney World that included Crist, his wife and her family. The party audit covers three years worth of spending while Mr. Crist's handpicked chairman Jim Greer was in charge and depicts a pattern of lavish spending on everything from electronics to trips to London with little oversight or control. Auditors concluded that nearly $500,000 was spent that probably had little to do with official Republican Party business.

SOMMER--William. With great sadness we announce the passing of William Sommer, cherished husband of Frances Sommer Anderson, adored father of Thea Sommer, father-in-law of Maria DiPietro-Sommer, loving Grandpa to Benjamin and Jeremy--the ice cream kids. He passed due to complications of a heart attack. A quintessential New Yorker known for love of baseball, number theory, history of New York City and the world, he regaled people in his favorite Chelsea joints with "long" anecdotes, corrected their grammar, and directed them to Google "watermelon sneakers"! We will remember him for his work ethic and refusal to "lie down and take it." In his Montecristi hats, assorted caps, and books tucked in the back of his pants, his saunter could be recognized at a distance. A gathering, Celebrating Bill's Life, will be held on Sunday, September 19, 11-3, Community Room, 343 8th Ave. at 27th St. Donations to Greenberg Division of Cardiology NYP-Weill Cornell Hospital.

Viewed from a distance, the natural world often presents a vista of sublime, majestic placidity. Yet beneath the foliage and hidden from the distant eye, a vast, unceasing slaughter rages. Wherever there is animal life, predators are stalking, chasing, capturing, killing, and devouring their prey. Agonized suffering and violent death are ubiquitous and continuous. This hidden carnage provided one ground for the philosophical pessimism of Schopenhauer, who contended that "one simple test of the claim that the pleasure in the world outweighs the pain is to compare the feelings of an animal that is devouring another with those of the animal being devoured."

In this remarkable novel, the entire world of a 5-year old boy is the 11-by-11-foot room in which his mother is being held against her will. Emma Donoghue’s child narrator is one of the most engaging in years.

ENGELHARDT--Patricia Lynn nee Berglund, age 78. Most beloved wife, mother and grandmother, Minneapolis, MN.

LEVIN--Norman Richard. In loving memory of Norman Richard Levin of Sunny Isles Beach, FL, originally from Brooklyn, NY, passed away on Sunday, September 12, 2010 at age 74, surrounded by his family and friends. He was the loving father of Bari (Troy David) and Stacy Levin. The adored grandfather of Alex, Charles and Katie Rae. Dear brother of Lanny Levin (Harriet). Loving uncle to Fran, Cori, Lori and Arona. He is survived by his wife Ida Gerson Levin, former wife Jacqueline Unroch Levin Feinberg and former wife and the mother of his children, Myrna Cohen Levin. His charm and zest for life will be missed by all the people who knew and loved him. May he rest in peace.

BAKER--Myra Augusta Mullins, 76 died September 10, 2010 in Birmingham, Alabama. She received a B.A. from Mount Holyoke College (1955) an MA in English Literature from Birmingham-Southern College (1961) a Ph.D. in English Literature from The University of Alabama (1966), and an MA in Art History from Hunter College (1977). Moving to New York in 1962, she taught English Literature and Grammar at New York University, Hunter College and Vassar College, served as a board member of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra from 1977 until 1981 and participated in other charitable activities and various professional bodies, although limited by illness beginning in 1980. Myra returned to Birmingham in 1998. Survivors include her husband of 54 years, David R. Baker; sisters, Marilyn M. Merkle and Elease M. Smith; brothers-in-law Douglas U. Baker and Stephen D. Baker; 14 nieces and nephews, and 23 great-nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York at 3:00pm. Saturday, October 30, 2010. Memorial contributions may be made to the Eleanor Ussher Baker and Myra M. Baker Scholarship and Loan Fund, Office of Development, Mount Holyoke College, 50 College Street, South Hadley, Massachusetts 01075 or a charity of choice.

COHEN--Abraham, devoted husband for 60 years of Marcia (Benderoff), of Margate, Florida, formerly of West Hempstead, NY, passed away on September 15, 2010. Beloved father of Vicki and Clifford (Leslie). Grandfather of Aliza and Willis Cohen and Hallie and Sara Baumann. Devoted to his family and his Deaf community. He will be missed by everyone who had the privilege to meet him.

FISCH--Solomon, M.D.,Ph.D., 84, passed away peacefully at home on September 18, 2010. Born in Cuba, Dr. Fisch earned a Ph.D. in Physiology from the University of Rochester and an M.D. degree from NYU. After serving in the Armed Forces, he completed his residency in Internal Medicine and was a research fellow at the Bronx V.A. Hospital. He served as Director of Medicine at Trafalgar Hospital and as an attending physician at Doctors Hospital/Beth Israel North. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the N.Y. County Society of Internal Medicine and N.Y. County Medical Society, and a member of Sigma Xi. He practiced medicine for over 45 years, caring for many elderly and Spanish-speaking patients. He will be remembered always by family, friends, patients and colleagues as a loving and devoted husband, father, and grandfather, and an outstanding and admired doctor. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Lila Mirkin Fisch; children Susan and Richard Reibstein, Melanie and Howard Kook, Amy and Steve Cohen, and Steven and Allison Fisch; grandchildren Reed, Samantha, Spencer, Samuel, Alexander and Rebecca; and siblings Ralph and Charlene Fisch and Ruth and Stuart Creggy. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association (www.alz.org).The funeral will take place on Monday, September 20, 2010. The Location and time of the funeral may be obtained from Gutterman Musicant Funeral Home (201.489.3800).

A review on March 28 about ''The Sabbath World,'' a study by Judith Shulevitz, misspelled part of the title of a tract by the Puritan Thomas Shepard. It is ''Theses Sabbaticae,'' not ''Theses Sabbaaticae.'' A reader recently pointed out the error in an e-mail.

Audi has announced that the 360-horsepower Audi TT RS sports coupe will soon be available in the United States. The car was introduced at the 2009 Geneva Auto Show and has been available in Europe and other markets since 2009. The decision to market the high-performance coupe in the United States reportedly came in response to a survey on Audi's Facebook fan page that drew responses from 11,500 drivers in the United States who hoped to see the car introduced here.

I don't have or want a dog. I told my children when the youngest was born that when he was 5, we'd get a used dog. He's 12, and the children seem to think I owe them two used dogs or one new dog. I tell them to look out on the grass that borders our sidewalk - it's as if we already have several pets.
GREENBERG--Charles H. You will be cherished and adored forever. Doree, Andy, Deanne, Emily, Charlie, Lynn, Hillary, Scott, Joely and Eric

LEVENSON--Kathe Tanous. A freer spirit was never on this earth, nor ever left it. Kathe died on September 17, with Bob holding her toes. She leaves behind, all in tears, her step-sons Keith and Seth, her brother Ron and sister-in-law Patty, her sister Dorothy and her shattered husband, Bob. She brought light into every room just by being in it. Her paintings and drawings and sketches (and even her Christmas cards) will always bring light into countless rooms the world over. Her last years were very hard, but now she is freer than ever.

I HAVE been fond of apples and apple trees for as long as I can remember. I grew up with a crab apple tree in front of our apartment in Flushing, Queens, which my Manhattan-born mother misidentified as a cherry blossom tree. At the start of every spring and autumn, I was beguiled by the dense cluster of flowers and fruit I saw through our living room window. Trees in the Malus genus, including crab apple and wild apple, produce abundant fruit, and this time of year even a short stroll through the city is an exercise in falling fruit. I was recently standing under a gorgeous specimen on Staten Island, admiring its sizable apples, when I was hit on the head by one, like some textbook lesson in gravity.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- With their multihulls and carbon-fiber bodies, the new America's Cup boats are light and lightning fast. But it is their predecessors, the sleek 12-meter yachts used from 1958 to 1987, that warm the hearts of veteran sailors. More than 700 people, including 250 sailors, gathered last week at the waterfront home of the New York Yacht Club for their first reunion, three days of racing and a backward glance at what many call the golden age of sailing. ''They're just nice boats and pretty, too,'' Ted Turner said Wednesday after completing the first day of the three-day 12-Meter North American Championships aboard American Eagle and joining sailors for panels and parties for 80 America's Cup teams of the era in Narragansett Bay. ''And I really wanted to see some of my old friends.''

BATES--Margaret Schieffelin Pardee, July 22, 1918 - September 14, 2010. Philanthropist, conservationist, educator. Born New York City, died Carmel, CA. Daughter of Margaret Trevor Pardee and Irving H. Pardee, MD. Granddaughter of Margaret Schieffelin Trevor and Henry Graff Trevor and Ensign Bennett Pardee, MD and Clara Burton Pardee. Direct descendant of Elder William Brewster of the Mayflower (tenth descent). Married: New York City, 1938 to Talcott Bates, MD (deceased). Chapin School. BA Barnard College '40; MA Washington University '41. California State Board of Education 1960-1968. Trustee California State Universities and Colleges 1960-1969. Trustee Barnard College, member Accrediting Commission of Western Association Schools and Colleges. Her papers are in the Hoover Institution. Memberships: Casa Abrego Club Monterey CA, Junior League of the City of New York, National Society of Colonial Dames. Children: David Talcott. Seth Pardee, Anthony Stewart, Charles Carroll, Margaret Schieffelin (deceased). Service of remembrance is on September 26, 3:30pm at the York School, Monterey CA. A great woman: We will not soon forget her. Contributions to the York School: www.york.org

GELBERMAN--Rabbi Joseph H. ("Chaim") April 27, 1912 September 9, 2010. Our beloved Rebbe A modern day prophet. Gatherer of differences, pioneer of peace, physician of the soul. A message of love from your students of All Faiths Seminary. You showed us how to see each other through the eyes of the heart, as brothers and sisters connected in divine, loving unity. How to live life to the fullest, how to face resistance with love, how to always be giving of spirit, how to accept all living beings as part of G-d, how to study scripture and interpret it on our own, how to break down walls of hate, how to build foundations of love, how to always be on a journey inward, how to respect all beliefs and celebrate the miracle of life in concert with them, how to be resilient in the face of despair, how to sing and dance at every chance, how to remember that fear is the greatest sin and the opposite of love, how to be victorious over the negative, how to be forgiving, how to wake up each morning grateful for life, and above all else, how to be joyful always joyful. Yes, Rabbi, We Are Ready for life. We Are Ready to do the good and the beautiful. You must have had faith that we are. Once again, our brother, you have brought us all together. Never instead of, always in addition to. Adonai. li, v'lo, irah.

THE NEWSCraigslist said it had permanently closed the ''adult services'' section of its sites in the United States. BEHIND THE NEWS At $10 each, the ads were on track to generate an estimated $44 million this year. (Most other listings on the site are free.) The company is legally shielded from liability for what users post. But prosecutors pressed Craigslist to close the section, saying it facilitated prostitution and other sex crimes. Advocates for free speech questioned the wisdom of the shutdown, arguing that the site had helped the police crack crimes and that the ads were sure to pop up elsewhere.

The Bush tax cuts of 2001 and 2003 are set to expire at the end of this year, and the fight is on to renew some or all of them. Many Democrats want to scrap future cuts for the wealthiest taxpayers -- individuals whose income after deductions is more than $200,000 and couples at $250,000 or more. The Republican leaders insist that all taxpayers should get relief, even those in the highest income strata. Wealthy Americans, they say, can use their tax savings to create jobs. In either case, the extensions would be expensive: perhaps $2.7 trillion less for the Treasury through 2020. Here is a guide to who will get what if the cuts are extended, and who got what from the last seven years of cuts, according to an analysis by the Tax Policy Center, a nonpartisan research organization

Coyoacán still felt like an idyllic village on the outskirts of Mexico City when its most famous resident, Frida Kahlo, was born. But the capital's ever-expanding sprawl finally engulfed it, turning the village into a neighborhood that has retained many of its small-town charms -- a bustling zócalo, quiet streets meandering toward intimate plazas and past colorful houses -- while quietly carving out its own big-city cool. More obviously hip neighborhoods like Condesa and Roma may have greater commercial turnover, but they can't match Coyoacán's distinctive mix of preserved past and chic present.

VALVO--Richard. Our dear friend Richard passed away on September 13. Survived by mother Catherine Spitale and sons John and Peter Savino. Memorial October 15, 10:30am, St. Thomas More 89th between Park and Madison. Will be loved and missed. Patty and Mark Gottlieb

Here's a sampling of comments from readers who responded to A. O. Scott's Sept. 12 column, ''Are Films Bad, or Is TV Just Better?'' ''TV is better, and has been for a few years now. I realized this when faced with the choice of going out to watch a sophomoric Judd Apatow flick or staying home to watch 'The Wire.' In addition to the sophistication of TV shows that Mr. Scott notes, there is another reason that TV appeals more to grown-ups, and that is the depiction of women. It has been years since I have seen a female character in an American movie with the complexity of a Carmela Soprano, the compassion of a Carol Hathaway on 'ER' or the grit and intelligence of a Claudette Wyms on 'The Shield.' If Hollywood movies were your sole guide, you'd think all women were dimwitted, hypersexualized, fashion-obsessed appendages.

The Federal Aviation Administration has recently proposed rules to help combat fatigue among commercial pilots of passenger aircraft. Among the proposals: increasing the amount of rest between periods of duty to 9 hours from 8; increasing the consecutive hours between flight duty to 30 from 24; and limiting the flight duty time to 13 hours from 16.

For as long as there have been cyclists in the city, there have been pedestrians who have viewed them as a dangerous menace. First, there were the ''scorchers,'' a breed of fast riders from the turn of the last century, denounced by carriage drivers, pedestrians and other cyclists.

FOR the last six summers I have been operating a taxi along New York's waterways. It is not the yellow ferry that commuters ride around Lower Manhattan, but a small rowboat that I made from plywood. Instead of a diesel engine, I use the tidal currents in the harbor to propel my craft. On each trip I take one or two passengers, often strangers who have found me online and requested a ride. We visit places around New York that most people have never heard of: Swinburne Island or the ship graveyard in Coney Island Creek. Some are wild and overgrown, places where herons nest along deserted creeks. Others are industrial wastelands, canals where the oil sludge and debris are so thick that my little boat has trouble maneuvering. Most of them are within a few miles of Times Square.

JARETZKI--Paul, 89, died in New York on September 16, 2010. A devotee of opera from the age of ten, after graduating from Harvard in 1942 and serving in the Army, he was hired as Executive Assistant at City Opera. This led to a happy twenty-one year career at the Metropolitan Opera as Assistant Artistic Administrator under Rudolf Bing. In addition, Paul wrote for and coordinated the intermission programming for the Saturday afternoon radio broadcasts. He is survived by his siblings, Josie Lipman, Alfred Jaretzki III and Dotsy Eisner, and ten nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Monday, September 20 at 3:00pm. Contributions in Paul's memory can be made to the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
Classical Steve Smith

H AVING created iconic ad campaigns for Balenciaga and Stella McCartney, and imagery for French Vogue, Arena Homme Plus and Interview, Michael Amzalag and Mathias Augustyniak, the graphic design duo known simply as M/M (Paris), are well-known forces in the fashion world. But these days you ain't nobody until you have your own fragrance. As such, their latest project is a bottle of perfume, created in collaboration with the Swedish fragrance house Byredo. Called M/Mink, it is inspired by Japanese calligraphy and contains notes of patchouli, honey, amber and adoxal, an ingredient used in detergents. It is, as M/M (Paris) put it, ''a truly unusual and unique composition.'' Of course, given Mr. Amzalag and Mr. Augustyniak's day jobs, the perfume also has a series of striking ads, composed of photos by Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, smeared with ink.

Snyder in 1948, mothered three children, William Bunker Jr., Howard Aldred, and Joan Talcott Snyder. Grandmother of Laura Blakenship Silva and Taylor Marie Snyder. Great-grandmother of Alejandro V. Silva. Lived in Bronxville, NY for over 60 years, and in Vero Beach, FL. Family graveside services in Litchfield, CT. Memorials to The Reformed Church, Lawrence Hospital, or Jansend Hospice and Palliative Care.

A CD review on Sept. 5 about ''Great Strauss Scenes,'' by the soprano Christine Brewer, referred incorrectly to her performances in the role of Isolde in Wagner's opera ''Tristan und Isolde.'' She had sung the role previously onstage, at the San Francisco Opera during its 2006-7 season. Her performance in ''The Tristan Project'' with the Los Angeles Philharmonic was not her only staged performance to date.

RASSMAN--Joel. It seems like yesterday I wooed you away from Kenneth Leventhal. We certainly had a great ride. I will miss your business acumen and your sage thoughts on life. Rest peacefully, my friend. Your job is complete. Bruce Toll

OBITUARIES An obituary last Sunday about the Baptist minister and political activist Lucius Walker referred incorrectly to a 1988 incident in Nicaragua in which Mr. Walker and others were wounded and two people were killed. The delegation led by Mr. Walker was attacked by contra rebels -- not by soldiers of the Nicaraguan government, which was not supported by the United States at that time.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

COSACHOV--Bernardo, 88, of Kew Gardens Hills, NY, died at home on September 16. Warm-hearted and open-armed, he lived and loved passionately. Born in Argentina, he became an engineer and served in the air force. He emigrated to the US in 1958 and worked for electronics companies including Sigma, Ampex, RCA, Bertelsmann and GE, from which he retired in 1987. He married his beloved wife Rosa in 1961. They raised a son, John, of Auburn, NY, and a daughter, Grace, of Brooklyn, NY, who gave them five grandchildren, Andrew, Julia, Daniel, Talia and Mariele. He is dearly loved and will be missed by all whose lives he touched.

SCHONFELD--Sidney. The officers and members of the Board of Directors of the Jewish Home Family note with profound sorrow the passing of our Jewish Home at Rockleigh's long standing Board member, devoted supporter and very dear friend, Sidney Schonfeld. Sid, along with his late wife Hildegard, was an extraordinary man who exhibited a profound commitment to countless organizations and causes in the local, national and international Jewish communities; he will be missed by many. His kindness and gentleness were exceeded only by his desire to help those less fortunate. We extend our deepest sympathy to his children, Gary and Elisabeth, Victoria and Victor, his grandchildren, and his entire family. Sid's legacy will include the many fine institutions and programs he helped conceive and steward. May his memory be for a blessing. Ary Freilich, Chairman Sandra Gold, President, JHR Charles P. Berkowitz, President & CEO

During Tuesday's primary election, there were problems across New York City with the debut of a new system of voting -- paper ballots filled in by hand and then scanned electronically. Scores of polling places opened late, and many voters struggled to understand the new system. Some shared their experiences on the City Room blog. Excerpts follow. At P.S. 34 in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, at 7:30 a.m., there was no way to vote at all, as the machines were not even operational. The doors were locked. This is appalling. Smotri

POST--Pamela Peyton, died peacefully with family and friends on September 13, 2010 at her home in New Canaan, CT. Born in New York City on October 30, 1953 she was the daughter of Joan Paton Tilney now of Yarmouth, Me. and the late Bernard Peyton Jr. In 1978 she married her cherished husband William Stanton Post. Pammie led a courageous life choosing to turn the adversities of Cystic Fibrosis into the gift of appreciating every moment of every day. Her love and joy had an indelible effect on us all. A celebration of her life will be held at 11am on Saturday, October 2, 2010 at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, please live your life as Pammie did, smiling out loud.

STEIN--Edwin R. Practicing Attorney for more than 50 years. Devoted husband of Phyllis for more than 51 years. Beloved father of Gregory Stein, Jeanette Kelleher, Amy Stein, Michael Moskowitz and Kenneth Stein. Loving grandfather of Sarah and Rachel Moskowitz. Mr. Stein was a devoted member of the Board of Trustees of the North Shore/ LIJ Health System, and also served in leadership roles in Knickerbocker Lodge K. of P. He was also a Past President of Inwood Country Club.

THE number of times one heard the statement ''the '90s are back'' during the New York shows is a reminder of how potent minimalism is in American fashion. It did seem to make a return, in a variety of forms -- from the abundance of white fabrics, some of them sheer, to loose and often floor-sweeping skirts that had little detail. Minimalist designers, like Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein and Narciso Rodriguez, expressed themselves with greater precision. Mr. Costa's paneled dresses and coats seemed to hover between firm structure and airy volume. One thread in the minimalist discussion that intrigued me was a California influence. In his press notes, Derek Lam quoted passages from an art review earlier this year by Peter Schjeldahl about California minimalism. Mr. Schjeldahl said of the small art community in Los Angeles in the late '60s: ''They shared a serene sensuousness that couldn't have been more remote from New York's principled asperity.''
Television Ginia Bellafante

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press baseball roundup in some editions last Sunday misidentified the division that includes the Atlanta Braves and the Philadelphia Phillies. It is the National League East, not West.

Giants (1-0) at Colts (0-1)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Colts by 5 1/2Summon the mourners and light the funeral pyres: the Colts lost their season opener. The Texans ran for more than 250 yards against them, injuring the top run defender Bob Sanders in the process, and the Colts' offensive line was no match for the Texans' front four. The dynasty is dead! The sky is falling! Yawn. The Colts lost their season opener in 2008 and beat the Jaguars by a hair in 2009. They often look flat at the start of the season. Their run defense is always a little leaky. Sanders is always injured. Despite the loss, the Colts still gained 463 yards of total offense. They may not be as strong as in years past, but that just means the Colts might go 11-5 instead of their usual 12-4 or 13-3.

EISENBACH--Elliot, 80, beloved husband of Judith, loving father of Steven and Ronit and five grandchildren, passed away at home September 16. He had an unparalleled adventurous spirit and a never-ending curiosity. Elliot, with an abiding commitment to public life, was involved in many Jewish and civic organizations. Many people were touched by his generous and kind spirit. He will be deeply missed.
WINIKOFF--Ellen Ann. Dearest daughter, sister, aunt on your birthday and every day we think of you, miss you, love you. Marcia, Stan, Linda, Amy, Kenny, Sami and Eli

An article last Sunday about the club Max's Kansas City misspelled the first name of a designer whose work has reflected the style of the club's regulars in the 1960s and '70s. She is Ann Demeulemeester, not Anne.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the bank analyst Richard X. Bove omitted the photographer's credit. The picture, of Mr. Bove, was by Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times.

Lot 65 at an auction scheduled for Sept. 24 in New York - on the block just after a police motorcycle that trailed John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963, and just before Clark Gable's medical bracelet - is a necklace that was worn once by the original owner. And also a pair of earrings that glimmer with diamonds and South Sea pearls. The auction house, Guernsey's, set an estimated selling price of $1.5 million to $2.5 million.

ANNA DELLO RUSSO, fashion director at large for Vogue Japan. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW An Yves Saint Laurent dress with strawberries on it, because I was thinking it's still warm outside, and nice to still have a summery feel. The hat has cherries on it, and it's from a very famous shop in Milan called Alan Journo that sells all the crazy stuff from Philip Treacy, Stephen Jones, Linda Farrow . . . I always go there to get my hats. I put the hat and dress together, and it's fantastic- looking! The shoes are Yves Saint Laurent, the clutch is Olympia Le Tan, the watch is a Rolex. I like the big size. The strawberry ring is vin- tage from the '70s, and the coral bracelet is an antique.

SUNDELL--Michael Gordon, Professor Emeritus of Humanities at The Cooper Union for the Advancement of the Arts and Sciences and former President of Yaddo, died in his sleep on September 7, 2010. In addition to his wife Nina, he is survived by his sister, Esther Lichti of Lubbock, TX; his children Marianne, of Wendell, Massachusetts, and David and Margaret, both of New York City; as well as his son-in-law Reinaldo Laddaga, and his grandchildren Julia and Lillian Sundell-Thomas and Tomas Laddaga. Sundell was born in New York City on April 1, 1934. The first member of his family to earn a university degree, he received a B.A. from Hamilton College, and an M.A. and Ph.D. in English Literature from Yale University. He met his wife, Nina Castelli Sundell, in Paris while a Fulbright Fellow at the University of Montpelier. A distinguished scholar and administrator in academia and the arts, Sundell taught English literature at Hamilton College, Queens College CUNY, Case Western Reserve, and George Mason University. He served as the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Art and Science, and was President of the artist's retreat, Yaddo, in Saratoga Springs, a position he held from 1992 until his retirement in 2000. Sundell oversaw the transfer of Yaddo's archives to the New York Public Library. At George Mason, he supervised the preservation and indexing of the archives of the Federal Theater Project of the WPA, which were on deposit from the Library of Congress. He wrote and lectured about nineteenth-century English literature, twentieth-century American art, the history of photography, and relations among public policy, patronage, and the arts. Mosaics in the Eternal City--his book about late antique and medieval mosaics in Rome and the fruit of research conducted as a Visiting Scholar at the American Academy in Rome --was published in 2007. In lieu of sending flowers, donations may be made in his name to the American Academy in Rome, the Yaddo Garden Association, the New York Public Library, or the New York University Cancer Institute.

An article on March 21 about Taiwan's hot springs referred incorrectly to air service between Taipei and New York. There are indeed direct flights between the two cities; it is not the case that flights require a connection. (Flights on China Airlines and Eva Air from New York to Taipei require a fuel stop; their flights from Taipei to New York are nonstop.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail received Sept. 3.

I don't have or want a dog. I told my children when the youngest was born that when he was 5, we'd get a used dog. He's 12, and the children seem to think I owe them two used dogs or one new dog. I tell them to look out on the grass that borders our sidewalk - it's as if we already have several pets.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Cup Race Is Taking Different Direction,'' Sept. 14: Television turned figure skating into jumping, tennis into serving, hockey into fighting and baseball into home run hitting.

MARJA, Afghanistan -- The first voter here was Muhammad Akbar, 22, who dipped his finger in the indelible purple ink, collected his ballot and had just stepped into the cardboard box that served as a voting booth when gunfire broke out. ''They're right on time,'' said Lt. Col. Kyle Ellison, commander of the Second Battalion, Sixth Marine Regiment.

BOHRER--Lee. Penn South Social Services Inc. extend our loving condolences to fellow board member Harry Bohrer and family on his beloved wife's death. Nat Yalowitz, President Jack Raskin, Vice President

Most jobs begin with a training session or some sort of ''why don't you familiarize yourself with these documents'' meeting. But no orientation could have covered the sheer breadth of my first assignment as Frugal Traveler: to get from Sao Paulo to New York City on less than $500 a week and blog about it. During the 13-week trip - most memorably through Brazil, Bolivia, Peru, Colombia, Nicaragua, Guatemala and Mexico, I slept in hammocks, farmhouses and under-$15 hotel rooms; I ate ants, guinea pigs and every local fruit I could find; and I saw pre-Columbian fortresses, Mayan priests who foretold my future and dolphins when I went searching for alligators on the Brazil-Bolivian border.

Calling all museum fanatics! On Sept. 25, more than 1,000 museums and cultural institutions nationwide will offer free admission as part of Smithsonian magazine's sixth annual Museum Day. You can search for participating museums and download the ticket at Smithsonian.com/museumday. Each ticket grants free entry to two people, but the pass is limited to one ticket per household. While the Smithsonian's museums in Washington are always free, Museum Day offers savings elsewhere. For example, the $24.95 adult admission for the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco will be waived with a ticket, as will the $15 admission to the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York. Other participating museums include the Dallas Museum of Art, in Texas, the Adler Planetarium, in Chicago, and the Experience Music Project and Science Fiction Museum and Hall of Fame in Seattle.

For as long as there have been cyclists in the city, there have been pedestrians who have viewed them as a dangerous menace. First, there were the ''scorchers,'' a breed of fast riders from the turn of the last century, decried by carriage drivers, pedestrians and other cyclists.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Champ Has Rivals, but No Equals,'' Sept. 12: I was assigned to be the ball girl for a women's doubles game on Sept. 4 in which Esther Vergeer played at the United States Open U.S.T.A. wheelchair tennis championships in St. Louis.

McINTYRE--Angus Philip, of Oyster Bay, NY died at his home on September 12, surrounded by his loving family. He was 84 years old. The cause was advanced osteoarthritis and a series of strokes. He grew up on a horse farm in Dix Hills, graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale, spent one year in the Air Force, and spent the rest of his life as chairman of his family's Direct Marketing company, O.E.McIntyre, Inc. and O.E.McIntyre of Canada, Ltd. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Barbara Eckhardt McIntyre, five children: Angus, Jr., Katherine, James, Rebecca, and Anne, ten grandchildren: Duncan, Sally, Andrew, William, Philip, Laura, Charlie, Julia, Amanda, and Rebecca, and a sister, Sally Lewis of Santa Barbara, California. He served two terms as president of the board of East Woods School in Oyster Bay, and two terms as president of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club. He had a lifelong interest in science and also served as Treasurer of the Board of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. He was an enthusiastic sailor who raced a Wood Pussy, a Cal36 and a Cal39, was a member of the Cruising Club of America and the New York Yacht Club, did the Halifax Race, the Bermuda Race and many local races on Long Island Sound. He was also an avid skier and a longtime resident of Stowe, Vermont. A memorial service is planned for October 16th at 12:00 noon at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor

HOLT--Philetus ("Phil"), of New Haven, died at age 74 on September 11, 2010 after a brief illness. Phil was raised in Summit, New Jersey, educated at Phillips Exeter Academy, and graduated Yale College and Yale Law School. He spent his career as a consultant in housing and urban redevelopment, first at the New Haven Redevelopment Agency and later at Holt, Wexler and Farnam and Yale New Haven Medical Center, Inc. He also gave much of his time to a variety of New Haven charitable organizations, as president of Schooner, Inc., treasurer of the Schubert Theater, and as a member of the board of Long Wharf Theater, among many others. He enjoyed a long retirement, traveling widely, scuba diving, fly fishing in Montana, horseback riding and rounding up cattle on a cousin's ranch. He was known for his warmth, intellect, sense of humor and distinctive laugh, and kinship with people from all walks of life. He was a generous host with considerable culinary skill, an avid sailor, a lover of jazz and an energetic supporter of liberal politics. He is survived by daughter Elizabeth of New Haven, son Stephen, daughter-in-law Laura, and beloved grandsons Philetus and Tattnall all of Manhattan, sister Frances Covert of Athens, Georgia, as well as a wide circle of dear friends. A memorial service and burial in Grove Street Cemetery, New Haven are planned at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Schooner, Inc. and the Schubert Theater.

A roundup last Sunday of television actors to watch this fall misspelled the surname of the police officer played by Tom Selleck in ''Blue Bloods.'' He is Frank Reagan, not Regan.

The ever-growing list of private flash-sale Web sites has just gotten longer with SniqueAway, a new site that is offering its first sales on Sept. 20. But this one has one selling point that Jetsetter.com and RueLaLa.com don't: an affiliation with TripAdvisor. SniqueAway will list sales for three luxury properties a week that have received an average of four out of five stars on TripAdvisor and that boast four-star-and-above amenities. The sales, which offer rates of up to 70 percent off and are nonrefundable, last for seven days or until inventory sells out. The inaugural sales include the Reefs in Bermuda, the Greenbrier in West Virginia and the InterContinental Boston.
